If the end-all-be-all point of psychedelic music is transcendence
column3: Psychic Ills have taken a whack at just about every path that shows any promise of getting there. The Brooklyn trio has done space-rock freak-outs
column4: heavy minimalist drones
column5: and abstract synthesizer mulch
column6: all of which has been unspooled across two LPs
column7: a handful of small-press singles
column8: a compilation album
column9: and
column10: probably
column11: a box full of all-night free-form practice tapes.

column1: The Ills' third LP
column2: Hazed Dream
column3: finds them taking another approach
column4: sidelining the guitar solos in favor of stripped-down and straightforward songwriting. In his lightly blazed tenor
column5: Tres Warren-- the band's guitarist
column6: singer
column7: and principle songwriter-- coolly considers the subjects that have long fascinated and vexed his space-rock forebears: sunshine
column8: roads
column9: walking down roads
column10: walking with Jesus
column11: and things that are and aren't all right. The pace is whispery and mellow
column12: the fuzz pedal presumably out of batteries. It's pure moods music for cowboy stoners. There's nothing here that's going to explode any eyeballs or melt the paint off the wall
column13: but it's a step in the right direction for Psychic Ills
column14: whose output has been fairly inconsistent since their 2006 debut
column15: Dins.

column1: During the mid 2000s
column2: it sometimes felt like Psychic Ills were a band in the right place at the right time with the wrong music. Their contemporaries and labelmates
column3: like Gang Gang Dance and Black Dice
column4: ditched guitars for samplers and new-age synthesizer tones
column5: pursuing spacey music's more under-explored permutations and
column6: eventually
column7: finding modest popularity. For all their stylistic restlessness
column8: Psychic Ills were traditionalists
column9: sticking to established
column10: well-worn 1960s psych and krautrock sounds.

column1: Hazed Dream is a record that fits more precisely into its time and place. With their mumbled verses and slacker spirituality
column2: Warren's compositions aren't terribly distant from Kurt Vile's effect pedal-enhanced folk-rock
column3: albeit lacking in some of the Philly-based rocker's gift for conjuring pastoral sprawl. In the subdued soloing
column4: you can hear echoes of San Francisco retro noodlers Wooden Shjips. Psychic Ills hung on to their schtick long enough that they seem to have phased back into tune with their peers.

column1: But transcendence via free-form freak-out is further away than ever. Hazed Dream has some heady moments-- the languid guitar intro to ""Incense Head"" and the head-nodding chords of ""Mexican Wedding""-- but the songs are just too mellow
column2: understated
column3:
and lyrically anonymous to move the needle much.

The first two tracks of Mungolian Jet Set's third album Schlungs (following an album as a modern jazz collective
column3: and 2009's excellent remix compilation We Gave It All Away… Now We Are Taking It Back) offer everything you might want from the expansive prog-disco group. ""2011 - A Space Woodysey"" is a stirring
column4: dramatic opener of flaring strings and mysterious tribal percussion
column5: leading directly into the ten minute frenzy of last year's single ""Moon Jocks N Prog Rocks""
column6: an endlessly mutating singalong disco epic that draws the natural short-circuit between the Mos Eisley Cantina and the Muppets. Taken together
column7: they form the culmination of the group's aesthetic
column8: offering a version of dancefloor maximalism that always threatens to become too large
column9: to careen out of control and explode or implode into the purely ridiculous--  like every great Muppets finale
column10: really.

column1: In fact
column2: ""Moon Jocks"" is so perfect an encapsulation of Mungolian Jet Set's seductive extremism that it really ought to have been the last track of its type
column3: after which the silly voices were locked away forever. For Schlungs
column4: however
column5: the Norwegian collective mostly go down the opposite route
column6: spotlighting the puppets while backgrounding the elaborate set pieces behind them. The results are somewhat mixed: Even on the group's most outrageously rococo remixes
column7: the speed of their largesse and the friction of their ridiculousness felt evenly balanced. Here
column8: the music frequently scales down to more human dimensions
column9: at which point the silliness starts to resemble that of real humans: flushed with an over-enthusiastic pleasure you can observe but not share
column10: and at times a bit uncomfortable to be in the same room as.

column1: Hypothetically this equation could work
column2: but on the jaunty ""Bella Lanay"" (Doobie Brothers take a trip to the disco) and ""We Are the Shining"" (Giorgio Moroder outtake)
column3: it doesn't quite come together
column4: the frequently excellent music sinking beneath the weight of the raucous warbling of a choir of funny uncles. The results aren't awful
column5: but they do feel top-heavy
column6: the unusually restrained arrangements never given a moment to breathe. The charming central synth vamp on ""Bella Lanay"" especially could benefit from an airier vocal
column7: perhaps from a Michael McDonald or Phil Collins pretender who could gift the music's insistent prettiness with a pretense of self-belief. It's telling that ""Smoke N Mirrors""
column8: the album closer and unofficial sequel to ""Moon Jocks""
column9: switches from irritating to marvelous the moment the atonal vocal harmonies are abandoned.

column1: For the most part
column2: Schlungs works best when it runs as far from this idea of animatronic pop as possible: the sly
column3: water-treading slomo disco balladry of ""Ties N Downs""
column4: the wonderfully mutational instrumental melodrama of ""Moonstruck""
column5: and the collision of the Black Dog and Jon Hassell on ""Shelton's on a Bender"". The last of these might be somewhat ungainly in its mixture of stabbing percussion
column6: eerie trumpet
column7: sampled choral vocals
column8: and growling bass
column9: but it's perhaps the album's most interesting moment
column10: fully inhabiting the dark fourth-world funk that forms the yang to disco's yin in the group's best work.

column1: Darkness-- or
column2: more precisely
column3: a certain ominous alienness-- is what gives Mungolian Jet Set's preposterousness its charisma
column4: suggesting an extraterrestrial consciousness operating beyond questions of humor or seriousness. Human dimensions don't really work for this group
column5: not because the epic is what they ""do
column6: but because their music sounds best when it becomes lost in its own logic
column7: creating and then exploring a world of its own rather than just a quirky version of ours-- more 2001: A Space Odyssey
column8: less ""Mork & Mindy"". In its pinnacles and pitfalls
column9: Schlungs confirms that
column10: even if the results can be cute
column11:
communicating with humans is usually the least impressive talent any alien has.

The liner notes for Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You-- the complete recordings guitarist John Fahey made for the tiny but crucial Fonotone label between 1958 and 1965-- comprise an 88-page book
column4: bound in beautifully toned
column5: dense cardboard. These 88 pages brim with an obsessive sort of information about Fahey: his slapdash drawings of important people and places in his life
column6: the first known photograph of him with a Gibson F-hole guitar
column7: the receipt for his Holzapfel 12-string
column8: his Boy Scouts photo
column9: and even a personal letter to Fonotone owner Joe Bussard where he begs for recordings of a few old blues heroes. There's a revealing and hitherto unpublished interview
column10: remembrances from past collaborators
column11: and Italian researcher Claudio Guerrieri's guide to the various hand-written labels Bussard affixed to the center of each record he hand-cut on order.

column1: The centerpiece of the book is Malcolm Kirton's exhaustive 40-page examination of every track on the 115-piece
column2: 5xCD
column3: six-hour set
column4: including Fahey's thoughts on the tunes
column5: his tunings
column6: his techniques
column7: and how a scrawny
column8: awkward white kid from the suburbs of Washington
column9: D.C. came to learn obscure songs from even more obscure black bluesmen long before CD reissues and online archives were even an idea. It should be noted that Kirton also helped produce The Roots of John Fahey
column10: a free online archive of many of the songs in question. Like this set
column11: it is also essential. As the guitarist
column12: enthusiast
column13: and project co-producer Glenn Jones quips in his own introduction
column14: ""Let's face it
column15: who is this set for if not Fahey's most hardcore fans?""

column1: Actually
column2: Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You is not just for Fahey zealots. It's for anyone interested in the story of American music
column3: from its Appalachian string bands and mean-moaning Delta blues singers to the hymns sung from its church pews and the country-rock anthems soon enough crafted by its hippies. But Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You is not only the story of the musician John Fahey
column4: it's also the story of the songs that have become crucial to his country
column5: a place that Fahey explored from one end (he was raised in Maryland) to the other (he lived in Hawaii at one point and died in Oregon). Somewhat comparable to the sprawling ethnomusicological work of Alan Lomax
column6: Harry Smith
column7: Art Rosenbaum
column8: Nick Perls
column9: and others like them
column10: Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You is a rich overview of America's musical bedrock-- only here
column11: it's told through the hard-won
column12: fast-paced development of a guitarist who
column13: in turn
column14: changed the way future players could consider their instrument. A must-have collection of lore
column15: music
column16: and history
column17: it's a unified
column18: brilliant
column19: and often very challenging archive.

column1: During four decades between the time this set was recorded and Fahey's death in 2001
column2: the guitarist would cover expansive musical ground
column3: from transfixing
column4: blues-based tone poems that stretched the boundaries of his instrument to
column5: years later
column6: luminous drones that synced with the interests of a new generation of his advocates. As Robbie Basho said in an oft-repeated explanation
column7: ""Fahey and myself are playing frustrated little symphonies on guitar."" Over time
column8: he was a philosophy major
column9: an author
column10: a record label owner
column11: a curator
column12: and a strange storyteller. However
column13: here on these either unreleased or very hard-to-find tracks
column14: he's a young American adult rifling through his friends' record collections and taking road trips to rural lands to find the music and musicians that he really loves-- raging country blues and blissful acoustic hymns
column15: written and recorded by the likes of Charley Patton
column16: Robert Johnson
column17: Elizabeth Cotten
column18: Bukka White
column19: Will Moore
column22: all while building his own style.

column1: Emotionally
column2: technically
column3: and stylistically
column4: Fahey makes for a suitably uneven tour guide through these dusty back pages
column5: like a metabolic personification of Greil Marcus' old
column6: weird America. On one version of ""Poor Boy Blues""
column7: recorded in 1959
column8: he plays with a great
column9: repetitive sadness
column10: the 20-year-old doing his best to sing like a Mississippi septuagenarian
column11: as if inborn with an inescapable melancholy. About a year earlier
column12: he'd folded the same tune into ""Libba's Rag""
column13: an apparent homage to mentor Elizabeth Cotten. It sounds young and vaguely hopeful
column14: always on the verge of lifting off. Nearly two years later
column15: he wove a glimpse of another version of the tune-- learned from his master of sorts
column16: Charley Patton-- into ""Dasein River Blues""
column17: the kind of slow
column18: wobbly
column19: serpentine country-blues stagger that would eventually give some of Fahey's best-known music its trademark
column20: trance-like essence. Fahey sometimes navigates these tunes with crystalline clarity
column21: as with his stately reverence for the fifth-century ""St. Patrick's Hymn"" or his haunted slide guitar dirge behind ""In the Pines""
column22: a duet with mountain singer Fran Vandiver. Elsewhere
column24: as when he snaps the strings hard against the slide of a 1960 take on ""John Henry"" or slurs the words of ""Green Blues"". He hammers out the chords with a great aggression
column25: as though they'd said something about his mother.

column1: Admittedly
column2: some of the material here stands as a curiosity at best. Fahey's six collaborations with flautist Nancy McLean function more as a testament to his inquisitiveness as a player and listener than something you'll want to hear repeatedly; the same goes for his raucous
column3: wasted take on ""I Shall Not Be Moved"". Similarly
column4: some of the short guitar solos included here-- two versions of the gorgeous cowboy song ""Goodbye Old Paint"" or his slide through ""House Carpenter""-- aren't testaments to his otherwise-apparent abilities as an arranger. They simply shape our understanding of his lexicon. By set's end
column5: though
column6: Fahey's working through knotty versions of the romantic ""How Long"" and ""You Take the E Train"" (better known as ""The Last Steam Engine Train""). These songs and several of their contemporaries illustrate Fahey's very original synthesis of folk
column7: blues
column8: classical
column9: and even old American standards. He was a zealous collector and an ingenious interpreter
column10: two qualities that Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You takes great care to link.

column1: Fahey's legacy and reputation among modern guitarists is overwhelming and inescapable. Just as pop-rock bands with stacked harmonies and two guitars can't escape Beatles comparisons
column2: an upstart learning to flatpick must initially step up to or around Fahey's prominence. Though Your Past Comes Back to Haunt You lives up to its name by finally presenting a lot of material Fahey admitted he would rather forget
column3: it ultimately confirms his stature as one of music's pioneering polymaths. The tunes here are
column4: at turns
column5: funny or solemn
column6: sober or delirious
column7: studied or shambolic
column8: but
column9: with it all
column10: Fahey was able to ingest and utilize a broad range of feelings and ideas into takes that remain totally singular and identifiable.

column1: During a session at home with Bussard in the spring of 1960
column2: Fahey cut seven songs
column3: including a particularly charged version of ""Sitting on Top of the World"" and a delicate
column4: subtle ragtime mutation he called ""Hill High Blues"". The last song Fahey ostensibly cut that day was ""Paint Brush Blues""
column5: improvised on a lark after he picked up a paintbrush Bussard used to keep his record lathe clean. He beats the strings
column6: the chords radiating through the speakers. It's a tossed-off moment
column7: certainly
column8: but the anything-goes spirit validates what Kirton calls a sign of ""Fahey's experimental propensities."" Fahey was a restless listener
column9: tinkerer
column10: thinker
column11:
and player-- a combination that makes this set fascinating both as a history book and a lifetime listening indulgence.

Six months after his Passed Me By EP advanced like a scorched-earth campaign over the ruins of dance music
column2: Andy Stott is back with another six tracks of charred techno. You can bet that in the fast-zombies-versus-slow-zombies debate
column3: Stott sides with the groaners and stumblers: As was his previous record
column4: We Stay Together is a Frankenstein's monster pieced together from scraps of club tracks pitched down to an agonizing crawl. Funny things happen at this speed: The beats lurch violently
column5: kicking up clouds of ash with every impact; every syncopation becomes a hesitant shudder. Sampled vocals
column6: looming in the background
column7: turn to a jellied groan.

column1: The record begins rather demurely with ""Submission""
column2: five minutes of choral samples and ambient flutter that suggests the sound of a thousand pigeons ruffling their feathers in a catacomb. ""Posers""
column3: which follows
column4: sets up the idea that will maintain across the rest of the record
column5: with a slowed-down railroad chug
column6: tri-tone strings
column7: and dissonant washes of synthesizer; distant horns sound the mournful call of a failed hunt. Despite the leaden drowsiness
column8: it still moves: There's an infectious sense of groove in its shuffling percussion and echoing finger snaps.

column1: After ""Posers""
column2: the record's fastest track-- around the same tempo as many of the slow-motion house and disco records being produced by artists like John Talabot
column3: Kassem Mosse
column4: and Blondes; it only feels slower
column5: thanks to its blasted
column6: narcotic production-- things get really torpid. Not just sluggish
column7: but also nasty and mean
column8: degraded and depraved
column9: with more of that death-gurgle bass that led me to compare Stott's last record to Sunn O))). If anything
column10: We Stay Together sounds even more like it could have been released by Southern Lord.

column1: On vinyl
column2: We Stay Together serves a two-for-one purpose: It's meant to be played at 33
column3: but if you speed it up to 45
column4: most of the record's tracks actually become punishing
column5: industrial-strength techno
column6: the kind of sledgehammers associated with Berlin's famously intense Berghain club. Even played like this
column7: though
column8: they don't sound like ""normal"" techno: they're warped
column9: muted
column10: blown out-- they sound wrong. ""Bad Wires"" becomes like Surgeon being run through a cubic meter of boiled wool; the clanging ""Cracked"" comes to sound like several dub techno tracks being played in parallel
column11: with rhythms so disorienting you may wonder if Stott simply sampled a particularly hairy passage from an old DJ mix and slowed it down by 30%.

column1: There's another reason to get this record on vinyl: It sounds way
column2: way better. That might seem odd
column3: given that so much of Stott's sound has to do with using compression
column4: distortion
column5: and other effects to make his music not just strange but even ugly. But
column6: on wax
column7: his swollen low end growls in a way that's almost sensual. (If you must buy digital
column8: pay the extra bucks for the FLAC version; the difference between the high-bitrate version and a compressed MP3 is very real.)

column1: Despite the surface similarities between We Stay Together and Passed Me By
column2: it doesn't feel like Stott is repeating himself. Both records may seem like hellish vultures picking over the carcass of dance music
column3: but every track on the new record yields fresh morsels. Fans of Stott's labelmates Demdike Stare
column4: and all the other goth-n-screw artists out there at the moment
column5:
will be happy to gnaw on these bones.

Here's the biggest surprise in rap this year: Its preeminent tastemaker is Rick Ross. Imagine that being true in 2009
column2: when

column4: Ross got roped into a childish feud with 50 Cent

column9: careers. Wale

But Ross' most intriguing protégé is the young (though by no means rookie) Philadelphia street rapper Meek Mill
column12: a fact not lost on Ross
column13: who saw fit to include himself on both of Meek's radio singles from this year.

column1: Being from Philly

column3: eager shout. But we're a long way from 2002
column4: and there's a distinctly Southern bent to his rapping that has helped him rise to prominence during the reign of Lex Luger. Meek still carries an air of detached cool that is no doubt filtered down from Jay-Z

column6: both rappers engage the listener on a purely visceral level
column7: primarily through deliveries that seem on the verge of careening off the rails. The ability to connect in this manner is something that can't be taught

column9: but certain guys-- DMX
column10: Waka
column11: Boosie-- have an innate ability to connect with their audiences in a way that can leave non-believers
column12: especially ones who privilege lyricism
column13: baffled. Sometimes pro scouts will watch an athlete and say that the player has ""it""-- well
column14: Meek Mill
column15: at least in this regard
column16: has ""it.""

column1: Dreamchasers -- coming after the relative success of singles ""Tupac Back"" and ""Ima Boss""
column2: and with DJ Drama on foghorn duties-- is easily the biggest solo release of Meek's career
column3: and it ends up serving a dual purpose. On the one hand
column4: it easily showcases how deep his talent runs and how versatile an artist he can be. On the other
column5: it functions as a blueprint for exactly what kind of rap music he should and should not be focused on making as his career moves forward. Let's start with the disappointing stuff. The tape is littered with beats either produced by Lex Luger or by people copying Lex Luger
column6: and while that sound is now minted and unavoidable
column7: Meek Mill isn't a rapper that needs to be working off the template. ""Ima Boss""
column8: which is also included on the tape
column9: is evidence enough that Meek can bark his way onto the radio without having to fall back on Luger's lurching productions.

column1: Meek doesn't sound bad on those songs
column2: per say
column3: but the highlights of the tape prove just how unnecessary the generics are. For someone who doesn't try and dazzle with his lyrics
column4: he possesses an exceptional eye for telling stories on both a macro and micro level. ""Middle of Da Summer""
column5: for instance
column6: finds Meek using the season as a frame for sketching a portrait of how his city revolved around him as he grew into a life of crime. ""Tony Story"" is not only one of the most vivid story raps in recent memory
column7: but its plot and development are so engrossing on a cinematic level that it should give David Simon pause. And then there's the title track
column8: with a beat straight out of the Clams Casino school of ""soulful"" and featuring a particularly devastating guest shot from Beanie Sigel
column9: which transcends the trappings of rote inspirational ploys via Meek's sober and realistic rendering of the life of a struggling rapper.

column1: Meek is being groomed for rap stardom
column2: and the genre would be better off if he were able to get there. But while his proximity to Rick Ross has accelerated his career and will continue to open doors for his art
column3: it's important for him to remember that he's not Ross and doesn't need to be. There are plenty of mid-tier rappers willing to merely ride out Lex Luger's wave
column4:
but Meek has enough dimensions to be in it for the long haul.

But even with the portentous
column3: droning keyboards

column9: a concerned wife

not with you.

When Night Slugs Allstars Vol. 1 dropped late last year
column2: Jam City was a still-new artist for the still-new London label. His work to date has flitted between heavy-lidded rave-hop (it's easy enough to infer what the title of his Magic Drops 12"" refers to) and manic electronic funk (""Arpjam""
column3: from the Allstars comp). I preferred the latter; crystalline techno pinging always seems a more difficult bar to hurdle than stoned beat-smithing. On his latest
column4: five-track EP
column5: Waterworx
column6: Jam City paints in the bright
column7: bold strokes that Night Slugs has made its name on while adopting a clarity and purposefulness he hasn't shown before.

column1: Waterworx reminds me of the work of second-wave Detroit techno producers like Carl Craig and Anthony ""Shake"" Shakir. Craig and Shakir (and their peers) were in a unique spot: The techno sound had been developed
column2: and they weren't necessarily beholden to it. They incorporated house and rave into their compositions. The result was often a level-headed brand of dance-funk that felt clean and precise. Jam City has no need for that scene's fantastical futurism-- Waterworx sounds very
column3: very contemporary-- but it does borrow its linear beats and organized busyness.

column1: Jam City pushes the melodic elements of his tracks to the fore
column2: and the tracks are interesting in part because these elements are unlikely focal points. ""Aqua Box"" takes the recent proliferation of rave sirens and turns it on its head
column3: offering a distended
column4: zombie-fied bleat. An industrial hammer of a synth patch powers ""Countess""; the peeling scythe that interrupts it reminds me of the pitched strings in Britney Spears' ""Toxic"". ""Waterfalls"" is softened by electric pianos and Villalobos-like chants. The only track that doesn't maintain this pattern is the widescreen ""Island""
column5: which shoots chords toward the horizon then aims drum rolls at them. The bass on Waterworx-- thumping mallet hits
column6: ever so slightly fuzzy-- confirm a producer who's spent his formative years in the bass scene but never became obsessed with it.

column1: Though a good fit on the Night Slugs roster
column2: Waterworx positions Jam City among artists like San Francisco's Salva and Nottingham's Lone (he lacks Lone's knack for winding melodies) who have dropped bass music like an Alka-Seltzer into techno and rave. (There's lots of fizzing
column3: and it may take a few years before they learn how to make it taste good.) Waterworx is an obvious step forward
column4:
the first clear sign of direction from an exciting talent.

""No one knows what it means

column3: but it's every bit as applicable to the title of Mylo Xyloto and speaks toward Coldplay's lofty ambitions on it. A new Coldplay album is the sort of thing that's used as a health check for the record industry
column4: and the band is very much aware that they could just release ""a new Coldplay album"" that would leave everyone involved satisfied-- this is essentially what happened on 2005's X&Y

column6: R.E.M.
column7: or Radiohead has clearly worn on them-- and truth is

column1: While retaining the studio services and crucial cosign of Brian Eno

column4: sleeker

column8: but never too off-putting if you still insist that ""real music"" is played by men with guitars.

column1: Indeed
column2: the militant
column3: pound-the-dashboard beat that powers ""Hurts Like Heaven"" sounds like the band jockeying for the Boss' nod of approval. It's a remarkably aerodynamic piece of all-purpose inspirational rock that never gets too pushy even with Martin's meaningful/meaningless proclamations (""You use your heart as a weapon/ And it hurts like heaven"")
column4: tweaking its classicist template with a slight Auto-Tune on the falsetto harmonies. Likewise
column5: the imperial march of ""Paradise"" is wheelhouse Coldplay
column6: as is Martin's unfortunate tendency to stretch out syllables for rhymes that really aren't worth saving. But its power has little to do with whatever Martin's going on about (dreaming of paradise
column7: mostly)-- it's all about how they unabashedly flirt with contemporary R&B production
column8: cranking the drums way up in the mix and the massing the vocals on the chorus to overwhelming
column9: Pavlovian effect. They don't want to completely do away with Coldplay qua Coldplay-- they're still four normal-looking guys who introduced themselves with frail post-The Bends Britrock like ""Yellow"" and ""Trouble"". But they continually ask
column10: why limit themselves to that?

column1: Of course
column2: some of their limitations aren't really a matter of choice. While there's no shortage of venomous carping at Coldplay's expense
column3: I've never heard anyone complain about Jon Buckland's guitar tone or the rhythm section not being up to snuff. All sonic tinkering aside
column4: Martin is still a full-time target serving as the perfect avatar for Coldplay
column5: undeniably well-meaning
column6: painfully earnest
column7: and lord
column8: does he try. When Martin tells you that Mylo Xyloto is a conceptual love story inspired by the White Rose movement and The Wire
column9: don't you at least believe that he believes it? So he's still a sucker for big parables told like he's the first to come up with them-- the innocence lost on the Muse-like stargazer ""Charlie Brown"" is documented awkwardly enough (""Took a car downtown where the lost boys meet/ Took a car downtown and took what they offered me"")
column10: even before you deal with the use of the Peanuts character as some sort of entry-level embodiment of adolescent purity. Likewise
column11: though it's commendable that a multi-platinum band on its fifth record could make a swooning
column12: waltz-time ballad called ""Us Against the World"" notable for not laying it on too thick
column13: Martin pops off a line
column14: ""Drunken like a Daniel in a lions' den
column15: like someone who's somehow just managed to hear ""Hallelujah"" for the first time.

column1: Still
column2: the collection of softies is among their best-- the measured beauty of breakup weeper ""Up in Flames"" and ""U.F.O."" confidently update the guilelessness of Parachutes through a self-described and self-explanatory ""Enoxification."" But maybe restraint's not what you're looking for out of a Coldplay album
column3: and if that's the case
column4: none of the ballads have the sort of shameless goosebump triggering of ""Fix You"" or ""The Scientist"". Which isn't to say that Mylo lacks populist thrill; it's just trying to mine alternative sources. They've sidled up toward music of more hedonistic ideals before
column5: especially on A Rush of Blood to the Head; Martin's vocals on ""Clocks"" worked incredibly well filtered through dance remixes
column6: while the ecstatic surge of ""Daylight"" really needed no translation. And thankfully
column7: the revolutionary rhetoric of Mylo is based on love in this club rather than dope
column8: guns
column9: and fucking in the streets.

column1: The aforementioned ""Princess of China"" is an insistent
column2: mechanized grind that fits just as easily on Mylo as the next Rihanna album
column3: though it wouldn't be a single-- everyone seems to be taking it just a little too seriously. The important thing is that it'll sound great at the Grammys. And ""Every Teardrop Is a Waterfall"" will surely work well as a festival closer: As a call to arms
column4: it's pretty much nonsense
column5: Martin's already infamous ""I'd rather be a comma than a full stop"" threatening to bring ""Teardrop"" to a dead halt. But then you remember Coldplay aren't just Martin-- it's Will Champion's kick drum guiding its four minutes of skyward propulsion
column6: one of the cruelly underrated Buckland's pealing
column7: major-key guitar leads (think ""Strawberry Swing"")
column8: and
column9: yes
column10: Martin's wordless cooing coming together in a way that's sui generis Coldplay-- a band on top of a game they really don't have much competition in.

column1: These are the moments I think about when people lament the lack of a monoculture-- so often we speak of indie bands that ""should be huge"" and songs that ""could be hits"" in an alternate universe. But with ""Teardrop"" and ""Hurts Like Heaven""
column2: there's a thrill of knowing these songs can
column3: should
column4: and will be on the radio that you just can't recreate. With all due respect
column5: while M83 shoot for a similar extroverted exhilaration on Hurry Up
column6: We're Dreaming-- the penultimate electro rush of ""Don't Let It Break Your Heart"" proves both bands are ever closer to intersecting-- the idea that it could fill arenas still involves wishful thinking. It's still one man's project
column7: whereas Coldplay was built for this from day one. It shouldn't matter
column8: but it does-- while so many bands at their status revert to bloated contentment or some vague idea of rockist salvation
column9:
Mylo Xyloto finds Coldplay successfully continuing to explore the tension of wanting to be one of the best bands in the world and having to settle for being one of the biggest.

What does dance music sound like when it's made by people who seem slightly worried about the whole idea of dancing? What about people who are totally passionate about dance music even if it's not their native language
column2: who can tackle it with the fearlessness of musicians who love something but aren't of it? Stateside
column3: the music of Talking Heads is one answer. Along with a host of American artists from the same time
column4: they carved out a unique interstice between rock and dance-- not quite one or the other. Fac. Dance goes some way to answering those questions from the UK's perspective
column5: and it's probably no coincidence that some of it mines the same vein as Talking Heads before they discovered M.O.R. A collection of singles from (mostly) the early days of Factory Records
column6: it's a glimpse of world where former wallflowers
column7: whether one-time punks
column8: or one-man avant acts suddenly found the possibilities of disco and post-disco club music too enticing to ignore.

column1: For some
column2: those possibilities were purely musical
column3: a new set of compositional ideas to explore and formal rules to bend or break. On their 1985 single ""Boss Toyota Trouble""
column4: Manchester post-punks Biting Tongues
column5: featuring future members of Simply Red
column6: Yargo
column7: and 808 State
column8: sound like an industrial band who got its wigs flipped by Middle Eastern music and Ethiopian jazz and gamelan
column9: but who couldn't quite shake the perversity that leads people to form industrial bands in the first place. Two inclusions from the Durutti Column are just jittery and uptempo variations on Vini Reilly's usual plangent and gorgeous brand of guitar-based instrumental music
column10: seeming to have wandered in from a completely different compilation. In each case
column11: the communal qualities of dance music get short-circuited
column12: in both interesting and ""interesting"" ways
column13: by artists too individualist to join any club night that'd have them as a member.

column1: And sometimes this formalist fucking around just leads to jokes that burn themselves as quickly as you'd expect. Experimental jazz-rock group Blurt founded by poet/puppeteer Ted Milton
column2: for example
column3: certainly earn their name
column4: their 1980 track ""Puppeteer"" featuring an early hip-hop groove where the MC is replaced by an imitation of a mentally ill ranter who owns a cheap saxophone. It's a curious artifact of one of those rare moments when bands felt the compulsion to experiment with whatever was in the cultural air around them
column5: but ultimately that's all it is
column6: like a lot of the stuff collected here to pad things out to two discs (the inclusion of such tracks when the comp has nothing by New Order doesn't help).

column1: For other Factory artists
column2: though
column3: dance music became both an experiment in new sounds and their first real attempt to make records that met the needs of an audience who wanted to do more than nod with approval at the innovation on display. This is the impulse that animates the bulk of Fac. Dance
column4: and it's why the compilation is worth hearing. Dance music can be many things
column5: but to actually be dance music
column6: it's got to be
column7: you know
column8: funky. You can't impede the groove
column9: whether out of nervousness or perversity or indifference. What's most surprising is how many of these artists
column10: a lot of them reared more on the pogo than the hustle
column11: made these tracks into real-deal dance music that also served as experimental tape collages or extended trance-rock jams.

column1: Section 25's legendary but only intermittently available-for-purchase 1984 B-Side ""Looking From a Hilltop (Megamix)"" is
column2: on one level
column3: pure street-level electro of the glassy and inhuman sort that was everywhere in the early 1980s. But the tension comes from the way it seamlessly weaves in the abrasive
column4: clanging post-punk Factory was first known for
column5: jolting you out of dancefloor hypnosis without disturbing that groove. Section 25 and a few other Factory artists also helped not to break but to extend the rules enough to help create the next wave of dance. It's telling that Fac. Dance cuts off at 1987
column6: a year before acid house took parts of Factory's later
column7: compulsive
column8: electro-driven sound and remade the dance mainstream. However out-there or abrasive it gets
column9: much of Fac. Dance is also stuff that still worked for clubbers
column10: mostly young ones hungry for something new
column11: in New York and Detroit as much as Manchester and London
column12: kids who saw group revelry as the whole point of pop.

column1: Note
column2: for example
column3: how many tracks here are the ""New York Mix"" version
column4: with Factory also drafting in U.S. producers like Jellybean Benitez as the label's records became international DJ tools and its artists began making pilgrimages to New York studios to learn the ropes
column5: often leaving any lingering trace of their punk past behind. One representative and truly obscure American inclusion
column6: the Hood's 1987 cut ""Salvation! (Nitromix)"" is pure early freestyle/electro
column7: that simultaneously most machine-driven and most pop brand of mid-80s dance
column8: denigrated by old heads but integral to all the house and techno tweaks that would follow. Much of Fac. Dance probably wasn't considered ""true"" dance music by certain disco aesthetes at the time. But its fearlessness
column9: its untrueness
column10:
helped in a small way to invent the future we're still living through.

More than a decade after releasing 1994's Burn My Eyes
column2: the groove metal group Machine Head

column5: the Grammy-nominated The Blackening. The 2007 effort made it onto my Show No Mercy year-end list and didn't leave my stereo for long stretches. It followed 2003's Through the Ashes of Empires
column6: a solid enough return to form that came on the heels of a couple of misdirected nu/rap-metal duds-- 1999's The Burning Red and 2001's Supercharger. Which is why The Blackening caught a lot of other folks off guard
column7: too. Once someone flirts with Limp Bizkit territory (and then feuds with Fred Durst and friends)
column8: it's usually safe to stop paying attention. In that sense
column9: The Blackening was a revelation. I was drawn to its ambitious sprawl and its dark
column10: angry scowls; its impressive scope
column11: melodies
column12: vastness
column13: and unexpected changes. There was no attempt to make it easy: The opener was close to 11 minutes long
column14: the closer not much shorter

column16: too
column17: was huge-- enough so that
column18: at the time

column1: Album seven

column4: but it feels tighter
column5: more easily digested
column6: and yet somehow pleasingly rougher around the edges. As a whole

column9: for instance
column10: opener
column11: ""I Am Hell (Sonata in C#)""
column12: an eight-minute
column13: three-movement anthem that starts
column14: somberly
column15: with a mass of a cappella voices

column1: There are curious details worth pointing out-- overlapping guitar and cello
column2: the repeated use of a string quartet
column3: crazy time signatures
column4: a Pink Floyd-style children's choir-- but none of this would matter much if the material weren't strong enough to contain these elements. (Machine Head are still very heavy
column5: they've just done away with their earlier template.) Despite the length of these songs
column6: Unto the Locust is focused
column7: with memorable choruses
column8: expressive riffs
column9: escalating dynamics
column10: and swarming instrumentation. Crunching floor punching shifts easily into acoustic madrigals. Classical moments turn into vintage thrash. The guitar solos are expressive and self-contained but deepen the rest of the track. Standout ""Be Still and Know"" opens with ultra-technical
column11: dueling double soloing topped only by the track's huge chorus. There
column12: and elsewhere
column13: you get clean vocals messing with and cascading alongside raspy howls. At its best
column14: this music is invigorating
column15: urgent
column16: necessary.

column1: Unto the Locust does fall off a bit toward the end
column2: but that's largely because the first four tracks add up to just under 30 minutes of the most exciting metal you'll hear all year. (""Pearls Before the Swine"" is a solid enough thrasher and the anthemic closer ""Who We Are"" features the first use of kids in a rock context in ages that hasn't made me wince
column3: though we could've done without the nu metal-ish ""Darkness Within"".) All told

column7:
progressive elements into the mix without forgoing their roots.

The Duke Spirit are a band you want to root for
column4: blessed as they are with an alluring frontwowan (Liela Moss) and good taste (drawing on everything from 1980s UK indie to northern soul to murder ballads)
column5: but also a willingness to burnish those outsider sources with a considerable sass and swagger to bring the masses on-side. And yet
column6: the masses have been mostly resistant to their charms-- the London group first surfaced in 2005 in the shadow of the similarly seedy but more widely celebrated Kills

column8: attention-grabbing takes on shared noise-pop influences.

column1: The title of the Duke Spirit's third album would suggest they're tired of being relegated to second-class NME citizenry and ready to show the kids who's boss. But Bruiser-- produced by alt-rock spit-shiner Andrew Scheps-- feels oddly restrained
column2: as the band sounds caught between the duelling desires to hold onto its grit-rock roots and to make its sound more sophisticated. The Duke Spirit have always attempted a tricky balancing act in their music--between the classic and the modern
column3: the dissonant and the accessible

column6: swing
column7: and vigor; by contrast

column9: mid-tempo backbeats that don't provide the band with much opportunity to catch fire and push the Duke Spirit perilously close to run-of-the-mill mid-2000s modern rock. (The pomped-up power ballad ""Northbound"" doesn't do them any favors in that regard either
column10: sounding a few years too late for an O.C. prom-scene placement.)

column2: the album does find the band showcasing its dynamic range in new and intriguing ways

column4: piano-rolled lullaby Nina Persson might've brought to a latter-day Cardigans or A Camp record-- to ""Sweet Bitter Sweet""
column5: a solitary blues that blossoms into a theatrical show-stopper. Best of all is ""Bodies""

column8: almost stoner-metalesque surge. It's a rare instance where Bruiser lives up to its titular threat

column10: downcast balladry
column11: it's safe to say that
column12: at this point
column13:
the Duke Spirit are becoming ever more interested in cataloguing emotional wounds as leaving physical ones.

column11: Holger Czukay

column1: Odd

He dug out the Drummer One drum machine that was one of the group's signature sounds in its early days and crafted a series of keyboard sounds very similar to the ones he might have used in the early-to-mid 1970s. The resemblance is more than superficial
column6: though. The convergence of strict
column7: steady rhythm and drifting
column8: amorphous melody on Wasser Im Wind has close relatives on Zuckerzeit and Sowiesoso. It's almost as if
column9: one year removed from Cluster

column1: Think about going back to look at a house you lived in long ago

column3: it's going to look familiar

column5: the tree they planted

Let's get something out of the way: prog. As in
column4: it's impossible to discuss Justice's sophomore album
column5: <i>Audio
column6: Video
column7: Disco without noting just how thoroughly the Parisian duo has adopted the brash sounds of late-1970s progressive rock. The referents-- Yes for turbulent guitar lines
column8: Goblin for sly italo beats
column9: Queen for unapologetic bombast-- jump off the plastic

column11: clubby obelisks that defined †. Their new direction is precocious

column14: fidelity

column1: Though it sparked a still-running debate about the duo's credentials
column3: by accessing unexplored levels of sleaze and cheese
column4: actually fit into dance music's long
column5: proud tradition of not giving a fuck. That they did this in a rock context-- leather jackets; big live show; loud
column6: terrible mastering-- seemed at the time reverent of peak-era Daft Punk but in retrospect appears prescient: Deadmau5 and Skrillex headline festivals
column7: hellbent on teasing out the most seizure-inducing mix of lighting and music possible. In 2011 anyone looking to beef about ""real"" dance music stares into a smaller barrel filled with bigger fish.

column1: In this way
column2: AVD is a natural progression for Justice.
column3: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px; background-color: #ffffff;"">Their M.O. is bold irreverence
column4: and they've found multiple ways to express it. Still
column5: it's hard not to admire their choice: It threatens to alienate their core audience while endearing them to a group of fans unlikely to take up their cause (or realize they exist). Prog-rock has long been championed by experimental music fans for its complexity and ambition-- it was outsider art that made the mistake of actually selling records.

column1: Prog remains a mostly unclaimed orphan of rock history
column2: and while certain corners of the indie establishment-- Fiery Furnaces
column3: Sufjan Stevens
column4: Dirty Projectors-- have adopted its structure and imagination
column5: they've left the flute solos behind. (Dance acts like Aeroplane and Wolfram have mined this territory to mixed effect.) Justice take the opposite tack: AVD is composed of short
column6: simple tracks stuffed with stairway-climbing solos
column7: ascendant male vocalists
column8: and starry-skied bridges. The duo has called AVD a ""daylight"" album
column9: presumably in contrast with †'s nocturnal vibe. But just like a low-lit club can mask flaws
column10: Justice's full-bore wall-of-dance bulldozed some of their compositional shortcomings. AVD is brighter and more diffuse (though
column11: sadly
column12: its recording style is no more dynamic)
column13: but the light shining through does Justice no favors.

column1: It's easy to admire progressive rock for its immersion and commitment to concept
column2: as well as its musical prowess and scope. These are
column3: sadly
column4: the elements Justice strip away. Instead
column5: they employ prog's sounds in short
column6: distracting bursts
column7: filling AVD with melodies that are curious but difficult to remember or enjoy. They do this in the style they know how--
column8: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px; background-color: #ffffff;"">with hoary
column9: space-eating electronics-- which suggests supreme digital craftsmanship but doesn't do the listener any favors. The guitars sounds are uniformly shrill
column10: the bass flatulent
column11: the rhythms rudimentary.

column1: They employ singers more frequently than on †: male voices
column2: pinched and bleating. I won't do you the disservice of examining their lyrics (they're hardly the point
column3: for Justice or for us)
column4: but suffice to say they don't add much. AVD's finest moment is the title track
column5: in which a voice is digitally manipulated into a current of high-strung
column6: winsome tunefulness. ""Helix""
column7: their most blatant disco move
column8: is robotically funky
column9: a reminder of what Justice are capable of when they commit fully to Daft pyrotechnics.

column1: The majority of AVD
column2: though
column3: is cheese-rock signifiers dressed up as dance music. Once you get over the fact that the band got a little Cerrone in your ""Kashmir"" (""On'n'on"") or spiked your Moroder with Toto (""Horsepower"") there's little reason to come back to AVD. Immersing yourself in the record is an exercise in liking Justice as a concept more while liking their actual output less. There's too much space between AVD and actual prog to accept that Justice are committed to this direction. They spent all their daring on concept

column5:
there is little style in their reduction.

There's been no shortage of dialogue around how dubstep has exploded and splintered into countless fragments-- disparate but still interlinked shards reflecting shades of techno
column2: house
column3: garage
column4: drum'n'bass and everything else under the sun. English-born Paul Rose has historically been one of the earliest agents of this dubstep disintegration
column5: making the move to techno haven Berlin early and establishing an interest in the genre that soon became commonplace among many of his genre contemporaries. Founding what would become one of the leading institutions in the techno/dubstep fusion with his Hotflush Recordings label and unprecedentedly landing a residency at the world's most infamous techno club
column6: Berghain
column7: Rose-- better known as Scuba
column8: SCB
column9: or Spectr-- has been a leading light in dissolving the boundaries between different worlds of dance music.

column1: But no matter how experimental or cross-boundary this particular sphere of music gets
column2: there's always a line drawn between all these iterations of ""bass music"" and what might be considered ""proper"" techno and house. It's the reason why Rose splits his time between Scuba (bass music) and SCB (straight-up techno)
column3: why his memorable RA podcast was a ""versus"" between his alter egos
column4: and why his SUB:STANCE club night happens on Fridays at Berghain and not Saturdays. It's the reason why his only previous commercial mix CD as Scuba focused almost exclusively on dubstep-centric sounds with none of SCB trickling in. But all bets are off with Rose's contribution to the long-running DJ-Kicks series
column5: where that border fence between ""bass"" and techno is finally demolished. Mixing genres isn't anything out of the ordinary anymore (in fact
column6: it's pretty much expected)
column7: but rarely do we see this kind of flitting between extremes in such a small and confined space.

column1: I'm tempted to say that the overarching theme here is techno
column2: but it's a weird sort of techno. Even when we get big names like Surgeon and Marcel Dettmann
column3: we're not given chunky workouts or sleek
column4: streamlined bangers
column5: but the militarist thrust of ""The Power of Doubt"" and the jerky IDM of ""Captivate"". Rose prefers these album cuts over easily more functional single material from either producer
column6: which says a lot about his outside-the-box approach here. Forgoing both the instant-gratification quick mixing of bass music DJs and the lengthy blends of Berlin techno jocks
column7: the tracks feel like they're melting in and out of each other
column8: which means their generic signifiers melt away as well.  Rose's style is a fastidious ebb and flow of microscopic beat-stitching. Structurally
column9: Scuba's DJ-Kicks throws another curveball: It doesn't build toward any particular climax
column10: nor is it centered around the ""drop"" structure inherent to most bass music. The closest we get are the bits of warm melody that seep in with tracks like Braille's jazzy ""Breakup"" or Mr. Beatnick's elegant G-funk epic ""Don't Walk Away From My Love"".

column1: Lately Rose's own productions have been moving into house territory
column2: slowing below even the accepted median ""bass"" tempo of 130 beats per minute (as theorized by Pitchfork's own Martin Clark). What this means is that his mix plays the aural illusion of actually slowing down over the course of its duration: where most DJs would gradually ratchet up the tempo
column3: Rose drags it down from a healthy 132 BPM to a leisurely 125
column4: right where his newest tracks sit. The descent is deceptive
column5: because the mix comes closer to anthemic as it slows: The CD-exclusive ""M.A.R.S"" is an uncharacteristically happy-go-lucky banger
column6: and it's followed by a rousing selection of house producers like Recondite
column7: Jichael Mackson
column8: and Rivet
column9: previously unassociated with either Scuba or SCB.

column1: No late-2011 Scuba mix would be complete without his controversial ""Adrenalin""
column2: and DJ-Kicks finally delivers it. The track is given a five-minute spotlight
column3: a gratuitous move for an equally gratuitous track touching on the untouchable: The pariah genres of prog house and trance are fastened with the most decadent breakdown you've heard since you used to listen to Sasha. Leaving ""Adrenalin"" to the end of the mix is perhaps the only predictable moment on Paul Rose's DJ-Kicks
column4: a disc that's otherwise determined in its mission to keep you on your toes
column5: knitting complex percussive webs and blending genres at a reckless rate that feels like a new gold standard for an already bled-through music world. It might be just a mix CD
column6: but Scuba's DJ-Kicks is a landmark both personal and scene-wide. It shouldn't come as a surprise though
column7:
because Paul Rose is just leading the pack like he's always done.

There are at least two ways to look at a guitar riff-- as a building block for a song
column2: or as an end in itself. Ryland Wharton
column3: aka King Blood
column4: has taken the latter viewpoint to a mesmerizing extreme. On Eyewash Silver-- originally released in a tiny edition in 2010-- he treats fuzzy guitar riffs not simply as ends
column5: but as mantras to be chanted and monuments to be worshiped. Each track offers one simple figure devoutly repeated
column6: as if musical nirvana is always just one more riff away.

column1: If I'm making Eyewash Silver sound too solemn or reverent
column2: don't worry-- it's also a lot of fun. Wharton's clanging chords never feel dry or studied. Instead they're charged with an impulsive exuberance. Often it sounds like he came up with a guitar loop right before he hit record on his four-track
column3: and was so excited that he didn't want to waste another second before churning away. That feel is enhanced by muddy
column4: static-drenched production. The album drips with overload
column5: creating a raw
column6: gut-level immediacy. The idea behind each song is delivered unwashed and unrefined.

column1: In that sense
column2: Eyewash Silver reminds me of Neil Young
column3: particularly his solo guitar soundtrack to Jim Jarmusch's 1995 existential western Dead Man. Wharton's songs aren't nearly as sparse or forlorn as Young's score
column4: but both share a near-anthropological fascination with the primal force of repeated notes. (Besides
column5: the swinging hooks of ""Poison in Jest"" and ""Sinfull Woman"" sound extracted and extended from Crazy Horse tunes). You'll hear other reference points throughout Eyewash Silver-- the noisy wash of Japanese bands like Fushitsusha and Les Rallizes Denudes
column6: the motor-garage of Wooden Shjips
column7: and
column8: on the near-perfect ""End of a Primitive""
column9: the classic amp-melt of great Velvet Underground bootlegs. But I keep coming back to Young and his exploratory wanderings
column10: a standard to which Wharton measures up well.

column1: The only flaw you might find in Eyewash Silver is the claustrophobic effect its relentless distortion can create. Sometimes after I've listened to it repeatedly
column2: it's taken me a while to shake the feeling that I'm wearing earmuffs. But this also gives the album a world-apart feel-- it's unlikely you'll get distracted by anything else while this album is on. Besides
column3: even if you can't bear to hear King Blood over and over
column4:
one listen to its echoing riffs might make you feel like you have.

What binds the work of those artists with Cacciapaglia's intent for this album is a desire to funnel avant-garde influences into a robust future-pop sound. This record originally came out in 1979
column4: just a few years after Giorgio Moroder was in his pomp with ""I Feel Love""

column8: pop

column1: So who are Roberto Cacciapaglia and Ann Steel? The former is an Italian musician who specialized in electronic composition after starting his career in the early 1970s on the edges of the krautrock scene. The latter is a Michigan-bred singer who spun into Cacciapaglia's orbit during a trip to Italy in the 1970s to do some modeling. The Ann Steel Album is the one-off result of that happy accident
column2: a record so full of joy that it's a surprise they weren't tempted to go back for another bite once it was in the can. But it's a credit to both of them that they knew when to stop
column3: perhaps feeling that the sugary pop perfection of these recordings could never be replicated. There's a clunky charm to many of the synth sounds

column1: There are two modes that Cacciapaglia and Steel flit between on this album. Mostly it's a precise brand of fizzy avant-electronica with a utopian edge to it (""My Time""
column2: ""Media"")
column3: set to lyrics about metaphysics
column4: Freud
column5: Warhol
column6: the media
column7: candy bars
column8: and a huge range of pop culture marginalia. Albert Einstein gets a mention in both of the first two tracks
column9: preceding a brief trend for writing songs about him (Landscape
column10: Big Audio Dynamite) in the 80s. The second type of song on The Ann Steel Album echoes the kind of ruminative electronic work Broadcast would pick up on in future years
column11: with tracks like ""Quite Still"" and ""Sparkling World"" set around half-paced beats and blotchy keyboard noise. But it's in the upbeat work that the pair really excels
column12: and the basic formula is often retooled to work in other elements such as the funk undertow of ""Portrait"" and the unabashed ABBA tributary of ""Media""

column7: precision

column9: and TV. It's a song that works in two ways

column18:
where its reputation has deservedly grown to something approximating cult-classic status.

This sequence finds Crow easing up on the tricky rhythms and the guitar tangles that are his stock-in-trade

column6: 15 easy minutes. Blithely confident
column7: Astro Coast's sunsoaked power-pop found Surfer Blood blowing through one breezily bulbous hook and escapist lyric after another. Tarot Classics finds Surfer Blood throwing a little shade.

column1: With its so-bright-you'll-squint melody and bummer-in-the-summer vibe
column2: ""I'm Not Ready"" would've fit just fine almost anywhere on Astro Coast. But its crisp handclaps and neon guitars belie a serious compositional sophistication
column3: a seemingly endless string of bridges charting the path to the song's bounding hook. ""Your mouth is running off now that you've seen a few things
column4: Pitts admonishes
column5: and ""don't get too big for your britches"" seems in some ways Tarot Classics' guiding principle. As on Astro Coast
column6: they seem confident in their every move but unwilling to take on more than they can handle.

column1: First single ""Miranda"" is a bit of a blur
column2: highlighted by its a rousing guitar break
column3: its one-word chorus (hint: it's a girl's name)
column4: and a more-than-passable Morrissey impression from Pitts. The hints of Anglophilia that emerge on ""Miranda"" and through the rest of Tarot Classics are
column5: in many ways
column6: their biggest step away from the distinctly American roots (Beach Boys
column7: Weezer
column8: Cheap Trick) of Astro Coast. Pitts' voice wears this somewhat dolorous tone every bit as well as he did Astro Coast's shouty Brian Wilsonisms
column9: and the band follows suit
column10: lending a richly textured
column11: slightly overcast New Romantic lean to the proceedings that feels deeper-- if a bit less retina-searing-- than the brasher Astro Coast.

column1: ""Voyager Reprise"" takes off slowly
column2: eventually settling into a shuffly
column3: somewhat morose melody and dance-night-at-the-pub groove pitched somewhere between the Strokes and those early Cure singles. It's aching melody amplified by that newfound gravity in Pitts' voice
column4: ""Voyager"" certainly feels like Surfer Blood's first truly sad song
column5: the longing in its simply stated chorus impossible to miss. Closer ""Drinking Problem"" is alternately Tarot Classics' highlight and its least characteristic track
column6: a lush
column7: staggering bit of New Romantic pop that finds Pitts switching out the Moz for a Bernard Sumnerian swoon not unlike that of Kisses frontman Jesse Kivel. A shimmering synth melody buoys the aching Pitts
column8: reassuring himself with
column9: ""at least I know who my friends are
column10: every utterance sounding less and less convinced of itself.

column1: A year and change on the road finds Pitts seeming a bit guarded
column2: picking at the long-term scars of short-term affairs
column3: questioning everyone's motivations
column4: starting with his own. But if he's undergoing some crisis of confidence
column5: it's not shared by his bandmates; like Astro Coast
column6: Tarot Classics' popcraft proves well beyond promising
column7: and these songs are certainly sturdy enough to handle their lusher productions and knottier sentiments. Tarot Classics once again fixes the spotlight on Surfer Blood's insidious melodies
column8: refining-- rather than reconfiguring-- their self-possessed sound. It's still summer where Surfer Blood come from
column9:
it's just a little colder there now.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17092/homepage_large.f88f2a26.jpg|Let the Poison Out|29365.0|The Beets|['Rock'
column3: in an interview published shortly after the release of Stay Home
column4: Beets principles Juan Wauters and Jose Garcia revealed that the writing for their next album had already been completed. This is far from a surprising development in the world of garage-rock
column5: where most bands worth their weight in Nuggets compilations are prone (or
column6: at the very least
column7: prepared) to release two albums
column8: five 7"" and 12"" singles
column9: and maybe even a tour-only cassette as a forget-me-not in the span of about nine months. Being prolific is not a minor miracle in garage so much as it is muscle memory; the defining trait of this style of music is that it's not incredibly difficult to compose.

column1: This is especially true of the Beets
column2: a band who tours the Continental 48 in a station wagon
column3: whose cover art is exclusively drawn with crayons. You get the impression that a Beets song takes about as much time to write and record a song as it takes Beets album artist Matthew Volz to run to Walgreens and get a 64-color box of Crayolas. What would probably be considered an insult to most other bands is part and parcel to the Beets' charm.

column1: Much like their heroes Ramones-- a band namedropped in Howard Stern's brief on-air appraisal of the band-- the Beets are long on attitude. On their debut
column2: Spit in the Face of People Who Don't Want to Be Cool
column3: the album's title served equally well as a mission statement. When the production quality of your record is equivalent to a damp fast food napkin
column4: attitude is pretty much all you have to go on. Spit in the Face was intriguing and enjoyable because it was a lot like watching a band playing through a garage door made of opaque glass: You couldn't tell exactly what they were doing
column5: but you wanted to be a part of it anyway.

column1: Let the Poison Out continues the band's gradual crawl out of the basement
column2: and with the added sonic clarity comes the best collection of songs Wauters has written. Granted
column3: the chords haven't ventured into jazzy diminished sevenths-- nor has the band decided to use a full drum kit to play its songs-- but the album showcases the Beets as a band every bit as off-the-cuff as it has been
column4: though far more distinctive. With Wauters' voice pushed to the forefront
column5: the bratty scream-singing of Spit in the Face of People Who Don't Want to Be Cool and Stay Home makes way for heavily accented-- and
column6: in the case of ""Wipe It Off""
column7: intentionally broken-- English
column8: something undetected on past Beets records
column9: where the vocals either sat among or were buried underneath the thudding drums. In general
column10: Wauters is working with a broader songwriting palette. Adding  to various Beets traditions-- the tune sung in Spanish (""Preso Voy"")
column11: the loopy
column12: experimental interlude (""Eat No Dick 3"")-- he boasts a love  for stream-of-consciousness imagery on opener ""You Don't Want Kids to be  Dead""
column13: offers sage advice on ""Doing as I Do""
column14: and plays a lovelorn game of ""this or that"" on ""I Don't Know"".

column1: The record also marks the addition of drummer Chie Mori
column2: whose plaintive anti-harmonies augment Wauters' singing in a way that recalls a less irksome version of the Moldy Peaches. The boy-girl vocals do more than just add to the pop bliss of the record's more infectious moments: ""Friends of Friends"" is made rowdier by Mori's contributions
column3: while her backing vocals on quasi-psychedelic closer ""Walking to My House"" give the song a skewed and eerie vibe. The Beets' newfound focus on recording quality could have easily highlighted shortcomings
column4: but instead
column5:
the band found a way to broaden its sound by recruiting a member who exponentially adds to its worth.

Mondkopf is a French artist with a German name
column2: which is fitting
column3: given how often his productions play in a middle ground between those two countries' archetypal modes of electronic music. Looked at a certain way
column4: Rising Doom
column5: the 24-year old's latest full-length and first for Fool House
column6: the label imprint of French fashion/mp3 blog Fluokids
column7: borrows the machine muscle of harsh Teutonic techno and leavens it with just a bit of the joviality and melody of French touch.

column1: Of course
column2: genre divides don't break down cleanly along national lines. German and French electronic music have long been in close conversation-- especially in recent years
column3: with crossover acts like Digitalism or the Ed Banger roster frequently blurring the lines
column4: or with UK dubstep usurping the conversation altogether. And while Rising Doom is no more dubstep than it is minimal or filter house
column5: it might actually be British bass music's mutations that make the single largest mark on the album.

column1: This is most apparent in terms of overall mood. From the name Rising Doom to track titles that sound like weightier Dr. Who episodes (""Where the Gods Fall""
column2: ""The Song of Shadows""
column3: ""Day of Anger"") on down to the creeping stereo synths and stalking drum-machine beats
column4: the album is permeated by the kind of ominousness and menace that is increasingly the currency of dubstep as it goes teenage testosteroned and mainstream. Which would grate or bore if it weren't also so meticulously sculpted.

column1: Rising Doom is full of the kind of 3-D sound design
column2: melodramatic melodic arcs
column3: and chest-thumping bass beats that might make Mondkopf's closest peers in terms of pure sonics the German duo Modeselektor
column4: especially on songs like the staticky
column5: synth-sawing ""Day of Anger""
column6: although its classical-sounding piano bookends recall something else entirely. Other audio-engineering showpieces include the muffled haunted-house organs and big-room shuffle of ""Deadwood""
column7: or ""Where the Gods Fall""
column8: which-- with its lurching rhythm
column9: shushing
column10: shrill-as-hell hi-hat slicing
column11: and mid-frequency rave synths stabbing in the background-- might be the closest thing here to a proper dubstep track.

column1: This stuff can turn ponderous
column2: though
column3: as on the nine-minute-long closer ""Fossil Lights""
column4: a half-time fade-out which strains for the sort of cinematic epic of an M83 coda but ends up feeling incidental. He sometimes succumbs to this sort of well-crafted sound for its own sake
column5:
rather than in the service of either a memorable song or a physically functional track.

Stevie Jackson joined Belle and Sebastian about 15 years ago

column7: and
column8: yup
column9: showtunes. Put together intermittently since 2006 with fellow B&S members and a few longtime friends

column1: Chalk it up

column8: ""Along came a bigger bird/ More bigger than he

column10: context isn't the problem. On a musty tape somewhere
column11: there must be a forgotten Jens Lekman song that brings this stale theme to wittier
column12: more vivid life.

column1: That said
column2: Jackson has long since proved himself to be more than merely an adept sideman
column3: and he flashes glimmers of those skills here. Jittery preview track ""Try Me"" skirts the album's occasionally narrow topical concerns (two songs loosely about directors
column4: one about a redevelopment project) and dippy faux-innocence (""He was my best friend at school...""). Instead
column5: Jackson homes in neatly on a rich
column6: distinctive emotional state-- ""I got pills and I'm looking for thrills/ At the same time I want to start a family""-- and an equally well-developed organ-rock sound that builds on predecessors like ? and the Mysterians
column7: the Clean
column8: and Love Is All. This one's definitely worth the attempt.

column1: The new album's other preview track
column2: the string-splashed
column3: many-voiced ""Man of God""
column4: comes closest to the Jesus Christ Superstar theatricality of The Life Pursuit songs like ""Act of the Apostle"". Only appropriate
column5: given the title. Here
column6: though
column7: Jackson dodges some of the new record's pitfalls with yet another droll piece of songwriting: The religious imagery turns out to be just an unlikely setting for a music fan's doomed attempt to seduce through the strength of his record collection. Thankfully
column8: Jackson doesn't make that mistake on (I Can't Get No) Stevie Jackson. Still
column9:
there's a disconnect between this fair-to-middling solo record and the vital role its creator plays in one of the indie world's truly singular ensembles.

column1: Formed in 1981

column3: thanks to their third album

column7: the big
column8: romantic ballads were still there
column9: but they were strangely muted. They had an eerie jazz-like minimalism and attention to atmosphere that suggested an appreciation for Eno's ambient records.

column1: This canny mix
column2: stadium-friendly melodrama in an experimental but not too out-there package
column3: paid greater commercial dividends than probably anyone would have guessed. With EMI's accounting department more than pleased
column4: the label gave Talk Talk carte blanche to make any damned album they wished. The result was the band's fourth album
column5: 1988's Spirit of Eden. Talk Talk took up this new freedom with a perverse relish
column6: racking up countless hours and major dollars recording Spirit
column7: a gorgeous but amorphous epic that proved that ruthless quiet could be just as difficult as ear-harassing volume. Talk Talk took this go-ahead from their label as their chance
column8: possibly their last
column9: to explore their truly envelope-pushing ideas
column10: rather than the hints they'd offered on Spring.

column1: By the time of Spirit
column2: Talk Talk had fully rejected the sleek and kitschily futuristic music that first brought then to prominence. In its place
column3: they crafted an immersive and ever-flowing style
column4: alternately hushed and loud
column5: lush and arid. It was a brand of unashamed art rock that was completely out of step with both the underground's unkempt roar and the manicured mainstream. Jazz became a more major component than ever
column6: both in the overall style of playing
column7: especially drummer Lee Harris' steady and cymbal-heavy swing
column8: but also in the band's increasingly complex and usually improvised interaction. These improvisations were stitched together after the fact into what sound like carefully thought-out compositions that still somehow vibrate with the surprise of in-the-moment exploration. Which partly explains how ""I Believe in You""
column9: Hollis' most comprehensible performance on an album where a lyric sheet is very necessary
column10: can feel like a singer-songwriter ballad floating in and out of a swirl that evokes avant-classical at its least forbidding and electric jazz at its most beatific.

column1: This genre-blurring fearlessness
column2: along with the way Spirit and Laughing Stock bloom from extreme quiet to extreme loudness only to slowly recede again
column3: is why these albums get tagged as precursors to post-rock
column4: when no post-rock albums much resemble them in sound
column5: construction
column6: or especially ambition. Talk Talk use ideas from jazz and classical to build the subtlest gradations of drama. But despite the restraint
column7: it's also not polite
column8: musically or otherwise.

column1: Hands were wrung on a corporate level over Spirit. Some old fans understandably balked
column2: though new fans did gradually accumulate. An note of puzzlement could be read in the press notices
column3: whether they offered praise or derision. The band decamped to Polydor and made an even more opaque fifth and final album
column4: using much the same methodology as on Spirit and seeming to give even less of a shit about how it would all be received.

column1: This is the oft-repeated and probably too-pat story that gave Talk Talk a second life as fame-spurning and journey-hardened underground icons. But it's also not hard to understand why the band broke up after Laughing Stock
column2: or was simply broken. There's more going on in these six tracks than on Spirit
column3: but the song structures are even stranger
column4: built up from the tiniest musical gestures
column5: clashing in mood from track to track
column6: frequently more improvised-sounding than ever. The goal
column7: assembling a coherent album from all this stuff
column8: probably seemed quixotic to many of the contributors as it was being made. The recording process has long been described as one of the most arduous and prone to control freakitude ever. The band members were probably relieved to dissolve Talk Talk
column9: move on to less demanding projects
column10: or recede back into private life
column11: once Laughing Stock was finished
column12: despite the monumentality of what they finally made.

column1: And it remains wholly singular
column2: however many indie rock bands and experimental composers have genuflected toward it over the last 20 years. The half-dozen songs on Laughing Stock feel discrete
column3: complete-unto-themselves
column4: each one a little world that doesn't always seem to have much to do with the song that precedes or follows it. The underwater glide of ""New Grass"" is Talk Talk as a purely placid and lovely proposition
column5: electric organ and lilting guitar endlessly circling around Harris' heartbeat-steady drumming
column6: recalling the tranquility threatened with an edge of disquiet in Robert Wyatt's early solo work. ""Ascension Day"" remains the band's most chaotic and vicious song
column7: like a small jazz combo being elbowed aside by a noise-rock band
column8: with a climactic barrage of drumming that falls on your ears like an avalanche before the audible tape-splice cuts it dead. But even in this assault you can hear the monomaniacal care and craft that went into assembling and recording Laughing Stock
column9: from the full-bodied throb of the upright bass to the little twitches and groans of horror-movie music lurking in the background on the verses. Laughing Stock was Talk Talk at their most demanding
column10: and when listening to the spectral free jazz squeal of ""Taphead""
column11: you understand why it was saddled for so many years with the ""difficult"" epithet.

column1: The Laughing Stock reissue sounds amazing
column2: as good as  the album's ever sounded
column3: in any format. Which is crucial
column4: because on  some level Talk Talk's later albums are all about sound. How startling
column5: isolated moments of sound
column6: or a formless wash of sound
column7: can wring  emotions out of listeners as powerfully as any conventional  melody. How the ambient sound of the room in which an album was recorded  can be used almost as instrument in itself
column8: and how the studio can be  used to create a sense of environment in the listener's mind that has  nothing to do with recording booths and control decks. How far the sound  of a rock song can be pared back and loosened up and still be ""rock
column9: or even still be ""a song."" And especially how sound can become all the  more powerful when surrounded by silence
column10: great gulfs of which are all  over the later Talk Talk albums
column11: especially Laughing Stock
column12: captured here in a remarkable vinyl mastering job on Ba Da Bing's part.

column1: Seven years after Laughing Stock
column2: and seven years into the band's slow word-of-mouth rehabilitation from pretentious flop to shining example for independent artists
column3: Mark Hollis returned with a completely unexpected solo album
column4: which seemed to almost sneak out into the real world rather than be ""released"" with the usual promotional fanfare. Part of this feeling comes from Hollis' almost Salinger-grade rejection of celebrity
column5: journalism
column6: the industry
column7: even making art for public consumption. (Talk Talk virtually disappeared as a public entity from Spirit onward
column8: leaving the records to do most of the talking.) But it also comes from the startlingly private sound of Mark Hollis itself
column9: like the kind of painful
column10: personal document that's usually released only after the artist's death.

column1: Where Laughing Stock creates multiple environments
column2: Mark Hollis is intimate
column3: almost shockingly so. Hollis often sings as if he's right up against your ear
column4: at a volume designed to not wake spouses and small children. Listening
column5: you often feel like you're eavesdropping on a musician working in the supposed seclusion of his home. Indeed
column6: like few other records I know-- maybe Panda Bear's Young Prayer and Arthur Russell's World of Echo-- Mark Hollis creates the sensation that you're very much in the room where it was recorded.

column1: But where those albums sounded very much like thrifty
column2: one-man-band operations
column3: Mark Hollis draws on a cast of musicians almost as large as Laughing Stock
column4: and in their own self-consciously restricted way
column5: these songs are as dramatic as anything on that album. Certainly they're as immersive
column6: if only because you have to listen so closely
