column8: in order to follow the even more classical-informed logic of their movement
column9: whole songs carried by just an oblique dance of woodwinds or a long-decaying string melody. Over its eight minutes
column10: ""A Life (1895-1915)"" plays like a novel whittled down to a haiku
column11: tracing one WWI soldier's tragic arc from birth to early death on the battlefield
column12: with Hollis' barely audible voice at the song's end communicating as much ache as any of his more full-throated performances. If the hermetic Laughing Stock was a scaling back of the wide-open grandeur of Spirit of Eden
column13: then Mark Hollis is an even more radical reduction of scale.

column1: So it's no surprise that Hollis has been publicly silent ever since
column2: since silence always seems to be where the songs on Mark Hollis want to go
column3: as if it took great effort to even decide to commit these particular sounds to tape. Perhaps Hollis just feels that he's said everything he had to say. Or perhaps he's still deliberating as to what
column4: if anything
column5: he's comfortable with releasing next. Unlike many reclusive musicians
column6: though
column7: you won't feel that Hollis absented himself before his overall project was completed. These albums still stand a good chance of alienating you
column8: but if you find yourself vibrating sympathetically to them
column9: there's enough mystery and beauty in them to sustain a lifetime's listening
column10:
whether Hollis or Talk Talk ever record another note.

column6: or especially ambition. Talk Talk use ideas from jazz and classical to build the subtlest gradations of drama. But despite the restraint
column7: it's also not polite
column8: musically or otherwise.

column1: Hands were wrung on a corporate level over Spirit. Some old fans understandably balked
column2: though new fans did gradually accumulate. An note of puzzlement could be read in the press notices
column3: whether they offered praise or derision. The band decamped to Polydor and made an even more opaque fifth and final album
column4: using much the same methodology as on Spirit and seeming to give even less of a shit about how it would all be received.

column1: This is the oft-repeated and probably too-pat story that gave Talk Talk a second life as fame-spurning and journey-hardened underground icons. But it's also not hard to understand why the band broke up after Laughing Stock
column2: or was simply broken. There's more going on in these six tracks than on Spirit
column3: but the song structures are even stranger
column4: built up from the tiniest musical gestures
column5: clashing in mood from track to track
column6: frequently more improvised-sounding than ever. The goal
column7: assembling a coherent album from all this stuff
column8: probably seemed quixotic to many of the contributors as it was being made. The recording process has long been described as one of the most arduous and prone to control freakitude ever. The band members were probably relieved to dissolve Talk Talk
column9: move on to less demanding projects
column10: or recede back into private life
column11: once Laughing Stock was finished
column12: despite the monumentality of what they finally made.

column1: And it remains wholly singular
column2: however many indie rock bands and experimental composers have genuflected toward it over the last 20 years. The half-dozen songs on Laughing Stock feel discrete
column3: complete-unto-themselves
column4: each one a little world that doesn't always seem to have much to do with the song that precedes or follows it. The underwater glide of ""New Grass"" is Talk Talk as a purely placid and lovely proposition
column5: electric organ and lilting guitar endlessly circling around Harris' heartbeat-steady drumming
column6: recalling the tranquility threatened with an edge of disquiet in Robert Wyatt's early solo work. ""Ascension Day"" remains the band's most chaotic and vicious song
column7: like a small jazz combo being elbowed aside by a noise-rock band
column8: with a climactic barrage of drumming that falls on your ears like an avalanche before the audible tape-splice cuts it dead. But even in this assault you can hear the monomaniacal care and craft that went into assembling and recording Laughing Stock
column9: from the full-bodied throb of the upright bass to the little twitches and groans of horror-movie music lurking in the background on the verses. Laughing Stock was Talk Talk at their most demanding
column10: and when listening to the spectral free jazz squeal of ""Taphead""
column11: you understand why it was saddled for so many years with the ""difficult"" epithet.

column1: The Laughing Stock reissue sounds amazing
column2: as good as  the album's ever sounded
column3: in any format. Which is crucial
column4: because on  some level Talk Talk's later albums are all about sound. How startling
column5: isolated moments of sound
column6: or a formless wash of sound
column7: can wring  emotions out of listeners as powerfully as any conventional  melody. How the ambient sound of the room in which an album was recorded  can be used almost as instrument in itself
column8: and how the studio can be  used to create a sense of environment in the listener's mind that has  nothing to do with recording booths and control decks. How far the sound  of a rock song can be pared back and loosened up and still be ""rock
column9: or even still be ""a song."" And especially how sound can become all the  more powerful when surrounded by silence
column10: great gulfs of which are all  over the later Talk Talk albums
column11: especially Laughing Stock
column12: captured here in a remarkable vinyl mastering job on Ba Da Bing's part.

column1: Seven years after Laughing Stock
column2: and seven years into the band's slow word-of-mouth rehabilitation from pretentious flop to shining example for independent artists
column3: Mark Hollis returned with a completely unexpected solo album
column4: which seemed to almost sneak out into the real world rather than be ""released"" with the usual promotional fanfare. Part of this feeling comes from Hollis' almost Salinger-grade rejection of celebrity
column5: journalism
column6: the industry
column7: even making art for public consumption. (Talk Talk virtually disappeared as a public entity from Spirit onward
column8: leaving the records to do most of the talking.) But it also comes from the startlingly private sound of Mark Hollis itself
column9: like the kind of painful
column10: personal document that's usually released only after the artist's death.

column1: Where Laughing Stock creates multiple environments
column2: Mark Hollis is intimate
column3: almost shockingly so. Hollis often sings as if he's right up against your ear
column4: at a volume designed to not wake spouses and small children. Listening
column5: you often feel like you're eavesdropping on a musician working in the supposed seclusion of his home. Indeed
column6: like few other records I know-- maybe Panda Bear's Young Prayer and Arthur Russell's World of Echo-- Mark Hollis creates the sensation that you're very much in the room where it was recorded.

column1: But where those albums sounded very much like thrifty
column2: one-man-band operations
column3: Mark Hollis draws on a cast of musicians almost as large as Laughing Stock
column4: and in their own self-consciously restricted way
column5: these songs are as dramatic as anything on that album. Certainly they're as immersive
column6: if only because you have to listen so closely
column7: thanks to the lower-than-low-volume approach to recording and playing
column8: in order to follow the even more classical-informed logic of their movement
column9: whole songs carried by just an oblique dance of woodwinds or a long-decaying string melody. Over its eight minutes
column10: ""A Life (1895-1915)"" plays like a novel whittled down to a haiku
column11: tracing one WWI soldier's tragic arc from birth to early death on the battlefield
column12: with Hollis' barely audible voice at the song's end communicating as much ache as any of his more full-throated performances. If the hermetic Laughing Stock was a scaling back of the wide-open grandeur of Spirit of Eden
column13: then Mark Hollis is an even more radical reduction of scale.

column1: So it's no surprise that Hollis has been publicly silent ever since
column2: since silence always seems to be where the songs on Mark Hollis want to go
column3: as if it took great effort to even decide to commit these particular sounds to tape. Perhaps Hollis just feels that he's said everything he had to say. Or perhaps he's still deliberating as to what
column4: if anything
column5: he's comfortable with releasing next. Unlike many reclusive musicians
column6: though
column7: you won't feel that Hollis absented himself before his overall project was completed. These albums still stand a good chance of alienating you
column8: but if you find yourself vibrating sympathetically to them
column9: there's enough mystery and beauty in them to sustain a lifetime's listening
column10:
whether Hollis or Talk Talk ever record another note.

Sandro Perri has never shied away from expressing his admiration for Arthur Russell; among the highlights of the Toronto musician/producer's decade-plus-long career was a distended
column4: 21-minute reinterpretation of Russell's already lengthy Dinosaur disco classic ""Kiss Me Again"". But as Perri's discography has pluralized and diversified in unexpected ways
column5: Russell has become less of a direct musical influence than an inspirational model of following one's muse across dance
column6: avant-garde
column7: and roots-rock boundaries
column8: and marking those stylistic shifts with different
column9: highly evocative aliases. Since first establishing himself in the early 2000s as a producer of aquatic
column10: cerebral techno under the Polmo Polpo moniker
column11: Perri has variously indulged his interest in Nigerian juju and shantytown funk with one-album wonders Glissandro 70 and dubby disco as Dot Wiggin. But since 2007
column12: he's been releasing albums under his own name
column13: signaling a singer-songwriterly shift that foregrounds Perri's considerable talents as a pedal-steel guitarist and fondness for 1970s AM-radio pop
column14: even going so far as to faithfully cover Fleetwood Mac's ""Dreams"" and Harry Nilsson's ""Everybody's Talkin'"".

column1: Scanning the tracklist on Perri's new album
column2: Impossible Spaces
column3: you're first greeted with another familiar title: ""Changes"". But while the song that bears its name turns out not to be a version of either the David Bowie classic or the Black Sabbath piano ballad
column4: Perri at the very least embraces the root sentiment behind that well-worn title. Though ""Changes"" picks up where 2007's tropically tranquil Tiny Mirrors left off
column5: there are some immediately noticeable developments: Perri's plainspoken voice is several inches higher in the mix
column6: and the sound has been thickened considerably by warm organ tones and more scabrous electric-guitar lines
column7: while drummer Dan Gaucher sounds like he's itching to kick into a more robust backbeat. But then after three and a half minutes of stop-start teases
column8: ""Changes"" does just that
column9: by shifting into a glorious instrumental coda-- powered by a chugging Afro-funk groove and analog-synth starbursts-- that feels like an ecstatic
column10: out-of-body-experience answer to the more tentative passage that preceded it.

column1: ""Changes"" effectively confirms Impossible Spaces as the first Sandro Perri release to truly synthesize his myriad musical interests and place equal emphasis on rhythm
column2: texture
column3: and melody. With Perri backed once again by a coterie of Toronto improv-scene all stars-- who provide him with all the queasy-listening sophistication of a more inebriated Sea and Cake or a less spastic Dirty Projectors-- the album strikes an uncanny balance between sounding ambitiously executed and completely off-the-cuff; an epic of both accident and design. Perri isn't afraid to push his song lengths past the seven-minute mark (or thematically link shorter tracks into two-part suites)
column4: but Impossible Spaces never feels taxing or overwrought. Rather
column5: extended and exceedingly patient pieces like the woodwind-powered ""How Will I?"" and the exquisite 10-minute beast ""Wolfman"" yield a sustained thrill of discovery as
column6: with each new verse
column7: they wind and wander into an ever-dislocating swirl of brass
column8: flutes
column9: electric guitar
column10: strings
column11: and synth drones.

column1: Throughout it all
column2: Perri's invariably calm tenor assumes the reassuring presence of a tour guide who won't tell you where you're going but ensures you pass through safely: He rarely sings his verse melodies in any kind of formalized cadence but always returns to a familiar chorus refrain at just the right time to help you get reoriented. In that sense
column3: Impossible Spaces isn't simply the most accessible and immediately rewarding album to bear Sandro Perri's name
column4:
it also serves as a handy musical roadmap to its maker's sinuous creative course.

Taking it easy doesn't seem to come naturally to White Denim. They've been an ongoing concern only since 2007
column2: yet they already have five LPs and just as many EPs (and a handful of singles) to their credit.  However
column3: unlike other similarly prolific acts like Guided by Voices or Thee Oh Sees
column4: where the energy to write and record all those songs doesn't necessarily find itself reflected in the actual music
column5: White Denim's material more than reflects the speed with which it was released. It's only fitting one of their earlier full-lengths was titled Fits.

column1: It's not just that the band itself often seems eager to stuff as many notes as possible into every moment of every song
column2: but that the songs themselves are filled to the brim with tempo shifts and nods to  different kinds of music-- and all these ideas that just seem to pour out of the band.  Even as the group's brand of psychedelica has grown from its garagey roots into something more expansive and jammy
column3: that frenetic energy hasn't ebbed.  For the most part
column4: White Denim succeed with this full-steam-ahead tack
column5: though the generosity of creative spirit (and the high-speed fashion in which said spirit is imparted onto the listener) might seem exhausting as often as it does exhilarating. What makes Takes Place in Your Work Space a welcome addition to the burgeoning White Denim discography is its road-not-taken approach. This EP might be the most relaxed the band has ever been on record.

column1: Of course
column2: I am talking in terms of the group
column3: not what most folks consider ""relaxed.""  When ""Cat City"" starts up
column4: the guitar and drums kick into high gear as if it's business as usual.  Despite how that may sound
column5: the song itself is sedate
column6: thanks in no small part to subtle
column7: backward guitar loops and James Petralli's easygoing vocals.  Elsewhere on the EP
column8: the band uses similar tactics and arrangements to take the edge off.  On ""Handwriting""
column9: the contrast to the main group's hustle is provided by a string section
column10: some nicely pitched background vocals
column11: and a little pedal steel.  For ""Company""
column12: it's Petralli's falsetto (at times sounding a lot like Andrew Bird's) that does the job
column13: though nicking the gait and melody from Love's ""Alone Again Or"" doesn't hurt. The EP's best track
column14: ""No Real Reason""
column15: is similarly beholden to its possible source material-- LCD Soundsystem fans might hear more than a passing resemblance to ""Never as Tired...""-- but White Denim's homage (inadvertent or otherwise) is wholly successful
column16: showing the group can slow its roll without losing its sense of direction or purpose.

column1: More heartening than that minor revelation is the EP's overall cohesion. Being only four tracks long goes a long way toward maintaining a release's integrity and focus
column2: but unlike other White Denim albums-- which contain some great-sounding
column3: highly dissimilar tracks that just happen to be sharing the same space-- the songs on Takes Place complement each other and sound like they belong together. If there's been any tool missing from White Denim's warehouse-sized arsenal
column4:
it's this sort of ability to mete their boundless creativity with a sense of consistency and cohesion.

Fake-diamond punchlines aside-- and on a label called Fool's Gold
column2: no less-- there's something hard to shake about the all-surface nature of Cubic Zirconia's floss. Here's a group from New York that shoots for a Basement Jaxx-caliber house/funk crossover

column6: universal club-hopper soundtrack  that's aimed to fuse altered-state headrush and restless libido in ways  that made those two sensations feel inseparable. And after surveying the  crowded field of all-purpose post-hip-hop/post-electro  dance music
column7: they set about figuring out what parts to draw from to synthesize it all into the only album in the field that anybody would need to own.

column1: The end result of all this is Follow Your Heart
column2: and it's the  most frustrating kind of retro-pastiche. This is one of those albums  that attempts to fuse multiple instances of the familiar instead of  trying to coax underheard and unusual ideas out of a single deeper vein.  There's a dominant
column3: vaguely 1980s feel about it
column4: and even if there's  some loosely hinted signs of picking up a particular inspiration from  the big three mid-American hotspots of the era-- Minneapolis
column5: Detroit
column6: and Chicago-- they're rolled out with what feels like the musical  equivalent of received wisdom
column7: letting experienced listeners fill in the  blanks in the hope that the blanks aren't the only thing they hear. You  like frenetic
column8: high-concept synthesized funk à la Prince? See if you can cope with the way ""Freebase You"" and ""Runnin' in and Out of Love"" siphon it into a nuance-free piledriver. Think acid/techno fusion is interesting? The title track provides the absolute basic clichés of that potential and lets it ride out on autopilot. You want an aloof
column9: slightly off singer muttering come-ons and empty debauched phraseology over electro homages that don't sound much different as 30-year throwbacks than they did as 20-year throwbacks? ""Cherry Nights"" and ""Yellow Spaceship Pt. 2"" have you covered.

column1: The singer in question
column2: Tiombe Lockhart
column3: is not untalented-- there are some flashes of charisma and fuck-what-you-think oddness that sneak through during odd moments in Follow Your Heart. But there's this sort of semi-intentional Teflon aloofness to her voice
column4: and  for the most part her notes just kind of drone out instead of soaring  or piercing or hitting with any real impact. For most singers
column5: that  detached
column6: flat
column7: and affectless tendency can sound either cool or empty depending on the surrounding production.

column1: So when it's hard to tell how much depth the backing track's supposed to have
column2: it's also hard  to suss out any real emotion from that pro-forma deadpan
column3: whether she's quipping about ""writing a neo-soul song"" on the exact opposite thereof in electro workout ""Darko"" or making lovestruck euphoria sound mildly diverting on ""Take Me High"". It only becomes more obvious when she's pitted against someone with some chops (Bilal providing subtly rich harmonies on ""Night or Day"") or an actual personality (Dâm-Funk going all-out on ""I Got What You Need""). And when you pair that voice and those beats with similarly placeholder-feeling lyrics-- ""Summertime"" actually follows up the couplet
column4: ""Never makes me feel bad/ Never makes me  feel sad
column5: with the line
column6:
""Every time I see you my heart skips a beat""-- it's enough to make you wonder if trendy NYC dance music's found a way to run on aggregators.

The combination of pop songcraft and electronic texture that Jimmy Tamborello conjured on Dntel's Life Is Full of Possibilities seemed to achieve one of the implicit cardinal goals of independent music: to strike a seamless balance between ""catchy"" and ""experimental."" It was a coup for those of us who had both Squarepusher and Promise Ring discs in our CD changers
column4: a promise that the exhilarating high-budget sonics of Radiohead's Kid A could be brought down to the more human scale of bedroom indie pop. In a certain
column5: ineffable way it just sounded right for its time
column6: much in the way that Dirty Projectors' Bitte Orca and tUnE-yArDs' w h o k i l l have in recent years.

column1: In the decade since Life Is Full of Possibilities was first released on the Plug Research label
column2: we've realigned our perceptions of both ""catchy"" and ""experimental."" The sweet
column3: straightforward melodies on Life Is Full of Possibilities now seem almost embarrassingly earnest
column4: the electronic manipulations cold and procedural. While Tamborello's mastery is undeniable
column5: there's a staggering sense of openness to Life Is Full of Possibilities in both its content and its execution. There is no mystery here; you can see the gears turning
column6: both emotionally and sonically. For all its skittery beats and overdriven synthesizers
column7: Life Is Full of Possibilities often feels less like an ""intelligent dance music"" record than a straight-up 1990s emo record
column8: with the muscle of a traditional rock band proxied by Tamborello's smart
column9: dynamic arrangements.

column1: Though Tamborello's instrumentals are the only constant on an album studded with guest vocalists
column2: Life Is Full of Possibilities feels more like the product of a disciplined
column3: rotating collective than a solo album with one-off collaborators. Each song is particularly well-suited to its respective singer
column4: and each singer fully engages with Tamborello's instrumental tracks. An air of melancholy hangs over most of this album
column5: but Tamborello understands that Mia Doi Todd's flat
column6: confident vocals on ""Anywhere Anyone"" evoke a very different kind of melancholy from Beachwood Sparks singer Chris Gunst's fragile
column7: unsteady vocals on ""Umbrella"". Tamborello foregos a more manipulated vocal treatment and lets a tuneful vocal from Death Cab for Cutie frontman Ben Gibbard anchor the swirling
column8: overdriven ""(This Is) The Dream of Evan and Chan""
column9: setting the stage for the bajillion-selling full-length collaboration the two would release as the Postal Service. (Music theory geek aside: there's a certain magic to Gibbard's voice when he sings a perfect fifth up followed by a minor third down
column10: as he does in nearly all of his best songs.)

column1: Four remixes of ""Evan and Chan"" are far and away the drabbest bonus material on Sub Pop's deluxe reissue; removed from the original song's arc
column2: the individual sonic elements here just aren't that interesting. An alternate version of ""Umbrella"" shows what a more half-assed version of this album might have sounded like

column4: heavy-handed swells of distortion. ""Evan and Chan"" B-side ""Your Hill"" is the strongest non-album cut here
column5: culling its primary melody from a loud monophonic synthesizer while using vocals as abstract
column6: poetic ornamentation. Broadly speaking
column7: the bonus material here veers more toward the conventional IDM of its time
column8: falling short of the original album but also making a case for its unique strengths.

column1: The best thing about this reissue has nothing to do with its bonus material
column2: though; a solid remastering job pushes both treble and the bass beyond the relatively thin
column3: high-mid-leaning sonic footprint of many late-90s and early-00s computer-recorded albums. Digital conversion technology
column4: much like music itself
column5: has changed a lot in the last 10 years-- which seems like a fairly short time between release and reissue
column6: but also a really long time to have passed since this particular album came out. For a record fixated on personal nostalgia
column7: Life Is Full of Possibilities still feels bright-eyed and forward-thinking. That Tamborello's ambition and optimism now seem slightly distant and idealistic probably says more about us now than it does about this album. This may not be the future we chose
column8:
but it remains a beautiful future to imagine.

column9: the jittery throb of ""Mop It Up"" (the one that goes
column10: ""You say goodbye"")
column11: the sparkly shuffle of ""Overkill"" (something about ""praying"" and a ""vision""). On closing track ""Shout in Tongues""
column12: the drums drop out to expose a repeated shout that brings to mind the most famous song by the godfathers of the current decade's artsy
column13: reverb-damaged experimental poppers

column15: goes to school

and""-- I'm not sure what comes next. Adobe slats? Better listen again.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17067/homepage_large.a3013b8e.jpg|Trust Now|28935.0|Prince Rama|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paw Tracks']|2011-10-19 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:08.712848|"

When Pitchfork's Joe Colly reviewed Prince Rama's fourth album
column2: Shadow Temple
column3: he signed off by hinting that the band's psych experiments ""might become something more"" in the future. A little over a year later
column4: Trust Now has arrived
column5: again on Animal Collective's Paw Tracks imprint
column6: to test out that prognosis. A few things have changed in the intervening months-- they've slimmed down to a duo of sisters Taraka and Nimai Larson after their fellow founding member Michael Collins went on hiatus from the group
column7: and Scott Colburn (Sun City Girls
column8: Arcade Fire) replaced Avey Tare and Deakin in the producers' chair. There's been a minor toughening up of the sound
column9: with everything from the swampy keyboard work to the wailed vocal lines gaining a little more bite
column10: but otherwise Trust Now continues in the same vein as its predecessor.

column1: For a band reportedly raised on a Hare Krishna farm and with a live show that positively reeks of patchouli oil
column2: there's a surprising amount of bad vibes sunk into Prince Rama's music. They may give their songs titles like ""Golden Silence"" and ""Summer of Love""
column3: but the repetitive stretches of tribal drumming and vocal incantations makes them sound like they're trying to cook up the accompaniment to a horrific Wicker Man-style ritual. The problem is one of identity; the music doesn't swing far enough in a full-on occult direction to give a true sense of nastiness
column4: nor does it completely bask in the hippy idealism the Larson sisters are clearly so well versed in. It's a touch too polite and apologetic
column5: more <i><a href=""http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0115341/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Sabrina
column6: the Teenage Witch than Witchfinder General.

column1: ""Trust"" is the best demonstration of the dichotomy at the heart of the band. It begins with a vocal line that intones the title of the song over and over
column2: like we're being ushered into the most genial ritual sacrifice of all time
column3: while squealing synth tones wail in the background. Midway through the song
column4: it's turned into much lighter fare
column5: with a keyboard motif that could have been ripped straight from Haha Sound-era Broadcast
column6: which picks out a poppy melody that feels at odds with the first half of the track. In fact
column7: Prince Rama could learn something by listening to Broadcast and the Focus Group's collaborative album
column8: Investigate Witch Cults of the Radio Age
column9: which contains the creepy air of inventiveness that Trust Now is striving for but can't ever reach. The music here contains germs of good ideas
column10: but too often they get frittered away through loose and indulgent jams that never go anywhere.

column1: On those Broadcast/Focus Group recordings
column2: the musicians appeared to be immersed in the kind of folkloric tales that provide the unpleasant edge material like this needs. It's also got the kind of razor-sharp sense of purpose from which Trust Now could benefit. Instead Prince Rama end up mired somewhere closer to kitsch
column3: especially when their music meanders without much purpose on songs like ""Portaling"" or uses a corny ""boing"" sound (presumably made by a mouth harp
column4: or a sample of one) on ""Incarnation"". Frustratingly
column5: Trust Now doesn't advance on the better ideas from Shadow Temple
column6: particularly the elements of dance music that occasionally surfaced. Essentially it's the core Prince Rama sound boiled down to its essence
column7:
which means anyone hoping for this band to ""become something more"" should sit this one out and hope the Larsons can finely trim their vision next time.

"|15933.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15933-trust-now/|5.8|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17053/homepage_large.dc7156db.jpg|Days|27602.0|Real Estate|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2011-10-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:09.241057|"

For a mix of songs made at different times
column2: Real Estate's self-titled 2009 debut was impressively consistent. Given how well the New Jersey band fused disparate moments
column3: you had to figure they could reach even greater heights were they to craft their next set all at once. They did just that last winter
column4: and the result is indeed a step forward. Cleaner
column5: sharper
column6: and just plain stronger
column7: Days is like a single idea divided into simple statements-- a suite of subtle variations on a theme.

column1: Its coherence sounds remarkably effortless
column2: as if stringing together catchy gems is as easy as
column3: in the words of one song
column4: ""floating on an inner tube in the sun."" Interestingly
column5: Real Estate actually acknowledge this sense of ease. The opener is bluntly titled ""Easy""
column6: and references to carefree simplicity abound. As singer/guitarist Martin Courtney puts it
column7: ""If it takes all summer long/ Just to write one simple song/ There's too much to focus on/ Clearly there is something wrong."" But the band's celebration of the uncomplicated is less about how Days was written than about the beauty of life seen in retrospect
column8: especially young life in small towns.

column1: Like the stirring scenes of suburban Texas in Terrence Malick's The Tree of Life
column2: these songs find meaning in daily mundanities-- in houses and gardens
column3: phone lines and street lights
column4: names carved in trees and leaves pressed by footsteps. ""All those wasted miles/ All those aimless drives through green aisles
column5: sings Courtney wistfully. ""Our careless lifestyle
column6: it was not so unwise."" That sentiment was evident on the band's debut
column7: but here they've honed it to its essence.

column1: The music bears a simplicity to match. These aren't minimal songs by any means
column2: but the layers of cycling guitar
column3: rolling rhythm
column4: and gentle echo are always understated
column5: more about conveying feeling than showing off the band's considerable chops. There's also a smooth efficiency in these rich tunes. No note feels wasted
column6: and nothing happens at the wrong time or in the wrong place. Much of this precision comes from guitarist Matt Mondanile
column7: whose nimble playing adds color to each song's shape. It's most noticeable in the insistent ""It's Real""
column8: but I'm even more taken with his sonic smoke rings in ""Out of Tune""
column9: and how his shimmering guitar evokes sunrays mingling through branches and sparkling off pools.

column1: That idyllic tone permeates Days
column2: and in lesser hands could deprive it of tension or variety. But Real Estate have such a knack for classic-sounding melody that every song quickly engages on a musical gut level. It's a quality their music shares with the jangly hooks of early R.E.M.
column3: the breeziness of later Pavement
column4: and the garage twang of the Fresh & Onlys. But their closest kin are New Jersey forefathers the Feelies. That group's undying ability to mine repeated chords and Zen phrases is matched best by the album's closer
column5: ""All the Same""
column6: a looping study of how night and day are merely sides of the same coin. Lasting over seven minutes
column7: it might be Real Estate's first epic. But it's as subtle and unassuming as anything on Days-- more evidence from this band that great music doesn't have to sound hard to make
column8:
even if it is.

"|15918.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15918-days/|8.7|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17080/homepage_large.edc93ab8.jpg|Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds|29794.0|Noel Gallagher's High Flying Birds|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sour Mash']|2011-10-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:09.758616|"

Oasis perpetually faced accusations of over-borrowing from rock history
column2: unapologetically nicking words and melodies from the biggest groups of all time. But the band were also skilled samplers of rock'n'roll storylines
column3: arriving in the early 1990s pre-equipped with that classic intra-band conflict
column4: the singer vs. the songwriter. The tension between Noel and Liam Gallagher arrived with Oasis in the early 90s as a fully-formed rock drama worthy of Keith-Mick
column5: Robert-Jimmy
column6: and Rog-Pete
column7: given added juice by shared genetics. With Chekhov's gun inevitability
column8: their squabbles blew Oasis apart in 2009
column9: with the final indignity of forcing Noel
column10: the band's master architect
column11: to quit his own masterpiece project via blog post.

column1: So here begins the familiar second act of the rock'n'roll story arc
column2: the competitive-solo-record period. While Liam and the rest of Oasis got in the first punch (reforming and flicking Vs at their former bandleader as Beady Eye)
column3: Noel has launched his High Flying Birds ""collective"" with a premise that's also rock canon: who needs a frontman
column4: anyway? Oasis history already gives Noel some credibility on that front-- by their second album
column5: the guitarist was already taking lead vox duties on a hit single (""Don't Look Back in Anger"")
column6: and the notorious MTV Unplugged episode proved he could do just fine without his brother on the band's other material
column7: thank you very much.

column1: But for a declaration of independence
column2: the self-titled High Flying Birds LP sounds awfully nostalgic for the good old days. Through most of the mercifully brief 10 tracks
column3: Gallagher passes on the opportunity to use this new career chapter for either an Albarn-like experimental exploration or something stripped-down and personal. Of course
column4: nothing in his career to date would suggest ""stripped-down"" is in Noel's vocabulary. His new band goes straight back to the widescreen aesthetic
column5: with choirs
column6: string sections
column7: horn sections
column8: and choruses aiming for the universal. Noel is still writing for the stadium-- it's the only audience he knows.

column1: Keeping that in mind
column2: a listener can forgive a lot of corniness
column3: even as Noel tests the limits. At this point
column4: it's almost endearing that he earnestly sees no problem starting a song with the lyric
column5: ""Hot time/ Summer in the city
column6: and thinks the clunky ""(I Wanna Live in a Dream in My) Record Machine"" is an acceptable song title and hook. But the latter track also shows Gallagher can still tickle anyone who once took the kind of soaring-orchestra-and-guitar-solo bridge (think Slash emerging from a pool of water in the rain) seriously. If the emotional power of anthemic rock is quickly draining
column7: Gallagher remains among the best conductors of the fumes.

column1: Still
column2: there are some intriguing ideas buried under the maudlin arrangements and verse-chorus-verses. Often
column3: the most interesting parts of the songs float frustratingly on the periphery of the mix
column4: as with the lap steel of ""If I Had a Gun…"" or the musical saw that eerily haunts both ""The Death of You and Me"" and ""AKA… Broken Arrow"". One place where that formula reverses promisingly is ""AKA… What a Life!""
column5: which is built upon a stormy piano loop
column6: filtered drums
column7: and Noel's melancholic take on 20 years of stardom.

column1: The song is a reminder that Gallagher might have found a more exciting solo path by revisiting ""Setting Sun""
column2: the Oasis-related moment that sounds most vital in 2011 (and perhaps the inspiration for his upcoming collab with Future Sound of London side project the Amorphous Androgynous). But instead he chooses to make another MTV Unplugged statement that's equal parts self-sufficient and self-conscious
column3: all but writing in Liam and the rest of Beady Eye drunkenly heckling from the balcony. Founding High Flying Birds on pretty much the same musical territory as his old band
column4: where Liam's snide yowl will always win out over Noel's passable but pedestrian voice
column5: is the album's critical flaw. Forever a slave to rock history
column6:
Gallagher feels like he's biding his time for the third act reunion rather than breaking from the well-trod path.

"|15944.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15944-noel-gallaghers-high-flying-birds-st/|5.7|Rob Mitchum

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17071/homepage_large.72ec58f5.jpg|Glass Swords|22484.0|Rustie|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2011-10-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:10.385335|"

Twenty years ago
column2: Warp released Frequencies
column3: the debut album by LFO
column4: a duo who'd come up in the North England rave scene and scored an unexpected UK chart hit with their bold and brutal eponymous bleep techno single. This year
column5: Warp releases Glass Swords
column6: the debut album by Rustie
column7: a young Glasgow producer who's come up in the protean post-dubstep scene and has yet to rough up the mainstream. (Give him time
column8: though
column9: especially if he catches the ear of a diva.) Most of the vinyl-only singles by LFO's revolutionary contemporaries are now sadly forgotten. In another 20 years
column10: there's a good chance that most of the singles by Rustie's boundary-pushing peers will likewise be gathering metaphorical dust in the deep recesses of some iPod. But LFO's music has survived
column11: and I have a feeling Rustie's will too. Because Rustie knows
column12: like LFO knew
column13: that the surest route to dance music immortality is to reach both the dabblers and the hardcore
column14: marrying underground innovation with as many of electronic music's biggest ideas and best hooks as you can cram in.

column1: Frequencies kicked off with LFO literally asking
column2: ""What is house?"" The duo's answer was the album itself. For LFO
column3: house was everything that had already come along
column4: from wistful Kraftwerk to future-shock electro to beatific Detroit techno. They then edited it all into short and vibrant jolts
column5: without watering things down a bit. Glass Swords takes the same tack
column6: to brilliant and sometimes bewildering effect. The heavy wobble of dubstep is the frame that holds everything together
column7: but thankfully Rustie's no purist. The title track is a dreamy and disorienting merger of metal guitar and IDM ambiance
column8: bombastic and beatless
column9: that owes as much to a portentous Metallica intro as old-school shoegaze swirl as Daft Punk's kitschy take on progressive rock. And like the new wave of take-rave-back-to-the-kids producers
column10: Rustie is also fearless about rehabilitating and reinventing the genre's cheesiest and most pleasurable moments
column11: the stuff dubstep's more glower-prone producers wouldn't even claim as being part of the genre's DNA. On the so-giddy-it-feels-unstable ""Crystal Echo""
column12: you might mistake Rustie for a happy hardcore producer brought out of retirement to remix Rihanna
column13: all squeaky
column14: sped-up voices and hammering drums
column15: twinkling melodies running smack into dubstep's bass whomp. Glass Swords might just as well have opened with Rustie asking
column16: ""What is dubstep?"" His answer is the same as LFO's was for house: Everything
column17: but as shiny and delirious and speaker-rattling as you can make it.

column1: But Rustie is operating in a world where radio producers have already plundered dubstep for fresh sounds
column2: and as if knowing he's now competing as much with Billboard hit-makers
column3: his tracks have the maximalist zeal of Max Martin bubblegum. Even his most traditionally ""dubstep"" tunes won't sit still or do what they're supposed to
column4: maniacally morphing plastic basslines and synth riffs with the sharpness of the album's titular crystal weaponry. ""Surph"" has the genre's requisite big bass drops
column5: but Rustie also throws in pop-rave pianos
column6: trance keyboards
column7: and snippets of sugary R&B
column8: because he can
column9: because he's showing off
column10: because it's fun
column11: because he's never interested in just turning out another scene-pleasing exercise. He shares the make-it-immediate urge of Deadmau5 and his ilk but has no time for their simplicity or brutality. One of the best things about Glass Swords is that
column12: for all of its pop-goes-clubbing bluster
column13: it's also as psychedelic
column14: where the devil's in the zillion little details zigzagging across the tracks-- as you'd expect from a Warp album-- whether we're talking their classic-era IDM records or more recent signings like Flying Lotus. ""Cry Flames"" has more of metal's brute force in its gnarled groove
column15: but the real shiver-inducing moment comes when Rustie begins weaving a fragile
column16: almost Satie-like piano melody into the bass snarl.

column1: All that said
column2: there's not a lot here that will redefine your ideas of what dubstep or electronic music in general can do. For all of Rustie's skill as a sculptor of very 21st-century beats
column3: Glass Swords can feel just as much like a ""greatest bits"" collage. A lot of déjà vu elements are worked onto the framework of a current club trend
column4: little hints of everything from Art of Noise to U-Ziq to the S.O.S. Band to old RPG soundtracks colliding with dubstep's bass pressure. But compared to the sterile sound of most retro-collage electronic albums
column5: it's also an undeniable and up-to-the-minute rush. And in a couple of decades
column6: when you're looking for an instant hit of what  electronic pop felt like in 2011
column7:
you'll be able to throw on Glass Swords and get a dose of that feeling in its purest form.

"|15937.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15937-glass-swords/|8.0|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17075/homepage_large.75a8b946.jpg|Severant|29925.0|Kuedo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-10-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:10.887895|"

Back when he was making music with Vex'd
column2: Jamie Teasdale was responsible for some of the more harder-edged
column3: aggressive dubstep out there. With partner Roly Porter
column4: the duo highlighted the genre's grimiest qualities
column5: making industrial tracks like ""Thunder"" that sounded not unlike high-speed car crashes. But that wasn't his true calling. ""I was more the technical guy in Vex'd
column6: Teasdale
column7: now going by Kuedo
column8: recently told the Quietus. ""A lot of the musical language came from Roly's side."" And so it turns out that Teasdale's own musical language is actually quite dreamy and even romantic. His debut LP
column9: Severant
column10: brings together expressive synth work and cinematic sweep with a degree of nuance and
column11: well
column12: prettiness that's frankly kind of surprising.

column1: Teasdale cleverly combines a few different genres here. First
column2: through the use of vintage synth equipment
column3: he conjures sci-fi soundscapes similar to the type deployed by Oneohtrix Point Never and Laurel Halo. With Vangelis' 1982 Blade Runner score an obvious touchstone
column4: he layers nostalgia-hued synths in swirling
column5: evocative patterns. But where guys like OPN like to leave these sounds untethered
column6: Teasdale grounds them in the wobble and kick of dance music. Hearing these generally spacey tones backed by drums is cool on its own
column7: but it's the kind of beats he chooses that really sets this record apart. Ignoring the cavernous drops of dubstep
column8: Teasdale pulls instead from the faster
column9: tinnier percussion of Chicago footwork and Lex Luger-style hip-hop production.

column1: This unlikely pairing creates variations in speed
column2: color
column3: and texture that make Severant a dynamic listen. There's constant tension between an otherworldly
column4: futuristic feeling and this more stuttering energy that keeps the tracks earthbound. Take ""Scissors"" for an example: Teasdale floats an airy
column5: alien organ over quick-hitting bass and machine gun hi-hats
column6: and the result is visceral
column7: like standing under a helicopter taking off; at the same time
column8: there's an eerily peaceful sensation to it. He also shows a good amount of range
column9: going moody on ""Seeing the Edges""
column10: darkly menacing on ""Flight Path""
column11: and even R&B-sexy with closer ""Memory Rain"". In each case the tracks avoid one-note flatness by spreading the sounds in several different directions at once.

column1: At 15 songs
column2: Severant is long and occasionally becomes drifty
column3: but at its best
column4: the album is a confident
column5: even inspired
column6: solo debut. There are stretches where it feels like you're hearing sounds being put together for the first time
column7: which is something that can't be said of many artists in an increasingly crowded and diluted electronic-music field. And it's not just that Teasdale cracks open a new micro-strain of music here-- call it the midpoint between experimental techno and the hip-hop street banger-- it's that he does it with a lot of warmth and nuance. Tonally these tracks are a world away from the aggro crunch of Vex'd. For other artists
column8: there's plenty of value in that style
column9:
but Severant feels like the kind of music that this guy is intended to make.

"|15945.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15945-severant/|7.7|Joe Colly

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17069/homepage_large.a021e001.jpg|Whatever/Whenever|5477.0|Mark Sultan|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2011-10-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:11.355347|"

Mark Sultan's plan was to release three albums this month: Whatever I Want
column3: Whenever I Want
column4: and a compilation of songs from each album
column5: Whatever/Whenever. Apparently
column6: the first two have been delayed
column7: leaving us with this-- a handful of songs from each LP. But if the compilation is an indicator of the rest of the material
column8: Sultan did an excellent job naming those records. These songs are exactly that-- whatever kind of track he wants to do
column9: inspired by whichever era he chooses. Sultan-- who has pilfered from doo-wop
column10: early-1960s rock and R&B
column11: punk
column12: garage
column13: and plenty of other styles--  isn't a guy with a limited palate
column14: so maybe he didn't want to be limited to one time period or sound or idea.

column1: In this sense
column2: and others
column3: Whatever/Whenever is a grab bag. The final track
column4: for example
column5: is an experimental free jazz song that's over eight minutes long. Surprisingly
column6: it's the best thing on the album. Two tracks earlier
column7: by contrast
column8: is the gratingly repetitive ""Party Crasher"". The positive part of putting out such an uninhibited range of work? By moving into territory not covered by him or one of his various bands (the King Khan & BBQ Show
column9: the Spaceshits
column10: the Ding-Dongs)
column11: he's managed to make something ethereal and oddly beautiful. The negative? Whatever/Whenever is all over the place.

column1: There are quality moments
column2: though
column3: and songs that would fit well with the source material he's evoking. ""Song in Grey"" could stand next to an early-60s girl-group or rock song with its sunny delivery of a heartbreaking message and earworm vocal hook. But even when a song stands out
column4: the next track cheapens it. ""Just Like Before"" follows ""Song in Grey""-- it's a breezy ukulele-wielding ballad that would've fit tidily in the Mills Brothers' catalog. And after that
column5: ""Calloused Hands""
column6: a fuzzy pop rocker
column7: jumps in. Just about every song presents a new disparity
column8: and with each subsequent track
column9: it's a new genre or time or attitude that jumps in. It's a crowded album layout that doesn't give the songs much room to breathe.

column1: One saving grace is Sultan's croon
column2: which is especially bold this time around. ""If I Had a Polaroid"" finds him belting out those dragging vowels he's done for a while (""daaaaaarling""). It's a great vocal performance-- he tempers the volume to sound vulnerable
column3: and later he growls out lines for an extra emotional punch. Unfortunately
column4: the song itself sounds like a balladized cousin of King Khan & BBQ's ""I'll Be Loving You"" and doesn't bring anything new to the table. The songs where he does kick up the tempo are a welcome addition: ""Satisfied & Lazy"" lights a rockabilly-paced fire with its heavy-handed drums and biting vocals
column5: and ""Let Me Freeze"" is a lo-fi
column6: minute-long song where he shouts and points back to the Circle Jerks. Songs like these deserve to shine
column7: but Whatever/Whenever is too claustrophobic for that sort of possibility. Because Sultan casts such a wide net
column8: it would probably be better if each song had its own 7""-- all together
column9:
it sounds like a poorly organized collection of demos and ideas.

"|15935.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15935-mark-sultan-whatever-whenever/|5.8|Evan Minsker

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17014/homepage_large.be990fa7.jpg|Hurry Up
column2: We're Dreaming|2625.0|M83|['Rock'
column4: Anthony Gonzalez announced his next album was almost complete and would be ""very
column5: very
column6: very epic."" With all due respect
column7: consider the redundancy of that statement: Since 2003 breakthrough <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/5006-dead-cities-red-seas-lost-ghosts/"" target=""_blank"">Dead Cities
column8: Red Seas & Lost Ghosts
column9: every new and increasingly colossal M83 studio record has led to widespread crowdsourcing of synonyms for ""epic."" What exactly was he promising other than simply another album?

column1: Well
column2: throughout the past decade
column3: the 30-year old Gonzalez has honored the tremendous impact of growing up during the golden age of CD buying by implicitly serving as a patron saint for those who treat the weekly trip to the record store as a pilgrimage and still covet the album as a physical proposition: His output always comes stylishly packaged
column4: with cover art worth obsessing over and credits that need to be scoured in order to spot the guest appearances. Unsurprisingly
column5: he ups the ante here by aspiring to what is still the paradigm of artistic permanence
column6: both in terms of legacy and tactility: the double album
column7: that occasionally ambitious
column8: usually decadent
column9: and almost always fascinatingly flawed endeavor of musicians convinced (rightfully or otherwise) that they're at the peak of their own powers. <i>Hurry Up
column10: We're Dreaming might be all of those things
column11: but above all else
column12: it's the best M83 record yet.

column1: But let's talk about restraint for a moment: While each side of Hurry Up would be oddly slight for an M83 album
column2: the demands of its 74-minute runtime are hardly daunting. It's actually the easiest M83 album to consume in one sitting
column3: a reverse accumulation of past strengths that makes for Gonzalez's most compact and combustive music yet. He continues the path set by Saturdays=Youth by easing out of the mini-movie business in exchange for pop songcraft
column4: while trading that LP's pretty-in-pink pastels for the urban neons and fluorescents of Before the Dawn Heals Us and embodying Dead Cities' mile-wide expansiveness.

column1: But the most crucial change is how touring with the likes of Depeche Mode has inspired a newfound showmanship in his vocals: Previously
column2: Gonzalez enlisted outside help
column3: piped in plot-advancing narratives
column4: or sang in a low
column5: tentative murmur that submitted to its massive surroundings. But here
column6: within the first minutes of ""Intro""
column7: he's matching blows with the juggernaut bellow of Zola Jesus' Nika Danilova to the point where it's much tougher than you'd think to tell them apart. It's really not too different from the first chords of ""Planet Telex"" or Lil Wayne's ""Tha Mobb"" in terms of being an unmistakable sign that you're going to be listening to this familiar act differently.

column1: M83 have never stood for half measures in any aspect
column2: but Gonzalez is absolutely going for it here in a way that sheds new light on known tricks: The hair-triggered drum rolls of ""New Map"" recall Before the Dawn's searing car-crash fantasy ""Don't Save Us From the Flames""
column3: but Gonzalez's nervy punctuation at the end of each line sells the idea that he's along for the ride this time rather than being a passive observer. Dead Cities' ""In Church"" was the sound of blissful acquiescence
column4: but amidst the swaggering synth-metal of ""Midnight City""
column5: Gonzalez hollers
column6: ""The city is my church!"" empowered and present
column7: finding a voice for the evangelical zeal always implicit in his work.

column1: Gonzalez has stressed Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness as a major inspiration (and by extension
column2: its forefather
column3: The Wall)
column4: and its influence can be spotted in Hurry Up's power ballads ""Wait"" and ""My Tears Are Becoming a Sea""
column5: sumptuously arranged tracks that could still be played solo on an acoustic guitar. Thankfully
column6: he didn't retain much from ""Bullet With Butterfly Wings"" or ""The Trial""
column7: and rather than one man lashing out at the world from the safety of his own thematic construct
column8: you feel that Gonzalez is trying to connect with it.

column1: As such
column2: the moments of indulgence are in service of the album's most endearing and silly emotions: Some might consider ""Raconte-Moi Une Histoire"" a throwaway because it's ""the one about a magic frog
column3: but besides embodying the whiplash emotions of youth by following the magnificent melancholy of ""Wait""
column4: its almost eerie brightness and Windows 95-era sound effects capture a technological optimism better than a lot of artists who are trying only to do that. Meanwhile
column5: ""Year One
column6: One UFO"" attempts to distill the percussion-mad
column7: organic ecstasy of Vision Creation Newsun into three minutes
column8: while on the opposite side
column9: ""Claudia Lewis"" and ""OK Pal"" show a mastery of slapbass-poppin'
column10: corporate funk-rock comparable to Ford & Lopatin or Cut Copy without the twinge of pastiche.

column1: As with any double album
column2: there's a temptation to strip away the instrumental tracks or simply pick the best 50 minutes for your daily commute. But the interludes here are intended to be every bit as purposeful as the singles: The shorter the track
column3: the more evocative its title (""Where the Boats Go""
column4: ""Train to Pluton""
column5: ""Another Wave From You""). While many of them stand as intriguing meditations on their own merits
column6: they reinforce Hurry Up's intentions to be an immersive universe-- check in whenever you want
column7: but the magic's in the exploratory phases. And why leave out what falls in between
column8: like the thermite burst of the two-minute ""This Bright Flash"" or the stately ""When Will You Come Home?""-to-""My Tears Are Becoming a Sea"" triptych that serves as the connective transit between Side 1 and Side 2.

column1: Then again
column2: I can't blame anyone who takes shortcuts
column3: since the traditionally structured songs here are some of the most thrilling pop music released this year. The heavily saturated synths Gonzalez favored early in his career invited plenty of My Bloody Valentine comparisons
column4: but whereas pure shoegaze of that nature attempts to overwhelm and obliterate
column5: Hurry Up is like a sonic planetarium
column6: penetrable and totally geared toward enhancing the user experience. Few artists make more ingenious use of the sheer physics of rock to this extent-- defining which synth pads strike which emotional pressure points
column7: using percussion as explosives rather than mere elements of timekeeping
column8: coiling the tension of a verse to make every chorus feel phenomenally cathartic even without any words.

column1: At this point in the year
column2: you'd think a saxophone solo would have lost all the novelty it had accumulated over decades of disuse
column3: yet when one pops up at the end of ""Midnight City""
column4: it triumphantly squires the track out at the highest point possible. After a streak of staccato guitar chords and splashy cymbal hits rev up ""Reunion""
column5: the shouts from its chorus could come from a soccer stadium or a speedboat chase. ""Intro"" is typical of Gonzalez's love for zero-gravity arrangements of massed choirs and cathedral reverb
column6: but there's nothing buzzy or clouded about it-- as high as he takes things
column7: you can still see everything underneath in crisp
column8: butterflies-inducing depth and detail.

column1: And then there's ""Steve McQueen""
column2: which somehow makes the preceding hour of music feel like its prelude. Point blank
column3: it's as close as most of us will get to being strapped inside a space shuttle
column4: as midway through an almost unbearably tensile verse
column5: you don't hear drums so much as afterburners kicking in. By the chorus
column6: it simply cannot go further up
column7: and it explodes at the perfect moment into hair-metal guitar chords and synth-led skywriting. And yet
column8: because it's almost impossible to say what ""Steve McQueen"" is about (certainly not the actor)
column9: it's capable of glorifying anything you choose-- a slow motion shot of Kirk Gibson rounding the bases in the 1988 World Series
column10: a holiday fireworks display
column11: or getting into your car and simply celebrating the end of an exhausting day.

column1: Is it a lot to handle? Of course
column2: and those who have yet to connect with M83 may wonder if the sort of incapacitating longing expressed by ""Wait"" can possibly be experienced by anyone over the age of 16 or whether they'll ever be able to afford the stereo equipment seemingly required for its intended effect. But remember
column3: it's called <i>Hurry Up
column4: We're Dreaming: It doesn't attempt to be a comprehensive or even realistic purview of the human experience
column5: and lord knows there's plenty out there that's meant to capture small moments.

column1: It's easy to mistrust something so irrepressibly optimistic about the affective possibilities of music and to attribute these feelings to the domain of some ""other
column2: whether it's the 1980s
column3: teenhood
column4: or a pop product. Does it share some sort of commonality with ""Born This Way"" or ""Firework""
column5: or any other entry from 2011's chart music that attempts to convince you of your own superstardom? Surely
column6: but Gonzalez never comes off like he's selling a brand
column7: a lifestyle
column8: or even himself-- his lyrics remain as opaque as ever. Hurry Up instead serves as a framework to realize the marvelous capability of our dreams and daily lives
column9:
should we be open to experiencing it.

"|15881.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15881-hurry-up-were-dreaming/|9.1|Ian Cohen

The year 1991 was a significant one in Jane's Addiction lore
column2: marking both the launch of the L.A. art-rockers' Lollapalooza travelling-circus experiment and the announcement of the band's dissolution. Now
column3: on the 20th anniversary of those events
column4: both brands are still making headlines
column5: despite enduring extended periods of inactivity
column6: aborted restarts
column7: and organizational restructuring. And it's perhaps no coincidence that both Jane's Addiction and Lollapalooza have evolved in exactly the same way: What were once unpredictable
column8: chaotic forces have inevitably mutated into well-oiled
column9: monolithic entities bearing little of the charm and character of their original incarnations. This circumstance is not lost on frontman/Lolla visionary Perry Farrell who
column10: on Jane's Addiction's new album
column11: proudly declares
column12: ""We've become a big business/ A galaxy merger!""

column1: Even if that line is intended to be a metaphor for a blossoming romantic relationship
column2: the fact that Farrell's singing of love in the language of commerce effectively sums up the proficient but perfunctory nature of The Great Escape Artist
column3: Jane's Addiction's fifth official album
column4: their second comeback record (following 2003's Strays)
column5: and the first release since the short-lived reintroduction of founding bassist Eric Avery into the fold for a 2009 tour. No doubt
column6: their various attempts to keep Jane's alive over the past decade have taught Farrell
column7: guitarist Dave Navarro
column8: and drummer Stephen Perkins that replacing Avery requires more than just finding a talented bass player. In many respects
column9: Avery defined the band's sonic identity and mystique; think of any Jane's classic
column10: and often the first thing that pops into your head is one of those ominous
column11: propulsive basslines. So while the middling Strays tried to plug session vet Chris Chaney into the dynamic
column12: for The Great Escape Artist
column13: the band makes a more concerted effort at revitalization
column14: recruiting everyone from TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek to Guns N' Roses bassist Duff McKagan to Morocco's Master Musicians of Joujouka-- a trifecta of collaborators who respectively play to Jane's Addiction's affinities for heady atmosphere
column15: raunchy hard rock
column16: and tribal-percussion jams.

column1: At the outset
column2: The Great Escape Artist lives up to that on-paper potential: Farrell's freak-scene re-indoctrination ""Underground"" and Avery-directed invective ""End to the Lies"" (featuring the Joujouka crew) open the album with a pair of promisingly authoritative metallic grinds that sound like they were grafted from the slow-motion mid-section of Ritual de lo Habitual's ""Stop""
column3: but with Sitek's chrome-plated textures adding a post-apocalyptic ambience that greatly complements Navarro's eerie six-string squeals. But there's a palpable dip in intensity from there on in
column4: as The Great Escape Artist gets mired in the not-quite-rock/not-quite-ballad purgatory that defines so much post-grunge alt-radio.

column1: As slickly produced as Nothing's Shocking and Ritual de lo Habitual were
column2: you always got the sense that Jane's Addiction were a band of four interconnected personalities contributing distinct
column3: individual parts to the majestic whole. But even compared to the nu-metalloid sheen of Strays
column4: The Great Escape Artist's intricate
column5: heavily lacquered production-- courtesy of Muse-man Rich Costey-- has the effect of making Jane's Addiction sound like an anonymous assemblage of oversaturated recording tracks. More so than Avery's commanding presence
column6: what's really missing here is Jane's Addiction's sense of playfulness
column7: absurdity
column8: and rhythmic verve. Beyond hard-charging closer ""Words Right Out of My Mouth""
column9: powerhouse drummer Perkins is given scant opportunity to flex his percussive muscle and is instead relegated to playing the mild-mannered time-keeper on melodramatic turns like ""Twisted Tales"" and ""Splash a Little Water on It""
column10: while Sitek's bass contributions are barely perceptible underneath the glossy sheen. And for a frontman who's always been happy to flaunt his own ridiculousness
column11: Farrell is surprisingly humorless here
column12: the quirky character studies and brash swagger of old replaced by straight-faced pleading and vague second-person admonishments. Sure
column13: the line
column14: ""You were the foreskin/ I was the real head
column15: reads as hilarious but
column16: coming from a Jew
column17: probably isn't meant as a term of endearment.

column1: There is
column2: however
column3: one song here-- ""Broken People""-- that cuts through The Great Escape Artist's sleek surface and provides a glimpse of the charismatic
column4: affective band that Jane's once were and still could be. (Surprisingly
column5: it's one of McKagan's three co-writes.) And
column6: as per the standard set by ""I Would For You""
column7: ""Jane Says""
column8: and ""Then She Did...""
column9: ""Broken People"" is a melancholic reverie dedicated to a tragic female protagonist
column10: though instead calling upon his usual cast of junkies and eccentrics
column11: Farrell updates the archetype to paint a sympathetic portrait of a sex-vid-shilling celebutante. Despite the sensationalistic subject matter
column12: Jane's treat it with an understated elegance
column13: thanks to Navarro's beautifully restrained guitar line
column14: a sensitive but not mawkish vocal from Farrell
column15: and-- rare for this album-- a concise
column16: unfussy arrangement; even the amped-up
column17: fist-pump treatment applied to the third verse can't sully the song's graceful sway. In a world where truly nothing is shocking
column18: Jane's Addiction have understandably lost the will and desire to be as outrageous and confrontational as they once were. But as ""Broken People"" attests
column19: the most effective way for a big business to surprise you is through a simple

'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2011-10-17 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:12.840270|"

""Horse Thieves"" is the final and best track on An Ache for the Distance
column3: the second album by Chicago's distorted doom squadron the Atlas Moth. It opens with a pit-of-hell black-metal sigh: Vocalist/guitarist Stavros Giannopoulos sounds as malevolent as Malefic once did on Sunn O)))'s Black One
column4: when the Xasthur leader infamously recorded his vocal parts from inside a coffin that was itself inside a Cadillac hearse. Appropriately
column5: Giannopoulos sings of the end with apocalyptic imagery
column6: a would-be horseman requesting that a ""divine mare"" help him spread an unspoken plague. ""Our light has been eclipsed
column7: the tides washing ashore
column8: he screams
column9: his voice so serrated
column10: his tone so saturated
column11: that the words are barely decipherable. The sound is threatening enough
column12: with words or not. Indeed
column13: even during what turns out to be a fairly indelible chorus
column14: ""Horse Thieves""'s voices vacillate between dark
column15: darker
column16: and darkest. It's like a seven-minute history of the progression of black-metal vocals from the basements of Oslo 20 years ago to
column17: these days
column18: high-end recording studios.

column1: But the Atlas Moth aren't a black metal band-- at all. Rather
column2: they're one of a growing legion of bands to use bits of that form-- and
column3: really
column4: everything from stoner metal to psychedelic rock
column5: free jazz to electric blues-- to make militantly adventurous heavy metal. In fact
column6: when Giannopoulos is howling his imprecations during ""Horse Theives""
column7: he's backed by a slow
column8: stubborn
column9: swaggering blues riff and a rhythm section that has more to do with Mono's escalating brood than Mayhem's shrieking ferocity. Jamie Branch streaks the song's bridge with trumpet hiss
column10: while Andrew Ragin puts down his guitar to add eerie piano jet wash. It all sounds like some awesome
column11: evil vaudeville after-party that
column12: after an impasse
column13: somehow erupts into a sludgy sing-along about a serpent's tongue and staying alive.

column1: Such patent unpredictability and versatility fuel the entirety of An Ache for the Distance
column2: a dense
column3: 45-minute listen that never seems to stop revealing new aspects and assets. The Atlas Moth are an excellent three-guitar quintet as capable of heroic
column4: spiraling leads (see the start of ""Coffin Varnish"") as they are thick
column5: interlocking lines that serve more as a working matrix for the lyrics
column6: as with ""Your Calm Waters"". Giannopoulos takes the lead on that track
column7: crying out for a commitment of assistance should he not make it out alive. ""Before you climb off
column8: check the pulse/ Bring me back to life
column9: he yells. His call is actually answered by David Kush
column10: the Atlas Moth's sort of hook singer (the liner notes credit him with ""clean vocals""). Throughout Distance
column11: he and Giannopoulos trade lines and parts
column12: occasionally creating conversations between hope and despair.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Distance is anchored on old-fashioned worry for the future; as with those blues guitars and rock'n'roll drums
column3: Kush's hooks
column4: which strangely split the difference between Hawkwind and Hot Topics
column5: create tension for Giannopoulos' protestations. They make his bleak seem that much bleaker. What's more
column6: Kush's singing prevents the album's one collaboration from seeming out of place. Mark Solotroff is best known for his work in power electronics as Bloodyminded
column7: but on ""Courage""
column8: he sings like Mark Kozelek fronting Jesu. The unlikely ballad offers a perfect respite for Distance's general roar and
column9: once again
column10: reveals another capability of the band without squandering too much of the album's propulsion.

column1: The divide between advocates for purity and post-everything blends feels particularly polarized right now-- not just in metal or even music
column2: but in entertainment at large and politics. The Atlas Moth certainly falls into the latter category
column3: churning ideas sometimes considered mutually exclusive inside one relentless package. Importantly
column4: though
column5: it feels neither like a pastiche nor like a pretense. On only their second album
column6: the Atlas Moth have successfully captured a signature
column7: singular mix of ideas and impulses
column8:
quickly covering a distance that others waste careers trying to match.

Much of the indie rock coming out of the Pacific Northwest in the mid 1990s had a particular
column2: cross-eyed stare: one eye looking to the cosmos
column3: the other to the dirt. Something about the music felt both gigantic and life-sized
column4: characterized by a seamless mingling of the mythic and the quotidian. This was how Isaac Brock could stare at the queue at a dying shopping mall's Orange Julius and see a metaphor for an existential purgatory
column5: or how Doug Martsch
column6: in his friendly
column7: slacker lilt
column8: could have late night bro-to-bro conversations with the Big Dipper. The New York band Forest Fire don't sound much like early Modest Mouse or Built to Spill
column9: but one of the exciting things about their debut
column10: the sleeper hit Survival
column11: was that it recalled the spirit of indie rock's feet-on-the-ground
column12: eyes-to-the-sky stance. There was a lackadaisical quality to its casually strummed guitars and to Mark Thresher's easygoing drawl
column13: but embedded within what a cursory listen might mistakenly dismiss as sonic shrugs was something that felt decidedly and almost deceptively epic. It was one of those records that would always trick you into forgetting it was only 29 minutes long.

column1: It was also easy to forget that Forest Fire were from Brooklyn. Not just because of the sweeping sprawl of their sound
column2: but because they seemed to exist
column3: in 2008 anyway
column4: somewhere just outside of the churn of the hype machine. Released as a free download through the tiny but formidable blog-based imprint Catbird Records
column5: Survival built an audience mainly through blogs and ended up appearing on (and even
column6: in a few instances
column7: topping) some notable year-end lists. A vote for Survival was a vote against buzz
column8: as it seemed to gesture toward a whole
column9: wide internet dense with undiscovered gems. Three years later
column10: the digital landscape into which Forest Fire release their second LP feels more cluttered and complicated for sure
column11: but they've still got a rogue streak to their image. One of their press bios claims that Forest Fire ""reject the 'what's next' attitude plaguing so many of the NYC/Brooklyn scene
column12: which-- as far as Amazon.com editorial lines go-- sound like fighting words. Fortunately
column13: Staring at the X doesn't need them; it's good enough-- and weird enough-- to assert these kinds of claims on its own.

column1: Signs of the band's development are scattered all over the record's first two minutes. Gone are Survival's campfire strums
column2: and in their place some fuzzed-out
column3: Martsch-sized riffage that unfurls across ""Born Into""'s expansive sprawl. And in true Forest Fire fashion
column4: there's plenty more sprawl where that came from. Clocking in at six-and-a-half minutes
column5: the record's most extreme departure is also one of its standout moments: the sinister
column6: hypnotic
column7: bass-driven space-groove ""They Pray Execution Style"" (featuring perfectly deadpan lead vocals by multi-instrumentalist Natalie Stormann). Forest Fire swing between long stretches of darkness and sudden sunbursts (""The News"")
column8: and occasionally these two impulses compete within a single song. The ostensibly sprightly ""Future Shadows"" is a meditation on love and death
column9: concluding with Thresher's steady-voiced admission
column10: ""I am afraid/ And I'm on my way.""

column1: Staring at the X ambles and meanders-- occasionally too much for its own good. Its second half in particular stays at a pretty uniform and sluggish tempo
column2: which will make you long for such pop interruptions as the infectious single ""The News"" provided on Side A. As on Survival
column3: Forest Fire are at their best when they're teasing out the formal contrasts in their sound
column4: pivoting expertly between spacey slowburners and compact pop gems. But even more so than their promising debut
column5:
Staring at the X proves them to be a commendably ambitious band with the chops to carry out even their most far-flung ideas.

"|15925.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15925-forest-fire-staring-at-the-x/|7.1|Lindsay Zoladz
