0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17043/homepage_large.706b191c.jpg|Twirligig|29738.0|Jonti|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2011-10-17 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:13.911245|"

The weird thing about early synthesized pop was that it made a quick
column2: self-aware leap from signifying a shiny
column3: electronic future to a  sense of cheery
column4: almost inane frothiness. Early Moog-tweaking musicians  and engineers spent a lot of time figuring out how to electronically  warp the work of baroque composers into ironic juxtapositions between  tradition and technology
column5: but eventually they had to come to terms with the fact that much of it still registered as grotesque distortions of nuanced melody. And for every musique concrète and BBC Radiophonic Workshop genius who turned those limitations into successfully arresting experiments
column6: there was someone like Jean-Jacques Perrey who thrived on the potential of the equipment's inherent pop goofiness. Combine the cheerfully dippy
column7: utopian enthusiasm of late-1960s electronic  music with the more whimsical strains of the same era's psychedelic  experimentation
column8: and the end result can be clamorously demented at worst. Or best.

column1: Of course
column2: it means something drastically different to invoke that  synthemesc horrorshow now that it's 40-plus years in the past
column3: what with a couple of dozen hours' worth of Gary Wilson
column4: Stereolab
column5: and Black Moth Super Rainbow having had their say in the intervening decades. Twirligig is the first full-length album from Sydney multi-instrumentalist Jonti Danilewitz
column6: and if it follows those  aforementioned artists' archly playful approach to retrofuturist  synth-psych
column7: it also embodies it in odd
column8: frivolous little songs that are  as intricately constructed as they are naggingly irritating. Once the  second track and highlight ""Nightshift in Blue"" is done working  its sun-bleached
column9: rubber-limbed Pet Sounds vibe
column10: the rest of the  album falls into a succession of woozy
column11: disorienting
column12: somewhat uncomfortable assemblages of brow-furrowing sketch-songs that often amble along a little too preciously for their own good.

column1: Sometimes the tone is overly quirky: ""Firework Spraying Moon"" and ""Begone Slumber"" are short
column2: slight
column3: and often pretty
column4: but in a way  that seems too slapstick
column5: like the notebook-paper-doodled title  sequence to your typical indie comedy film. Sometimes it's almost  obnoxiously overstuffed with noise
column6: albeit in a half-speed
column7: low-energy  way
column8: as in ""Spooky Sport"" and the layers of screeching  bird/rubber/guitar/Atari ambiance that make its quasi-Polynesian swoon  so bracing. And sometimes it feigns one of those moods before dropping  the other on you. ""Nodlews Way Home"" stabs its ambling
column9: mellow blues  lope between the shoulder blades with a piercing
column10: oscillating  synthesizer squall that seems to be drunkenly picking a fight with the  rest of the song. And the title track feels like two half-finished ideas  haphazardly stapled together to make a quarter-finished song
column11: a rhythm-machine and faux-Theremin reverie pushed unceremoniously toward a fuzz-synth drone through a tunnel of overbearing distortion.

column1: But credit where it's due: Irritation and bafflement might actually be part of the intent
column2: especially when they're so often used to  cut through moments that would otherwise feel a bit pat in their serenity. It clearly took a lot of work to assemble some of these noisy
column3: chirpy things
column4: and there are a number of odd little details of four-track  alchemy to unearth
column5: even though the bulk of the songs clock in at less  time than your average commercial break. It's pretty dense stuff: Every sound melts into itself with  such viscous goopiness that eventually it's easy to forget that what  you're listening to may have involved instruments at some point
column6: rather  than just the residue of some kind of ancient digital ectoplasm. It is a  bit ephemeral
column7: but not quite as music to relax to-- more like music to  be bewildered by. And there's real craft in the way Jonti manipulates  his multitracked vocals
column8: pulling them apart to disorienting
column9: clashing  effect or merging them into seamless harmony. In either case
column10: he's got a  good sense of how to shape his voice into power-pop harmonic  wonderment. It's not a good enough sense to avoid having it buried in  the mix
column11:
rendering the occasional lyrics not only indecipherable but almost beside the point. But sometimes you've just got to let the machines win.

Despite their wall of noise
column2: Trash Talk work best in miniature. The Sacramento quartet (and OFF! tourmates) wield such an in-your-personal-space presence and messy
column3: spastic forward push that it can be hard
column4: as a viewer or listener

column8: and you're still locked in and protecting your head. The group's 10-song
column9: 17-minute 2010 third album

column12: five-song
column13: nine-minute Awake EP is great. Not all of this has to do with leaving-you-wanting-more brevity: The band

column15: wall-climbing vocalist Lee Spielman

column1: See
column2: for instance

column6: as usual
column7: the lyrics feel like a call to arms. We get the scene-setting introductory line
column8: ""In the land of nod
column9: he who sleeps with both eyes open is god

column11: gaunted
column12: sick sick sick/ Awake""-- that establishes a more interesting tone.

column1: It's a kind of vintage Maximumrocknroll vibe

column3: the disenfranchised lyrical sentiment (see the the smash-shit-up ""Awake"" video)

column5: it feels especially important and of this moment. In the 58-second track ""Slander"" we get: ""Line up and call me names/ Come spit in my face/ It doesn't matter/ I'm in a better place."" In the fantastic closer ""Gimme Death""
column6: we're given a protagonist making the most of destitution: ""Facedown in the gutter/ I've got my ear to the street."" In the breakdown-heavy ""Blind Evolution""
column7: we're told
column8: ""I've got a problem with no solution/ The solution's out of reach

column10: ""Your revolution's already lost."" Even on this short burst of an EP

column1: For instance
column2: the last lines of the record-- ""Gimme death""-- resonate as more than a standard punk toss-off after a close listen to fourth track ""Burn Alive"". In two minutes of the latter
column3: there's a Ramones nod (""When I grow up I wanna be sedated"")
column4: revolutionary imagery (""Plant the seed and the fury spreads like legs/ Without a light at the end of the tunnel unless they set the whole mountain ablaze"")
column5: and this: ""A blind man told me it's better to burn out than to fade away/ I said 'You're missing the point… yeah
column6: the good die young/ But the great survive to burn alive/ The good die young
column7: so burn alive.'"" Trash Talk have been drawing that sort of line in the sand for years-- it's the sort of thing lifers do. Still
column8: in 2011 it's satisfying seeing a higher-profile punk band carrying a torch like this
column9:
and unafraid to use it as a weapon.

The last volume in Matthew Herbert's ""One"" trilogy contains the same sonic ruminations on consumerism and mechanization as the previous installments
column3: as well as their mood and tenor. Like One One
column4: a heady singer-songwriter record
column5: there's a hushed creeping intimacy to the thing
column6: and a Zen-like acceptance of overbearing forces
column7: even if it intends to keep on kicking against them. Like One Club
column8: which twisted field recordings from the Frankfurt nightclub Robert Johnson into splayed-apart dance music
column9: thereby ingesting corporatized club culture on its own terms
column10: One Pig is an overwhelming
column11: inscrutably political electronic record culled from an unlikely source. In this case
column12: it consists of manipulated recordings Herbert made of a pig's life
column13: ""from birth to plate.""

column1: This certainly isn't the exploitation record PETA assumed it was gonna be
column2: and it's not a slab of musical vegan didacticism that presumably
column3: many more
column4: who prefer their music to be good first
column5: and message-oriented second
column6: feared either. No matter how visceral Herbert's mix of animal grunts and menacing electronics feel
column7: the message is never something simple like
column8: ""it sure is sad that we kill animals."" Rather
column9: it moves listeners to be more mindful of consumption and waste (the pig's parts were even turned into instruments)
column10: while acknowledging just how strangely disconnected we are from the animals killed to put food on our table
column11: or say
column12: shoes on our feet.

column1: But the lingering feeling on One Pig
column2: the first half in particular
column3: is still one of abject horror. ""September"" (each song is named after the time of year when the sounds contained therein were recorded) begins with stabs of noise that could be from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre score
column4: and then shifts into a slowly molting rhythm
column5: punctuated by horrifying retches from the pig. As the track perversely bounces along
column6: the animal wails become harsher
column7: and Herbert  pulls the growl in and out of the mix and you begin to expect
column8: even anticipate them. Its appearance in the mix becomes as viscerally rewarding as a typical pop-song hook.

column1: Much of the record intends to freak listeners out
column2: but there are gorgeous moments of pause too
column3: and often those conflicting feelings are contained on the same track
column4: making the message complex and never one-note. ""November"" is a delicate recording of the pig oinking
column5: jaggedly interrupted by telling sounds (knives clanging together
column6: something plopping on a hard surface) and nervous rhythms (gulps of tinny feedback
column7: vibrant drumming)
column8: foreshadowing the pig's death
column9: and even suggesting it's oddly cognizant of the end in some way. It's a way to invoke empathy for the creature. But then
column10: the track bounds foreword into an intense damaged dance track
column11: slamming into ""December"" which begins with an ominous metal gate opening. Rarely does a piece of music feel this genuinely temporal-- like anything could happen at any moment.

column1: As One Pig moves closer to the end
column2: the songs gain focus and the pig itself is subsumed into the process
column3: not just sampled
column4: but literally creating the music thanks to a strange ""pig blood organ"" and a drum made of pigskin. ""August 2010"" begins with recordings of the pig being cut up and fried
column5: and ends with it being joyously consumed by a room of people. In between is a sea of strange
column6: melodic whines and moans-- like the pig cheaply Auto-Tuned or vocoded. According to this excellent making-of video on The Guardian's website
column7: the sound's generated by that organ
column8: whose sucking rhythms are the result of blood coursing through the instrument.

column1: To suggest you cannot enjoy the record would be inaccurate
column2: but Herbert has cleverly designed an album that must be experienced on its own terms. The last track
column3: a touching
column4: voice-and-guitar ode to the pig by Herbert that looks back to One One's simplicity-- and in that sense
column5: provides circularity to the entire trilogy-- makes the pig's absence palpable. Throughout the album
column6: even those most viscerally catchy and hypnotic songs
column7: just as they're almost getting into a conventional groove
column8: are boldly interrupted by the pig
column9: making it impossible to ignore the processes that lead to the record's creation. Imagine if those really sweet leather boots you bought let out a ""moo"" every time you stuck them on your feet and tightened the laces.

column1: Herbert notes in the making-of video that
column2: for legal reasons
column3: he could not record the actual death of the pig. And that says a great deal more about government-sanctioned ignorance and the bizarre regulations on food manufacturing than One Pig really ever could. What Herbert has put together is a witty
column4: difficult
column5:
touching testament to making something lasting out of one of the world's many cruel inevitabilities.

The breezy yet meticulous music of Norway's Casiokids sneaks up on you. It radiates earnestness and simplicity
column3: which can obscure the fine inner workings. Watery vocal hooks and refrains tug at your ear first
column4: but it's the tiny moving parts and lathed instrumental motifs that really get lodged there. This works out to either a kind of failure for a persona-seeking indie-pop band or a kind of success for an atmospheric dance band
column5: two spheres Casiokids have always seemed slightly adrift between
column6: to intriguing but muddying effect. After a scrappy debut and a singles collection disguised as a sophomore album
column7: you might consider this their first shot at a ""mature"" record-- meaning more lavishly recorded
column8: majestically played
column9: and ambitious in scope. Maturity can be tricky to navigate for bands that have established themselves in the symbolic context of childhood.

column1: At this point
column2: Casiokids are a synth-pop band only in the same
column3: broad sense that the Flaming Lips (whose multimedia extravaganzas must have been an influence on their celebratory live show) are a psych-pop band. Big sing-alongs
column4: Western house and disco beats
column5: and squiggly analog synths are important elements of their sound
column6: but no more so than Afro-Caribbean percussion
column7: beatific 1960s pop
column8: swarming funk guitars
column9: and (especially as of Aabenbaeringen Over Aaskammen) gnarled psychedelia that drives the Flaming Lips comparison more firmly home. After about seven years in the game
column10: they're no longer a motley crew of promising upstarts-- they're actually kind of a big deal. Their records are distributed all over the world (Universal in Norway
column11: Polyvinyl in the U.S.) and they were one of four recipients of a million-kroner grant from Norwegian pop gods A-Ha. If they still seem fringe-y here in the States
column12: it may be because the communal pageantry of their live show is an indispensible aspect of their music. Somehow
column13: their loopy mishmash of styles just makes more sense when you're dancing with giant puppets under seizure-inducing lights.

column1: So here's the weird thing about Aabenbaringen Over Aaskammen: I like almost every song on it
column2: but they don't add up to an album I love. It's not quite hype enough to be pure party music and lacks the cohesive point of view that fosters a more personal connection with a record. At first I thought Casiokids sounded like a different band on every song
column3: but that wasn't quite right. It's more like the same band trying on different looks
column4: different ideas of what a band that got a million-kroner grant from A-Ha should maybe sound like. Aabenbaringen is actually more all-over-the-place than the singles collection. The stately orchestration of the opening track might make you think you've wandered into the wrong Norwegian record by accident. Lead single ""Det Haster!"" recalls the electro-funk of ""Fot I Hose""
column5: but built from commanding slabs rather than twitchy bursts
column6: indicative of a general deepening and swelling of Casiokids' sound. Meanwhile
column7: ""Dresinen"" sounds like a post-punk Dungen and the very catchy ""Golden Years"" is tropics-kissed indie-pop. No one's saying a band should only make one kind of song
column8: but it takes a strong identity to make eclecticism feel personalized. I hear lots of cool grooves and marvelous texture
column9: but I have trouble connecting them to anything beyond that.

column1: Still
column2: a vivid
column3: decorative imagination makes these songs fun to glide along. ""Det Haster!"" begins with a bad-stereo-connection fake-out that will have you jiggling the pin in your speaker jack before it comes roaring into full 3D. The intro of ""London Zoo""
column4: a coasting drums-and-synths haze evocative of Au Revoir Simone
column5: features some of the most lusciously precise pin-pricks of guitar you'll encounter. The arpeggiated synth lead of ""Olympiske Leker"" morphs from voicing to voicing with unruffled ease. But no amount of microscopic detail feels sufficient without forming a bigger picture. This one's fun but kind of blurry
column6:
perhaps capturing a band in a moment of transition between anarchic youth and... whatever happens next.

As shaky as his output was in the years since he first set hip hop orthodoxy aside
column2: writing RJD2 off as a total loss seems premature. The Third Hand's dippy bedroom-pop flopped in the way that only abrupt stylistic detours can
column3: but when he honed that lite-funk sound on last year's decent-enough follow-up The Colossus
column4: he seemed on his way toward actually taking it into appealing places. Factor in this year's oddball side project as the Insane Warrior
column5: the 1980s horror soundtrack/electro-prog/library music pastiche We Are the Doorways
column6: and he's already put out a couple of solid pieces of work in the last few years that retain his adventurous nature without letting the burden of his early rep stifle him. Maybe all he really needs to do is keep working out the kinks and find a way to let his beat-making chops translate more readily into traditional song arrangement.

column1: Plus
column2: teaming up with a pretty good vocalist wouldn't hurt. Enter Aaron Livingston
column3: a singer originally out of Philly who flirted with fame via a guest spot on the Roots' ""Guns Are Drawn"" and showed up on The Colossus six years later to lend his talents to ""Crumbs Off the Table"". That went so well that Livingston and RJ recorded another dozen songs under the name Icebird
column4: and if The Abandoned Lullaby is the best piece of evidence so far to justify RJD2 Mk. II
column5: it's also a good showcase for an eccentric singer on the verge of reaching a wide
column6: receptive audience. Both parties click together because they're willing to let genre be an afterthought
column7: yet they still avoid succumbing to a rootless
column8: stylistically overreaching identity crisis.

column1: Identity crises being what they've been over RJD2's career
column2: the fact that he's pulled together a number of familiar elements from his past repertoire is unsurprising but well-executed. Fans enamored with the rangy
column3: all-things-1970s blowout Since We Last Spoke will find some good moments to grab on here-- there's still no gymnastic drum-break sample flipping
column4: but RJ's geeky ear for cross-genre fusion pays off in a similarly satisfying way. The ""Move on Up"" vibe of ""Just Love Me"" and the minor-key
column5: piano-driven skulk of ""Please
column6: Don't"" are retro-funk 101
column7: but their straightforwardness is driven by a marked flair for percussive arrangements that hit with more oomph than anything on his last two solo records. And his sense of ambition starts cresting on the album's dramatic
column8: moody second half
column9: where he indulges in the best instincts of his prog affinity to ends both icily ambient (""The Return of Tronson"") and arena-rock heavy (""Gun for Hire"").

column1: Livingston
column2: meanwhile
column3: makes for a good foil to RJ's occasionally grandiose production. There are moments where he switches from a casually conversational way of singing into a full-on jolt of unadulterated joy or frustration with Swiss-watch timing. He works his raspy tenor well enough to make the moments where he drops flat
column4: bum notes (like the quasi-Egyptian chorus in ""King Tut"") more of a jokey
column5: self-aware idiosyncrasy than actual sandbagging. Best of all
column6: he's got enough charisma to break out of pro-forma neo-soul roles: an optimist getting frustrated in the face of aggravating bullshit on ""Going and Going. And Going""
column7: the desperately haunted lover on ""Spirit Ache""
column8: the recidivist begging not to be led back into temptation on ""Please
column9: Don't"". He doesn't have the show-stopping voice or the lyrical incisiveness of a Cee-Lo to justify the surface-level Gnarls Barkley comparisons The Abandoned Lullaby might rack up-- and RJ's not quite at the full command of a landmark signature sound like Danger Mouse was a couple of years back
column10: either. But if there's been a better two-man indie-funk producer/singer superduo to come out of the woodwork since ""Crazy"" dropped
column11:
I must have missed it.

Dreamers of the Ghetto frontman Luke Jones has this great big voice; not just recording-booth big
column2: but grain-silo big
column3: the kind so rousing
column4: so grandiose
column5: it'd overpower anything short of an anthem. And so Dreamers of the Ghetto write anthems
column6: all these great big songs to go with their frontman's great big voice. Enemy/Lover
column7: their debut LP
column8: is not just indie rock-club big. It's mainstage big. Listening to Enemy/Lover
column9: it takes no stretch of the imagination to see the band's long name inching its way toward the top of all sorts of bills in the months ahead.

column1: Enemy/Lover works in widescreen
column2: searching verses crashing into sweeping choruses
column3: Jones shouting big questions at the sky. Towering and triumphal
column4: Dreamers take most of their cues from stadium-fillers from U2 to Springsteen to indie overgrounders like Arcade Fire and the National. I sometimes hear an optimism-infused spin on much-missed Canadian rockers Constantines; listen close
column5: and you'll pick up hints of Rod Stewart
column6: Simple Minds
column7: and Coldplay. It's not that Dreamers of the Ghetto sound especially like any one of these
column8: but that they sound a bit like all of them
column9: and just about anybody else who's ever stretched the canvas out as far as it goes. Nearly every note on Enemy/Lover is pitched as far as it'll fly; subtlety
column10: as befits a band who would call itself Dreamers of the Ghetto
column11: isn't exactly job one. More room under the big tent that way
column12: I reckon.

column1: A panoramic guitar figure and a stampede of drums set the scene for the ponderous ""State of a Dream""
column2: a slice of Inception-style uncertainty blown up to billboard size. It's bettered by ""Connection""
column3: its bleary
column4: solitary organ giving way to its towering chorus
column5: ""When you're gone
column6: I know you're with me."" This is no mild disruption in the REM cycle or absence-addled fondness; both songs find Jones practically doubled-over from pleading
column7: bouncing those lines off a (for now
column8: imaginary) sea of thousands. The constant craving in Jones' throat keeps Enemy/Lover well-suited for a solitary bedroom hideout
column9: but its insistent songs aim for anyone within earshot. The Dreamers aren't seeking some midpoint between intimacy and grandiosity
column10: they're aiming for both at once; that same combination's kept Bono in leather and wraparounds for decades now
column11: a rarified territory these Dreamers seem almost born into.

column1: The band's gaping chords and roaring percussion rarely snag the spotlight from Jones' voice; when it does
column2: as on the oscillating guitar that closes out ""Regulator""
column3: what could easily turn to empty embellishment feels instead like an elevation of the song itself. Again
column4: decorum's not their strongest suit
column5: but when they swing a line from the aforementioned ""Regulator"" back around into ""Dark Falcons""
column6: it suggests that there are plenty of small pleasures to be found amidst Enemy/Lover's biggie-sized wallop. It's the sort of record you locate yourself in
column7: its concerns universal
column8: its populist appeal easy to grasp
column9: its songs at once moving and movable.

column1: Stirring as they can be
column2: a couple of Enemy/Lover's sky-streaking melodies seem to stick to a similar flightpath. And at times
column3: the Dreamers' all-encompassing approach proves a little too ecumenical
column4: its arms outstretched too wide to pull you in close. But those are the risks you run when you're operating on such a grand scale
column5: and the exultant
column6:
openhearted Enemy/Lover is rarely outpaced by its lofty ambitions.

The most common caricatures of Björk tend to fixate on her outsized aesthetic sense. But for all the bonkers fashion choices
column3: outré collaborators
column4: and leftfield influences she pulls into her orbit
column5: it's easy to forget that her worldview is also equally informed by a sympathy and awareness of the systems that guide us. From the ""beats and strings"" manifesto that shaped Homogenic to the ""music for laptop speakers"" mandate that drove Vespertine through to the vocals-only absolutism of Medúlla
column6: her obsession with patterns and structure and conceptual boundaries has consistently been at the center of her work. Often
column7: she has celebrated the messiness and the chaos implicit in these very things; in fact
column8: the very first line of her very first single took a perverse delight in the lack of logic inherent in one of the biggest and most complex systems of all: human behavior.

column1: Biophilia marks Björk's eighth full-length release
column2: and represents her definitive attempt to create an ecosystem around her work. Billed as her ""most ambitious and interdisciplinary project yet"" and boasting all the usual fixings of a Björk release (dazzling artwork
column3: a Michel Gondry video
column4: vanguard instrumentation
column5: a bizarre list of collaborators)
column6: it also comes supported by a corresponding iPad application for each of its 10 tracks
column7: a new website
column8: a series of live shows and ""music workshops""
column9: and a forthcoming 90-minute film documenting its creation. Beyond that
column10: the album itself purports to engage with some pretty momentous themes
column11: with song titles like ""Thunderbolt""
column12: ""Dark Matter""
column13: and ""Cosmogony"" and imagery focusing on time
column14: space
column15: and the natural world. (Note that editor Brandon Stosuy wrote press materials for this release prior to being hired by Pitchfork.)

column1: The stakes feel even higher in light of Björk's mottled output over the past decade. Between 2004's well-received but thin-sounding Medúlla and 2007's unfocused and sprawling Volta
column2: Björk has arguably been unable to produce anything definitive since 2001's Vespertine. In its worst moments
column3: Volta painted a picture of an artist whose quality control instincts had been eroded by indulgence. One would be forgiven if news of all the scaffolding around Biophilia sounded up alarm bells: Is this her coming back strong
column4: or piling conceptual materials on top of her music in an effort to give it extra depth?

column1: If the songs themselves are any indication
column2: the answer leans more toward the latter. While the promotional and conceptual packaging around Biophilia are as forward-thinking as ever
column3: the sheer quality of Björk's songwriting remains problematic. It feels
column4: once again
column5: as if she's prioritized the superficial aspects of Biophilia's presentation over
column6: well
column7: the music. I can't imagine
column8: for example
column9: how a middle section as dull as ""Dark Matter"" and ""Hollow"" made the cut. Even slightly more realized compositions like the the music box plink of ""Virus"" and the twitching ""Thunderbolt"" are essentially just simple motifs stretched way beyond their limits. Too often
column10: she combats the lack of any real structure or melody by over-singing
column11: or lapsing into one of her familiar and increasingly lazy-sounding house vocal runs.  It too often feels as if Björk's songwriting process is now to sing arbitrarily over top of her collaborators' instrumental tracks rather than structure the music around a melody.

column1: Sure
column2: there are highlights. When she does get a tune to sing
column3: she attacks it with almost apologetic gusto. Lead single ""Crystalline"" features one of the album's best hooks
column4: and as a result
column5: one of Björk's best and most focused performances. Elsewhere
column6: the gorgeous ""Cosmogony"" carries a faint hymnal quality and an immediacy that wouldn't sound totally out of place on Vespertine or even Homogenic. With its satisfyingly filthy electro skronk
column7: the uptempo ""Mutual Core"" may be the album's best track overall.

column1: Although a big part of the PR story around Biophilia
column2: the apps ultimately feel less than essential to the overall experience. Even after spending significant amounts of time with them
column3: it's easy to separate them mentally from the music. They're well-designed and infused with appropriate amounts of playfulness and mystery
column4: and a few have almost meditative properties that suit the music well
column5: but ultimately they feel like they're there to support a concept rather than vice versa. Beyond that
column6: in costing $1.99 apiece (or just under $10 for the full complement)
column7: the app gambit ultimately hits upon another latter-day Björk tendency
column8: which is her seeming willingness to exploit all available revenue streams.

column1: Is it fair to fault Biophilia for failing to realize its own ambition? That's a tough question; Björk's curatorial acumen
column2: her visual sense
column3: and her vision are so beyond reproach that it feels almost churlish to complain about something as simple as a lack of melody
column4: or the fact that she's an experimental music pioneer who might just be over-charging for her experimental iPad apps. Nonetheless
column5: for an album ostensibly about the elements
column6: there are some essential pieces missing here. As an innovator
column7: she's as vibrant as ever
column8: but as a songwriter
column9:
she sounds tired.

"|15915.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15915-biophilia/|6.2|Mark Pytlik

column2: 'Experimental'
column4: and you risk damning yourself to frivolity

column6: and you flirt with a potentially stultifying self-seriousness. Brooklyn-to-L.A. junkyard-pop duo High Places managed to keep their whimsy in check on their early EPs and stellar
column7: spectral self-titled LP

column1: Things took a turn toward the serious on last year's High Places vs. Mankind. Adding further wrinkles to their rippling productions while tamping down some of Pearson's vocal buoyancy
column2: it's an intriguing-sounding record full of alluring textures and warped schoolyard chants. Next to what came before it

column4: Mankind's melodies could seem soft-pedaled
column5: its hooks wedged into tracks rather than constructed alongside them. And Pearson's oft-unaffected vocals took on a disaffection that felt a bit like detachment
column6: that wonder in her voice oddly absent. This shift-- toward a fuller sound

column1: Drawing on a spectrum-spanning array of dance music
column2: Original Colors takes its cues from drum'n'bass
column3: minimal techno
column4: and trance's dalliances with pop. Easily their most danceable
column5: production-centered record to date
column6: Original Colors moves with a quicker pulse than anything that came before it. Pearson and Barber still favor their homespun beatmaking setup

column8: they at times manage a pretty good duct-tape-and-popsicle-stick approximation of Roni Size & Reprazent's earthy clamor and the epic
column9: arid trance-pop of Everything But the Girl beatmaker Ben Watt. Though dance purists will likely find Original Colors' careening too sinewy and scattered
column10: every beat is set just so

column1: Though this shapeshifting sound world proves immersive enough

column3: wide-eyed debut
column4: Original Colors maintains a certain distance. Further flatlining her post-Mankind vocal delivery
column5: Pearson deadpans her way through a good chunk of her lines in a distracted
column6: almost drowsy manner. There are stretches where it seems as though she's left the room entirely; she's certainly singing less than ever before
column7: and her vocals are often backgrounded or otherwise processed in a way that diminishes their potential impact. The crumbly
column8: constantly undulating percussion seems to have edged Pearson out of the frame
column9: and apart from a few more-than-milquetoast melodies they manage to set out front

column11: a task they're not always up for. The few graspable melodies she gets out front fare quite a bit better; ""Dry Lake"" is comfortingly loopy

column15: shedding some of the timidity that seems to trail her here

column1: Original Colors opens up a bit with repeat spins
column2: but its meek melodies never quite bubble to the surface the way you'd hope. Instead

column4: their alien textures grow ever-weirder from prolonged exposure; they
column5: too
column6: lack some of the warmth of High Places' earlier work. But Original Colors' production still doesn't quite sit right next to its paucity of melody
column7: and its sidestepping of the song in favor of the sound never feels like a fair trade. The beguiling interplay between the two halves of High Places-- the ethereal
column8: almost cherubic vocals and the clattering racket in
column9: around
column10: and behind them-- is lacking here

Original Colors can feel unusually drab.

Quick question for anyone who's zoned out to Julianna Barwick's gorgeous 2011 album The Magic Place: Did you ever think to yourself
column2: ""This is cool
column3: but I'd love to hear some beats laid on top of these tracks?"" Me neither. But given that this EP is a low-key release being sold on Bandcamp for $5 (and available to stream for free)
column4: you can't begrudge Barwick or her label for wanting to extend the life of that album. If nothing else
column5: given the strength of her last record
column6: she deserves a victory lap.

column1: One issue with remixing tracks from The Magic Place is that they're hard to pull apart. With their layers of voices
column2: heavy reverb
column3: and instrumental loops
column4: they feel integrated and whole
column5: each part gaining its meaning through its relationship to the others. That's true in all music
column6: of course
column7: but with immersive ambient tracks based on addition and subtraction and so dependent on harmony for musical content
column8: it becomes that much more difficult to isolate one element and build something new out of it.

column1: Four remixers here give it a try (the six-song set is rounded out by the album versions of ""Vow"" and ""Prizewinning""). Diplo and Lunice's take on ""Vow"" is
column2: in one sense
column3: the most cookie-cutter version
column4: in that it mostly does what remixes of indie music have been doing since the late 1990s: isolates a small section of the original and adds some programmed drums. By foregrounding an electric keyboard refrain
column5: giving the tune more of a pulse
column6: and adding a 1980s sheen
column7: it actually bridges the gap between Barwick and Enya circa Watermark
column8: but it feels more like an uninspired original track that happens to have some samples from Julianna Barwick than a proper song. Helado Negro's take is more interesting
column9: as it condenses rather than separates
column10: creating a compact loop of highly melodic sound that reminds me of early Four Tet remixes. On top of the loop is an original vocal
column11: presumably from project leader Roberto Carlos Lange
column12: and it has some relationship to the original but doesn't feel bound to it. It's solid
column13: but not something I'm likely to return to.

column1: The two remixes of ""Prizewinning"" include the set's high and low points. The duo Alias Pail cut up Barwick's vocals and fold in some tribal drums
column2: and the result feels like an empty exercise. Prince Rama
column3: on the other hand
column4: take the track and amplify it
column5: making it more in every respect-- surging sounds
column6: changed vocals
column7: extra-shimmery production-- and it works surprisingly well
column8: almost brilliantly. To my ears
column9: it's the best thing Prince Rama have ever done
column10: and it winds up feeling like a proper collaboration that has a compelling reason to exist. That's ultimately all you can ask for from a remix
column11:
even if it doesn't happen often enough.

Sets & Lights is Brooklyn duo Xeno & Oaklander's third album overall and second for analog-fixated NYC label Wierd. It's also their best release yet
column2: but it it takes some time to sink in. The sounds that X&O (Liz Wendelbo and Sean McBride) make are regularly referred to as ""coldwave""-- deadpan D.I.Y. post-punk filtered through brutal drum machines and synth lines so brittle and thin you could practically snap them over your knee. It's easy music to appreciate but hard to outright love this stuff in large doses (that held even for last year's excellent look at the original coldwave movement from the late 1970s and early 80s
column3: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13910-the-minimal-wave-tapes-vol-1/"" target=""_blank"">The Minimal Wave Tapes
column4: Vol. 1). The formal rigidity of Xeno & Oaklander's artistic aims can cause them to blend together at first listen
column5: and since this isn't wide-reaching
column6: crowd-pleasing stuff
column7: it takes some commitment to stick with it.

column1: So Sets & Lights is more of the same chilly
column2: dusty electronic gloom
column3: but they've stuck with their aesthetic and gotten better. Compared to 2009's attention-getting Sentinelle
column4: Sets & Lights is full-bodied and lush. Artists who release music on Wierd typically forgo computers""
column5: so the fact that Wendelbo and McBride were able to coax such austere beauty from their machines is impressive in its own right. The highlights seem to take cues from ""Secret Stores""
column6: a blissful track from You Today
column7: McBride's otherwise disappointing solo effort as Martial Canterel from earlier this year. There's more intricacy
column8: more gloriously tangled arpeggios
column9: and a stronger focus overall on melodic composition. That last one is key
column10: as it also Wendelbo and McBride have also developed stronger vocal presences. Wendelbo no longer sounds like she's simply sighing into an amplifier
column11: while McBride's range has expanded and now runs from the gothic sighs on the lovely opening title track to fierce determinism on ""Corrupt""
column12: an aggro headblast of a number that should satisfy fans of the latest Cold Cave album.

column1: Sets & Lights is also the first release from Xeno & Oaklander where they reveal that they have a sense of humor-- one of the digital-only bonus tracks is a four-alarm Italo disco assault called ""Italy"". But Sets & Lights
column2: like earlier records
column3: is ultimately a bit too stuffy and self-serious as a whole. Still
column4: while this collection may not be a breakout release
column5:
it's good to hear them stepping out and experimenting with new moods and textures.

Hull don't squander opportunities to make first impressions. Sole Lord
column2: the Brooklyn quintet's 2009 debut
column3: offered a promising extension of the ambitiously psychedelic doom legacies of Neurosis and Isis
column4: simply caked in the residue of stoner metal record collections. Moments of atmospheric drift
column5: mathematical twist
column6: and belligerent march tied together into the suggestion that this was a band to watch. Hull's sprawling follow-up
column7: Beyond the Lightless Sky
column8: appropriately opens with ""Earth From Water""
column9: an 11-minute triumph of that potential and one of the best gambits you're likely to hear all year. ""Earth From Water"" not only synthesizes those earlier qualities-- a pensive instrumental break here
column10: a crusty mid-tempo stomp there-- but adds seemingly conflicting moments of hardcore maul and melodic bursts memorable enough for modern rock radio. What's more
column11: ""Earth From Water"" is deftly built
column12: with impossibly exhilarating moments of lift added at precisely the right moments
column13: whether through a spiraling solo or a bass-thick
column14: full-band roar. No moment is wasted
column15: no idea is idle: This is the longest track in the band's catalog
column16: yet it doesn't seem quite long enough.

column1: ""Earth From Water"" serves as a sort of manifesto for the rest of Beyond the Lightless Sky
column2: an unabashed attempt to increase both Hull's scope and scale. While Sole Lord felt mostly like a collection of related tunes
column3: Beyond the Lightless Sky is a deliberate sequence of songs and segues. Hull attempts to replicate the push and pull of ""Earth From Water"" throughout these 57 minutes by splicing an often-meditative instrumental between each pair of roaring
column4: full-band numbers. ""Earth From Water"" exits with the sort of full-spectrum thunder that makes headphones hurtful
column5: and the title track pirouettes open with a serrated guitar line and a restless drum rush. But ""Just a Trace of Early Dawn""
column6: which separates the two
column7: rises slowly from an electronic din into a Six Organs of Admittance-style smoky haze
column8: drums tapping lightly behind a circular acoustic guitar. Like the opener
column9: ""Fire Vein"" and ""False Priest"" both set their aims for triumph
column10: dividing throaty declamations and malevolent moments with distended solos and elaborate bridges for nine minutes at a time. But they're distinct enough not to require ""Wake the Heavens
column11: Reveal the Sun""
column12: the intercalary passage that wraps an interesting sample of primitive chants in needlessly ponderous guitars and drums. Of the four shorter passages meant to bridge the album's five proper songs
column13: only the last one
column14: ""A Light That Shone From Aside the Sea""
column15: stands for greater consideration. Suggesting a more rigorous Pelican indulging in restraint
column16: the brief piece reveals yet another
column17: more nuanced side of Hull-- as the suggested coda falls into a fade-out-- one capable of denying gratification.

column1: That quality is consistent with and complementary to Hull's ostensible aim on Beyond the Lightless Sky-- to make a colossal and cohesive statement that moves beyond the bounds of simply being a good rock record. This is
column2: after all
column3: a concept album about two Mayan brothers struggling with their separate and conflicting destinies. But the antiphonal approach between surging
column4: complicated epics and complacent
column5: ruminative tone pieces not only squanders Hull's hard-won momentum
column6: but also renders an album full of misdirection and surprises sometimes indistinguishable from one side to the next. (Over time
column7: a landscape of high hills and beautiful valleys eventually becomes just another landscape.) Still
column8: at their best
column9: Hull join a rare but growing class of bands resurfacing doom with new influences and expectations. Beyond the Lightless Sky doesn't meet recent high-water marks set by the Body
column10: Rwake
column11: Baroness
column12: or Thou
column13: but it does seem like the next stepping-stone for Hull. Two years ago
column14: they proved they had the songs. Now
column15: they've proven they have the ideas
column16: aims
column17: and skills. Given the depth and delivery of the best moments here
column18:
it's intimidating to consider how Hull might sound when they get it all right at once.

Perhaps the most conventional story Will Oldham has to tell is his own. As a teenager in the late 1980s
column2: he moved from his hometown of Louisville to Hollywood
column3: where he struggled as an actor before eventually landing a small role in John Sayles' Matewan and a larger role in a TV movie about Jessica McClure. Oldham soon defected to music
column4: writing songs first under the Palace set of monikers and later as Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy. Twenty years later
column5: while he still takes the occasional role
column6: Sayles and McClure represent the poles of his subjects: His songs
column7: often in a skewed country or folk tradition
column8: are full of darkly American oddities and characters trapped down in their own metaphorical wells.

column1: Oldham's film career continues to inform his music
column2: as he writes songs as soliloquies and inhabits them the way an actor might perform a dramatic role
column3: transforming dialog and stage direction into something flesh-and-blood
column4: memorable
column5: and moving. He writes in isolation and hires a small cast of backing musicians to help him bring these one-act songs to life. For his latest Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy album
column6: Wolfroy Goes to Town
column7: he's chosen a cast of regulars
column8: including guitarist Emmett Kelly. Most of the Wolfroy troupe
column9: like composer/multi-instrumentalist Shahzad Ismaily and Chicago-based singer-songwriter Angel Olsen
column10: have toured with him for a while now
column11: and backed him on many of his most recent records. Together
column12: they give these new songs a soft
column13: casual vibe
column14: and the minimal instrumentation-- mostly acoustic guitars and bass-- evokes a dark
column15: bare stage.

column1: Oldham places the hardiest emphasis on vocals-- not just his own
column2: but those of his players. His female duet partners have tended to act as his opposites
column3: the coo of their voices offsetting his weathered creak. But on Wolfroy
column4: Olsen sounds just as odd and ragged as he does. There may be no spark of contrast between them
column5: but there's a spark nonetheless
column6: and she's one of the most grounded female characters on any Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy record. The rest of the band's harmonies are rough and pointedly unrehearsed
column7: barely holding together on ""Black Captain"" and ""Quail and Dumplings"". Rustic
column8: however
column9: does not mean primitive. ""Cows"" ends with a sophisticated vocal roundelay that has more in common with British folk than with its American counterpart. It's a lovely moment-- a spare
column10: hushed
column11: and unexpected coda.

column1: Oldham's music is deeply attuned to the past and to the people we imagine inhabited it
column2: yet his actorly approach separates him from the mainstream Americana crowd
column3: who tend to favor a more autobiographical approach
column4: or at least some sense of direct confessionalism. Oldham's songs are only obliquely about himself
column5: and they rarely reveal much about the man singing them. ""As boys
column6: we fucked each other
column7: he sings at the beginning of ""New Tibet"". ""As men
column8: we lie and smile."" In other hands
column9: such a line might deliver a shock to interrupt the lull of the music
column10: but Oldham never breaks character. That f-bomb becomes part of the lull
column11: and is not so much sung as ruefully breathed. The song possesses all the ruminative gravity of ""I See a Darkness"" and in tone and character could be interpreted as a sequel.

column1: Heroes hold no interest for Oldham
column2: who is much more concerned with the moral tangles of everyday people
column3: like the character in ""Quail and Dumplings"" who promises a bright future of full bellies and no worries. Despite the subject matter
column4: it's almost impossible to read that song strictly as a 2010s recession anthem
column5: although it certainly derives some power from current conditions. Oldham's antiquated diction and sepia-toned details-- ""one day it's going to be quail and dumplings for we""-- removes the song from the present and sets the characters deep in some imagined past. In one sense
column6: it robs the song of any topical gravity
column7: but in another
column8: he allows ""Quail and Dumplings"" to transcend any one era.

column1: By this point in his career
column2: Oldham seems to realize that it's difficult for his audience to hear his songs outside of the context of his previous albums and incarnations. So he plays that up on Wolfroy
column3: both by shifting away from the fuller sound of his recent albums

column6: that sense of connectedness lends these songs a reassuring familiarity
column7:
as though they were new corners of a strange world whose boundaries grow larger and whose scenery grows more inviting with every Oldham release.

It's incredibly easy to say ""forget everything you know about Bombay Bicycle Club
column4: when they really haven't established much of an identity to begin with. But I'll try to sum it up: If you've ever wondered what might happen if Editors were fronted by a freak-folk singer
column5: by all means pick up their debut. Meanwhile
column6: on last year's mostly acoustic soft parade Flaws
column7: they sounded like they'd get their lunch money stolen by Kings of Convenience. I suppose their sales inspired more patience from Island than their art
column8: but on A Different Kind of Fix
column9: they follow in the proud tradition of Snow Patrol's Final Straw and Travis' The Man Who
column10: wherein a band links up with a hotshot producer
column11: ditches a trad-indie sound that just wasn't working
column12: and discovers its destiny churning out soft-serve sweetness that completely neutralizes your critical reasoning skills. I'm fairly certain the same impulse that triggers my desire for an Oreo McFlurry makes me want to listen to A Different Kind of Fix.

column1: It's more likely that Bombay Bicycle Club sought out producer Ben H. Allen than the other way around-- after all
column2: BBC have dutifully namedropped Allen clients Animal Collective and Deerhunter as big influences leading up to the release of Fix. Yeah
column3: it's 2011 and just discovering those bands is just another aspect of BBC that seems so easy to make fun of before they totally disarm you: While nothing here will make you say
column4: ""yeah
column5: total 'Summertime Clothes' moment
column6: they've opted out of ""quiet is the new loud"" by investing themselves in the elemental songwriting aspects of America's indie elite: repetition is the new chorus
column7: texture is the new volume.

column1: And indeed
column2: Apple might need to take a long look at Allen as a product designer if they haven't found a worthy successor for Steve Jobs-- as with Merriweather Post Pavilion
column3: Halcyon Digest
column4: and especially Washed Out's Within and Without
column5: Allen gets a sound that's sleek
column6: bold
column7: and covetable
column8: yet within the price range of the young and upwardly mobile. The easy lilt of Jack Steadman's vocals (thankfully shorn of his prior melismatic fringe) gives Fix enough humanity and extroverted charm to keep it from being a mere showcase for Allen's production tricks
column9: but the depth of the low-end and a prudent amount of abrasive grit imparts a three-dimensionality that saves BBC from getting pushed around like any band that could reasonably be compared to early Coldplay.

column1: Sure
column2: the guitars on ""Bad Timing"" are thickly distorted
column3: and the drums get a digital makeover into machinery
column4: but it doesn't exactly rock-- it just asserts itself the right amount where a Steadman solo performance would be content to play the wall. The point of ""Lights Out
column5: Words Gone"" isn't to praise BBC for apparently owning a Talking Heads record
column6: or writing the catchiest Foals song Foals didn't actually write-- it's to lose yourself in the luxurious gulf between the band's vaporous harmonies and the glassy
column7: yacht-funk riffs. The title of ""Shuffle"" might just be an indication of whose ad dollars Fix has in its crosshairs
column8: and it could very well get there. BBC make full use of a stammering piano loop for both melodic and percussive purposes
column9: and Steadman's vocals tumble over handclaps and layered harmonies in a manner that becomes subtly unstoppable instead of mawkish.

column1: And Fix is all about accumulative properties
column2: little bits and pieces that add up to way more than it should. ""How Can You Swallow So Much Sleep"" seems genial enough in its first minute-- a blindingly clean guitar riff providing an acoustic sunrise while Steadman somnolently delivers the same line the same way (""Can I wake you up/ Is it late enough"") for nearly the song's entirety before an EQ-tweaked drum break sets things in motion. Frankly
column3: you wonder what something this sparkly and chipper was doing on a Twilight soundtrack
column4: but the sonic color is secondary to BBC and Allen playing off each other's skills in service of a certain kind of emotional ""click"" that's certainly in that franchise's demographic. I can't speak much for the actual biochemical workings
column5: but at its best
column6: Fix strikes that point where
column7: ""oh
column8: they're cute"" hits a groove in your mind and gets looped into total infatuation. After its three and a half minutes run out
column9: not much has changed about ""How Can You Swallow So Much Sleep"" except maybe your way of looking at it.

column1: But there's something faintly troubling about A Different Kind of Fix even in light of its success: While the songs are wildly improved
column2: I still can't say there's much of a discernible identity. How much of Bombay Bicycle Club are you actually getting here? Steadman's lyrics and the band's tasteful playing convey
column3: above all else
column4: a kind of utilitarian earnestness endemic to young Brits with acoustics writing about girls and feelings. And you might find some of these hooks creeping up on you when you least expect it-- whistling the melody to ""Lights Out
column5: Words Gone"" while buying groceries
column6: realizing how deeply the riff of ""Your Eyes"" burrowed into your consciousness. But just as easily
column7: it can pass right by you as you're actually listening to it
column8: and the closing piano howler ""Still"" serves notice that they've still got an awkward sweet tooth or two left to extract. And maybe this stands out on account of filling a real void. Prior to the Strokes and the Libertines
column9: this is often what UK guitar bands sounded like-- unabashedly cuddly
column10: a little cloying
column11: and in thrall with even the most rudimentary facets of electronic music. But hell
column12: this is called A Different Kind of Fix and not The Shape of British Rock to Come for a reason: whether you're totally nostalgic for a time when Turin Brakes loomed large or just hoping that the Maccabees and the Vaccines might have a decent album in them at some point
column13:
BBC are your pushers.

column6: but one that still has a glossy coating that never allows it to
column7: well

column1: The aspect of ""ashes"" also designates this as a record obsessed with aftermath
column2: searching for truth and permanence within the wreckage of the past. Though it lacks for autobiographical detail
column3: it's easy enough to fill in the blanks when Adams gravely intones ""I'm just looking through the rubble/ Trying to find out who we were"" on ""Dirty Rain""
column4: or more pointedly on first single ""Lucky Now""
column5: ""am I really who I was?"" And Adams' lyrics are every bit as based in the elemental: shadows
column6: stones
column7: rivers
column8: and way more rain than should be allowed for a record made in Los Angeles. And yet
column9: Ashes & Fire's mixed and muddled use of big symbols too often result in ballads of big nothing. A literally rendered song called ""I Love You But I Don't Know What to Say"" should be a self-deprecating epigram to an album that sounds like it's got so much truth to share
column10: but here it's an M.O. It's actually more of a political work than his Love Is Hell laugher ""Political Scientist"" in how it asserts that saying all the right things in light of a public admonishment is to say nothing that can be held against you. While the subtly devastating line
column11: ""and the night will break your heart but only if you're lucky now

column5: he could rock

column11:
here he might have accomplished something more difficult: making it somehow seem underrated.

A ghost hovers over instrumental rock outfit the Drift's third proper LP
column3: Blue Hour. After 2008's Memory Drawings
column4: the band reunited with original bassist Trevor Montgomery. But as a band member returned

column12: out-of-place ""Peter Gunn""-isms (early leak ""Horizon""). The band's gift for melodic interplay is in limited supply here

column1: On one hand

column1: Little of the band's careful detail work

column3: makes it onto TKOL RMX 1234567
column4: a listenable but ultimately bloodless collection of remixes of songs from The King of Limbs. Whether intimidated by the thought of reinterpreting a band renowned for experimentation or unsure how to take apart and reassemble the band's tightly-wound recent material
column5: too many of these 19 artists seem content to settle for bland beauty
column6: or simply apply their usual sonic tricks without pushing themselves in the slightest.

column1: The highlights are the tracks that take TKOL's joy in rhythm to new places. Acclaimed UK neo-rave producer Lone turns out a typically brilliant take on ""Feral"" that somehow keeps the original percussion pattern intact while recasting it as an early-1990s ambient house record
column2: giving us TKOL RMX's most bizarrely enjoyable image: Radiohead gone to Ibiza. Pearson Sound
column3: the alter-ego of dubstep progenitor and Hessle Audio label head Ramadanman
column4: pulls a fantastic bait-and-switch
column5: opening with an extended drone intro that shifts into a punchy mix of early Detroit techno and jagged jungle breaks. These two
column6: along with a small handful of other acts-- Anstam squeezing drama from just a handful of skeletal drum patterns
column7: SBTRKT recasting Thom Yorke as a forlorn garage diva
column8: Caribou returning to his roots as a left-field beatmaker-- are fearless enough to recreate the feeling of TKOL in a new form. And a few do get by on sheer loveliness alone
column9: like Four Tet spinning ""Separator"" into an old-school IDM lullaby.

column1: But a far greater number of these remixes flatten out the complexity of TKOL's grooves in favor of commonplace arrangements. Instead of Radiohead's pinpoint editing
column2: we get generically ""wonky"" takes on house and techno filled with stuttering drums and formless synth goo
column3: whether aggressive like Blawan's take on ""Bloom"" or shoegaze-lite like Nathan Fake doing ""Morning Mr Magpie"". And some of the most touted names fail to deliver the craft we've come to expect from them: On his ""Bloom"" rework
column4: Jamie xx ditches his minimalist gloom-funk for gauzy
column5: forgettable ambience. More ethereal or abstract remixes of such anxious music could have been interesting
column6: but few seem up to the task here
column7: instead doling out placid and perfectly pleasant background noise.

column1: For a while
column2: until its complex grooves revealed the songs beneath
column3: I dismissed TKOL as a brave but opaque attempt to remake Radiohead as just individual components in a roiling rhythm machine. In other words
column4: it seemed like the perfect Radiohead album for remixing. Who would better understand that everything-is-rhythm impulse than dance music producers? If anything
column5: wouldn't they take it further
column6: make it wilder
column7: go funkier?

column1: The lack of rhythmic invention here could be forgiven if most of TKOL RMX displayed any kind of invention. Failing to match TKOL's peculiar vibe-- aggressive rhythms made out of dainty bits of digital detritus
column2: robotically repetitive yet humanly off-kilter
column3:
parched thickets of drumming graced with fleeting moments of melodic relief -- is one thing. Failing to replace it with anything that similarly rewards listening deeper and harder is quite another.

When I first read that Tim Hecker made the source material for Ravedeath
column3: his masterful album from earlier this year
column4: on a pipe organ in an church in Iceland
column5: I figured the album might sound dark and eerie. I pictured Hecker using the setting's natural reverb to reflect what I imagined to be the space's chilly mysteries. I wasn't wrong-- some of that mood is there-- but <i>Ravedeath
column6: 1972 is wider and deeper than that
column7: encompassing a multitude of tones. It's also a big
column8: enveloping work
column9: more interested in quickly surrounding you than in creating dark spaces for you to enter as you choose.

column1: It turns out Hecker actually did create some dark spaces for Ravedeath
column3: but he did so before entering that church. The nine early sketches collected on Dropped Pianos are starker and colder than what ended up on the final album. Heavy reverb and minor-key tones produce lots of negative space-- shadows in which the spirit of the music hides a bit
column4: poking its head around corners rather than looking straight into the camera. The source of these sounds is clear-- a piano on which Hecker is unafraid to bang out bold
column5: dramatic notes. But most of those notes decay into echo right after they are struck.

column1: That effect makes the album name apt-- Hecker's piano seems to always be falling from view. Such quick absence is an inversion of the more-present Ravedeath
column2: 1972. In fact
column3: inversion is the prominent theme here: the album's title flips the name of <i>Ravedeath
column4: 1972's opener ""The Piano Drop""
column5: while its cover image is the exact negative of its predecessor's. Of course
column6: the album name also indicates how piano was literally dropped from Hecker's creative process
column7: replaced by the church organ. But what's most interesting about these pieces is their musical inversion
column8: the way they can be as compelling as what they eventually became despite being tonally opposite.

column1: They're compelling mostly because they sound intimate. Where Ravedeath
column2: 1972 had a widescreen flavor
column3: these sketches feel personal and individual. You can imagine Hecker sitting alone at a piano spinning simple yarns
column4: rather than at a huge organ generating worlds of sound. Granted
column5: there is a cinematic quality here that can be as moving as anything on <i>Ravedeath
column6: 1972. But where that album is grand enough to soundtrack the space scenes in 2001
column7: this one would better fit the lonely
column8: haunted journeys of Eyes Wide Shut. That analogy might imply that Ravedeath
column9: 1972 is the bigger
column10: better work
column11: and it is. But the value of Dropped Pianos is not just in showing how small ideas can lead to greater ones. It's a strong record on its own
column12:
and solid evidence that Tim Hecker's range continues to expand-- even in reverse.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17036/homepage_large.ac2fcf52.jpg|On the Water|28423.0|Future Islands|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2011-10-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:29.690508|"

Samuel T. Herring
column2: lyricist and lion-throated singer of Baltimore synth-romantics Future Islands
column3: has written a lot of break-up songs. He penned some pretty vitriolic ones on the band's 2008 debut
column4: Wave Like Home
column5: and then he wrote an entire record's worth on their terrific 2010 release
column6: In Evening Air. About four songs into their latest-- which contains such boldfaced melodrama as ""I loved you and I still do""-- you get the idea that this guy might be something of a Sisyphus
column7: relieved at last of the whole boulder-up-the-hill business but doomed to sit on the receiving end of an ""It's not you
column8: it's me"" conversation ad infinitum.

column1: Future Islands initially came out of Baltimore's Wham City scene; their first
column2: rather unexceptional record was built from electro-punk and day-glo squiggles. Over the past few years
column3: though
column4: they've become more aesthetically disciplined. The thing that made In Evening Air such a bruiser was how seriously it took its job as a break-up album: Its gaze was singularly affixed on hurt. Herring's lyrics were simplistic and conversational
column5: yet pointed: ""You couldn't possibly know how much you meant to me
column6: ""You hurt me so bad
column7: etc. Amidst a steady
column8: drum-machine heartbeat and uncommonly sentient-sounding synths
column9: he repeated these lines-- the banal poetry of relationship-speak-- until they started to sound downright sinister. His refrain on ""Long Flight"" builds from a quietly mounting frenzy into
column10: by song's end
column11: a full blown
column12: grown-man temper tantrum. Listening to the part when he finally breaks evokes the skin-prickling claustrophobia of watching a mild-mannered airplane seatmate start to freak out 30
column13: 000 feet above an exit route.

column1: Their third and latest LP
column2: On the Water
column3: is more invested in wide-open spaces. The opening (and title) track gives all the elements of the band's sound more leg room: Herring's unhurried vocals
column4: epic
column5: smoldering synths
column6: and the steady churn of a not-too-choppy tide on a sample that begins the song. Recorded in a friend's house in Elizabeth City
column7: North Carolina
column8: overlooking the Pasquotank River
column9: On the Water draws from the imagery and movement of the sea. It's less intent on bringing the drama or the fury than In Evening Air was
column10: but its reflections on aging and memory accumulate into something surprisingly moving.

column1: With the songs' energy scaled back
column2: the efforts of the other two band members come to the fore. Gerrit Welmers handles the keyboards and programming
column3: bringing an evocative
column4: setting-sun vibe to slowburners like ""The Great Fire"" (a soulful duet with Jenn Wasner of fellow Marylanders Wye Oak)
column5: while William Cashion's guitars have the same low-end lurch of early-New Order riffs. Though treading familiar sonic and thematic waters at the start
column6: On the Water really comes alive midway through
column7: beginning with the mournful ""Where I Found You"" and building to ""Close to None""
column8: the record's most buoyant track.

column1: Though some of Herring's more temperate moments make me miss his snarling freakouts of yore
column2: one of On the Water's most striking moments is decidedly minimal: ""Tybee Island"" pairs the sound of crashing waves with a warm synth tone
column3: both of which overpower the presence of their frontman. For most people
column4: Herring's hyper-theatrical vocals are the make-or-break point of Future Islands: He sings every line like Meat Loaf serenading Yorick's skull. It's an acquired taste for sure
column5: one that's much easier to be unequivocally swept up in when you're watching him on stage (doing grand hand gestures
column6: grinning like a maniac
column7: and occasionally slapping himself across the face)
column8: but even on the record
column9: Herring's signature affect communicates something about the operatic sadness of life's everyday banalities. ""Tybee Island"" finds him
column10: for once
column11: barely audible. It's a powerful moment to hear a voice usually so big made to sound-- in contrast with the natural world-- so human and small. It's the polar opposite of the tension-building repetitions of In Evening Air: With each utterance of this coda
column12:
he seems more and more to loosen his grip on the past.

"|15903.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15903-future-islands-on-the-water/|7.7|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17037/homepage_large.d382e814.jpg|Coracle|28335.0|Walls|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kompakt']|2011-10-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:30.347519|"

Walls' eponymous 2010 debut album was praised for applying lo-fi pop structures to the kind of slo-mo beats that aligned them with their peers on Kompakt. The duo of Alessio Natalizia (Banjo or Freakout) and Sam Willis (Allez-Allez) have built on those promising beginnings by stretching Walls' sound on Coracle
column2: principally by scraping away all the fuzz and upping the production values. Tracks like ""Burnt Sienna"" and ""Soft Cover People"" from the band's debut album flirted with the kind of filmy arrangements that chillwave was founded on
column3: although their disposition toward harder dance music took them far enough away from the genre to escape too many comparisons. Still
column4: it's hard not to feel that the tightening up of their sound on Coracle is a deliberate cutting of the chillwave tether
column5: even though it's a change that feels natural and has forced the duo into functioning in brighter spaces.

column1: One point of interest from that debut record was Walls' propensity for taking Krautrock influences and shaving them down into bite-size chunks; the entire record stopped short at just over 29 minutes. Here
column2: they take the more obvious route and expand those inclinations out and latch them to the sunnier beats that are now firmly within their domain. There is more focus on producing complete songs and less deviation into abstraction here than before
column3: although there are a few welcome moments (""Vacant""
column4: ""Drunken Galleon"") when their fondness for ambient shines through. As such
column5: Coracle is stylistically all over the map
column6: with the pair behind Walls indulging vastly different parts of their personalities through the mostly instrumental tracks.

column1: At the center of the album is ""Sunporch""
column2: a strapping electro-pop number built around a skeletal Giorgio Moroder throb and pitch-shifted vocal screams. It's telling that Walls are touring with Battles to promote this album
column3: as ""Sunporch"" is their ""Atlas""
column4: a great utopian future-pop moment that demonstrates the power to startle that this band occasionally possesses. But whereas ""Atlas"" felt like a genuine bolt from the blue
column5: ""Sunporch"" is more of a distant cousin to it
column6: playing out in an alternate reality where Battles have set down a blueprint for all manner of forward-thinking acts. Despite those misgivings it's definitely a step in the right direction
column7: and it's almost equaled in the pretty ""Raw Umber/Twilight""
column8: which combines Walls' love of setting forlorn shoegazer-y patterns to the grind of old analog bass synths.

column1: There's a sharp contrast between the twin peaks of Coracle and the rest of its material
column2: especially when they try to pointlessly channel Spacemen 3 circa ""Honey"" and shackle that sound to some perfunctory beats on ""Ecstatic Truth"". It highlights a danger when groups try to veer too far into eclecticism
column3: where the overall focus of the band is lost amid the desire to keep playing around with the sound. There's little in the way of identity to cling onto
column4: with no shared tropes to bind the sound together
column5: making this feel more like a compilation than a focused work by one act. It demonstrates how big the band's record collections are
column6: and how skilled they are at bringing those influences into their sound
column7:
but it leaves the question of who Walls are and what they are trying to achieve frustratingly open.

Being a fan of Bullion can be frustrating. The West London producer-- real name Nathan Jenkins-- first caught a fire in 2007 with Pet Sounds: In the Key of Dee
column2: a surprisingly deft
column3: quasi-mash-up record that married snatches of the Beach Boys' classic LP with a variety of J Dilla samples. Roughly four years
column4: an EP
column5: and a handful of singles later
column6: and an honest-to-goodness Bullion full-length still hasn't fallen into our laps. This brings us to You Drive Me to Plastic
column7: which saw release on Young Turks at the tail end of last year as a one-sided 12"". The 500 copies went fast
column8: and while it was made available overseas on CD this past April
column9: it's only now available stateside.

column1: While it might be the second closest thing he's ever done to making an album proper
column2: You Drive Me to Plastic is
column3: in fact
column4: not the debut we've been waiting out for. Billed as a ""non-LP
column5: the piece's nine tracks blend into one another to create a 20-minute extended mix
column6: highlighting Bullion's genre-smashing groovers that continue to prove just as idiosyncratic and danceable as past efforts. Using shorter
column7: less movement-minded pieces to glue together three big
column8: single-friendly tracks and a more ambitious finale
column9: Plastic most certainly doesn't feel like a debut
column10: but it also doesn't seem like just another keeping-busy-mix-of-the-month either. Whether the whole ""non-LP"" tag sounds like a bunch of nonsense to you or not
column11: a little more Bullion in any capacity is a good thing.

column1: One of Bullion's greatest assets is being able to work with so many different ideas and styles while being overwhelming
column2: and the way Plastic is structured is perhaps even more of a testament to this ability. Each of those interludes provide a specific purpose
column3: linking the more memorable moments to create an even more fluid experience. And while stuff like ""Lol Express"" can get by on its own merits
column4: sounding something like M83 crashing into a 1980s cop-show theme
column5: the real pull are the more fully realized songs that will inevitably end up in a ""Best Of"" folder along with his more pop-oriented assemblages. Everything from wandering saxophones
column6: strange vocal clippings
column7: chic club pulsings
column8: and a variety of geographically varied rhythms coexist together while rarely sounding jumbled or too mazy. It shows that
column9: for a guy who isn't terribly prolific
column10: his attention to pacing and matching incompatible sources with finesse often results in success.

column1: Bullion has often oriented himself using hip-hop-- he's the same guy that could thrown Klaus Nomi and Buffy Sainte-Marie on a track and still have it sound like an Afrika Bambaataa record-- but Plastic finds him exploring the dancefloors of Europe and the Carribbean. ""Magic Was Ruler""
column2: which again features a Sainte-Marie sample (<a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FhmeroR20lc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""God Is Alive
column3: Magic Is Afoot"")
column4: feels as if you could salsa to it
column5: with a bright guitar line and horns that are evocative of a night out in Havana
column6: while ""Pressure to Dance"" splits the different between slinky Italo-disco moves and Kraftwerk.

column1: There was always a sort of deranged quality to Bullion's sound as well-- maybe it has something to do with the fact that his music has always had a joyous
column2: almost spritely disposition
column3: but often contained imperfect samples and darker tinkerings that could readily translate as feelings of unease. A good many of these 20 minutes explore even more haunted extremes. ""Too Right""
column4: which features a pulsing Laurie Anderson vocal sample
column5: is one of the more menacing things he's ever produced. Plastic might not contain your favorite Bullion moments (some of the shorter tracks feel a bit lost)
column6:
but they're important in the sense that he can feel comfortable exploring certain extremes of his personality without compromising the sound he's been sculpting over the past few years.
