When asked to give his definition of dubstep in an interview last month
column3: James Blake said
column4: ""There's a very broad template
column5: but it largely focuses on a bassline and the intricacies of drum patterns and it has an intense focus on a feeling-- and I think that's a separation from some other dance music."" Ostensibly
column6: the feeling Blake is talking about is that of heady isolation-- the shadowy sensation that Burial perfected with 2007's Untrue and Blake successfully brought into the singer-songwriter realm with this year's self-titled LP. As for the many dubstep artists who rely heavily on computers during gigs
column7: Blake hates them: ""To me
column8: laptops have got no place on a stage
column9: he told Pitchfork in March. And when he covers quintessential songwriters like Feist (on his album) or Joni Mitchell (on this EP)
column10: he's not trying to render them obsolete as much as join them within the canon of authentic artistes. For all of the futurist conversation surrounding him
column11: James Blake is a bit old-fashioned.

column1: When he took on Feist's ""Limit to Your Love""
column2: he infused it with water-rippling sub-bass and epic pauses while retaining its original emotionality. In that way
column3: it was the perfect cover-- he made the track his own while keeping all the key elements of the original. Enough Thunder's remake of Mitchell's 1971 ode ""A Case of You""
column4: recorded live at the BBC
column5: is different. Blake switches Mitchell's guitar for piano
column6: and leaves it at that. There's no bass. No additional production. Unlike his ""Limit to Your Love""
column7: which expanded and beautifully distorted the notion of a ""singer-songwriter
column8: the ""A Case of You"" cover contracts the term
column9: revealing Blake's limitations as an artist. Without any of his signature
column10: modern embellishments
column11: Blake's take has the feel of a stiff recital
column12: his vocal undulations ironically sounding less natural without those well-situated sonic accoutrements. The same can be said of the title track
column13: an original piano-and-voice composition. Even though Blake has been slowly unveiling his singing voice over the last two years
column14: these plain and flat tracks sound surprising. Perhaps they shouldn't. In an interview from April of last year
column15: he said
column16: ""Although I'm making this heavy dance music
column17: I sometimes just sit down at the piano and just sing. It's like that's my ultimate calling.""

column1: Enough Thunder's remaining four songs are also decidedly low-key
column2: though vastly more engaging. These are dubstep ballads reminiscent of his 2010 EP Klavierwerke
column3: except with his vocals brought to the front of the mix. As with many of Blake's best songs
column4: they're simple
column5: minimal
column6: glacial. And even though it's pretty damn hard to understand a word he's saying
column7: that melancholy core is present. It's conveyed through the elongated guitar feedback and pulsing submarine call of ""Once We All Agree""
column8: or the sound of a record skipping (or is it a hard drive clicking?) that forms the subtle foundation of ""We Might Feel Unsound""
column9: or the dolphin-like vocal whoops of Bon Iver's Justin Vernon on the duo's collaborative track ""Fall Creek Boys Choir""
column10: which is blessed (and kinda cursed) by sounding exactly like what you'd expect a Bon Iver/James Blake track to sound like. Only three-and-a-half minutes into the EP's penultimate track
column11: ""Not Long Now""
column12: do we get anything resembling a beat dropping. For those who adored Blake's heavier
column13: more rhythmic early material
column14: Enough Thunder could easily turn into Not Enough Thunder.

column1: But one of the great things about Blake is how he's willing to make a statement: in his uncompromising music
column2: in his candid and thoughtful interviews
column3: or in his choice of titles. Enough Thunder could be self-reflexive since this is easily his quietest release thus far. But it could also indicate a sort of corrective to the abrasive and cartoonish strain of dubstep that has taken grip as of late
column4: especially in America. To Blake
column5: dubstep means something intimate and internal
column6: but to the many fans of acts including Skrillex and Bassnectar-- who use their wobbling bass like hair metal guitarists used solos-- it means something exuberant and euphoric. And while Blake recognizes both feelings
column7: he certainly prefers one over the other. Talking about the faster-louder-stronger evolution of the style
column8: he recently said
column9: ""Those melodic basslines are insultingly simple and aggressive and annoying. That is now a valid genre
column10: but it certainly isn't dubstep. It's turned into something else. That's cool
column11: I'm happy about it. I'm not like
column12: 'As soon as it became mainstream it became rubbish
column13: or whatever.' It's just something different now."" It's a refreshingly mature yet opinionated take from someone who turns 23 this month. Blake is fighting the respectable fight on Enough Thunder
column14:
though the EP's totally bass-less tracks show that he needs dubstep as much as dubstep needs him.

Blue Daisy doesn't do ""light."" The few singles that the London producer has released over the past two years have sounded anything but
column2: with disjointed rhythms rubbing up against queasy tones and deep pockets of echo. Not that his music is joyless-- if you were captivated by 2009's collaborative single with French vocalist LaNote
column3: ""Space Ex""
column4: following the breadcrumbs he's dropped since has been a heady pleasure. But his music is geared toward dark landscapes.

column1: Last year's single with vocalist and frequent collaborator Anneka
column2: ""Raindrops""
column3: featured a remix of the title track from Spanish psychedelic house wiz John Talabot; like most Talabot re-works
column4: the remix was outstanding
column5: but it also sounded as if he were forcing his own style on the original's liquid gurgles and irregular beat. Some in the UK beat scene work with difficult
column6: self-set parameters-- Pearson Sound's brittle woodblock accents and Blawan's hard-as-nails acid patterns both immediately come to mind. But Blue Daisy isn't making music you can dance to. ""I don't go clubbing that much... the club thing
column7: it's not timeless
column8: he says in the press notes for this release. ""I'm making music for the long run
column9: in 10 years I still want people to be able to listen to it... I'm not down with the idea of fitting in.""

column1: Accordingly
column2: The Sunday Gift is about deep listening
column3: with plenty to get lost in and little to soundtrack a night out. There are long stretches of unsettling ambiance
column4: with jarring
column5: harsh textures and sonic mayhem erupting from the album's foundation. The tension is made tighter by elliptical strings and distant vocal samples spouting vaguely threatening political klaxon language and speaking in foreign languages. The guest vocalists-- Anneka
column6: Cinematic Orchestra collaborator Heidi Vogel
column7: UK rapper Hey!Zeus
column8: smoky singer Stac-- are treated less like stars and more like instruments in the mix
column9: slathered in their sonic surroundings. For an electronic album from someone well-versed in beatmaking
column10: the idea of rhythm almost seems secondary.

column1: Comparisons to Massive Attack's unimpeachable run in the 1990s come immediately to mind
column2: but The Sunday Gift feels a shade darker. A better comparison would be Tricky's debut
column3: 1995's Maxinquaye
column4: a record that contains its share of blasted dub and hollow-point production. Another quality Maxinquaye and The Sunday Gift share is anger
column5: something in no short supply in the UK lately. The mix of sounds and sensations has a cumulative quality. Some albums work best as front-to-back listening experiences; The Sunday Gift practically demands such attention
column6: flowing in a single-track style that makes skipping around to specific songs feel like walking into a movie in the middle. And the payoff comes in the form of the album's gorgeous closing suite
column7: which includes the woozy house of ""Spinning Channels"". For a producer who made his name with a sporadic series of singles
column8:
Blue Daisy knows how to fill a larger canvas.

If you're interested at all in the intersection of ghostly

column2: which is devoted to highlighting obscure international sounds not usually covered by Western music outlets. Her own songs wouldn't be out of place there. Mixing Julianna Barwick-style vocal layering with traditional Islamic songs

column1: As unconventional as it sounds

column3: generally speaking
column4: an affecting listen. Just hearing Al Qadiri recreate a version of this sacred music (which sounds like prayers

column6: and the addition of computerized elements creates an unsettling tension. The songs feel ancient and futuristic at the same time
column7: like there's no identifiable place or time to pin them to. If that was Al Qadiri's artistic aim here
column8: then she's achieved it
column9: but in doing so I think has sacrificed some approachability. While at times beautiful and certainly inventive

column11: and it can be difficult to differentiate between the three short original tracks. It's also free-form to the degree that it can sometimes be difficult to engage with.

column1: That's where L.A. production duo Nguzunguzu come in
column2: who close things out with a 12-minute ""megamix"" of the EP's original numbers. Also globally minded but considerably more playful
column3: Nguzunguzu are a great remix choice

column5: neon makeover
column6: adding in lots of fluttering drums
column7: handclaps
column8: and trunk-rattling bass. This is where WARN-U is most accessible and arguably most enjoyable
column9: since the addition of structure helps bring Al Qadiri's more avant-garde leanings back toward earth. That a key track here comes from an outside source detracts some from the overall impact
column10: but this is still a boundary-pushing work with strong ideas at its core. Whether or not you fall for it will likely come down to taste
column11: but at the very least
column12:
WARN-U doesn't sound like anything else.

The timing wasn't right for the Boy Better Know collective's first Tropical mix: in 2006

column9: Todd Edwards-style vocals and rough-hewn 2-step loops

column11: high-contrast aesthetic had circled back to swallow early UK garage whole. But its rave was radically dysfunctional

column1: But the unrepeatable always does repeat

column5: Rustie
column6: the Night Slugs stable)

column8: grime and bassline

column5: their glowering basslines
column6: gauzy synths

column10: ""Cool Down"". Like a hyperactive dub of Robin S.'s ""Show Me Love""

column12: an exhilarating victory lap of organ basslines
column13: xylophone riffs

column1: But with the glorious exceptions of ""Cool Down"" and ""The Stranger"" (unexpected but welcome bustling syncopated garage from Todd Edwards in a startling piece of Back to the Future-style intergenerational meddling)

column5: beautiful uncertainty. In particular

column7: less laughing-gas rave than alien ballet on a helium-cloud planet. With their delicately stabbing snares and hesitantly strobing cut-up vocals

column9: existing in a state of zero-gravity paranoid grace-- think the feel
column10: rather than the specific sound
column11: of Super Mario Bros.' underwater levels in the game's rudimentary
column12: mid-1980s incarnation.

column1: Throughout
column2: the Tropical celebration of wrongness is retained
column3: but in a manner more creeping and creepy for its near-respectability. Preditah's ""New York"" mis-remembers Skepta's earlier Tropical tunes like jungle misremembered hardcore techno
column4: its jagged
column5: asymmetrical snares and shrill
column6: sliding vocal samples subsiding into jazzy piano chords
column7: and the soothing refrain
column8: ""tell me you need me
column9: pushing U.S. garage to the max. What Preditah-- and everyone else here-- recognizes is how mixing in the smooth with the rough simply makes the latter more estranging and disquieting. This music is most exciting at its most morphological: Best of all are the interstitial moments between tracks when one contorted
column10: molten shape deliquesces into another
column11: beats interlocking in strange patterns of the residual and emergent while melting hiccup vocals form impromptu harmonies.

column1: It's this sense of being thoroughly of its time and yet out-of-time

column5:
a slippery articulation of that sense of (im)possibility in rave that is more than rave and more than dancing: the shapes we throw to constrain the aliens seething under the surfaces of our skin.

Martyn's sound isn't going to be plugged into a YouTube video with a ""lol dubstep"" punchline. KoRn aren't going to ask him for a remix. And he doesn't hang too close to either of the distant poles that James Blake placed between his own indie-friendly ambience and the aggro

column3: Great Lengths

column5: the nuanced buildups of techno and tech house influences either diverting or streamlining 2-step into 4/4.

column1: So it's worth noting that emphasizing any real connection to dubstep as most people know it doesn't do Ghost People much of a service. Sure
column2: there's an appearance by Hyperdub's in-house toaster the Spaceape on the sub-two-minute opener ""Love and Machines""
column3: but the mannered cyborg deadpan he injects into his usually resonant

column6: polyrhythmic highs of Great Lengths and the character that came with it

column2: focused ends: between the steam-hissing
column3: clap-driven Detroitisms of ""Masks"" and ""Horror Vacui""
column4: the way the title track's congas-and-hi-hats pulse buffets a spiky tech-house riff
column5: and the way he pits stammering vocal loops against clipped synth stabs and a spine-rolling locomotion in ""Twice As""
column6: there's a lot of comfortable revivalism at work. (And if that's not late-1980s enough for you
column7: check out the pitched-up integration of the spasmodic wah-wah loop that drove Public Enemy's ""Mind Terrorist"" sneaking into the 808-punctuated ""Popgun"".) Wading through a lot of old-school signifiers and contending with the overarching feel of a two-decade retreat takes a bit of effort
column8: but if you opt out of worrying your head over the nostalgic implications

column1: Martyn's said that he's aimed for a sort of Paradise Garage feel to this set of songs
column2: but the sense of uncanny vibe-catching perception and mood manipulation that Larry Levan was legendary at doesn't entirely take here. There's plenty of intensity

column5: its source material is done more justice than the artist's own back catalog-- which isn't a big loss if you care more about dancing than engaging with an artist's continuum of work. And as an extended buildup to the near-nine-minute closer
column6: ""We Are You in the Future""
column7: the first 10 tracks of Ghost People make for a good preparatory exercise. That last track might be the most audacious thing Martyn's pulled off to date
column8: a stirring buildup to everything he's gleaned from a deep engagement with his classic techno and house heritage

column10: even if it's only temporary
column11:
he's benefited from the breather.

Bad enough that the palm-muted guitar chug of ""Border Crossing"" finds Shadow trying to recreate ""She Watch Channel Zero!?"" by getting his fingers dusty digging in crates of Godsmack records. But as worrying as the conceptual aspect is

column1: But as an instrumental

You can call ""Sad and Lonely"" feminized blues haunted by CGI ghosts or whatever you choose; just know that Moby tired of it nearly a decade ago. All of which is just a long way to say that The Less You Know is the kind of forward-thinking excursion that inevitably donates its sole hip-hop track to Talib Kweli. The Miles Davis quintet of the mid-to-late 1960s occupies a weird place in the trumpeter's canon. Critics (this one included) will tell you that it isn't just the best band Miles ever led
column4: but one of the choicest small groups in jazz history. If you're not a jazz nerd
column5: though
column6: you may not know it existed. This is because the outfit-- rounded out by tenor saxist Wayne Shorter
column7: pianist Herbie Hancock
column8: bassist Ron Carter
column9: and drummer Tony Williams-- doesn't register on Miles' pop-cultural timeline. The group issued a string of brilliant studio LPs during its 1965-68 run
column10: yet there's no Kind of Blue or Bitches Brew among them; by this period
column11: Miles had pushed way beyond the sumptuously chilled-out sound of the former but hadn't arrived at the murky psych-jazz of the latter.

column1: So if the Shorter/Hancock/Carter/Williams band (often called Miles' second great quintet
column2: in deference to his stellar 1950s group) was transitional
column3: a checkpoint between consensus masterpieces
column4: why should you care that there's a new box set featuring previously unreleased live recordings from this time? Given that nearly every microphase of Davis' career has been expanded into box form by this point-- ask an expert before gifting a random one at Christmas-- casual consumers are right to be suspicious. But Live in Europe 1967
column5: which presents five concerts from October and November of that year on three great-sounding CDs and one DVD
column6: is no footnote: This set
column7: Volume 1 in a new Davis Bootleg Series built on the Bob Dylan model
column8: offers a chance to hear one of the greatest bandleaders of the 20th century push his collaborators into a creative frenzy and be pushed back in return.

column1: Aside from Carter
column2: each of these players would become giants of electric jazz (Davis and Hancock transitioned into something like pop stardom)
column3: and the period documented on this set represents their farewell to their bebop roots: both an ecstatic celebration and a ballsy deconstruction of how small-group jazz had been played for the previous two decades. Live in Europe 1967 won't soundtrack any romantic dinners or inspire dorm-room acid trips
column4: but it does show off the central thrill of jazz-- spontaneous interplay among dangerously skilled players-- as well as almost any other collection you could name.

column1: That ""among"" is key. As much as this set testifies to the leader's own vision
column2: the real takeaway is the virtuosity of other musicians
column3: and how Miles' anti-hierarchical aesthetic spurred them toward the riskiest
column4: most engaged performances of their careers. No player on this set reaches more than Tony Williams. A famously precocious drumming prodigy-- he first recorded with Miles in 1963 at age 17-- he was exactly the kind of daredevil Miles was looking for
column5: a player naturally inclined toward pure outrageousness. (By 1967
column6: he'd already explored cutting-edge improvisation on deeply unusual masterworks such as Eric Dolphy's Out to Lunch.) Williams is in particularly wired form here on the version of ""Footprints"" from November 2 in Copenhagen (disc two). During Miles' trumpet solo
column7: the drummer casts himself as Donkey Kong to Davis' Mario
column8: throwing out flaming barrels for the leader to navigate; Williams keeps time on the ride cymbal
column9: but runs a near-constant interference pattern of asymmetrical fills and swelling cymbal flurries. (You can hear the legacy of Williams' pot-stirring percussion style
column10: rarely better documented than on Live in Europe 1967
column11: in players like Deerhoof's Greg Saunier
column12: who loves to slide around a song's central pulse
column13: sending bits of rhythmic shrapnel flying at his bandmates.)

column1: As dazzling as Williams sounds
column2: what really catches the ear is how the entire band provides the improvisational boldness that Miles was after. On the Copenhagen ""Footprints""
column3: Herbie Hancock plays like a deranged outsider artist. Instead of providing a sturdy foundation underneath Wayne Shorter's saxophone solo
column4: he offers squiggly little phrases
column5: like jumbled fragments from a 20th-century classical score; on the outro
column6: he answers the horn players' theme statement with a mocking paraphrase. Ron Carter
column7: meanwhile
column8: constantly reconfigures the piece's waltzing bassline
column9: jumping between half-time and double-time
column10: and mixing in percussive slaps and low
column11: droney digressions.

column1: These performances represent an upending of the soloist-and-background model of small-group jazz up to this point. Miles' second great quintet wasn't the first to play this way; by 1967
column2: Ornette Coleman
column3: John Coltrane
column4: and Cecil Taylor had each exploded the conventions of 1940s and 1950s jazz in their own ways. Yet none of these other artists had figured out how to combine deep
column5: risky interactivity with such sustained coherence. Many of the pieces on Live in Europe 1967 play like cooperative action paintings
column6: with everyone allowed but no one entitled to be the center of attention at any given time
column7: and with the overarching logic of the compositions keeping chaos in check. It's at this stage
column8: just before the quintet's dissolution-- over the next two years
column9: as Miles engaged with electric jazz
column10: Carter would exit
column11: followed by Williams and Hancock-- that the conversation is at its most lively and lucid.

column1: Crucially
column2: though
column3: freedom
column4: as it was interpreted by this band
column5: didn't always equal volume and density. Some of the strongest moments on Live in Europe 1967 are also the calmest. During ""Masqualero"" from the November 6 Paris concert (disc three)
column6: as Miles plays a poignant
column7: slow-building solo
column8: Hancock settles into a haunting
column9: repetitive figure and Williams quiets to a whisper
column10: marking faint tempo on the hi-hat. Later
column11: when Hancock's solo begins
column12: Williams drops out entirely
column13: leaving the pianist and Carter to play a delicate
column14: free-floating duo. During the same set
column15: on ""Walkin'""-- a staple of Davis' 50s repertoire-- Williams and Carter guide Shorter into an up-tempo frenzy and then gradually fade to silence. The saxophonist moves into a rare unaccompanied passage
column16: playing an abstracted kind of bebop
column17: full of tumbling phrases and murmuring digressions.

column1: By late 1967
column2: thanks in large part to John Coltrane (who had passed away in July) and mavericks such as Albert Ayler
column3: shrieking
column4: high-density free jazz was in full flower. As you can hear in Live in Europe 1967's many boldly stripped-down moments
column5: Miles and his band were aiming for a different kind of freedom
column6: one where aggression coexisted with near-stillness. Funk was in the mix too: During the October 28 ""Masqualero"" in Antwerp (disc one)
column7: Williams and Carter keep up an infectious Latin pulse behind the soloists
column8: providing a danceable base for Shorter to tear off his heated phrases and also foreshadowing Davis' groove-based experiments
column9: which would begin in earnest on 1969's In a Silent Way.

column1: Miles clearly savored this band's broad dynamic and emotional range
column2: and constructed its sets accordingly. Unlike the quintet's studio recordings
column3: the concerts on Live in Europe 1967 take the form of unbroken medleys. On four out of the five sets here
column4: the tempestuous ""Footprints""
column5: a Shorter original
column6: segues into the Thelonious Monk favorite ""'Round Midnight""
column7: which begins each time as a beautifully sparse dialogue between Davis and Hancock. Other transitions keep these long sets feeling brisk. In Antwerp
column8: a lengthy version of Miles' hard-swinging
column9: midtempo ""No Blues""
column10: gives way to a turbulent three-minute sprint through Hancock's ""Riot""; in Paris
column11: ""No Blues"" snaps into Shorter's moody
column12: Spanish-inflected ""Masqualero""
column13: a striking shift that immediately reengages the ear. Live in Europe 1967 marks the first time we're hearing this band engage with such a wide range of material; a previous second-great-quintet live box
column14: The Complete Live at the Plugged Nickel 1965
column15: featured mainly well-worn jazz standards.

column1: As much microscopic variety as there is in these shows
column2: it's important to note that Live in Europe 1967 documents a single tour with a more or less fixed set list. Davis did vary the repertoire occasionally-- trying out ""Walkin'"" and the standard ""I Fall in Love Too Easily"" in Paris-- but buyers interested in a more diverse overview of what this band could do might be better off picking up one of their studio releases (E.S.P.
column3: from 1965
column4: and Nefertiti
column5: recorded just a few months before the shows heard here
column6: are both great starting points). Don't let the repetition scare you away
column7: though. All five concerts here have their own rewards and idiosyncrasies; the best path through the box is to treat each segment like the concert it originally was and savor it individually.

column1: The DVD
column2: which documents two shows not featured on the CDs
column3: is a sharp addition. There's a bit of arty treatment-- often two players appear superimposed in the same frame-- but on the whole
column4: these are tasteful black-and-white concert films that put you in the midst of the onstage action. You see the youthful Williams bearing down fiercely on his ride
column5: Shorter entering a closed-eyes trance while playing
column6: and Hancock cocking his ear
column7: tuning in to his bandmates' improvisations with genuine curiosity. And in the middle of it all is Miles: his usual
column8: unflappable self. This is one of our last glimpses of the trumpeter in pre-psychedelic mode; the sequined pants and wraparound shades would arrive by 1969
column9: as Miles flipped for Jimi and Sly and started co-billing with future rock legends at the Fillmore and the Isle of Wight
column10: but here he sports natty suits (the sidemen wore tuxes)
column11: embodying the same model of 50s cool that won the trumpeter a mention in a 1960 Esquire list of ""Some of the Best-Dressed Men in the United States.""

column1: That shift in fashion wasn't just superficial; Miles' music changed drastically in the period following Live in Europe 1967. LPs such as 1969's In a Silent Way and 1970's Bitches Brew are still some of the most compelling jazz-crossover experiments ever attempted. And Miles' sidemen would make equally important contributions to the movement that came to be known as fusion: Shorter with the vibrant Weather Report
column2: Hancock with his funky Mwandishi and Headhunters bands
column3: and Williams with Lifetime
column4: one of the grittiest and heaviest of the early jazz-rock groups.

column1: These impending transitions are part of why Live in Europe 1967 is essential: You get to hear exactly how these virtuosos were behaving just before the big change occurred. They were still operating in an old mode
column2: small-group acoustic jazz
column3: but they were interrogating it relentlessly
column4: seeing how far they could stretch its conventions without ditching them altogether. Before they could break into the larger world of pop

column3: and goodbye to the past
column4: declares John Cale on the first song on his new EP
column5: and no doubt
column6: he's earned the right to sing that line. For a good chunk of the past two years
column7: Cale has been touring a front-to-back performance of his 1973 chamber-pop masterpiece Paris 1919
column8: the most enduring and beloved album amid his sprawling post-Velvet Underground discography. Naturally
column9: the process of revisiting a specific body of work night after night can't help but exert some influence on an artist's subsequent move
column10: and Cale is no different. However
column11: in the case of the Extra Playful EP-- Cale's first release in six years
column12: and a teaser for a new full-length coming in 2012-- the Paris 1919 revival has seemingly inspired him not to revisit that album's orchestrated elegance
column13: but to take a reactionary leap into the opposite direction
column14: to further explore the deconstructed electronic productions and mechanized power pop heard on 2005's Black Acetate.

column1: From an artist who's always evinced an adventurous spirit and sense of humor (however dry and dark it may be)
column2: the title Extra Playful is to be received as both a promise and a threat. The ideal here is a sort of absurdist
column3: avant-garde take on adult-contemporary pop
column4: feeding straight-forward
column5: mid-tempo rock'n'roll songs and romantic balladry through synthetic sonics and alien frequencies. From the mellotron-like psychedelic textures that lend the endearing serenade ""Whadda Ya Mean By That?"" a woozy
column6: weightless feel
column7: to the Scary Monsters-esque freakazoid guitar squall that rips through the android funk of ""Perfection""
column8: Cale takes considerable glee in destabilizing his songs' structures. To wit
column9: the Francophone-sung trip-hop flashback ""Pile a L'heure"" would sound right at home on some circa-1996 chill-out compilation
column10: were it not for an unnerving background drone that provides a distant echo of Cale's viola-scraping on the Velvets' ""Venus in Furs"".

column1: But Cale's sense of playfulness can degenerate into cringe-inducing silliness
column2: as on ""Hey Ray""
column3: which works the same Beats-plus-beats formula as Black Acetate's equally ill-advised ""Brotherman"". As a satire of 1960s idealism
column4: ""Hey Ray"" is actually pretty funny
column5: as Cale plays call-and-response with his backing chorus
column6: counting off each year from the decade before reducing it to a punchline: ""1967-- it's the golden age/ 1968-- and it's all over!” (Tellingly
column7: he stops short of calling out 1969
column8: effectively dismissing the year of Woodstock
column9: Manson
column10: and the lunar landing as just another year with nothing to do.) As a song
column11: however
column12: ""Hey Ray"" is a sore-thumb irritant on an EP that otherwise carefully mediates between Cale's populist and deviant tendencies. That said
column13:
it's still guaranteed to be only the second worst thing a former member of the Velvet Underground will release this year.

Nika Roza Danilova began her Zola Jesus project with a formidable arsenal already in place. She had a richly gothic perspective honed by a rural upbringing and studies in philosophy
column2: a background in opera conjoined with a taste for industrial music
column3: and a scarred-yet-commanding voice. The albums and EPs she issued over the last couple of years were startlingly realized for such a young artist
column4: but Conatus
column5: a big record that keeps turning dark and strident
column6: makes them seem like warning shots. Most traces of obscuring murk have burned away
column7: so that every pock and ridge in the rugged
column8: elemental music stands out distinctly. It's new wave mounted on a geological scale
column9: where Danilova's solipsistic spirit-- ""I was able to communicate this universe that is my prison
column10: she said of ""Vessel""-- assumes epic proportions. Her bouts of nihilism feel nervier and more bracing in the unforgiving light of sonic clarity. The closer she gets
column11: the more enigmatic she's revealed to be.

column1: Conatus is mainly built from thundering toms
column2: majestically revolving synthesizers
column3: and warm courses of classical stringed instruments. ""I kept having these primal images
column4: she said of the music
column5: ""just quite strange landscapes and shapes I couldn't shake."" That may sound like a meaningless gloss
column6: but on ""Swords""
column7: the minute-long opening track
column8: you can hear exactly what she means. Concussive drums and scrolling mechanical textures vividly evoke a terrain. Whatever biosphere you choose to project on it (I get desert)
column9: Danilova's voice remains fixed on a faraway horizon
column10: receding as you approach. When she bursts into the foreground on ""Avalanche"" and stays there for the remainder of the album
column11: the impression of impassable distance lingers. This is partly because of the authority of Danilova's voice
column12: and partly because the music gives nothing away
column13: thrumming along with power that shades into ambivalence toward the shifting emotional register of the singing. The results are dramatic but never melodramatic
column14: as Danilova maps the dimensions of her self-imprisonment with resolve.

column1: There has always been something almost subliminally idol-killing about the Zola Jesus project
column2: and it really comes into focus here. Danilova's childhood opera aspirations are subverted into something nearly opposite. Opera singing is narrative and flows smoothly from deep within. Danilova is more allusive and tortuous. Her voice keeps getting caught in her throat
column3: where it's stressed and twisted by transient emotional surges. Though the theatricality and the epic-pop trappings may evoke artists like Dead Can Dance
column4: the vocals have the passion of blues singing. Danilova is equally iconoclastic when it comes to industrial influences like Throbbing Gristle
column5: finding ways to make abrasion as musical as possible without sacrificing tension. Her touchstones have been digested into a personal style that is much more substance than reference.

column1: She has said that she struggled with the psychological pressures of opera singing. You could regard her early run of Zola Jesus recordings as a direct reaction against intricate formality and classical perfection: an eruptive loosening of strictures and simultaneous retreat into shadow. Though some may miss the rough and raw approach of her last two EPs
column2: it's refreshing and exciting to hear music that relies on bone-hard essence rather than gauzy trimmings to create an aura of mystery. There's a newfound sense of purpose
column3: as if
column4: having tested her abilities
column5:
Danilova now understands exactly what she's doing.

For MGMT

column5: elegant cars
column6: and models for wives that a platinum record presumably affords you. No
column7: the real reward is in being elevated to a position where your words suddenly carry some weight
column8: where a simple endorsement can provide a career boost to an unsung forebear. In retrospect
column9: MGMT's wiggy
column10: divisive 2010 release
column11: Congratulations
column12: was less a premeditated ploy to alienate their more casual fans than a noble attempt to turn them onto some of Andrew VanWyngarden and Ben Goldwasser's more eccentric influences

And if but one of the 39 million people who've watched the ""Kids"" video on YouTube was inspired to pick up a Spacemen 3 record on account of seeing Pete ""Sonic Boom"" Kember's name listed in the Congratulations liner notes
column14: then his producer's fee was worth it. (Likewise
column15: when recently invited to perform a cover for Pink Floyd Week on ""Late Night With Jimmy Fallon""
column16: MGMT passed over the Floyd's deep well of FM-radio standards in favor of Syd Barrett's menacing ""Lucifer Sam"".)

column1: That same charitable spirit more explicitly informs MGMT's curatorial contribution to the LateNightTales series
column2: which draws evenly from obscure turn-of-the-1970s psych-folk

column4: and modern variations thereof. The tracklist is dotted with some notable avant-rock icons (the Velvet Underground

column6: Suicide)

column10: the mood here is almost uniformly somber

column12: ""Pink Frost"" by the Chills). More so than previous participants in the series
column13: VanWyngarden and Goldwasser take the LateNightTales concept at face value
column14: weaving together their song choices into a dark-night-of-the-soul narrative heavy on themes of isolation and 4 a.m. introspection. Even the band's own contribution is a straightforward rendition of the one Bauhaus song (""All We Ever Wanted Was Everything"") that perfectly suits this stoned-and-dethroned mood.

column1: VanWyngarden and Goldwasser take great care to ease you into this despairing headspace
column2: opening with the fortuitously timed inclusion of a track from the recently resuscitated Disco Inferno (the gorgeously glistening ""Can't See Through It"")

column4: Julian Cope's ""Laughing Boy"") with affecting instrumental interludes (Felt's ""Red Indians""
column5: the Durutti Column's ""For Belgium Friends""). However
column6: everything on this compilation feels like a set-up for and recovery from the harrowing ""Drug Song"" by Dave Bixby

column8: lines like ""How did I get this way/ It's so unreal/ I'm no longer a person/ I can't even feel"" seem especially resonant for a couple of guys who went from recording in their dorm room to suddenly finding themselves playing VIP parties at upscale department stores. MGMT may have gotten famous by ironically declaring they're fated to pretend
column9:
but with LateNightTales they take solace in building a soundtrack for when shit gets real.

Michigan trio Wolf Eyes are known for bursts of harsh noise

column1: It's hard to guess what turns the Stare Case plot will take next. I've listened to a lot of their rumblings in the past year and have yet to tire of the way their music lurks and lurches around
column2:
like the unexplained creaks of a decaying house's dimly lit basement. It seems likely that they'll eventually unleash the loud detonations that Lose Today implies and previous releases have veered toward. The impressive patience that Olson and Young have exhibited so far has certainly earned them the right to fire away.

column3: aside from leaning on a well-worn analogy between the end of a relationship and the end of a road trip
column4: is a beautiful ballad with glitchy synths. ""Nothing"" features the best hook on the album
column5: and its droplet synths and drum machine backing don't leave much room for empty space. ""Felt"" is over 10 minutes and uses pillowy synths and string sounds. The unadorned acoustic guitar in the last minute feels especially powerful. At moments like this
column6: Young Man transcends easy comparisons.

column1: Boy was a set of cheerful bedroom recordings about being a kid
column2: and you can hear Caulfield trying to run away from that sound. Ideas of Distance feels like an album about growing up. At times
column3: the vague lyrics about love and the darker vibe sound like an affectation. It's Caulfield's first foray into more mood-driven territory
column4: and it ultimately feels like a collection of pleasant sketches
column5:
unburdened by the need to resolve a sound or be especially deep.

David Toop imagined future music in his book Ocean of Sound as ""all winking lights and digital exchanges across alien cultures."" In July of this year Blur/Gorillaz frontman Damon Albarn brought a group of producers to Kinshasa in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) in an attempt to forge some of those exchanges of his own. Along for the ride were XL Recordings boss Richard Russell
column2: frequent Albarn collaborator Dan the Automator
column3: and self-styled ""R&B concrete"" producer Actress. Over the course of five days
column4: local musicians came and went
column5: bringing with them various esoteric instruments and lending their vocals to different songs
column6: while Albarn's producer-collective worked as a unit to fashion the finished product into Kinshasa One Two. Video from the recordings highlights the cross-cultural gap that needed to be bridged
column7: with Albarn communicating via hand gestures and vocal inflections
column8: and the rest of his team surrounding the local musicians with the ""winking lights"" of their digital gadgetry.

column1: In a sense this is a more fully realized vision of the Mali Music project Albarn released in 2002. That record saw him gingerly feeling out whether harmony could be extracted through the osmosis of his trip-hop and pop-oriented outlook and the work of Malian artists including Afel Bocoum and Toumani Diabaté. In contrast
column2: Kinshasa One Two is a more confident recording
column3: with Albarn still working outside his comfort zone but given little chance to think or breathe due to the self-imposed time limit on the project. All the colors feel a little brighter here
column4: especially when the energy of the Congolese musicians is allowed to shine through. With so many people involved
column5: both locally and from the imported crew of producers
column6: it's no surprise that Kinshasa One Two feels unfocused at times. There's no underlying narrative or musical structure to this record; instead it's a grab bag of ideas and impulses
column7: assembled as an approximation of the raggedy and lively way in which the recordings were conceived.

column1: For much of this album
column2: it doesn't feel like the two contrasting approaches solidify into a satisfying whole
column3: with stems of ideas stretching out toward one another but never fully germinating. Instead
column4: the focus gently rocks back and forth. At times (""Hallo""
column5: ""African Space Anthem"") the gap between DRC Music and Gorillaz is negligible. ""Hallo"" comes across like this album's ""Stylo""
column6: with its featherweight pop groove and Albarn's strained falsetto demonstrating his undeniable pop know-how. On ""K-Town"" the group moves closer to the exuberant Ethio-jazz swing of Mulatu Astatke's ""Yègellé Tezeta""
column7: while ""We Come From the Forest"" leaps into a frantic pace via the great swoons of thumb piano that click and clack into place. The latter is a stark demonstration of the successes and failures of this project
column8: where the bubbling electronics of Albarn's team become cursory and intrusive
column9: causing the vigorous backbone laid out by Bokatola System (who surface four times on this album) to feel like it would work better in isolation.

column1: So Kinshasa One Two often comes across an album that doesn't know what it wants to be
column2: and that's mostly in keeping with the nature of the way it was conceived. But the raw power of the music from the region
column3: which is presumably what attracted Albarn and his group to make this record
column4: often feels curiously lacking in this context. Perhaps that's an inevitable consequence of mixing up these different styles. But the weak
column5: Portishead-lite beats aren't missed when you hear the vocalist Love performing the song ""Love"" a cappella
column6: and the ultra-distorted hidden track at the end of the album derives a brash charm from its coarse textures. The unshackled nature of those pieces makes the contributions of the Congolese musicians elsewhere on this record feel restrained. There's none of the unhinged joy you might find on a Sublime Frequencies recording like Group Inerane's startling Guitars From Agadez
column7: which causes it to feel like unnecessary restrictions were being imposed for the sake of balance between the musicians involved.

column1: It's when the quest for equilibrium eases up that the quality rises a notch or two in either direction. The contribution of Washiba is barely detectable on the slamming
column2: LFO-circa-""Freak"" techno of ""If You Wish to Stay Awake""
column3: while the softly spun groove of ""Lourds"" is pleasingly dominated by the forceful personality of Yende Bongongo. Occasionally successful collaborations arise
column4: usually when the loopy impulses of both sides are fully indulged; the rattle and bump of ""Customs"" is particularly notable in that regard. But often it's hard to reconcile the songs here with the lively video clips from the sessions on the DRC Music Tumblr
column5: and that's its central flaw-- a little spirit got lost along the way
column6: somewhere between the performance and the final mastering
column7: possibly due to the sheer weight of numbers involved in the recording process. Despite those reservations
column8: Kinshasa One Two is worthwhile both as a cause (all proceeds from sales go to Oxfam) and as an experiment
column9:
albeit one that requires some judicious editing to extract the tracks that really count.

column3: Superchunk's Foolish perfectly sums up what made so much early-1990s indie rock so great. It was rambunctious enough for kids who craved the caffeinated buzz of punk rock at its catchiest. It was also tender enough for kids who loved hearing their own human-sized romantic foibles reflected in indie's everyperson approach to the love song. Foolish can be plenty fast and plenty noisy
column4: but it skips the meathead aggression that's a nasty side effect of so much fast and noisy music. It's unafraid of getting down to personal angst
column5: but smart enough not to get all gross and mawkish about it. It was made by a group who could have walked off stage and gone to their day jobs without having to change out of their Rock Band costumes. These are the kind of songs about bad breakups
column6: worse parties
column7: and lonely walks home that you and three of your friends might have written.

column1: Except you probably wouldn't have
column2: or couldn't have. Like a lot of early-90s indie music
column3: Foolish still projects a D.I.Y. spirit
column4: a welcoming vibe of accessibility
column5: community
column6: small-scale ingenuity. But there's nothing about the album that really says ""anyone can do this."" In fact
column7: it still sounds like a major statement
column8: albeit one from a self-effacing band. You knew from ""Slack Motherfucker"" that Superchunk would not be destined to play college-town gigs for a couple of years and then disappear. They were just more driven than the bulk of their contemporaries
column9: a work ethic that's pretty obvious from at least album no. 2 onward. You don't come up with that many intense and memorable choruses
column10: or play that tight
column11: thanks to luck. And while they had an anti-pretentious streak that was a godsend in the messianic years of grunge
column12: Foolish is where the band's ambition really blossomed for the first (but not the last) time
column13: a dozen songs that turned small-town heartbreak into loud and weirdly triumphant anthems.

column1: A big part of that is the sound of Foolish
column2: and how that sound perfectly complements the more adventurous songs. But then
column3: despite their rep as a smoking live act who do their best to simply translate that vibe in the studio
column4: Superchunk have always had a real knack for picking the right producer for a specific set of songs
column5: almost from the start. Steve Albini's typically unembellished recording on 1991's No Pocky For Kitty accentuated the wiriness of its very frantic tunes. John Reis added an almost claustrophobic
column6: garage-rock intensity to the rawer set that would make up 1993's On the Mouth. Those albums weren't exactly static
column7: though they did get a lot of mileage out of punk's joyful bashing. But Foolish is very much a big-canvas album
column8: full of stark
column9: quiet-loud shifts
column10: songs with more breathing room
column11: and grander peaks.

column1: Given that producer Brian Paulson's the guy who recorded Spiderland
column2: he seems to have been the perfect choice to give Foolish the appropriate weight and ferocity. Mac McCaughan and Jim Wilbur's guitars on ""The First Part"" clang and scrape as fiercely as any of the post-hardcore bands coming out of D.C. at the same time. But there's also a real bottom-end under all that trebly attack
column3: the kind missing from most classic indie albums of the period
column4: give or take the similarly minded Archers of Loaf. Paulson keeps things crisp and booming in the low-key moments
column5: going full-tilt when the band decides to get loud. Painful examinations of an exhausted relationship
column6: like ""Keeping Track"" and ""Revelations""
column7: start out at a slow-burn and build to a thrilling climax or three
column8: the wave of feedback coming almost as a relief after all that pensive tension. Foolish is a heavy album
column9: musically and emotionally. But it's also never a drag. That controlled sense of pacing extends not just across the songs but the whole album. There's still plenty of that old joyful bashing
column10: the caustic moments balanced by speed and sweetness. Heart-punching breakup songs like ""Driveway to Driveway"" are also bright shout-alongs.

column1: This remaster sounds just fine to me
column2: maybe a little louder in the top end as usual
column3: though my much-played and more-than-a-decade-old CD copy also sounds plenty fine. The real benefit is that Foolish is once again available on vinyl; while clearly aimed at longtime fans
column4: the newly appended live set and handful of other bonuses are still largesse on the part of Merge
column5: one the few labels that actually bothers to include something of value if you're going to repurchase an album you've already owned in multiple formats. But the original album remains the main draw
column6: especially if you just came onboard with last year's swift and colorful and totally fun Majesty Shredding. This is probably the darkest album Superchunk ever made
column7: but however serious Foolish gets
column8: there's always more of the giddy thrill of hearing a group friends who sound like they're having a blast playing together
column9: even if they're also pushing themselves to go further
column10:
giving the songs that much more all-or-nothing intensity than everyone else around them.

In 2001
column2: a Gothenburg
column3: Sweden-based duo called the Embassy released a 7"" titled Sneaky Feelings. Sharing a name with both an Elvis Costello song and a jangly 1980s New Zealand indie-pop group
column4: the four-song EP was little-noticed by Americans at the time
column5: but it marked a turning point for their city's music scene. Blending Fredrik Lindson's yearning vocals and chiming guitar chords with Torbjörn Håkansson' pattering percussion
column6: euphoric electronics
column7: and occasional exotic sample or two
column8: the record had more in common with the twee-meets-house hybrids of early-1990s Saint Etienne than with any record of its period-- even the Avalanches' similarly balmy
column9: ambitious Since I Left You. By the end of the 2000s
column10: echoes of the Embassy's aesthetic could be found in critically acclaimed albums by Jens Lekman
column11: the Tough Alliance (who named their imprint
column12: Sincerely Yours
column13: after an Embassy song)
column14: Studio (ditto for their Information imprint)
column15: Air France
column16: jj
column17: and the Honeydrips
column18: among others. Gothenburg's indie pop scene was now run by mysterious pranksters all too happy to tie the already thin line between sincerity and artifice up in sailing knots.

column1: Life in the Trenches contains 13 hard-to-find tracks
column2: most of which haven't appeared on an album. The set has a gleaming surface-level appeal
column3: with the meticulous production and bountiful melodies that are to Sweden what beer is to Milwaukee. This music's vibrant lushness is most evident on the two newest tracks
column4: the stoic strummer ""You Tend to Forget"" and loping fake-it-til-you-make-it manual ""St8""
column5: both 2009 singles--  a woman's soft moan
column6: a vaguely African vocal snippet
column7: or a bit of oceanic echo converts fairly simple songs into endlessly replayable tracks. But there's a fragile
column8: unfiltered quality to Lindson's contributions
column9: in particular
column10: that keeps the atmospheric prettiness from lapsing into wallpaper. Slick craftsmanship? Raw expression? The Embassy reinforce how moot such questions can be.

column1: Life in the Trenches also embodies most of the contradictions that make the Embassy so beguiling. The impression of earnest sensitivity that makes you want to pat the guys on the head often gives way to a mischievousness that leaves a not-unpleasant sensation that you're being had. Subtitled ""The Other Side of 2001-2011
column2: the album sure gives the impression of being a rarities compilation
column3: but one of the songs
column4: ""Information""
column5: appeared on the second of the band's two highly recommended full-lengths
column6: 2005's Tacking. Then there's 2004 single ""Flipside of a Memory""
column7: which starts with a guitar part that's jarringly similar to Nirvana's bone-simple ""Come as You Are"" riff
column8: then builds it into a shiny electro-pop stomper about old love-- vague and vaguely familiar but no less affecting for either. Whether venturing into synth-drenched instrumentals (""Puttgarden"")
column9: dubwise hip-house (""Heathrow"")
column10: or distorted electro-rock (""No Thanks"")
column11: Life in the Trenches rarely keeps its simple pleasures as simple as they may at first appear. If these guys were handing out Halloween candy
column12: you'd check it for syringes.

column2: the Embassy look finally poised to capture some of the attention they were too early for the first time around. Elements of their cryptic presentation and polished yet slightly warped sonics can be heard across the indie pop spectrum
column3: and the press materials for Life in the Trenches hint at potential new Embassy recordings in the near future. In the meantime
column4: it's worth seeking out Tacking and 2002's Futile Crimes (itself a likely inspiration for the Tough Alliance title ""Silly Crimes"") to get a fuller glimpse of the duo's style. As for the Sneaky Feelings EP
column5: the only copy I can find online is selling for upwards of $100
column6: and the other non-album releases compiled here aren't much easier to track down. So for those of us who prefer to own our music in tangible form
column7:
Life in the Trenches is the best chance many listeners have had to acquaint themselves with these overlooked architects of some of the past decade's best new sounds.

column4: Franciotti is able to create a dynamic contrast by giving equal prominence to each

column6: and while she's not as cosmically bent as either

column8: at its best

column1: Ultimately
column2: the album's song-oriented material is the most memorable. ""Romantic Streams""
column3: ""Casual Diamond""
column4: and highlight ""Stickers"" are peppered with space-age chimes and melting glissandos that feel grounded and organic. And despite all the machine noise

column7:

First you notice what's missing: gone are the gently echoing dubscapes
column2: the shivering multi-tracked female vocals
column3: the heartsore melodies
column4: the insectile arrangements
column5: the billowing evocations of desire. Finnish producer Sasu Ripatti's Luomo is nominally his ""house"" project (as distinct from excursions into stripped-back dub-techno or fractured ambience) but to date it has consistently flirted with an idea of house-- as feminine
column6: gentle
column7: lovelorn
column8: ostentatiously emotive-- quite distinct from the often quite blunt realities of the genre. Plus
column9: then
column10: is Ripatti's first album of house qua house: specifically the cooler
column11: big-room sound of tech-house circa 2006
column12: equal parts Michael Mayer and Carl Craig.

column1: If Luomo's previous work often could feel like the sound of the ""body speaking"" (to steal the title of one of his best tracks)
column2: the colder and harder surfaces of Plus are positioned between the body and the dancefloor
column3: less the sound of movement than the sounds that make you move. Song takes a backseat to groove: while most of the tracks here feature gentle ""Computer Love""-style male vocals (courtesy of the Chicago Boys)
column4: they are less the music's emotional center than a framework around which Ripatti can weave his typically intricate
column5: hypnotic arrangements. Only on the fragile
column6: trebly new wave of ""Form in Void"" and the seductive schaffel of ""Immaculate Motive"" does Ripatti gesture toward the glittering disco-pop of his prior work.

column1: This feels like a deliberate aesthetic shift. Previously
column2: many of Luomo's finest tracks featured late-blooming hooks that would carry the tune's second half in euphoric or melancholy new directions. By contrast
column3: the best moments on Plus tend to turn inward
column4: homing in on the beat until its urgency is almost too close to your ears. The effect can be like sitting in the front row at the cinema
column5: the peripheral details of melodic color and vocals overwhelmed by the abstract throb of the hyper-percussive
column6: multi-tiered groove. In particular
column7: the massive climaxes of ""How You Look"" and especially ""Make My Day"" (by some distance the album's finest moment) feel designed to burn out your senses with an overload of physical intensity.

column1: These tracks stand and fall on their own robust physicality: ""Happy Strong"" features an inane vocal hook and almost no melody to speak of
column2: but its immense
column3: banging groove (all slamming snares and delectable hand-clap counter-rhythms) makes it an album highlight. Only on ""Good Stuff"" does Ripatti's new aesthetic veer off course entirely
column4: spending nine minutes trying but failing to achieve lift-off through chattering Chicago-house revivalism. Here
column5: the groove isn't compelling enough to distract from the perfunctory song it props up.

column1: If Plus ultimately is only the fourth-best Luomo album (after 2008's Convivial and certainly Ripatti's peerless first two albums under the moniker)
column2: it's because maintaining that level of intensity across entire tracks
column3: let alone a whole album
column4: is near impossible
column5: while the moments in between the peaks no longer can coast on the singularity of the producer's sound. The less-exciting stretches on previous albums at least might have boasted a bruised-sounding bassline or delicately mutated vocal harmonies to establish a sense of unity with the climaxes. On Plus
column6: the periods in between the climaxes can slip more easily into the category of fine-- but rather less-distinct-- German-sounding tech-house.

column1: The importance of this criticism depends on how invested you are in house as dancefloor music first and foremost: Ripatti's music demands to be judged purely on the terms of the genre it inhabits
column2: and the way that genre interacts with the bodies of dancers. If you come looking for house with an obvious point of difference
column3: this decision seems puzzling
column4: but if you're prepared to forget the name ""Luomo"" and simply lose yourself in the groove
column5:
then Plus is as involving and engaging as any dance music you'll hear this year.

column3: ""Shia LaBeouf and Michael Bay Got in a Really Big Fight Over Feist."" To prepare for an emotional scene in Transformers 3

column5: ""spit [was] flying

column7: it tells us even more about where we're currently at
column8: culturally speaking
column9: with Feist. Even among Hollywood titans
column10: she's divisive. She has probably
column11: over the past couple of years
column12: helped an infinite number of jocks and action stars get in touch with their latent emotions (""It's a little feminine
column13: LaBeouf told the Los Angeles Times of ""Brandy Alexander""

column1: And yet
column2: her third album
column3: Metals
column4: is full of dynamic outbursts. There's the chorus of austere
column5: male shouts that punctuates ""A Commotion""
column6: the towering

column11: Metals is a record animated with
column12: as she put it
column13: ""the movement of a lot of humans."" Though her least immediate album-- it lacks The Reminder's pop showstoppers or the charm of Let It Die's restless genre-hopping-- Metals is a vivid evocation of a place that touches on fittingly vast themes about nature
column14: love
column15: and life itself.

column1: To record Metals
column2: Feist-- along with her trusty producers Chilly Gonzales and Mocky (who've been working her since she was Peaches' hypegirl back in early-2000s Toronto)-- headed out to Big Sur and built a studio on the side of a cliff. All the things you might associate with the area (majestic expanse
column3: outdoorsiness
column4: and Kerouac-sized spiritual interrogation) seep into Metals' sound
column5: which conjures panoramic vistas with quiet ease. String and brass arrangements (the latter of which heavily feature avant-saxophonist Colin Stetson) are omnipresent but never overworked: check out the way they briefly balloon into the frame toward the middle of ""Anti-Pioneer"" and then gracefully recede a moment later. Metals is invested in subtle
column6: textural detail and shifting dynamics; it sometimes stays so quiet that a whole flock of birds would feel compelled perch on it
column7: and then in the next breath it does something surprising enough to send them scattering in a flurry.

column1: Metals is the Meek's Cutoff of Feist records
column2: both in the way it eschews the traditional rules of the crowd-pleasing blockbuster
column3: and also because there's a lot of talk about pioneers and mountains. Nature imagery is everywhere: the serene meditation ""The Circle Married the Line"" escapes the busy squiggles of modern life (""I'll head out to horizon lines/ Get some clarity oceanside"") by boiling down a sunset to its simplest geometric forms
column4: while the gorgeous acoustic number ""Cicadas and Gulls"" takes flight: ""The land and the sea/ Are distant from me/ I'm in the sky."" Metals displays a shift in Feist's perspective as a songwriter; after The Reminder she's said she's now less interested in writing songs that could be read as intimate and personal but instead crafting lyrics that read almost like sparse proverbs. (She's likened some of the lines on Metals to ""adages and morals that you find embroidered in junk shops."") The resulting tracks feel universal
column5: and not unlike Bill Callahan's Apocalypse

column7: erratic ways of human beings.

column2: earbud-wearing
column3: silhouetted elephant in the room: there's no ""1234"" on this record. In fact
column4: though it's by no stretch a difficult album

column3: she got it so right: An unhurried guitar lick and the bluesy gust of her vocals roll like tumbleweeds over a minimal soundscape as she sings about a woman who was used to moving but

column9:
and Feist herself-- shifting between moments of repose and restless explorations of new frontiers.

column3: and Ornette Coleman. The music was so animally energetic that it took me a while to realize how off-base this early impression had been. But while those free-jazz shamans embraced volatility
column4: Stetson is much more aligned with minimalists like Philip Glass
column5: which is to say that he restricts himself and knows exactly where he's going. Glass' longtime saxophonist Dickie Landry
column6: whose excellently mellow 1977 album Fifteen Saxophones was reissued earlier this year
column7: provides an intriguing precedent. Landry was a member of the Philip Glass Ensemble who played on Music in Twelve Parts
column8: a piece whose edge-of-madness harmonic grind is in full force on Those Who Didn't Run. The title's whiff of courageous endurance gets more and more apt as Stetson pulverizes daisy-chained squalls for 10 minutes at a time
column9: in two uncompromising arcs that exclude the airier respites of Judges.

column1: Like Bryce Dessner and Glenn Kotche
column2: Stetson adeptly straddles pop and the academy. And like Merrill Garbus of tUnE-yArDs
column3: a big part of his magnetism derives from a combination of unusual music and bold feats of physical daring. A one-man polyphony machine
column4: Stetson sets his feet in a resonant room and wires himself up like a cyborg
column5: with microphones on the walls
column6: all through his bass sax
column7: and on his throat. Pointedly ignoring decades' worth of looping and overdubbing technology
column8: he blows the bejeezus out of arcane contrapuntal variations over and over again
column9: with phantom sounds gathering around the deep pulse. The music seems weirdly sentient because only the continuous cycle of breath pumping through it keeps it alive.

column1: You wonder why Stetson doesn't just turn blue and fall down
column2: and how one instrument can make so many different noises at once. Circular breathing accounts for the former (Stetson must play a mean didge) while inventive mixing accounts for the latter. The clack of keys becomes an insistent rhythm track
column3: microphone signals fry into ambient ozone
column4: and ghost voices reverberate through the reed. Not only does this technique make brainy variations feel hot and haunted
column5: but it gives us a fresh vantage on the saxophone itself. Though it plays a highly respectable role in jazz
column6: the instrument takes on cheesier cultural baggage as you move outward
column7: from marching bands to soft pop to Sergio. By enlarging the inner workings of the sax
column8: Stetson demolishes clichés to unleash fresh
column9: unexpected energies. It's like being inside an enormous brass tunnel full of windy byways and slamming valves
column10: at once exhilarating and frightening.

column1: Here
column2: Stetson pits the low end versus the high; granular texture versus crystalline purity; deep
column3: earthy groove versus high
column4: watery shine. On the A-side
column5: grungy riffs churn over a thumping substructure of bass and key action
column6: and on the B-side
column7: the bottom falls out and we're transported to a completely different world
column8: one cleansed of heavy metal and drone-rock traces. Stetson's horn spirals through an upper-register series of intervals that seem to be trying to wrench themselves free of each other
column9: and the disparity between prettiness and conflict is riveting. Though this EP plows a narrower row than Judges
column10: Stetson still manages to show us two very different aspects of his visceral minimalism. The only downside for me is that his music really thrives on accumulation
column11: which is to say that it thrives in longer formats. I suspect that this EP serves as a palate-cleanser for the final volume of the New History Warfare trilogy
column12:
clearly polarizing Stetson's impulses for incantatory force and eerie beauty before drawing them back into a complex whole.

"|15876.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15876-those-who-didnt-run/|7.8|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17003/homepage_large.c66ffc4e.jpg|Monkeytown|2978.0|Modeselektor|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Monkeytown']|2011-10-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:47.186317|"

With their last couple of albums
column2: Modeselektor have proved themselves artists with a range of far-flung good ideas that just can't seem to coalesce into one big concept. But if the Berlin duo has never been entirely easy to categorize-- hip-hop with techno sensibilities or vice-versa
column3: with recent forays into all-purpose et cetera-step (Modeselektion Vol. 01)-- it helps quite a bit that they've never been self-serious purists. As it happens
column4: their new album
column5: Monkeytown
column6: should benefit from the fact that there's still a boom market for nebulously connected circles of ""bass music."" Listening selectively
column7: it's pretty easy to hear Modeselektor picking up on some post-Flying Lotus signifiers.

column1: Opener ""Blue Clouds"" seeps out like a slightly more placid take on Cosmogramma highlight ""...And the World Laughs With You""
column2: swapping out its frantic
column3: future-junglist breaks for a less-cluttered rhythm and letting the synths simmer instead of boil. Busdriver feature ""Pretentious Friends"" rides off a buzzing throb that fits the MC's wiseass art-rap credentials well
column4: though the most interesting sonic tweaks-- and maybe the most disorienting ones-- are all the hitches and hiccups and pitch-warps that they embed into his voice
column5: like a mangled stretch of magnetic tape that can't quite find the right tracking. ""Humanized"" is a nauseatingly wobbly Anti-Pop Consortium team-up teeming with winking
column6: retro-space-age analog noise.

column1: And the highest-profile cosign comes in the form of Thom Yorke; ""Shipwreck"" and ""This"" highlight his ability to sound more emotionally compelling the more his voice is dissected. The former track's ramped-up
column2: nervous-twitch ambience and the latter's massive yet isolated empty-arena echo both loop snatches of half-formed words and phrases into hypnotic swells that are bobbed and tossed by roiling
column3: skittering rhythms-- it's heady stuff
column4: easy to sink into.

column1: But don't look for that sort of Brainfeeder-like atmosphere to run through the whole album-- there are more than a few tracks that refuse to let Monkeytown be defined by a single operating motive. ""Evil Twin"" in particular busts out a more straightforward take on techno
column2: bumping a 4/4 beat that's as upfront as some of the glitchier tracks are evasive. ""German Clap"" flirts with UK-funky rhythms in a way that seems to beg from a titular scene of its own
column3: ascending synth chords clashing against descending
column4: liquid-burble bass.

column1: The club tracks
column2: the more experimental IDM-skewing cuts (""Blue Chords"")
column3: and the Yorke collaborations form their own kinds of peaks
column4: but Modeselektor pull off accessible
column5: pop-friendly stuff just as well. Hearing Miss Platinum go from disconnected voice-chopping to euphorically harmonizing with herself on ""Berlin"" gives the slow-ride electro-R&B groove some real gravity
column6: especially when all those parts finally reassemble into her untouched human voice for the hook. And even if the delicate melodrama of ""Green Light Go"" seems a bit too self-serious amidst an otherwise playful and energetic collection of songs
column7: it still builds tension in a way that manages to sell its wistfulness as something legitimate. The album may be scattershot
column8:
but perhaps that doesn't matter so much when it's delivered out the barrel of a 12-gauge.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16991/homepage_large.c277205d.jpg|In the Pit of the Stomach|27752.0|We Were Promised Jetpacks|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Cat']|2011-10-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:47.757597|"

Preconceptions are usually kind of a bitch
column2: but they've mostly worked in this Scottish band's favor. Knowing that they were championed by Frightened Rabbit on MySpace and then signed to FatCat would have you believe that they're similarly aligned as scrappy
column3: heart-on-sleeve romantics. And yes
column4: their 2009 debut
column5: These Four Walls
column6: delivered on that notion
column7: however intermittently. But based on the name We Were Promised Jetpacks
column8: you might think they're a hyper-stimulated and wordy post-hardcore/emo act too. That's also kinda true. Shuttling between the sound of weathered
column9: masculine brooding and the lyrical sentiment of immobilized
column10: teenage pining
column11: they're something of a genre of one that's managed to sound perfectly compatible as an opener for both Twilight Sad and Jimmy Eat World.

column1: There was hope that These Four Walls
column2: like most overeager and uneven debuts from killer live acts
column3: was a dry run for inevitable greatness once their execution caught up with their energy. And yet
column4: while more focused in just about every way conceivable (no more eight-minute songs with glockenspiels)
column5: In the Pit of the Stomach can't seem to move things forward
column6: weirdly sitting in a purgatory of sounding like an anthemic rock record without the actual anthems.

column1: Feeling stuck is certainly something WWPJ identify with. As with These Four Walls
column2: the pervading feeling expressed on In the Pit of the Stomach is foretold by its title: a sense of jittery readiness as reaction to the unease of being trapped inside yourself. Fittingly
column3: WWPJ's musicianship sports the tightly-coiled motions of someone trying to bust out of restraints-- drill-like riffs and insistent hi-hats are punctuated by short
column4: almost epileptic bursts of distortion and drum rattle. Despite the roomy lengths and arena aspirations of these songs
column5: Peter Katis' strapping production casts WWPJ as meticulous and muscular post-punk militants at their core. Though they don't aspire to the jackbooted combativeness of WU LYF or Iceage
column6: Thompson's melodies do have an orderly
column7: call-and response aspect to them.

column1: And yet this newly disciplined sound mostly reveals a band that has the earnest diligence of foot soldiers but not the spark of leadership. Catharsis is something they just don't have the patience for
column2: and In the Pit of the Stomach blasts out of your speakers from ""Circles and Squares"" and never yields
column3: buzzing constantly rather than building toward moments of rabble-rousing revelation.

column1: While posing as assaults
column2: ""Medicine"" and ""Picture of Health"" ingratiate their jagged hooks subtly through insistent repetition. But elsewhere
column3: WWPJ typically treat verse-chorus structure like a straitjacket with the longer instrumental passages feeling just as maxed-out for radio readiness: first single ""Act on Impulse"" patiently works through some pretty
column4: post-rock guitar figures during its build-up to the verse
column5: yet it ends five minutes later without reaching any kind of gratification-- it's just a single with an unusually long intro. The LP's one true blowout comes halfway through ""Sore Thumb""
column6: and it requires a preceding production trick where you hear Thompson's voice
column7: stripped of all studio treatment
column8: sounding like he's doing practice takes in a hallway. I've heard this done on Snow Patrol records. And while I get the feeling ""Pear Tree"" was intended as an epic
column9: exhaustive closer because it's six minutes long
column10: it draws to a close pounding as loud as anything else on the record. This leaves Pit to end with the vague sense that you've been pummeled for the last 45 minutes but with no real recollection of the specifics. It's the sort of thing that can feel thrilling in perhaps five-minute bursts
column11: but the evenness of Pit's landscape makes it hard for me to say which five minutes that is.

column1: Admittedly
column2: it's easy to be a sucker for Thompson's Edinburgh accent and to assume it lends a wizened gravitas to his grief over enlisting in ""an army that only fights boredom"" and painting rainbows black. But unlike the rangy vocals of benefactors like Scott Hutchison and James Graham
column3: there's something wooden about Thompson's intonation that betrays his hot-blooded emotional state. For the most part
column4: WWPJ show up to each track with the same bundle of nervous energy and simply churn until they wear themselves out. Though Thompson's plaintive wails and the brawny playing of the rhythm section give the impression of relentless and differentiable activity
column5:
they're holding patterns all the same.

James Leyland Kirby is an ambient musician whose records tend toward the romantic and sentimental. Tinkling bells
column3: faraway strings layered with static
column4: soft-pedal piano lines ready to soundtrack footage of rain falling from the window of a slow-moving train: This is Kirby's world
column5: and in Kirby's world the moments are lost
column6: the opportunities missed
column7: and the sky gray
column8: then black
column9: than gray again.

column1: I suspect this all sounds heavy-handed
column2: but what makes his music appealing to me is its curious lightness. It takes a teenager to be melodramatic
column3: but it takes an adult-- an adult capable of the weird human reflex called nostalgia-- to achieve Kirby's levels of ambivalence and indifference. Eager to Tear Apart the Stars-- his first full-length under his own name since 2009-- is melancholy
column4: sure
column5: but it doesn't strike me as the kind of album designed to make its listeners melancholy. Its operative verbs are drift
column6: float
column7: shrug.

column1: A record like this takes poise and patience-- aside from the grim opener ""The Arrow of Time""
column2: I almost never feel any muscle
column3: any sense that a mood is being forced on me. And yet at nearly every turn music like this seems eminently delicate: A stray sound could shake the listener out of whatever dream the album has put them in. There's depth here
column4: too
column5: and enough bass
column6: grain
column7: and atmosphere to make the music as engaging at louder volumes as it is passive at quieter ones.

column1: On my first few listens I thought of a quote from the filmmaker and archivist Jonas Mekas that my editor
column2: Mark Richardson
column3: quoted in his review of Fennesz's Endless Summer
column4: in talking about the look of decaying Super-8 film footage: ""time is laying a veil of poetry over them."" Eager is filled with moments where static is employed as a texturing device and sounds have a recycled
column5: distant
column6: and broken-down character. In 2011
column7: this tactic is nothing new-- nostalgia is just a clipped signal away. Ultimately
column8: though
column9: that is where the album's poetry comes from: hearing Kirby's sweet
column10: sad piano and string lines sound like they're crumbling as they reach our ears.

column1: Eager is Kirby's second great album of 2011: He's also responsible for the Caretaker project
column2: under which he released An Empty Bliss Beyond This World near the beginning of summer. The alias isn't really just for the sake of the artist's ego: While both this record and and An Empty Bliss have an unrepentantly nostalgic quality to them
column3: the Caretaker records have become narrowly focused on microedits of pre-war parlor and ballroom music
column4: but the music Kirby's releasing under his own name has a more cinematic
column5: less conceptually unified feel. I'm not sure one's better than the other: There's something satisfying about how contained the Caretaker sound is
column6: and something equally satisfying about how permissible-- and personal-- Kirby sounds under his own name.

column1: I can't say as many nice things about the two Intrigue & Stuff 12""s he's put out this year. The first has a vaguely techno conceit to parts of it
column2: with more clearly defined and rhythmically rigid synthesizers. The second
column3: for interested parties
column4: is closer to Eager
column5: but denser and outrightly threatening. In both cases what I think turns me off about them-- and what turns me on about Eager-- is the constant feeling of Kirby's presence
column6: pushing buttons
column7: triggering things
column8: mixing sounds together. And that brings me back to what makes Eager a compelling and frankly weird album: At times
column9:
it sounds like there's nobody there making it.
