0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17012/homepage_large.28f5ca9e.jpg|The Hunter|2699.0|Mastodon|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Reprise']|2011-09-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:20:49.856990|"

Mastodon chose the right time to scale back the concepts. For 2002's Remission
column2: they focused on fire; 2004's Leviathan
column3: water (and Moby Dick); 2006's Blood Mountain
column4: earth (plus a vision quest up the side of the title's mountain); and 2009's Crack the Skye
column5: aether
column6: linking astral travel
column7: wormholes
column8: Rasputin
column9: possession
column10: and the suicide of drummer Brann Dailor's sister Skye. There's no way to follow that
column11: so for their fifth album
column12: The Hunter
column13: they offer 13 stylistically and lyrically varied tracks. The title references the death of guitarist/vocalist Brent Hinds' brother
column14: who suffered a heart attack while hunting last December
column15: but there's no overarching thread. Despite the heaviness of that kind of information
column16: the record works best as a catchy guilty-pleasure party album-- there's a song about sex in zero gravity
column17: another about the Swamp Thing
column18: one titled ""Bedazzled Finger Nails"".

column1: Instead of worrying about a storyline they can barely explain in interviews
column2: Mastodon put the complexities into the songwriting and vocal harmonies. The Hunter is longer than Crack the Skye by a couple of minutes
column3: but it feels briefer. As the band itself noted early on
column4: it comes over like a Mastodon mixtape. The Atlanta sludge veterans have never taken the easy way out
column5: sure
column6: but they've also never cycled between so many styles: We get crusty snarling dotted with spaced-out moments (""Black Tongue"" and its ""I burned out my eyes/ I cut off my tongue"" welcome)
column7: funky
column8: psychedelic heavy rock (""Curl of the Burl"")
column9: crazy keyboard noodles (""Bedazzled Finger Nails"")
column10: meditative
column11: progressive Milky Way excursions (""Stargasm"")
column12: hammering tech-psych anthems with crazy-climber riffs (""Octopus Has No Friends""). Outside that
column13: ""Blasteroid"" could almost pass as Torche. Really
column14: it's like pressing buttons at random on a jukebox.

column1: Mastodon 2011 are largely about restless experimentation. The Hunter is the quartet's first collection with cover art by someone other than Paul Romano. They recorded it with hip-hop and Maroon 5 producer Mike Elizondo
column2: the guy who co-wrote 50 Cent's ""In Da Club""
column3: and the Game's ""Higher"".  It also features the first track sung entirely by Dailor. They use a Theremin. The sound is certainly chewier and
column4: at times
column5: more pop than usual. Two of the best songs--  the fuzzed sing-along ""All the Heavy Lifting"" and the slowly unfurling title track-- deliver memorable
column6: vaguely radio-friendly choruses. But there's also the tech-heavy weirdness of ""Bedazzled Finger Nails""
column7: a pretty
column8: stumbling track that offers mathy psychedelia with a variety of vocal approaches (though I could do without the synth squiggles).

column1: As you might expect from a record this jumbled
column2: there are parts that lag. Here
column3: they sequenced three duds together
column4: the generic classic rock of ""Dry Bone Valley""
column5: the mid-tempo ""The Thickening""
column6: with its sexy oohs and ahhs
column7: and Brann Dailor's Syd Barrett-like ""The Creature Lives""
column8: a song that opens with more than a minute of Moog and laughter. (Note: It's not a great idea to follow one of your throwaway tracks with more than a minute of Moog and laughter.) They come back strong with ""Spectrelight""
column9: a burnt offering sung by  regular guest Neurosis' Scott Kelly
column10: and the pretty finale
column11: ""The Sparrow""
column12: a track dedicated to the band's accountant's wife
column13: who died of stomach cancer. Lyrically
column14: they simply
column15: rather beautifully
column16: repeat her supposed life motto: ""Pursue happiness with diligence.""

column1: It feels like The Hunter's motto
column2: too. I do miss the grit
column3: heavy-lifting
column4: and larger excavations of their earlier work-- nothing merits tossing around the word ""epic"" here-- but what they do
column5: and what they've become
column6: is fascinating. I ended my review of Blood Mountain by jokingly referring to the guys as the new ""Monsters of Rock."" They went on to play the festival of the same name the next year
column7: but I was more talking about the ascension of a new brand of mainstream heavy metal
column8: one that would sit beside Metallica
column9: Megadeth
column10: Slayer

Remember when everyone was having panic-attack cred-spasms over skinny-jeans rap? Thinkpieces about indie appropriation
column2: flame wars about ""real hip-hop
column3: stock insults hefted toward Billyburg trusties-- good times
column4: right? Well
column5: not every pioneer goes unrewarded. Five years after the Diplo-sanctioned fuck-bass shtick of Spank Rock's YoYoYoYoYo set critics' brows furrowing
column6: there's a lucrative boom in party music that turns the once-communal dancefloor/club experience into overblown swag-level competitions between Red Bull-addled alpha males. And if you push hyperactive pussy-popping anthems to enough well-meaning lefty skeptics who are otherwise hesitant to buy into strip-club chic
column7: eventually that noise will ricochet its way toward the mainstream. Anything that skeevy to the point of being problematic has to have real transgressive pop cred
column8: right?

column1: So waiting a good half-decade between the debut and the follow-up shouldn't matter too much. Not with an updated production sound and some choice gigs sharing bills with Ke$ha and LMFAO to back the sophomore effort. The beats on this new album signal a shift in emphasis from Spank Rock as self-contained Hollertronix-satellite rapper/producer group to Spank Rock as MC showcase
column2: with YoYoYoYoYo's sonic architect XXXChange taking a backseat to a new palette heavy on German electro-scuzz specialist Boys Noize. It all bumps distractingly enough
column3: sure. The opening salvo of ""Ta Da"" builds off a decent swath of plink-thump minimalism that serves as a little early snap-music nostalgia
column4: and the Santigold-boosted ""Car Song"" pulls off a good mixture of jittery
column5: late-nite
column6: uptempo
column7: indie dance-punk bombast. Even the token sop to indie-punk
column8: the Death Set collaboration ""Energy""
column9: has a neat interpolation of the break from Can's ""Vitamin C"" underpinning its bursts of freakout rock. The worst you can say about the production is that it can be sort of anonymous-- there's a song called ""#1 Hit""
column10: and I bet you know what it sounds like without listening-- but it's nominally the sort of stuff an engaging presence on the mic can overcome.

column1: Which brings us to the problem of Spank Rock himself. After originally carrying himself like a smartassed joker on the debut
column2: he now comes across as someone more ambivalently unserious. Everything Is Boring & Everyone Is a Fucking Liar is the title
column3: and maybe the easiest joke on the whole album: the cynical veneer on a loosely bundled collection of bass-rap tics that are delivered from a vantage point you can't quite see. There's no point in trying to sneak bass music through under cover of irony these days
column4: but the edge that sparked Spank Rock's best moments back in the day either isn't there or flails around without direction. His rhymes are occasionally vaguely political
column5: sometimes intentionally disingenuous
column6: but never confident enough to tell you just where he stands. Somewhere between the rote
column7: my-dick-rules bragging (""Hot Potato""; ""Nasty""; ""Race Riot on the Dance Floor"") and the even more rote
column8: I'm-so-fucked-up material (this is a dude who requests coke in place of salt on the rim of his margarita in ""Cool Shit"")
column9: it's easy to hear that title's disillusioned cynicism in the spaces where the actual persona should be. YoYoYoYoYo at least tried to let some of the sketchier meat-market catcalls off the hook because they were funny; here it's just a bunch of boilerplate sex raps that seem a little too possessive to be fun.

column1: Trying to engage the pop market with something there's already a surplus of is tricky enough when you're outsized enough to justify it. For Spank Rock
column2: it just gets exhausting. He's a stylistic free-agent with a flow that drifts between Baltimore club
column3: Southern bass
column4: post-Guetta house-rap
column5: and the occasional halfway-inspired Prince pastiche (""Baby""). But if his enthusiasm for genre-hopping gives him carte blanche to work his hyperactive
column6: higher-register yawp into some interesting shapes
column7: it does so at the expense of attention-getting things to say. And if lines stick out
column8: it's usually because they're kind of tone-deaf-- ""now I wanna go west (like Kanye?)/ I was thinkin' more Cornel"" (wow
column9: someone just heard his first Das Racist track). But his flow is either too rushed or too buried in the mix to jump out. What you're left with half the time for a lyrical identity is a hook
column10: and the thing about hooks is that they work best if you can shout along without either feeling like an asshole or hoping everyone catches your scare quotes. If you can pull that off with lines like ""shake it 'til my dick turns racist"" (""Race Riot"") or ""I can make you famous/ He can buy you bottles but I can buy you Billboard"" (""#1 Hit"")
column11:
congratulations on overcoming the crippling burden of self-awareness.

J. Cole is the kind of rapper who worries aloud
column3: and frequently
column4: if he's getting too deep for his own songs. A St. John's University magna cum laude graduate raised in poverty by a single mother
column5: Cole distinguished himself in his early career as much through effort as talent. Over a string of fiercely earnest
column6: frequently impressive mixtapes
column7: he rapped in writerly thickets in which the semicolons and embedded clauses were audible
column8: and he produced all his own tracks. He became a leading light of the conscious-rap crowd
column9: who
column10: always eager for a viable mainstream entrant in rap's ongoing culture wars
column11: fervently embraced him. And then
column12: perhaps inevitably
column13: Jay-Z swooped down and signed him.

column1: The resulting major-label debut
column2: Cole World: The Sideline Story
column3: which finally saw release this week
column4: is shaping up to be an actual Big Moment for Cole: Despite a tepid radio presence
column5: it is projected to sell nearly 250
column6: 000 copies. Those are startling first-week numbers for a new rapper these days
column7: and they assure that J. Cole will get at least a partial promenade through the spotlight. People appear to care deeply about this guy. But it's difficult to imagine why from the evidence of this studiously bland and compromise-riddled record
column8: which seems to be searching for the meeting point of every conceivable middle.

column1: About half the album bears Cole's production signature: a glimmering update on 1990s jazz-rap
column2: spiked with live-sounding boom-bap drums. As a rap aesthetic
column3: it's about as rigidly conservative as they come. But Cole is admirably committed to it
column4: and he fleshes it out with surprising musical detail-- backup vocals
column5: comping jazz guitars
column6: lots and lots of grand piano. The songs that stick to this template feel warm
column7: pleasant
column8: and Cole-ish. The rest of Cole World is a 2011-era pop-rap project with a varying success rate: the madcap
column9: syncopated single ""Can't Get Enough"" feels like a lost transmission from 2002-era rap radio
column10: and it succeeds only insofar as it compels you to imagine how much better an '03-era T.I.
column11: or even N.O.R.E.
column12: would have finessed the beat than does Cole
column13: who deflates the track's bounce.

column1: It doesn't help that Cole brings the least-flavorful bars of his career to his debut
column2: aiming
column3: most likely
column4: for something more universal than his diaristic mixtapes. The few glints we get of his personal life are intriguing: ""Lost Ones"" is a slippery and well-conceived
column5: two-sided argument between Cole and his baby mother over whether they will keep the child. ""Breakdown"" affectingly recounts his late-in-life reunion with his father. But otherwise he seems to be playing by implied
column6: major-label debut rules: keep it simple
column7: slow it down
column8: don't lose anyone. The result is like glutinous paste that results from mashing together Drake
column9: Kanye
column10: and Big K.R.I.T. and straining out what makes them interesting.

column1: Jay himself
column2: the benefactor figure
column3: pops up twice
column4: and both times his presence subtly undermines the marquee star. On his guest verse for ""Mr. Nice Watch
column5: he flexes his double -time flow and coolly blows Cole out of the water. He's heard again on the intro to ""Rise and Shine
column6: musing in a sampled snippet from his 2000 concert film Backstage on his ideal signee: rapping over his breakfast cereal
column7: gunning for Jay's own spot. ""I'mma find him
column8: though
column9: and sign him; I don't want no problems
column10:
he says and there is a startlingly predatory ring to his laugh. J. Cole certainly posed no threat to Jay-Z's crown; he's too humble and lacks charisma. But maybe the next up-and-coming rapper to successfully forge and remain in his own lane is the one who refuses Jay's help.

Shudder to Think's Pony Express Record remains one of the strangest artifacts of the post-Nirvana major-label gold rush
column2: a nugget of operatic
column3: sinister
column4: and gleefully self-aware art punk released at the peak of male angst-driven grungemania. Even the band's unexpected 2008 reunion was both of and against its time
column5: a beacon of clear-eyed virtuosity and precision amidst an encroaching tide of gauzy 1990s nostalgia. The reunited Shudder to Think toured sporadically for a couple of years
column6: released a live album (2009's Live From Home)
column7: and once again disbanded.

column1: WAND is Shudder to Think singer Craig Wedren's first album since he got the band back together
column2: and it is exactly the album you'd hope somebody would make after reengaging with complex
column3: dynamic music. While 2005's Lapland was stately and muted in its execution
column4: WAND is falling all over itself with ideas. Wedren's voice commands rising and receding string sections
column5: intricate multi-part harmonies
column6: and subtle electronic textures that bloom into full-on rock arrangements. The album's title is apt; though Wedren is joined by a formidable cast of supporting players
column7: much of the record feels conjured out of thin air.

column1: Wedren possesses one of those rare rock voices that is both distinctive and versatile
column2: and he covers a good deal of expressive ground on WAND. On Lapland
column3: Wedren was able to coax a surprising amount of understated sweetness from his voice. Here
column4: Wedren combines that sweetness with the eerie trills of Shudder to Think and the glammy vamp of his pre-Lapland quasi-dance project
column5: Baby. The resulting cognitive dissonance is one of WAND's greatest assets; the opening verse of ""Make Me Hurt You"" might be the most irresistibly catchy and unabashedly Classic Pop thing Wedren has ever recorded
column6: but the song's titular chorus proves
column7: uh
column8: awkward to sing along with.

column1: Thankfully
column2: no such reservations are present in Wedren himself. The man seems to be having an absolute blast here; his mugging
column3: cursing
column4: strutting
column5: cooing
column6: and wailing make for the most exhilarating moments on WAND. At his best
column7: Wedren spins incongruous-seeming sounds and gestures into shapely songs
column8: buttressed by smart
column9: lively arrangements. On WAND's weaker tracks
column10: these arrangements seem to follow a logic of their own
column11: building and shifting cleverly around songs that don't really stick. A lot of time (and
column12: presumably
column13: a lot of pent-up creativity) went into this record
column14: but the best songs here feel as tight and spontaneous as Shudder to Think
column15: even when the multi-tracked instrumentation is dense and meticulous.

column1: Shudder to Think fans who were disappointed by the relative timidity of Lapland should find a lot to love about WAND. The bangers here are true goddamn bangers
column2: and even the draggy stretches have their moments. But it would be unfair to call this a return to form. WAND builds upon aesthetics that Wedren has played with throughout his career
column3: including the understated pop of Lapland.  Taking the long view
column4: the fact that WAND feels a bit overstuffed is more exciting than it is disappointing; 17 years after releasing a classic album
column5:
Craig Wedren could do a lot worse than some young man's problems.

Many influences behind Bill Orcutt's acoustic guitar music are easy to guess-- the raw blues of Lightnin' Hopkins and Fred McDowell
column3: the abstract improvisations of Derek Bailey and Cecil Taylor
column4: Orcutt's own attacking bent in 1990s noise outfit Harry Pussy. But there's at least one that nobody could've deduced: ""tic videos."" As Orcutt told The Wire
column5: he's fascinated by clips ""made by people... who have these involuntary physical and verbal tics
column6: and they actually document their symptoms and put the videos up on YouTube."" It's an odd inspiration
column7: but one that says a lot about his playing style
column8: which Orcutt himself likens to hiccuping. His wiry plucks and messy note clusters come in exhilarating fits and starts
column9: so fast and impetuous that his guitar strings seem hard-wired to his firing neurons. His obsessive repetition is less about creating studied mantras than capturing the primal power of involuntary impulse.

column1: That goal is reflected in the title of his second acoustic album
column2: How the Thing Sings. It implies that Orcutt would rather document his muse than control it
column3: letting the flow of his spilling ideas be the thing that sings. This approach gives his music a distinct immediacy
column4: something like a waterfall of consciousness rather than a stream. And its rapid
column5: irregular heartbeat creates an urgency that commands attention. You may not love all the moves Orcutt makes
column6: but together they quicken your pulse and pressurize the atmosphere
column7: much as a good horror film makes even calm moments seem one second away from shock.

column1: Such tension allows Orcutt to venture into all kinds of territory without hitting lulls. Often he'll veer from plaintive strums to lone plucks
column2: then into torrents so hyperactive they sound overdubbed
column3: even though How the Thing Sings was recorded in single takes with a single room mic. This forceful jamming together of moods results in overlapping narrative arcs. In ""The Visible Bosom""
column4: sandy chords give way to halting minimalism
column5: only to smash into lightning bolts of string strangling accompanied by Orcutt's possessed moans. That sound collage is stretched to epic proportions on closer ""A Line from Ol' Man River""
column6: which fuses together so many hectic ups and downs that calling it a rollercoaster would be an understatement.

column1: The same is true of How the Thing Sings as a whole. It's tempting to focus solely on the adrenaline rush of Orcutt's playing
column2: and let it all fly by like a stoner zoning out to Jackson Pollock's splattery paintings or Stan Brakhage's color-filled abstract films. That's a fine way to experience Orcutt's music
column3:
but there also seems to be a lot of intense thought going on behind his impulsive acoustic clatter. Maybe that's why his solo acoustic work has so far had a lot more staying power than the fleeting pleasures of a single trip.

"|15875.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15875-how-the-thing-sings/|8.0|Marc Masters

There are a few things we've come to expect from recent
column3: home-recorded indie pop: thin production
column4: lyrics that reference childhood and nostalgia
column5: a vibe of hushed intimacy
column6: lots of reverb. Youth Lagoon
column7: the project of 22-year-old Boise
column8: Idaho
column9: musician Trevor Powers
column10: ticks all of those boxes and sounds immediately familiar the first time you put it on. ""Posters""
column11: the opening track on his debut LP
column12: The Year of Hibernation
column13: even starts with a warbly synth to evoke the fabled VHS glow that has become a touchstone for kids of his generation. When you hear so much of this stuff
column14: it starts to bleed together-- almost as if by design-- and you start to wonder what it would take for an artist in this realm to stand out. Powers has a few ideas.

column1: Some of the album's appeal is straightforward. Powers writes melodies you remember and has an excellent ear for arrangement
column2: even if the songs are rendered crudely. They generally start as whispered laments and then twist and turn until they become huge ""oh oh oh"" sing-alongs. The album sounds like it was recorded in a bedroom
column3: which feels right given the small and personal details of the songs
column4: but it strains to break free of its technical limitations. Rare is the record in this sphere that works much better loud
column5: but The Year of Hibernation wants to be cranked. Room-filling volume allows a song like ""Afternoon"" to grow from its delicate
column6: whistle-and-electric-keyboard opening into its grand
column7: swelling conclusion
column8: with a 4/4 marching drum and wordless vocal refrain that envelopes you like a hug.

column1: The title of the record describes its world. These are songs about alternately hunkering down and hiding
column2: and heading out into the world to explore and report back on what you've found. Powers is very much an innocent here
column3: a kid with an ear for poetry who mixes striking images with the occasional groaner. The music of the Pacific Northwest feels like a key touchstone
column4: and in many ways Youth Lagoon seems like a shy
column5: quiet
column6: and more hermetic version of what Modest Mouse were doing before 1997's The Lonesome Crowded West. Small town claustrophobia bumps against the possibility of wide-open spaces. Two of the first three songs reference the late-night strobe of the television and beds and walls of posters
column7: and these are mixed with campgrounds
column8: woods
column9: lakes
column10: and watching fireworks from a roof. I don't want to strain the Modest Mouse comparison
column11: since this record doesn't have a ""band"" feel
column12: but the guitar breaks also show Isaac Brock's early flair for simple melodic embellishments that complement the songs perfectly.

column1: Dean Wareham is another guitarist with an ear for elegant guitar leads
column2: and the comparisons with Galaxie 500 extend to Powers' cracked guitar whine and way of building clattering and echo-laden arrangements to moments of grandeur (not to mention the G500-like song ""July"" that outlines a disintegrating relationship against the backdrop of a sky filled with explosions.) Powers is small-town through-and-through and doesn't have a hint of Wareham's cosmopolitan sophistication
column3: but that works for this landscape. Hibernation is a record for pulling up the covers and dreaming and then venturing out to the town to see the strange and magical world of encroaching adulthood. The anthemic ""Cannons"" starts off with Powers singing
column4: ""Rolling up the windows of my '96 Buick so the rain can't get inside of it
column5:
and that pretty much sums it up: The record mixes feelings of protection and safety with the tug of adventure and wraps it in compulsively listenable music that explodes at just the right moments.

Full disclosure: I am totally cognizant of how this review might be utterly pointless. A rapper named Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire has chosen that for his album cover. Your mind's already made up. That is
column2: if it wasn't already after his searing
column3: anti-everything calling card ""Triple F""-- that's ""fuck 'em"" in triplicate-- or ""Huzzah""
column4: eXquire's dangerously catchy single produced by horrorcore vet Necro
column5: with a hook that packs boundless socio-pathology into five words: ""drunk driving on a Wednesdayyyy."" Such an assault of antisocial behavior would lead to you believe there's nothing pleasant or new about Lost in Translation. But it's a nice surprise how it reveals itself as a comprehensive and ultimately human
column6: if not always humane
column7: portrait of eXquire's consummate underground ruggedness.

column1: eXquire's been getting a healthy share of buzz of late
column2: in large part because of the most divisive aspect of Lost in Translation: this is a New York mixtape and one that's provincial as fuck. His cantankerous and bullish flow can be traced to all purveyors of unwashed hoodie rap

Casual fans will easily spot the interpolations of Jay-Z and Lil' Kim tracks from 1996 but bonus points if you spot the hat-tip to a 50 Cent freestyle on Hot 97. Likewise
column4: it's not enough to have a boom-bap medley called ""Pissin' Between Train Cars"" stuck between ""Cockmeat Sandwich"" (""if you ain't seen Harold & Kumar
column5: that means suck my diiiiick"") and an indefensibly drawn-out blowjob skit-- he tells you where his stop is on the C Train from Euclid (Utica
column6: if you're interested).

column1: That some of these beats are ripped from Cannibal Ox's The Cold Vein might be the best illustration of the realm in which eXquire functions. It's a world of post-Wu murk where even the gulliest sounding dudes escape into comic books and hip-hop CDs because girls just don't understand. Even if it all takes place within a couple of city blocks
column2: eXquire makes it feel like a universe of experience where he comes of age as a microphone fiend (""I Should Be Sleepin'"")
column3: lays out some deeply nerdy storytelling raps (""Maltese Falcon Pt. 1 and Pt. 2"")
column4: and joyfully gets on some Anthony Bourdain shit as an ambassador to his local chicken spots (""Plus they got pizza
column5: y'all can't fuck with this/ Got macaroni salad too
column6: but I don't trust that shit"").

column1: But don't think that this is merely a celebration of New York… or really a celebration of much of anything. His focus on humility and grind doesn't separate eXquire from many other up and comers
column2: but when I hear
column3: say
column4: Green Ova Undergrounds
column5: their hustle raps seem to take place in some sort of vacuum
column6: and it's unclear what they're pushing against other than themselves. Translation is similar in a lot of ways to Danny Brown's XXX mixtape in that eXquire's sharing some very uncomfortable and often unflattering aspects of his life in order to fully express just how real this is to him. You get the feeling Lost in Translation wasn't chosen as a title for the fact it's a cool phrase: Despite the occasional guest rap
column7: it shares the movie's overwhelming loneliness and desperation. He's in command railing against hip-hop ass kissers-- dud skits named ""Hip Hop Networking 101"" and ""YeahRight!.com"" should make that obvious-- but when bills
column8: guilt
column9: and the impending sense he's fucked up his life get the better of him on ""Nuthin' Even Matters (Regrets)""
column10: eXquire's surprisingly effective singing voice rings out like a distressing call from someone who might end it at any moment. Likewise
column11: while the drowsy hooks on ""Lovesponge"" and ""Build-A-Bitch"" might initially signal the point where this 18-track tape should've packed it in
column12: eXquire sounds more confused than misogynistic.

column1: On ""Huzzah""
column2: eXquire boasts
column3: ""publicist asked me what's my gimmick
column4: I said 'going in
column5: '"" and it's based in truth: these aren't the kind of lyrics filled with punchlines and tricky wordplay
column6: and his fairly unglamorous strengths lie in his ability to pick beats
column7: flesh out concepts
column8: and develop stories. There are plenty of easily identifiable precedents in his tone and cadence-- Method Man
column9: 50 Cent
column10: hell
column11: even a hell of a lot of Dr. Dre-- whether topically or vocally
column12: eXquire covers so much ground that I'm not sure I'd be able to spot an uncredited verse from him. Particularly on ""The Last Huzzah!""

column14: Das Racist

But the freedom they have allows them to honor and revive ""New York rap"" as an artistic framework rather than a matter of geography: Of course that designation was going to generate skepticism when the personality-free likes of Skyzoo

and it's tough to look away.

Maria Minerva is begging you to think about her music. And not just think about it: pick it apart
column2: deconstruct it
column3: comb it for references. Overthink it
column4: even. Hot-button issues both musical and not-- hypnagogic pop
column5: 90s revivalism
column6: feminism-- are baked into Cabaret Cixous
column7: her second album for Los Angeles-based anti-pop label Not Not Fun. Maria Minerva (real name Maria Juur)
column8: certainly has the pedigree: the daughter of an Estonian music critic
column9: Juur studied art history while in college; she contributes to The Wire. Cabaret Cixous borrows monikers from two Juur favorites: the pranging electro of Cabaret Voltaire and lauded feminist writer Hélène Cixous.

column1: Juur doesn't soft-pedal her exploration of sexual dynamics; she pouts lustily in photos and gyrates in music videos. Sex can be a tricky subject for an artist from Juur's world: mainly
column2: it's difficult to walk the line between the carnal and political in pop music. (Madonna
column3: for instance
column4: expertly managed both
column5: but it seems easier to err on the side of the carnal
column6: like almost everyone else.) Self-consciousness and obfuscation can be deeply unsexy
column7: and while it's easy to admire the games Juur wants to play with her image
column8: there's very little allure or attraction on Cabaret itself. It's one thing to undermine the exploitation of female sexuality to sell pop music; but in doing so she also seems to undermine the immediacy and compassion-- the very appeal-- of pop music.

column1: Juur
column2: at least
column3: has the right inspirations: 1980s electro and dance-pop
column4: 1990s house. Much of Cabaret sounds like Ariel Pink covering Jennifer Paige's ""Crush""-- hooks made to quiver over seasick chords and seasick-er drum machines-- though I don't think Juur is playing the same savant-like memory games Pink is. Her referents are too carefully cultivated
column5: too obviously considered (though no one should do her the disservice of suggesting insincerity). Juur's treatments are like the soap scum: Her aim isn't just to dull the shine of the nickel-plated pop that informs her music but to alter its texture. Cabaret conveys thinness above all
column6: Juur's dryly echoing vocals and keyboard presets hovering on the same plane. It constantly feels like even a cursory scrubbing would make a world of difference.

column1: In this environment
column2: beauty and melody are secondary concerns
column3: though they are concerns. It's impossible to hear standouts such as ""Pirate's Tale"" and ""Soo High"" as anything other than soberly conceived pop songs
column4: but ""pop songs"" is a tricky term: these tracks aren't meant to unite
column5: or inspire
column6: or empathize. They're meant to make you think. About what
column7: exactly
column8: sometimes gets lost: the lyrics of ""Ruff Trade"" eerily triangulate sex
column9: violence
column10: and despair
column11: but ""Soo High"" begins with ""Baby baby baby/ You make me so high/ When I'm around you/ Time just flies by."" Tongue-in-cheek? Probably
column12: but I don't always wish to exit my swoony pop trance to suss that out. So you see why Cabaret functions best in the midst of the Maria Minerva audio/visual/theoretical experience: Juur's music isn't yet precise enough to probe the nuances of admittedly weighty material on its own.

column1: I really like Cabaret Cixous' sound
column2: though-- it's fidgety and restless
column3: full of love for its inspirations despite its partly academic birth. I'd be more optimistic on Juur's future if her prodigious output-- Cabaret follows her Tallinn at Dawn tape
column4: also released this year-- and haphazard recording style signaled a clearer process of trial/error/refinement. She is not moving toward a more perfect remembrance of or epitaph for dance pop; we remain firmly in the realm of ideas. For now
column5: Cabaret is paper disco of a thoughtful and occasionally moving variety
column6:
more durable than it lets on.

In 2009
column2: YETI publisher (and Pitchfork contributor) Mike McGonigal assembled a compilation of ""raw
column3: rare
column4: and otherworldly African-American gospel"" that showcased his penchant for wild
column5: devil-fearing church songs. As far as gospel collections go
column6: Fire in My Bones felt revelatory
column7: crucial:  those three discs of evangelical missives reconfigured religious music as unpredictable
column8: sonically challenging material. McGongial's next project
column9: <i>This May Be My Last Time Singing
column10: focuses specifically on gospel songs recorded and released between 1957 and 1982. Like its predecessor
column11: it's a deeply compelling document of the various ways human beings talk to God.

column1: There's urgency to all good art
column2: but gospel music
column3: in particular
column4: is fueled by desperation: Transmit your message of gratitude to Heaven before you lose the chance entirely (and end up somewhere else). The mission is massive
column5: but in many cases
column6: the material legacy is humble; at least a third of the songs included on This May Be My Last Time Singing were self-released and pressed
column7: in small batches
column8: onto 7""
column9: 45-rpm discs
column10: a process paid for by church congregations or the singers themselves. Decades later
column11: McGonigal tugged those little records out of cardboard boxes and milk crates
column12: trawling record shops (this might be the only compilation in recent memory that thanks at least a dozen)
column13: online auctions
column14: and flea markets for lost prayers. That these songs were released commercially (even if they sold only a few dozen copies for local or vanity labels) feels paramount to any real understanding of the performers' intent-- these aren't field recordings. They're solicitations: holler along
column15: fall to your knees
column16: pray with me. Believe.

column1: McGonigal's finds are spread across three discs
column2: each loosely organized around a state of faith (""The Devil's Trying to Steal My Joy""
column3: ""Perfect Like the Angels""
column4: and ""All Wrap Up in One"")
column5: and while they range dramatically in style-- from funk to rhythm and blues to drum machine psychedelia-- they're linked by an industriousness that feels unique to the genre.  No matter how rowdy these tracks get
column6: their creators are still doing selfless work.

column1: This May Be My Last Time Singing focuses specifically on post-war gospel
column2: but most of it feels oddly timeless. Rev. J.W. Neely and Family's ""Don't Let Nobody Turn You Around"" was self-released in 1980 but sounds divorced from the era altogether; it's disorienting to consider that this rendition was born into the same pop landscape as Pink Floyd and Blondie. An a cappella
column3: handclap-heavy ode to solidarity in the face of temptation-- ""Don't you let nobody turn you around/ You just keep on together
column4: Neely and family shout
column5: their voices warm-- it's encouraging
column6: never threatening. Same goes for the Exciting Traveling Four's ""O Lord I Have No Friend""
column7: which was released by the National Recording Label in 1982. Save a wonky electric organ intro (which sounds as if it were being piped up from the deep end of a swimming pool)
column8: ""O Lord I Have No Friend"" is quaint and earnest in a way that defies its age. You can practically see the matching bow ties
column9: the four faces crowded around a single mic.

column1: The collection's longest track
column2: the seven-and-a-half minute ""He Walks With Me (Parts 1 and 2)""
column3: is also its most exhilarating. Calvin Leavy
column4: a singer and guitarist from Arkansas
column5: scored a modest hit in 1970 with ""Cummins Prison Farm""
column6: a scrappy electric blues that decried conditions at Cummins Prison
column7: the Arkansas penitentiary infamous for its abuse (torture and inmate rape were common
column8: and in 1968
column9: three skeletons
column10: one decapitated
column11: one with a crushed skull
column12: and a third with both legs broken back were discovered in shallow graves on the prison grounds). In 1976
column13: Leavy-- who
column14: in a particularly cruel twist
column15: would be shipped off to Cummins himself for drug charges in 1992-- recorded ""He Walks With Me (Parts 1 and 2)"" with the Cummins Prison Farm Singers for the aptly named Messenger Records. The song contains a bogus fade out three and a half minutes in
column16: but Leavy's really just warming up
column17: his raspy voice growing higher
column18: wilder. The music-- loose
column19: rudimentary rock-- gently revs back up
column21: rhythmic canvas for Leavy to scribble all over. His message is determined
column23: not ever. By the time the track actually fades out
column24: it feels like there's a full army of believers crammed into the room.

column1: Plenty of new
column2: privately sourced anthologies have inadvertently positioned the record collector as curator
column3: savior
column4: interpreter. But unlike many maniacal stockpilers of vinyl and shellac
column5: McGonigal doesn't fetishize these songs as hard-sought rarities. This May Be My Last Time Singing contains plenty of oddball finds
column6: but
column7: as McGonigal explains
column8: these are just the tracks he loves the most-- which is exactly what renders him such a reliable guide. As his brief liner notes state
column9: ""these are the songs I'm most obsessed with
column10: that if you dropped by my house I'd say 'You have to hear this.'""

column1: Which
column2: as any music fan knows
column3:
is the very best way to hear anything.

Punk rock has a long tradition of taking the counter-culture vibe that rock'n'roll cultivated back when hip-shaking was a crime against propriety and cranking up the volume to intentionally offend every possible denomination: the fans
column3: the critics
column4: the outcasts
column5: the bigots
column6: the sell-outs
column7: the scenesters
column8: and so on.  Some bands had a well-reasoned method to their misanthropic madness
column9: and some just wanted to piss people off (or
column10: in special cases
column11: actually piss on people). What's most 0ffensive about Cerebral Ballzy's attempts at ""edgy"" provocation isn't tastelessness or insensitivity-- it's the blandness.

column1: To be fair to these five guys
column2: it's not like they're aiming for any sort of lofty artistic goal.  They just want to be a punk rock band
column3: with their own stupid band name
column4: with their own songs about getting fucked up and telling various authority figures and peers to fuck off
column5: and with their own Raymond Pettibon cover art (complete with bonus photo-copier fuzz at the edge of the image
column6: for that extra bit of D.I.Y. verisimilitude).  Granted
column7: it's on the music-label offshoot of the studio famous for a lot of Cartoon Network's Adult Swim content-- it's the label's first non-compilation full-length that has nothing to do with one of their shows
column8: actually-- but let's leave the scene politics to the Maximumrocknroll's of the world.

column1: And it's not like they're necessarily bad at it. They know the moves (the spoken-word intro
column2: the slow-into-fast start-up
column3: the ""bridge"")
column4: they know the rules (the album proper is only 20 minutes long
column5: with only one song clocking in at over 150 seconds
column6: and to hell with a guitar solo)
column7: and they hit their marks. ""Singles"" like ""Cutting Class"" and ""Insufficient Fare"" are perfectly OK punk songs.  So are the other 10 ""official"" album tracks
column8: as well as whatever non-live bonus tracks come with the various different versions of the album. ""OK"" is about where these guys top off
column9: though-- subject matter notwithstanding
column10: the songs are pretty interchangeable
column11: meaning there's not much that distinguishes anti-establishment tracks like ""Anthem"" and ""Don't Tell Me What to Do"" with pass-the-pipe tracks like ""Drug Myself Dumb"" and ""Puke Song"".

column1: This album features perfectly serviceable and perfectly competent
column2: middle-of-the-road punk rock music that probably sounds much better live than it ever could in a recording studio. If it weren't being released at a time when groups like Off!
column3: Double Negative
column4: Trash Talk
column5: and any number of hardcore-flavored punk groups are putting their own individualistic spins on the well-worn
column6: three-chord monte
column7: Cerebral Ballzy's paint-by-numbers take would possibly stand out. And if it weren't for the countless number of precedents that have done exactly what CB are doing here
column8: their faithful-to-a-fault homage might actually seem quaint.  In this day and age
column9: though
column10: what these kids are doing
column11: and the way they're doing it
column12: means that their only truly distinguishing feature is their band name.  And when all you've got going for yourself is that you're called Cerebral Ballzy
column13:
you've got your work cut out for you.

column3: spice
column4: and overnighters in dank Italian jail cells-- these are the things that Dum Dum Girls' first record was made of. Equal parts girl-group gloss and brash punk energy
column5: I Will Be paired the tinny jangle of Psychocandy-coated guitars with lead singer Dee Dee's exquisitely aloof vocals to create a vibe of timelessly cool abandon. It sounded like a girl gang had kicked the authority figures out of the principal's office
column6: barricaded the doors
column7: and taken to blasting their delinquent anthems like ""<a href=""http://pitchfork.com/forkcast/14464-bhang-bhang-im-a-burnout/"" target=""_blank"">Bhang Bhang
column8: I'm a Burnout"" and ""Jail La La"" over the school's loudspeaker.

column1: The Dum Dums might have been the baddest girls on the scene
column2: but they certainly weren't the only ones: over the past couple of years Vivian Girls
column3: Best Coast
column4: and Frankie Rose and the Outs have each dusted off the kitschy cultural detritus of 1960s girl-group pop and filtered it through a hefty dose of D.I.Y. grit. It's been a blast. But even the most enduring of the original practitioners carried some decidedly pre-feminist baggage (baby love
column5: wide-eyed devotion
column6: Svengalis)
column7: and at times the new stuff didn't feel too much more enlightened. Or at least it could have seemed that way if you made the mistake of looking for meaning solely on the surface of the songs.

column1: Dum Dum Girls in particular had a way of reminding you that there was more to it than that. They had fun with irony; artifice; and winking
column2: revisionist takes on musical history (Kristin Gundred's Ramones-nodding stage name Dee Dee; Richard ""My Boyfriend's Back"" Gottehrer's co-producing credit on both full-lengths) that reminded you of the simple
column3: triumphant facts: these women were all pretty excellent pop songwriters
column4: and this thing they were part of was the most visible all-female front in indie rock since the riot grrrl movement in the early 1990s. And yet
column5: even the highlights of the girl-group garage scene (of which I Will Be is certainly one) still focused pretty narrowly on simple
column6: youthful emotions and didn't seem to care much about aesthetic development. Some time around the third Vivian Girls LP
column7: you couldn't help but wonder: Will any of these groups be bold enough to move forward? Will any of them stick around long enough to
column8: well
column9: grow up?

column1: Only in Dreams is the first record of this wave able to form an answer to that question
column2: and for that it feels admirably bold. Spurred by the death of Dee Dee's mother and the separation anxiety she felt while she and her husband (Crocodiles' Brandon Welchez) were touring with their respective bands
column3: it's a statement of thematic maturity and emotional depth we've not yet heard from Dum Dum Girls-- nor many of their contemporaries. It builds on the momentum of this year's terrific and shimmery He Gets Me High EP
column4: but it's even more of a hi-fi affirmation (""It's cool to record in [an] actual studio and use real mics
column5: Dee Dee said recently) and an introduction of a whole new set of influences (Mazzy Star
column6: the Pretenders) in the band's sound.

column1: The first thing you notice is Dee Dee's voice. If you've seen the band live
column2: you know: girl's got pipes. But you didn't get that from I Will Be
column3: which kept it distorted and low in the mix. In interviews
column4: she's been candid about her stage fright and her gradual acceptance of her role as a frontwoman
column5: and her newfound confidence is pretty thrilling to hear on Only in Dreams. Vocally
column6: Chrissie Hynde is the obvious reference point
column7: but Dee Dee's less interested in aping Hynde's sneering
column8: Jagger-like strut than channeling the lush depths of her own voice on tracks like ""Bedroom Eyes"". For the first time on a Dum Dum Girls record
column9: the rest of the Girls sing backup
column10: which adds even more fullness to the sound. As on He Gets Me High
column11: Gottehrer shares a producing credit with the Raveonettes' Sune Rose Wagner
column12: and they've effectively scrubbed the grit off the Girls' guitars until they glimmer.

column1: Which brings us to the problem with Only in Dreams: the pristine production sounds great
column2: but it makes the lack of complexity and occasional shortcomings-- the kind of issues that were easier to disguise
column3: or perhaps shrug off
column4: on I Will Be-- all too apparent. Most of the songs are mid-tempo
column5: and there's little variation in the drum beats
column6: phrasing
column7: or song structure. Some people might also take issue with the relatively simplistic rhyme schemes
column8: but thanks to Dee Dee's expressive vocals
column9: that's not a problem. She's able to conjure powerful emotions from minimal imagery and simple
column10: straightforward declarations. It's not much to look at on paper
column11: but the way she holds the notes in ""Heartbeat""'s bridge-- ""I don't know/ Where to go/ To get away from this sorrow""-- is nothing less than a gutpunch.

column1: There are 10 songs on Only in Dreams
column2: and every one of them contains the word ""you."" Some of them Dee Dee wrote about her husband
column3: and some she wrote about watching her mother succumb to cancer last year. Perhaps the most moving thing about Only in Dreams is that it's not always immediately apparent which of these people she's addressing; its state of longing feels universally applicable. ""Heartbeat""
column4: ""Wasted Away""
column5: and ""Teardrops on My Pillow"" can pass on a cursory listen for odes to romantic heartbreak
column6: but the startlingly direct references to death (""It's a game
column7: how tight/ Can you shut your eyes/ Shut out the light/ Death is so bright"") make you look back and realize that there's a sense of loss throbbing throughout the record. (Dee Dee's mom played an important role in the band's aesthetic-- that's her on the covers of I Will Be and the self-titled debut EP.) There's a passing moment on ""Caught in One"" when she wishes to trade places with her ailing mother
column8: but by the closer
column9: ""Hold Your Hand""
column10: she's facing down her own identity (""But she's not you/ No
column11: she's not you"") and finding the strength to begin picking up the pieces and rebuilding on her own. It's a step forward for her as a songwriter
column12: articulating-- let alone sharing-- a feeling this intimate.

column1: Nothing on Only in Dreams has the immediacy of a track like ""Jail La La""
column2: so those looking for a retread might be disappointed. But songs like the slow-burning ""Coming Down"" show Dum Dum Girls pushing themselves in new directions-- you get the sense
column3: if you hadn't before
column4: that this band might be around for a while. Only in Dreams isn't a perfect record
column5: but a little while down the line it might end up looking like the beginning of something-- the first steps forward for the band
column6:
or perhaps a raising of the bar for this entire revival. I wouldn't put it past Dee Dee to be the leader of the pack.

A third of a century into their collaboration
column3: Mekons have wandered so far down their own path that they don't seem to have much in common with anybody else anymore. They're an art-and-literature collective that happens to play music too
column4: a small community who used to be punks together

column3: Egypt"" or ""Now We Have the Bomb""

column2: of course

A lot of its lyrics might as well have been assembled exquisite-corpse style: ""Calling All Demons"" wanders from ""a reptile thinking its first thoughts"" to the head of John the Baptist to ""a fan-club meeting down the steps on Briggate"" to ""ice cream

column1: The other thing Mekons have picked up from contemporary art practice is the principle that
column2: once you've established your voice

column4: and it's hard to imagine a band more comfortable with each other's playing than they are. When they feel like it
column5: they can conjure moments of disarming beauty. (""I fall asleep when I should pray
column6: Timms and Tom Greenhalgh repeat together-- she's clear-voiced and reserved
column7: he's quavering and sardonic-- and then the song briefly dissolves into a dubbed-out froth of piano and violin before resuming.) When they don't
column8: they still sound like no one but Mekons: prickly
column9: jovial
column10: boozy
column11: resistant to the bourgeois pleasures of rhyme and tune but sometimes seduced by them anyway. For anyone who's not already a Mekons enthusiast
column12: though
column13: this has to be an alarmingly forbidding
column14:
cryptic piece of work.

Over the past several years
column2: as European electronic music's moved from its all-minimal-everything phase into fuzzier areas
column3: I've made a mental note of comparing no less than a dozen young producers to Plaid. I didn't listen to Plaid-- British production duo Andy Turner and Ed Handley-- very much
column4: not even their 1999 mini-masterpiece Rest Proof Clockwork. Instead they remained faintly but firmly ensconced in my memory
column5: the result of a burgeoning electronic music fan seeking a group Radiohead wasn't constantly namedropping (scratch Aphex Twin
column6: Autechre)
column7: but that was still available at Sam Goody. I would never suggest that Plaid were a direct inspiration for a group like Mount Kimbie
column8: though there are worse things than being a token in the revival of soft-focus
column9: reasonably scaled beatmongering.

column1: Scintilli is Plaid's first non-soundtrack work since 2008 and their first proper studio album since 2003 (2006's Greedy Baby having been an audio/video collaboration). It doesn't count as a ""new direction"" for the duo because they've never really fucked with ""direction"" in the first place. At their best
column2: Plaid nestled into the wide crevasses between hardline
column3: dystopian techno
column4: broken beat
column5: and experimental composition. Their synthesis was recognizable but not unrepeatable; they stood out for their casual
column6: unhurried sense of adventure. (In the late 1990s
column7: they were called Intelligent Dance Music because  their records had ""Warp"" on the back
column8: and they didn't sound like Moby.)

column1: There's a danger in this lack of direction
column2: though: sometimes you exist comfortably outside electronic-music narratives and sometimes you get lost. Scintilli isn't the first time Plaid have stumbled into the latter state; all things being equal
column3: they operate in this mode better than most. Still
column4: Scintilli underwhelms
column5: lacking the ease with which Plaid used to stitch sound together. They're no longer inscrutable; like their previous work
column6: Scintilli contains heavy doses of sounds that rile
column7: pacify
column8: and intrigue
column9: but here they constantly tip their hand. The dolloping keyboards of ""Craft Nine"" calm; the walloping bass of ""Sömnl"" disrupts.

column1: Plaid's skillful incorporation of the female voice remains intact (Björk sometimes seems to aspire to ""Lilith""
column2: her 1997 collaboration with the duo) on soft-footed opener ""Missing"" and closer ""At Last"". Their overall sound has remained eclectic even as their tracks grow compartmentalized.  I still appreciate Plaid's baselessness-- how I can never quite place  what I'm listening to. They're less diffuse than their late-90s Warp  peers but far more so than
column3: say
column4: Mouse on Mars or Flying Lotus
column5: artists with whom Plaid share sensibilities but little more. I find Scintilli-- and its ambitious alternating of composure and chaos-- admirable
column6: but ""admirable"" sounds (and feels) like a backhanded complement. I would prefer to find it fizzy or confusing or aggressive. Scintilli is a disappointingly static record from a duo of born tinkerers.

Despite its tremendous influence on the mainstream rock that followed
column2: it's hard to think of another album that sounds much like Nirvana's Nevermind
column3: a record with so much more pop and punk punch than any music it inspired. Of course
column4: no diamond-certified
column5: canonical treasure hitting the two-decade mark can be left well enough alone in 2011-- especially one that changed the lives of a lot people now approaching middle age
column6: with the discretionary income to prove it. After all
column7: ""super deluxe"" reissues of classic albums don't even have to be tied to an anniversary these days. But Nevermind is 20 this week
column8: still a pretty respectable number in a world where any milestone marks an excuse to shift a few more units. The only question is whether these reissues-- a single-disc remaster
column9: a 2xCD ""deluxe"" version
column10: and a 4xCD+DVD ""super-deluxe"" edition-- are that rare essential repurchase that makes you hear an album you've possibly exhausted in new ways
column11: or if it's just another mediocre jumble of odds and ends that inadvertently reveals the flaws and blemishes carefully excised from the original 12-song set.

column1: Sadly
column2: both expanded versions fall into the latter category
column3: with material ranging from ""interesting"" to ""historical curiosity"" to ""of zero value to even superfans."" But this mish-mash of sketches
column4: practice-space woodshedding
column5: and alternate-but-not-very mixes does help explain what makes Nevermind so unique. Nirvana certainly never made another album like it. The precocious Bleach still has its partisans
column6: folks who think its primal bash-and-howl is the be-all-end-all of rock
column7: while In Utero stands as the band's most harrowing statement
column8: where it's a toss-up as to whether the riffs or the lyrics hurt more. But Nevermind was and remains an unrepeatable object. It retains the gleeful pummel of the first album while hinting at the bleakness of the third. Yet there's also a concision and clarity that Nirvana hadn't quite mastered on the gnarly-by-necessity Bleach and wouldn't allow themselves on the stark and caustic In Utero.

column1: Nirvana began their career with no illusions about their chances for mass success and ended it by seeing just how abrasive a platinum-selling band could get away with being. But when they got their chance at the brass ring
column2: they went at it with a bubblegum band's canniness
column3: however much Cobain shit on the shiny final product after the fact. Andy Wallace's radio-ready mix certainly helped sharpen this potentially no-concessions
column4: indie-to-major leap into an obvious commercial proposition. But even if they'd settled on producer Butch Vig's slightly less slick mixes-- made as a reference for the band and identified on the super deluxe edition's third disc as the ""Devonshire mixes""-- Nevermind would likely have fared well in the charts
column5: since these early passes aren't far from Wallace's infamous high-gloss version. Listening in hindsight
column6: though
column7: they have the woozy effect of feeling just slightly off
column8: leaving you to focus only on what's missing.

column1: The box set does make clear that Nirvana honed these songs over a long period. Listening to the various sessions leading up to the one that gave us the album we know-- especially the nearly unlistenable ""boombox"" mixes of early demos-- you learn very quickly that these songs didn't arrive perfectly formed in one sustained burst of inspiration. The hours of rehearsals and the expensive time spent tinkering in the studio shaped them into classics. It helped that there are songs on Nevermind that might appeal to people who've never heard a hardcore album in their lives
column2: who might have even (gasp!) kinda liked the glossier hard-rock bands whose era largely ended with the rise of grunge. Moving away from the heavy-at-all-costs sound he'd always been both enamored with and suspicious of
column3: Cobain worked diligently on his big hooks and decided to stop smothering his natural melodic gifts under so much self-conscious sludge.

column1: The key was that Nirvana
column2: unlike many of their indie peers
column3: didn't assume that intensity was incompatible with polish. Cobain's discomfort could be unnerving because it sounded as unmediated as anything allowed on the radio could get. There was too much pop-rock study involved to claim Nevermind as some kind of art brut document of one dude's unraveling. Confronted with something like ""Polly""
column4: Cobain's distress was obvious in 1991
column5: long before his shotgun-assisted exit. But it wasn't the way Nevermind exposed Cobain's psychic wounds that provided support for those who related to him. It was the fact that
column6: fucked up as he was
column7: Cobain still found pleasure in rock's most emphatic clichés and bent them to his own never-quite-smirking ends. He snuck into the spotlight while remaining an alienated weirdo
column8: but for a while there
column9: you suspected he was enjoying the attention
column10: even if he knew that it was all a joke to be taken about as seriously as high school cliquishness. ""Territorial Pissings"" is as raw as any punk song I know
column11: but it actually found its way into the hands of suburban tweens. How good must that have felt
column12: to be responsible for such a thing?

column1: Even as they moved toward the mainstream
column2: Nirvana were trying shit that no one would have called an easy route to success. Nevermind is drenched in the filthy Pacific Northwest roar that slapped Cobain into action as a teen
column3: but it's as catchy as any of the radio giants that caught his ear as a kid. It's driven by pain as naked and personal as the riot grrrl bands whose company he kept and as fuck-around goofy as the Seattle contemporaries who both reveled in and mercilessly parodied machismo. And despite the fact that none of those modes would seem to fit together on the same album
column4: let alone all of them
column5: it's all hammered into a still-disarming whole
column6: a collection of anthems that retain the idiosyncrasies of the very weird band that made them. It helped that Cobain had yet to be disabused of the idea that you could be an idiosyncratic indie kid and a rock star without compromising on either front.

column1: That's probably why the bonus material here feels less like a revelation and more like the kind of peek-behind-the-curtain that you wind up regretting. Nevermind is basically a great fake-out. It presents itself as an off-the-cuff explosion
column2: a from-the-gut expression of realness and energy in the grand punk tradition
column3: but it was actually the product of a shit ton of hard work. If you don't hold with the first-take-is-the-best-take philosophy
column4: your respect for Cobain may actually increase when you realize how dedicated he was to getting every element right. Listening to him fumbling his way toward greatness on the ""boombox"" mixes of songs like ""Come as You Are"" and ""Something in the Way"" or hearing a newly cemented group working out the kinks in their interplay in the studio
column5: you may also realize that you don't want to hear the missteps and rewrites and second guessing that went into the perfect-as-is final product. The ""boombox"" mixes
column6: Devonshire mixes
column7: and Smart Sessions (early Vig-produced takes recorded with drummer Chad Channing that were initially intended for release on a second album for Sub Pop) are largely work tapes. Listening to them feels like studying every unused scrap of a film classic that someone managed to sneak out of the editing room
column8: which is about as fun as that description makes them sound. If you've always been suspicious of the album's production sheen
column9: there's no Holy Grail here that's going to give you the raw take you're looking for.

column1: For all its finessing and tweaking
column2: though
column3: Nevermind is still a thousand times closer to the unpremeditated intensity of Cobain's D.I.Y. days than any of the post-grunge rockers who claimed it as an influence. I defy you to listen to any of the live performances on this edition-- the only essential extras
column4: though less uncomfortably intense than 1994's MTV Unplugged set and less definitive and uniformly powerful than 2009's release of their king-making set at the 1992 Reading Festival-- and not hear a ragged
column5: joyful
column6: charismatic band that makes those inert
column7: angst-ridden followers sound like they come from another aesthetic universe.

column1: That charisma is a big reason why Nevermind remains a 10. But in-concert takes on ""Sliver"" and ""Been a Son"" that are the third most thrilling live versions officially available on CD? It's not as if all this ""exclusive"" dreck-- most of which has been floating around on bootlegs and .zip files and YouTube for eons-- will permanently dull the excitement of the Nevermind
column2: but trying to swallow it all might put you off the album itself for a long while. If you're truly interested in hearing this stuff
column3: the two-disc deluxe set is easily the better deal
column4: giving you a little hint of the various stages of Nevermind's construction without wearing you out the way the four-disc set will. But if you really want to celebrate the 20th
column5: you'll be better off just giving the original album a few spins. Despite how much better-left-forgotten material is being offered up here as essential
column6:
there's still more life in the real Nevermind than anything that's attempted to replicate its attack since.

In a review of the special edition reissue of Opeth's 2005 collection Ghost Reveries
column2: I quoted band leader Mikael Åkerfeldt as saying that what his group does is ""more than metal."" At the time
column3: the forward-thinking Swedish group was still very much performing within the metal tradition. On their 10th album
column4: Heritage
column5: they aren't. For longtime fans
column6: the shift from progressive death metal to full-on progressive rock won't be a surprise: 2003's Damnation gave a good idea of what Åkerfeldt sounded like doing clean vocals sans death growls
column7: and since 1995's debut
column8: Orchid
column9: he's never been afraid to stretch the templates of all the genres they incorporate. (Åkerfeldt's used his airier croon for ages-- here
column10: more confident in that angle
column11: he removed the heavier stuff and expanded upon the airier bridges.) What might surprise you
column12: though
column13: is the intense completeness of the transition: Heritage's 1970s-inspired prog feels more like the follow-up to fellow countrymen Dungen's 2004 opus Ta Det Lugnt than Opeth's own Watershed.

column1: The 10-song collection is another collaboration with Porcupine Tree's Steven Wilson

column3: analog feel

column5: scene-setting piano piece Åkerfeldt  says was inspired by Swedish jazz pianist Jan Johansson and the folk  music of his country. Elsewhere
column6: guest spots from Swedish flautist  Björn J:son Lindh and Weather Report percussionist Alex Acuña (both on eight-minute loud-quiet-loud standout ""Famine"")
column7: give Heritage a mystical
column8: pastoral feel. If you've heard only the King Crimson-nodding lead track
column9: ""The Devil's Orchard""
column10: you have a good idea what to expect: an exuberant
column11: forward rushing blend of bell-bottomed jazziness and Deep Purple
column12: Camel
column13: and Jethro Tull love made more complex with quick tempo shifts
column14: stop-on-a-dime implosions
column15: and breezy
column16: racing
column17: drifting
column18: and other sorts of atmospheric
column19: psychedelic flourishes.

column1: Another track
column2: the muscular ""Slither""
column3: is appropriately dedicated to Ronnie James Dio. The 37-year-old Åkerfeldt
column4: who says Heritage is an album he's been ""building up to write for and participate on"" since he was 19
column5: has also mentioned listening to Alice Cooper frequently over the past year. You won't necessarily detect the latter in any obvious way
column6: but you'll feel it in the album's appropriation of the texture and atmosphere of an era. Åkerfeldt and co. do offer a convincing take-- it's a pretty
column7: well-thought out collection-- but for all the ideas and layers
column8: Heritage feels somewhat empty. It's the group's most genre-melding
column9: but it's also the most obvious
column10: largely because much of it sounds like things we've heard before. The lifelessness may also be the result of the singularity of the vision: Heritage lacks the usual shift and pull between heavy and soft that they've managed to weave into their music for the past two decades. It feels a bit listless and emotionally distant. When it comes down to it
column11: Åkerfeldt's death growl is more memorable than his rock singing (and both work best when you get them together). There are dynamics here
column12: but not the kind that create unexpected chills.

column1: The story behind Travis Smith's colorful cover painting is instructive. We're told Åkerfeldt gave the artist a number of references including Pieter Bruegel's ""The Triumph of Death""
column2: Hieronymus Bosch (in general)
column3: and the Beatles' Yellow Submarine. The final picture depicts a tree sprouting the heads of each Opeth member with the noggin of ex-keyboardist and backing vocalist Per Wiberg
column4: who left the band after recording his parts for the new record
column5: toppling into ""a pile of ex-members' skulls."" Beneath those skulls? The roots of the tree that point to the band's devilish roots in death metal. We're also told the nine stars in the sky represent Opeth's nine past albums
column6: the sun representing Heritage. Then comes the line of people ""want[ing] a piece"" of the band
column7: etc. It's fine to get conceptual
column8: of course
column9: but the forced
column10: overripe symbolism of this image and its fussiness point to a problem with the record: Åkerfeldt remembered to include everything here except space for his songs to breathe. He refers to Opeth records as ""observations"" and
column11: ultimately
column12: for all its considerable beauty
column13: Heritage too often feels like a passive
column14:
backward glance.

Back in 1992
column2: you couldn't find two rock acts more diametrically opposed than Pavement and Suede-- the former were all-American every-dudes indulging in cryptic
column3: dissonant slop-pop; the latter were libidinous
column4: decadent Brit androgynes with Wembley-sized ambitions. And yet the bands shared uncannily similar trajectories-- each was at the forefront of significant sea changes in its home country's independent music scene (lo-fi American indie rock for the former
column5: Britpop for the latter)
column6: only to peter out around the turn of the millennium. Both bands' respective frontmen-- Stephen Malkmus and Brett Anderson-- have since embarked on solo careers that have seen each go to great lengths to redefine himself: Malkmus as a guitar hero
column7: Anderson as a brooding balladeer. And both had to put those personal evolutions on hold last year to take their old bands on the reunion-tour circuit for the sole purpose of airing out their 90s-era classics
column8: with no intention of recording new material.

column1: That last point is underscored by the fact that
column2: this year
column3: to the month
column4: Malkmus and Anderson have swiftly resumed their solo careers as if those Pavement and Suede reunions never happened. Like Malkmus' recent Mirror Traffic
column5: the origins of Anderson's fourth album
column6: Black Rainbows
column7: predate the reformation of his marquee band. But both albums are infused with the anticipation of what was to come: just as Malkmus reins in the Jicks-ian jamming on Mirror Traffic in favor of more Pavement-like concision
column8: Black Rainbows sees Anderson-- after three relatively sullen and sedate solo releases-- cautiously reconnecting with his suppressed pop-star swagger. When he plaintively sings
column9: ""give me your brittle heart and I'll light a fire
column10: on the album's lead single
column11: it's almost as if he's pleading for his old job back.

column1: That's not to say Black Rainbows is some calculated '92 throwback. As ever
column2: Anderson likes to speak in suggestive metaphors (""ashtray eyes
column3: ""a sabotage of lipstick
column4: ""burning mattress
column5: ""paper cuts
column6: ""carpet burns""-- the last two of which turn up on multiple songs)
column7: though his withered voice is far less elastic and outrageous than it was 20 years ago. And in lieu of Suede's glam-rock crunch
column8: the new album mostly favors the atmospheric
column9: middle-aged Brit-rock of
column10: say
column11: Urban Hymns-era Verve or latter-day Echo and the Bunnymen. (The invitation to ""come taste the orange blossom"" on ""In the House of Numbers"" is especially McCullochian in its pastoral whimsy.) As such
column12: there's often a palpable disconnect between Anderson's naughty narratives and the passivity of the performances: only in its accelerated
column13: 40-second finale does the shimmering ""Crash About to Happen"" realize its potential as a Stone Roses-worthy student-disco staple
column14: while the sluggish
column15: bluesy swing of ""Thin Men Dancing"" sounds like it'd be more at home on a Beady Eye album. But in the elegant opening ballad
column16: ""Unsung""
column17: and the ticking time-bomb intensity of ""The Exiles""
column18: we hear a boldness that's largely been absent from Anderson's solo work to date. ""I am yearning/ I'm still burning
column19: he dramatically declares on the latter-- and while Black Rainbows may represent more of a flickering flame than a raging inferno
column20:
it at least yields some evidence that Anderson's once-fiery persona has not been completely extinguished.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16994/homepage_large.ed6a06ca.jpg|Nice|28773.0|Speculator|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Underwater Peoples']|2011-09-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:00.674999|"

In spite of having the lo-fi ""slacker"" label hung around his neck at nearly every turn
column2: L.A.'s Nick Ray is far from a slouch. For the past couple of years
column3: he's been releasing tapes for his one-man project Speculator
column4: taking samples and blurring
column5: frying
column6: or completely eviscerating them. Much of his music to this point sounded like 1980s and early-1990s nostalgia blown apart from the inside. While the notion of sample-based music is usually accompanied by the image of someone hovering over a machine
column7: Ray treats his compositions with the immediacy of a garage band finally figuring out its parts-- everything is usually nailed in the first take. Last year's Lifestyle featured hair-metal
column8: chart-topping pop
column9: and the Super Shredder scene of the second Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie all thrown into a torrent of distortion. It was an avant-garde
column10: postmodern collage of blown-out pop music
column11: carrying the woozy and deteriorating quality of a frequently malfunctioning VHS tape.

column1: While Nice isn't as reliant on art-damaged nostalgic sign posts (it uses far fewer samples than his previous work)
column2: it certainly doesn't neuter Ray's flair for sonic exploration. The album effortlessly segues from 80s radio-ready pop-rock and chillwave to first-wave shoegaze and motorik. Ray can sound like he's from the Purling Hiss School of Classic-Rock Appropriation in one move
column3: and just as seamlessly turn in a lilting
column4: ambient piece that may or may not be named after a member of the Black Eyed Peas. There's the corrosive synth line that swells to the top of ""Design""
column5: and there's the tape decay and clanging guitars that interrupt ""I'm a Slug"". What's remarkable about Nice is how cohesive it sounds in spite of the vast array of styles; it never submits to the ""album that sounds like a mixtape"" format; instead
column6: it sounds like the work of an artist crafting everything he touches into something of his very own.

column1: This is the first Speculator full-length pressed onto vinyl
column2: and Nice is definitely a work of two sides. Side One sounds like an album all on its own
column3: starting with the found-sound rumblings and spectral guitar line of the album intro and ending with album highlight ""(It's on) Every Channel""
column4: a blaring drone track whose tempos and pitches are shifted by Ray using the tape machine itself as an instrument
column5: a trick he uses more subtly on a few of the album's tracks. The four songs on Side Two feature a meditative pace
column6: the album's final minutes a more glacial stride than the pop-focused numbers that populated Side One. Instead of ending with the slow burn of ballad ""Blue Rose""
column7: Nice closes with the buildup of distorted synths that is ""Sweet Emotion"". Even without a drum track
column8: the rhythm of the song's elements is hypnotic
column9: eventually swirling into a vertigo of drone and delay effects
column10: serving as the album's eroded
column11: dissonant
column12:
and weirdly effective punctuation mark.

This year's been a good one for 1990s revivalism

column3: the trio of Tucker Rountree
column4: Emily Oppenheimer
column5: and Ross Condon (brother of Beirut frontman Zach Condon)
column6: are an easy addition to the ""movement."" They've cited Nirvana
column7: Weezer
column8: Beck
column9: the Breeders
column10: and Sonic Youth as musical touchstones
column11: and you can hear those influences in their scuzzy guitars. But the 90s aren't just a musical inspiration-- they're the band's entire aesthetic. They co-opted the typography and dinosaur from the Jurassic Park logo and slapped their own name on it. They named their band after Richard Linklater's 1991 film Slacker. Their lyrics cite ""Full House""
column12: New Kids on the Block
column13: and Bagel Bites. They have an entire song about a VHS collection and another one called ""Stuck in '93"". It's not a subtle implementation of the decade's many pastiches

column1: Total Slacker's sense of humor is the album's driving force
column2: and it's both overt and weirdly specific. The lyrics
column3: for the most part
column4: are a goofy celebration of the slacker caricature. Between the references to weed and various snack foods
column5: and the record's languid pace

column7: for example
column8: is a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles-style branding for a guy who goes back to the 18th century because marijuana isn't illegal then. And the title ""Stealing From Salvation Army"" says it all-- he plans on doing just that after he wakes up in the afternoon. That's pretty much the whole album. Thrashin' largely depends on buying into that character and thinking it's funny
column9: or at least interesting
column10: for 40 minutes.

column1: At first
column2: it works-- the aesthetic is clearly defined
column3: and the jokey tone of each track functions as a cohesive statement. Most of the juvenile imagery is funny (""He's watching 'Full House'
column4: playing Sega on his Slip 'n Slide"")
column5: but an extended 1993 joke backed by a series of ""woo's"" and references to Crystal Pepsi ultimately doesn't stick. After you've heard the songs a few times
column6: the gags become empty and start to sound like a roll call of 90s nostalgia keywords and stereotypes. And worse
column7: some of the lyrics eventually grate (the second series of VHS references
column8: for example).

column1: It's up to the music itself to hold up the album
column2: and for the most part
column3: their alt-rock churn works in their favor. The hooks
column4: grinding guitars
column5: and ""ooh-waas"" of ""Psychic Mesa"" may drag
column6: but they're catchy. If that song presents a joke
column7: it's the most subtle one of the album (it's a song about an ideal psychedelic otherworld

column6: and the brash

column3: a moddish organ gives the bouncy ""I Might"" the spring in its step

column7: whose hotshot contributions to Wilco's last two LPs sometimes felt like glorified session work

column7: seconds later

column9: ""And yet I wish I were there with you""-- his meaning's certainly clear. This back-and-forth between alluring nonsense and open-hearted sentiment isn't new for Tweedy

column6: rather
column7: a very good

column8:
reveling in their own contradictions.

Gem Club is an exclusive society: two people
