You know that eerie feeling when you find yourself alone in a huge public place that's usually crowded-- maybe a shopping mall or a playing field-- but at that moment is totally empty? This record sounds like a sustained version of that feeling. ""I Heard the Party"" juxtaposes echoing piano chords and a general sense of unease (""No one could have told you/ Your body would fail you"") with the refrain ""I heard the party's here"" floating across the track like the sound of dried up laughter. The word ""party"" feels so out of place in a song so pensive and lonely that there's something jarring about the experience. The feeling crops up repeatedly on Breakers: a sense of slow-motion detachment
column6: a suggestion that there were signs of life here once
column7: but you've arrived a couple of hours-- or maybe a couple of weeks-- too late.

column3: and the succinct and powerful ""Red Arrow (John)"" showcases Kristen Drymala's cello playing. The strings often feel like the most corporeal elements of  the whole record-- Barnes' voice takes the shape of breath turned visible on a frigid morning. ""Wait until spring sets in

column3: Ariel Pink's music has felt like a memory dump. His smarmy 1970s hooks
column4: new-wave crooning
column5: and AM-radio aura aren't so much recycled as regurgitated
column6: the sound of internalized pop culture projected back out
column7: with many original qualities still intact. As his discography has grown
column8: though
column9: his songs have seemed less about other people's work than his own. His first big studio album
column10: 2010's Before Today
column11: had its share of retro references but was most interesting for how it furthered his own history.

column1: Pink's older days have returned via a ""one-off digital single
column2: the 16-minute ""Witchhunt Suite for WWII"". He started the piece in 2001
column3: right after the terrorist attacks of September 11 (eventually selling a CD-R of it at shows in 2007). This is a recently re-recorded version
column4: but it retains his early penchant for cultural collage. Samples of George Bush speeches and news reports mix with lyrics that rhyme ""Bin Laden"" with ""Sodom"" and dadaist war chants like ""Building big bomb/ Building the bombs/ Building bombs."" The song's video offers even more retro spew
column5: hacking together 9/11 imagery
column6: random ads
column7: and tons of VHS debris
column8: with Pink and his crew (including forefather R. Stevie Moore) occasionally keyed over the montage
column9: echoing cable-access parodists Tim and Eric.

column1: It's all pretty fun
column2: both as postmodern patchwork and nostalgia trip. But
column3: at least at first
column4: the only point seems to be the thrill of randomly tossing historically-charged words and images against the wall. It's tempting to let the point just be the great music-- ""Witchhunt Suite"" is intensely catchy
column5: and its length allows Pink to stretch good ideas into better ones
column6: moving from tight jamming to slow keyboard meditations to freaked-out climaxes. Still
column7: you'd hope there'd be more to a 9/11 concept piece than awesome tuneage.

column1: On further listens
column2: there are points where ""Witchhunt Suite"" transcends the sum of its hooks. Take a moment when Pink moans
column3: ""the human race is an invention of the West
column4: over a cycling keyboard. The obvious dig is that the first world has marginalized the rest of the planet
column5: but Pink's bigger point seems to be that everything is a construct. Whether art is random memories or finely tuned narrative
column6: it's all fiction
column7: a way of artificially ordering things that in reality are much messier. He's also implying that cheesy retro-pop
column8: especially when it's done this well
column9: can be as political as folk or punk. After all
column10: if the whole human race is an invention
column11: certainly genres are
column12: too.

column1: Having shot that conceptual hole into ""Witchhunt Suite""
column2: Pink fills it with a chorus that's ironic and yet somehow beyond irony: ""Gonna get 'em/ We got 'em/ We gotta!"" He's clearly taunting the childishness of treating world politics like pro wrestling
column3: but there's something joyful in the way he dives into that isolated slogan
column4: freed from the baggage of its specific context. Afterward
column5: Pink quickly drops back into 9/11 collage
column6: randomly rapping about burning bras
column7: ""mass deception
column8: and U.S. domination. But at its peaks
column9:
""Witchhunt Suite for World War III"" is more complicated than that.

column3: Fred McDowell-- an overalls-wearing
column4: stoop-shouldered
column5: Panola County cotton farmer-- picked up an old acoustic guitar and wandered over to his neighbor Lonnie Young's house. Word had spread that the folklorist Alan Lomax (traveling with the English singer Shirley Collins and a 26-pound
column6: two-track reel-to-reel tape machine) was hunting local artists to record for Atlantic Records. McDowell
column7: who was born around 1904 in Rossville
column8: Tennessee
column9: had grown up imitating the still-nascent sound of the Delta blues
column10: using an old pocketknife (and then a whittled-down bovine rib bone
column11: and finally the squat neck of a Gibson's gin bottle) as a rudimentary slide. By the time McDowell
column12: then 55
column13: cornered Lomax on Young's porch
column14: his scope (and his skill) had broadened
column15: and the sound he made-- a mesmerizing
column16: groove-based blues that both nodded to and defied his Delta predecessors-- instantly captivated Lomax
column17: and eventually the world.

column1: Fred McDowell: The Alan Lomax Recordings (available as a download through Global Jukebox
column2: the Alan Lomax Archive's digital imprint
column3: and on LP via Mississippi Records) opens with Bukka White's ""Shake 'Em on Down""
column4: a song that McDowell appears to enjoy playing more than he enjoys breathing or eating or maybe doing anything else at all.  Following Lomax's prompt-- ""1
column7: go
column8: he commands in his high
column9: nasal voice-- McDowell locks into a heavy
column10: propulsive groove
column11: while his sister
column12: Fanny Davis
column13: blows into a homemade kazoo that Lomax
column14: in The Land Where the Blues Began
column15: described as ""a fine-toothed comb wrapped in toilet paper"" (it sure is loud). ""Shake 'Em on Down"" is a bracing introduction to the cadence of North Mississippi Hill Country blues: McDowell's guitar is disorienting and relentless
column16: so rhythmic and mind-bending that if you were to
column17: say
column18: listen to it while driving down a dark road in the rain
column19: you'd likely veer off into a ditch (and then feel relieved). Davis' kazooing-- itself vaguely lawless-- provides a welcome counterpoint (it's like staring at a fixed point on the horizon while trying not to vomit over the side of a boat)
column20: while Miles Pratcher (of the excellent local square dance band the Pratcher Brothers) assaults a second guitar. The result is mystifying and spectacular.

column1: McDowell's rendition of ""Good Morning Little Schoolgirl"" (a deeply fucked-up-- if not particularly uncommon-- ode to little girls
column2: made famous
column3: first
column4: by Sonny Boy Williamson
column5: and then again by the Grateful Dead) is more of a showcase for his nimble guitar work than any rogue sexual proclivities. McDowell's muted delivery of the lyrics (""Good mornin' 'lil school girl/ Can I go home
column6: can I go home with you?/ Tell your mama and your papa/ Lord
column7: I'm a little school boy
column8: too"") is merciful; he's politely disinterested
column9: if not fully disengaged. McDowell reserves his howls of longing for slightly less uncouth fare
column10: like ""Worried Mind Blues""
column11: an unrequited love song he imbues with legitimate anguish (""You make me weak and you make me moan
column12: he groans
column13: sounding broken). Mostly
column14: though
column15: the rhythm is the thing: With his twangy
column16: piercing strums
column17: McDowell establishes himself as a singular player
column18: infinitely more interested in the transcendental than the germane. Somehow
column19: he manages to make the acoustic guitar-- that purveyor of sweet lullabies!-- sound menacing

column1: After McDowell was featured on one of Lomax's Sounds of the South compilations
column2: he enjoyed considerable acclaim outside of north Mississippi (the timing was right with the folk revival of the 1960s gathering steam) and more than a dozen solo LPs
column3: although none approaches the looseness of his first session for Lomax. In 1971
column4: the Rolling Stones covered McDowell's ""You Got to Move"" for Sticky Fingers; it's a sluggish and deliberate rendition
column5: and Jagger's approximation of McDowell's worn
column6: scratchy voice feels both flat and affected. A year later
column7: McDowell died of stomach cancer; his body
column8: swaddled in a silver lamé suit (a gift from the Stones)
column9: is buried at the Hammond Hill Baptist Church
column10: near Como
column11: Miss. Supposedly
column12: Bonnie Raitt-- a guitar student of McDowell's-- paid for a new headstone after the original misspelled his name.

column1: It's awfully easy to approach archival releases-- and field recordings
column2: especially-- with a detached reverence
column3: at least in part because they were rendered spontaneously on front porches and in backyards
column4: miles from the formal
column5: self-conscious fussing of the recording studio. Consequently
column6: any and all fidelity issues tend to be heard as sepia-toned
column7: ""atmospheric"" snafus (oh
column8: crickets!); judgment is clouded by access
column9: and we feel lucky-- embarrassed
column10: even-- to be privy to these odd little moments at all. Accordingly
column11: what's most remarkable about The Alan Lomax Recordings is its spectacular re-mastering job (per the Portland-based engineer Timothy Stollenwerk); now
column12: it's possible to divorce these songs from their contexts long enough to be properly flabbergasted by McDowell's hypnotic
column13: eager performance (although
column14: should you get curious
column15: the collection is also beautifully annotated by Arhoolie Records' Adam Machado and the Lomax Archive's Nathan Salsburg). None of these tracks was previously unreleased (all have appeared
column16: in one form or another
column17: on various compilations
column18: many long out of print)
column19: but The Alan Lomax Recordings still feels revelatory-- and for his part

Just as a new generation of musicians is finding inspiration in lo-fi indie from the early 1990s
column3: Jack Yarber has more or less abandoned the scene for a grittier sound that's more junkyard than garage. A onetime member of Memphis stalwarts the Compulsive Gamblers and the Oblivians
column4: he's also recorded a handful of albums under a variety of aliases
column5: plying a mid-fi
column6: R&B-tinged boogie rock that has more in common with Suicide or how you wish New York Dolls sounded than with his former projects. Rat City
column7: released under the Jack Oblivian moniker
column8: is a solo record in the truest sense
column9: with Yarber playing almost all the instruments himself and only occasionally outsourcing to local musicians like librarian/badass Ross Johnson and local guitarist John Paul Keith. These songs are Camaro'ed out
column10: streamlined for headlong tempos and seedy urgency.

column1: Rat City is not ironic cock rock: Oblivian betrays no smirk
column2: just a coolly stoic expression capped with dark sunglasses. What should be limiting
column3: however
column4: is instead a blueprint for a stylistically diverse album
column5: one that changes shape and direction almost with every song. Rat City is a bustling
column6: ungentrified metropolis: Memphis standing in for 1970s New York City. With its disco-derived bassline and close-to-the chest drumming
column7: ""Crime of Love"" wields a mirrorball as a murder weapon
column8: and Yarber's cover of ""Moses & Me"" mugs the Tommy James original
column9: drenching it in distortion but maintaining the original blues-pop energy. His greatest reach may be the album's greatest payoff: Local indie-pop outfit Star & Micey back him on ""Girl on the Beach""
column10: which sounds like boardwalk-era Springsteen and Dexys Midnight Runners kicking over Wavves' sandcastle. It's an adult summer anthem with a fall release
column11: a discrepancy that more or less sums up the song's sense of wistful frustration with unattainable people and unreachable places.

column1: The downside of this rambling aesthetic is that Yarber occasionally comes across as a cipher
column2: too cool and detached to maintain a specific perspective from one song to the next. Instead
column3: what threads the album together isn't his vocals or even the songwriting
column4: but the guitars. Yarber is a slyly inventive player
column5: deploying concise riffs in a variety of styles and changing them subtly with each repetition. By himself
column6: he's a commanding presence
column7: but he's even better when he can bounce off a second guitarist
column8: like Keith or Jake Vest. They bluster bluesily through ""Mass Confusion"" and roll out Bakersfield variants on ""Kidnapper""
column9:
simultaneously enabling the stylistic digressions to cohere into a focused record. They lend Rat City its punk shrewdness and endow these songs with a prickly intelligence that makes what could have been dumb rock sound seriously smart.

It can be difficult establishing a sense of personality in ambient music. Because of a relative formlessness and a lack of narrative-building lyrics
column2: many of the ways artists assert themselves are via extra-musical details like album art
column3: liner notes
column4: or artist bios on the far wonky side of the spectrum. Think
column5: for instance
column6: of Brian Eno's genre-defining essays to the nature-worshipping or the botanically-themed titles of Biosphere. Brock Van Wey
column7: aka bvdub
column8: offers another good example. Van Wey is a hyper-prolific ambient producer-- six full-length releases this year alone
column9: counting one collaboration with Ian Hagwood-- whose deeply sentimental titles (""This Place Had Known Only Sadnes""
column10: ""There Was Nothing But Beauty in My Heart"") and cover art of cold
column11: lonely landscapes lit from within by a heavenly glow
column12: place him in a corner one might term ""emo-ambient.""

column1: It's a minor niche
column2: maybe
column3: but bvdub is hardly alone. Ghostly International artist the Sight Below has leveraged similarly sad-sack song titles-- ""Feeling Lost Forever""
column4: ""Burn Me Out From the Inside""-- to evoke goth's mope and shoegaze's introversion. (The Sight Below's also gone so far as to record an actual Joy Division cover
column5: making the leap from mere signposting to straight-up homage). A certain type of music fan might be disposed to see these weepy marble-notebook poetry headings as kind of a flipside to the playful and potty-mouthed wordiness that helped distinguished the Locust and Kid 606 as abrasive sonic pranksters rather than faceless avant noisemakers.

column1: The songs on bvdub's newest
column2: <i>I Remember
column3: tend to follow a standard ambient formula
column4: one made most familiar to indie audiences via Wolfgang Voigt's masterful Gas albums for Kompakt
column5: on whose Pop Ambient series Van Wey has also appeared: a wash of sound builds-- layers of white noise
column6: echo
column7: and submerged melodies-- gradually reaching a climax sustained and minutely varied for minutes on end. Out of these slowly shifting clouds
column8: any number of distinct elements (massed choral voices
column9: the metallic pluck of an individual guitar string
column10: echoing finger snaps) might emerge before being swirled back into the fog. Which is not to say the songs are mere static-- a single track (all but one of which on the 78-minute album clocks in at 13 minutes or more) might subtly evolve through multiple movements before you realize they've passed. There are also slight but noticeable deviations from the ambient template: ""Would It Be the Same"" begins as a piano played in a bottomless well of reverb but gives way to the album's lone beat-driven passage
column11: full of prickly
column12: brittle-sounding hi-hat skitter.

column1: Personality is a different concern from mood
column2: of course
column3: and I Remember would be thick with mood even without the handy reference points of track names and album covers. From the slowly coalescing guitar figure that opens the record to the Arctic-wind howl that fades it out
column4: bvdubs' tracks effectively conjure feelings of
column5: alternately
column6:
frigid isolation and quietly blissful/wistful reverie.

Of all the loveable things about Jens Lekman
column3: my favorite is how he tosses banana peels on the paths of conventional taste. Seldom does such wonderful music sound so comically awful when you try to describe it to someone. ""Man
column4: he's amazing
column5: like Neil Sedaka with a bit of a head cold singing over the Love Boat theme song."" By the time you get that far
column6: dude is already backing away slowly. A Swedish indie-pop dramatist who introduces sarcastic modernity to the most gloriously moribund styles of the 20th century-- from orientalist world music to suburban exotica-- Lekman guides an enthusiastic tour through the dustiest yard-sale record collections
column7: conjuring obscure shades of Henry Mancini
column8: Harry Belafonte
column9: and Bobby McFerrin. Smooth saxes and indigenous flutes jostle against some of the most quotable one-liners this side of Das Racist. Listening to him gives me strange urges
column10: like downloading the latter-day Beach Boys discography.

column1: With such an approach
column2: it would be easy to slip into actual decadence or mere parody. Lekman
column3: a slippery character
column4: avoids both because of his rich
column5: alloyed personality
column6: which can sop up any amount of pink champagne. He whisks us out of the authenticity-obsessed house that punk built into provinces where music more openly embraces the attributes of the actor
column7: taking a stance of ebullient knowingness toward the abundant variety and complex artifice on the fringes of pop. He's very clever with frames
column8: using vocal inflections and contextual cues to pack whole ways of life into deceptively simple lines. On his previous full-length record
column9: 2007's Night Falls Over Kortedala
column10: he sang
column11: ""I was slicing up an avocado/ When you came up behind me."" Not much on paper
column12: but when activated by Lekman's exaggeratedly tony diction and cozy music
column13: it captured the texture of a contemporary bourgeois existence in one gnomic stroke. The Lucksmiths were great at this same kind of evocative shorthand
column14: though Lekman brings to it a slightly more jaundiced eye.

column1: Lekman's new An Argument with Myself EP is a compact gem. It tilts this way and that to show different facets of the singer: his ruminative side
column2: his topical side
column3: his devotional side
column4: his wicked  humor
column5: skewed insight
column6: and flawless banality. At less than 18 minutes
column7: there isn't a wasted moment. Each song does something distinct both sonically and lyrically
column8: filtering one rarified but relatable sensibility through guise after revealing guise. We meet Lekman the flâneur
column9: the desultory anecdotalist
column10: the affable trickster. You can practically see the emotions mugging on his face as he gets into character
column11: the startled eyes or the lopsided grin. There are elements of droll pastiche
column12: like how the goofy horns on ""New Directions"" take a seamless turn to resemble the augustly rational Jean-Joseph Mouret music made famous by Masterpiece Theater. But Lekman is equally a throwback to songwriters like Paul Simon; gifted raconteurs who weren't afraid to try just about anything and trusted their sweet
column13: creamy voices to make it work.

column1: If Lekman owes Simon any debt
column2: it's paid in full on the title track
column3: a sparkling Afro-Caribbean whirl that sounds like a 21st-century European's answer to Graceland. The elliptically conversational lyrics
column4: the clotted backing harmonies
column5: the thin line between singing and mellifluous speech
column6: the existential undertow of Lekman's self-interrogation while wandering through Melbourne
column7: his new home-- Simon probably would’ve stopped short of crying ""Why ya' hitting yourself? Why ya' hitting yourself?"" but otherwise they're totally simpatico. Lekman's thoughts meander with his footsteps
column8: which lead him in surprising but just-right directions. There's a song about stalking Kirsten Dunst while she filmed Melancholia in Lekman's native Gothenburg that works overtime as both an ode to provincialism and a protracted joke
column9: complete with a droopy slide-whistle punchline. And whenever we find our own feet in a song
column10: Lekman pulls the rug out from under us. He uses key changes to signal transitions between social criticism and personal pledges on the convalescence card ""A Promise""
column11: and switches narrative perspective midstream on the plush reggae closer so that what we initially heard as snarky small talk is suddenly bathed in a touching romantic glow.

column1: There's a lot to be said for exploring the nuances of clichés in songwriting
column2: and most of it has been said. Listening to Lekman makes me sharply aware of how the generic and the cryptic have come to dominate pop lyrics
column3: from Lady Gaga on down to Girls. The modern lingua franca is an abstract slipstream of memories
column4: slogans
column5: admonitions
column6: and impressions
column7: as if emotional states were free-floating entities
column8: unmoored from specific experiences. This mode is ideal for self-projection and introspection
column9: both valuable quantities. But Lekman's music makes me think more about other people than myself. For all of their polished mannerisms
column10: his songs are uncommonly free of pretenses-- they're about people
column11: places
column12: and things that happened or could happen in the world; about how we spend our time and how we talk to each other. Against a backdrop of enigmatic universalism
column13: musicians who undertake the ticklish business of pinning down the minutiae of human affairs are very dear. Alongside Dan Bejar and Bill Callahan
column14:
Jens Lekman stands tall among them.

column3: I had the opportunity to briefly interview Van Dyke Parks. It wasn't long after his collaboration with Joanna Newsom on Ys. brought him some fresh headlines
column4: but I mostly  asked about his long
column5: itinerant career as arranger for three decades of rock musicians
column6: from Brian Wilson and the Byrds to Rufus Wainwright and Frank Black. After amiably answering my questions
column7: he signed off
column8: semi-sardonically
column9: with ""Thank you
column10: Jayson
column11: for celebrating a position that perhaps serves best in its anonymity.""

column1: The remark seemed half self-deprecating jab
column2: half mission statement: Parks has a career-long acquaintance with anonymity.  His most well-known association is with a record that
column3: for thirty-odd years
column4: was famous for never coming out. His solo records
column5: starting with 1968's confounding Harry Nilsson-meets-Charles Ives opus Song Cycle
column6: are subjects of fervent cult adoration but known to few.  His arranging work
column7: meanwhile
column8: has put an inimitable stamp on American pop
column9: though the vast majority of music fans have no idea when they are listening to his work. He is the quintessential liner-notes hero
column10: in other words
column11: which makes the overview of <i>Arrangements
column12: Vol. 1
column13: on his own label Bananastan
column14: that much more gratifying.

column1: The compilation is curated by Parks himself
column2: drawing on what he calls ""my earliest studio adventures in the 60s."" The roster of collaborators represented here is dizzying-- Little Feat
column3: Arlo Guthrie
column4: Sal Valentino
column5: Bonnie Raitt singing calypso-- and hearing Parks' unifying hand presiding over this collision of styles makes for a wonderful way to experience the art of his arrangements; their lushness
column6: their invention
column7: how they provide the texture and teeth to a composition. He opens with an arrangement ripped off the bones of the song it was meant to accompany: a mono single mix of Donovan's ""Donovan's Colours"". It's a gently instructive focusing tool for the rest of the album
column8: training our ears to go to the margins
column9: to pay attention to the filigree.

column1: Not that Parks' arrangements need much prompting to be noticed. They don't exactly fade demurely into the background; they jostle and blurt
column2: intruding brazenly into the songs they support. His arrangement for Sal Valentino's goofy zydeco number ""Alligator Man"" boasts not  one vigorously sawing fiddle
column3: but two-- on top of twinkling mandolins
column4: a seasick tuba groaning low notes
column5: snatches of saloon piano
column6: and a piping saxophone. It sounds horrendously overcrowded on paper
column7: but Parks has an uncanny instinct for how to densely populate a composition's every corner without choking it. The instruments are spaced evenly in the mix
column8: and the result feels like a bustling table of gregarious friends instead of a crazy-making riot.

column1: All of these embellishments
column2: of course
column3: were obsessively layered and re-layered onto increasingly overworked analog tape
column4: and Arrangements
column5: which kicks off with the sound of a rickety reel-to-reel firing up
column6: is also partly a tale told by that tape. Parks' arrangements come through intriguingly warped
column7: as if all the instruments on the track had been fished from a flooded studio floor
column8: and the wobbly
column9: dazed sound world that results
column10: however accidental
column11: is crucial to the record's appeal. The sumptuous string orchestra Parks supplies to Arlo Guthrie's take on the Appalachian standard ""Valley to Pray""
column12: sounds gelatinous
column13: a symphony viewed through a fish-bowl. The Mojo Men's ""Sit Down I Think I Love You"" would be a standard-issue mod-pop song in a simpler context
column14: but Parks' arrangement sends the song stumbling through a haze of slide guitar and bandoneón that feels like linoleum curling in real time. It's nearly impossible to pick out every individual instrument from the soup on these songs (is that a harp? a celesta? a  zither?)
column15: but the sound world is wonderfully dense and liquid
column16: and it fills headphones like sunlight flooding a window.

column1: The songs selected on Arrangements are uniformly fantastic. Bonnie Raitt's cover of Calypso Rose's racy ""Wah She Go Do"" is hilarious and startling
column2: and Jimmy Cliff's ""Sitting in Limbo"" gets an improbably gorgeous reading by Dean Martin's son Dino. But trying to imagine them without Parks' additions
column3: as the compilation encourages you to
column4: is illuminating. Pop-song arrangements tend to hide in plain sight
column5: and are usually practiced by spotlight-averse eccentrics who fit comfortably into neither the classical or the pop worlds. But the pop universe would be drained of color without them-- try to hear the Delfonics' ""La-La (Means I Love You)"" without its nimbus of strings
column6: or
column7: for that matter
column8: the Beach Boys' ""Surf's Up"" without the distant horns and chimes. Arrangements is a joy to spend time with
column9: but it also amounts to a pretty forceful argument for the lost art of arrangement itself
column10:
and for Parks as one of its unrivaled masters.

column7: White ain't part of it. He works in sticky
column8: abstracted hip-hop rhythms coated in THC resin; 2009's The Strange Dreams of Paul White
column9: one of his earlier full-lengths (all of which can be heard on his Bandcamp page) found Captain Beefheart bumping up against weirded-out boom-bap.

column1: Those previous releases felt homemade and somewhat amateurish
column2: a distinction which makes Rapping With Paul White a bit of a coming-out party: there's equal parts mutant funk and dusty beats here
column3: but it sounds like White's first true statement of purpose
column4: his own preferred introduction to new listeners. Perhaps not coincidentally
column5: it's also his first LP that largely features guest vocals (this is where the Rapping comes in); White's gathered names both recognizable (Danny Brown
column6: Homeboy Sandman
column7: frequent past collaborator Guilty Simpson) and not-so-recognizable (Marv Won
column8: Moe Pope
column9: Tranqill).

column1: So this is a record that depends as much on what the spitters bring to the table as what White cooks up in the lab-- and
column2: unfortunately
column3: the rappers don't exactly come correct. Considering how he and White have a past history of collaborating
column4: you'd think that Guilty Simpson and White would be firing on all cylinders by now; instead
column5: the Detroit hardhead unfurls cliché after cliché and drops vague
column6: autobiographical teases that don't reveal much in particular. (Though he gets points for the ""murdering mic's like Conrad Murray"" line in ""Dirty Slang"".) His performances are uninspiring enough to think that of last year's full-length collab with Madlib
column7: the cleverly titled OJ Simpson
column8: relied solely on 'Lib's beatcraft.

column1: Fellow Motor City spitter Marv Won rides the chant-knock of ""Run Shit"" ably
column2: but spoils the broth by getting corny about Heath Ledger; Queens native Homeboy Sandman
column3: on the other hand
column4: basically recounts a trip to England on ""A Weird Day""
column5: which is about as thrilling as it sounds. Even Danny Brown
column6: another Detroit rapper that is having a very good year with his excellent
column7: audacious XXX mixtape
column8: is smothered by the spiraling carnival melodies and game-show filth of ""One of Life's Pleasures""
column9: his trademark excitability barely registering. The only rapper that comes out of this unscathed is White's labelmate Tranqill
column10: whose cadences on ""Rotten Apples"" match well with White's searing
column11: void-creating beat.

column1: There are instrumental versions of Rapping With Paul White out there and I strongly suggest seeking out those versions
column2: if only to feel the blunt impact of White's strongest moves (the spooky claps of ""Trust"" and ""Indigo Glow""
column3: in particular). You could take a rap-less version of this LP and convince your friends that it's a beat tape from Madlib or Oh No
column4: a quality that speaks as much to White's influences as it does his lack of a specific identity. Thing is
column5: copping to Stones Throw influences almost seems quaint these days
column6: as anyone with an ear to the ground has noticed that much of the underground hip-hop that's in vogue relies on quiet introspection
column7: stronger drugs
column8: and ambient
column9: eerie beats made by people who inexplicably refer to themselves as Friendzone. The fact that Rapping With Paul White sounds so old-head suggests that the ""Stones Throw sound
column10: made most popular by the late J. Dilla's inimitable Donuts
column11:
is on the verge of transitioning from old school to just plain old.

"|15852.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15852-rapping-with-paul-white/|6.7|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16969/homepage_large.d6bd1612.jpg|Fatou|29937.0|Fatoumata Diawara|['Global'
column2: 'Pop/R&B'
column4: Fatoumata Diawara moved to France to pursue an acting career. She appeared in a handful of films and worked with a street theater troupe but really found her calling later
column5: when she took up the guitar and started writing songs. Born in Cote d'Ivoire and raised in southern Mali
column6: Diawara grew up hearing Wassoulou music
column7: a song style that's thought by some ethnomusiclogists to be one of the main pre-colonial ancestors of blues. The Wassoulou cultural area is now split between three countries
column8: but it has a history that extends back centuries
column9: and Diawara merges that long
column10: traditional history with a modern
column11: globalized sensibility on her debut album.

column1: Diawara has honed her performing and recording craft through work with AfroCubism
column2: Orchestre Poly-Rythmo
column3: and Herbie Hancock
column4: among others
column5: so really the big step here is to recording her own songs with her own arrangements. She has a voice with a naturally sensual glide to it that sometimes reminds me a little of Sade. Unlike many of her peers
column6: such as Oumou Sangaré
column7: power is not really a part of her style-- she keeps her singing even and steady to complement the hypnotic
column8: cycling guitar parts of her arrangements. The album is quietly intense
column9: rarely rising above the volume of ordinary conversation.

column1: Diawara sings in her native Wassoulou language
column2: but understanding the exact content of the songs isn't necessary to enjoy them. There's plenty of information in the melodies and rhythms
column3: and inventive musicianship as well. Diawara locks in with the simmering funk backdrop of ""Bissa"" by playing harmonics on her guitar instead of full chords. The electric leads seem to float up out of the patterns; several times over the course of the album
column4: I found myself caught up in a flowing solo that I didn't even notice when it started. This is how the whole record works. There's no fanfare
column5: nothing is announced. It simply surrounds you with its atmosphere.

column1: It is an ultimately beguiling album because of this. Even in its most demonstrative moments
column2: such as the shivering lead guitar line that opens ""Bakonoba""
column3: it's a record you can sink into and enjoy for its sonics as well as its songwriting. ""Bakonoba"" is among the songs with the strongest West African character
column4: and that guitar is a big part of it-- it's reminiscent of the type of lead Malian guitarists Djelimady Tounkara or Kanté Manfila might have once laid down for the Rail Band. Otherwise
column5:
Diawara is one of a growing number of musicians working on a sort of pan-folk sound that incorporates influences from across a broad Afro-Western cultural spectrum. It's an approach that may be a better fit for the ""world music"" label than any of the highly localized sounds that tag's often applied to.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16977/homepage_large.2355ff8d.jpg|Parodia Flare|28970.0|Tropics|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-09-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:10.549020|"

Tropics mastermind Chris Ward is a voracious and accomplished student of sound. Parodia Flare is the British twentysomething's full-length debut as Tropics
column2: and it's made of compellingly lush and languid bits of sonic material culled from a vast array of sources
column3: including touchstones as disparate as synth-pop
column4: Balearic
column5: Britpop
column6: dubstep
column7: African guitar-pop
column8: and goth. Ward demonstrates an impressive sensitivity in picking out elements of these genres and styles that can be pieced together in ways that are texturally satisfying and often beautiful.

column1: But
column2: ultimately
column3: what is he building? That's the question that gets Ward stuck at times throughout the album. For the most part Ward wants to make pop music here
column4: albeit a pop that's refracted through layers of wistful haze and humidity. Ward sings on most of these tracks
column5: yet while his voice does have a pleasantly boyish
column6: Damon Albarn-esque quality at times
column7: little-to-zero effort is invested in making the vocals anything more than another quietly pretty element floating through the mix. So it's up to Ward's soundscapes to communicate any sort of urgency or momentum or drive. When they do
column8: the results are both intoxicating and memorably tuneful. Parodia Flare's first proper song
column9: ""Mouves""
column10: features a pretty affectless vocal turn
column11: but fortunately gets carried by thrumming bass and steady drums to a neat little hook of pulsing tones. In this context
column12: the track's decorative elements
column13: all its chimes and soupy synths
column14: don't have to worry about carrying the song and can serve their ideal function as colorful embellishment.

column1: Ward's real saving grace on Parodia Flare is the guitar
column2: which he utilizes in unexpectedly welcome ways to propel his compositions
column3: keeping them from dissolving into murky keyboard washes. In particular
column4: the title track
column5: ""Playgrounds""
column6: and ""After Visiting"" draw delicate
column7: glinting melodies from the instrument. You spend those songs listening to the guitars then waiting for them to come back-- they lends the tracks a logic and tension that don't exist in some of Ward's other efforts
column8:
where less-distinctive sonic elements wander in then bleed away without conveying the sense that they're intrinsic to some greater whole. Ward has already proven he knows how to paint really lovely scenes through sound. Now he just needs to figure out how to best set those scenes in motion.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16957/homepage_large.960a0811.jpg|Fabriclive 59|1547.0|Four Tet|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2011-09-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:12.598732|"

Kieran Hebden has always been singled out for his adventurous tastes and the way his disparate obsessions have been seamlessly melded into his own stylistically restless music. Hebden listened without prejudice
column2: a value prized by both the post-rock and DJ communities he came out of at the tail end of the 1990s. Even as eclecticism took a beating in the early 2000s
column3: with mash-up acts and bedroom DJs turning the whole idea into a one-note joke or a cheap way to get noticed
column4: Hebden never shied away from mixing it all up
column5: provided the whole felt greater than the trick of joining seemingly incompatible parts.

column1: Fabric has made a point of flagging Hebden's new mix for its sonic and conceptual unity. Certainly it does feel all of a piece compared to his last commercially released mix
column2: a 2006 installment for the DJ-Kicks series that swerved from Akufen to Animal Collective. By contrast
column3: Fabriclive 59 sticks pretty consistently to one scene. But it's a restless scene built on a premise of constant reinvention: UK garage
column4: which from the late 1990s to the early 2000s mutated from a simultaneously roughed-up and opulent take on house music to the fierce and rap-derived clang-and-bang of grime.

column1: So already we've got the promise and surprise inherent in a famously eclectic selector bringing a freshness and fearlessness to music usually only spun by purist DJs sticking to music from within the scene. On that level
column2: Hebden doesn't disappoint. For one thing
column3: he includes ringers from way outside late-90s London
column4: like Ricardo Villalobos. And despite their modern
column5: weirdo-techno palette of sounds
column6: these left-field inclusions fit perfectly with the vibe of the old-school tunes
column7: especially the way someone like Villalobos treats his own heavily syncopated drums. As usual
column8: it's to Hebden's credit as a DJ that he hears ways to join old and new that others might not.

column1: But this is also a pretty unexpected and exciting way to tackle a big-time commission from Fabric
column2: especially considering the Fabriclive series tends to focus on up-to-the-minute dance sounds rather than the archival impulse. UK garage as an inventive and real-time underground phenomenon already seems a distant part of dance history
column3: despite being only about a decade gone. So for longtime garage heads
column4: Hebden's obsessive crate-digging will provide them with lots of unfamiliar and almost lost-to-history moments of genius. I've spent more time tracking this stuff down than I care to admit
column5: and I recognize only a couple of the vintage tunes here. But Fabriclive 59 will also expose Four Tet fans who come from entirely different worlds (indie
column6: IDM) to some truly luscious and forward-thinking dance music that's otherwise available only on out-of-print vinyl singles and even-more-out-of-print CD comps.

column1: Despite his rep as a boundary-crosser not beholden to any one scene
column2: Hebden has deep roots here as an engaged fan. The B-side to one of his first Four Tet singles
column3: ""Calamine""
column4: was an avant take on UK garage when almost no one in the rock or electronic worlds seemed to be paying attention. It's easy to see what appealed to him. UKG fulfilled dance music's no. 1 rule (keep it funky) while also sticking to a less-often-followed guideline (make that funk feel new again). Few producers at the time were doing as much to reinvent the art of beatmaking without trying for something expressly ""experimental"" and alienating clubbers along the way.

column1: So if you're a fan of those moments in rap or dance when baffling syncopations become an art in themselves
column2: when drum patterns feel like they couldn't possibly be played by a human with just two arms
column3: you'll find a lot to love here. And if you like your mixes to have the smooth bump and ingratiating warmness of house
column4: amazingly
column5: this music also fits the bill. After all
column6: the earliest UK garage cuts
column7: like Persian's ""Feel da Vibe""
column8: weren't so far from house's more steady sense of groove. It just had a lot more swing. Making broken-sounding rhythms swing was actually the primary goal of the best garage DJs
column9: and Hebden proves himself very attuned to making all these not always mix-friendly rhythms flow together. So much so that
column10: when he drops Musical Mob's ""Pulse X""-- the stomping and snarling and totally blunt track that announced grime as a new thing-- it seems to fit naturally with all these super-subtle syncopations.

column1: But true to Hebden's status-- insider fan trying to rekindle the UKG vibe and outsider after-the-fact archivist not beholden to the scene's rules-- Fabriclive 59 doesn't really play out like a true vintage garage mix would have. For one thing
column2: our DJ has some formalist fun with the disc's structure. After building a stretch of groove
column3: he lets things simmer down
column4: bridging the sections with sampled crowd noise from the Fabric club itself
column5: less breaking the mix's momentum than allowing a breather before things bubble back to life. The effect is like catching a pirate radio DJ in the mix
column6: only to dial across the airwaves and find another just-as-good set on a different station. Keeping listeners on their toes while also mimicking the way this music was often heard by fans-- it's an odd but effective approach
column7: especially considering the usual keep-the-party-going Fabriclive style. Fabriclive 59 feels more like a mixtape in the handcrafted sense
column8:
one friend making another a tape of special moments they may have missed. But of course few of us have a friend with the mixing skills or deep record collection of Kieran Hebden.

"|15830.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15830-fabriclive-59/|8.0|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16973/homepage_large.9deb118f.jpg|Mikal Cronin|29837.0|Mikal Cronin|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Trouble in Mind']|2011-09-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:13.149640|"

Just out of college
column2: Mikal Cronin already has a proven record at garage-rock bashing. As bassist and singer for the Moonhearts (formerly Charle & the Moonhearts)
column3: he spent his dorm-dwelling years releasing a sporadic string of fuzz-infused surf-rock tunes. More notably
column4: he's the Waylon Jennings to Ty Segall's Buddy Holly-- a collaborator and sideman who sometimes fills the bass chair in the psych-rock upstart's live band. Friends since high school
column5: they've released a split LP
column6: Reverse Shark Attack
column7: and a handful of singles. But it's Segall-- among the most prolific voices in the thoroughly prolific San Francisco garage scene-- who tends to get the top billing.

column1: On his eponymous debut
column2: Mikal Cronin proves he can hold his own. It's an album of wistful
column3: psychedelic pop that pits lush and layered arrangements against needle-pinning power chords. Like Segall's latest
column4: Goodbye Bread
column5: Cronin's solo turn finds him dialing back his thrashier impulses in order to clear space for singer-songwriter-style introspection. But when the curtain of lysergic gristle is pulled aside
column6: it turns out that they're not the same person
column7: after all. Even when he goes all Neil Young
column8: Segall still retains an affable beach-dude demeanor. Cronin turns out to be the more vulnerable voice-- Elliott Smith in throwback dress
column9: minus the self-loathing. And
column10: like Smith
column11: he has an ear for arrangements.

column1: Album opener ""Is It Alright"" pivots from Beach Boys-worthy harmonies to chugging chords to jangling acoustic guitars before
column2: finally
column3: spinning off into an outro that sounds like Jethro Tull gone hardcore punk. It's no so much that Cronin knows how to effectively layer instruments (though he does) or collage disparate ideas together (though he does)
column4: but that he knows how to use dynamics to his advantage. On ""Gone"" he works soft-to-loud changes
column5: dropping the bridge down to a whisper before bounding back up for a final
column6: climactic freak-out. At the end of ""Again and Again""
column7: Cronin drops out the rhythm section
column8: rebuilding the song over a gentle falsetto melody.

column1: Cronin's music owes a heavy debt to 1960s pop
column2: mostly T. Rex and the Beatles (the sax outro on ""Apathy"" is weirdly reminiscent of the Beatles ""Hey Jude"")
column3: but his tunes aren't precious period reconstructions. They're delivered with the gritty
column4: gnarly abandon of a Black Flag fan trying to come to terms with their parents' record collection. Like Segall
column5: Cronin brings a young energy to classic rock sounds because
column6: well
column7: he's actually young.

column1: In interviews
column2: Cronin has explained that the bulk of the album was written during the twilight months of his college career
column3: when he was lonely and stressed and taking refuge in his tape recorder. Not exactly as trying a set of circumstances as
column4: say
column5: Tupac recording ""Me Against the World""
column6: but a sensitive time
column7: for sure. It's a transition that marks the end of structured life and the onset of a long-postponed adulthood
column8: when you're too young and too old at the same time. Cronin nails that mood perfectly
column9: with songs that are frustrated and energetic but flagged with uncertainty and doubt. The songs kick hardest when those melancholy sentiments collide with his crunching
column10:
chugging psychedelic urges-- when the volume is blasting in both the amps and the emotions.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2011-09-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:13.693334|"

Maybe the best thing about Sports
column3: last year's bruising debut from San Francisco noise-poppers Weekend
column4: was simply how refreshing it sounded. While so many other lo-fi acts were still messing around with balmy haze and Nuggets jangle
column5: these guys took the sound down darker
column6: more aggressive paths. The album's marriage of squall and melody wasn't really anything new
column7: but just by channeling a different set of influences-- post-punk
column8: shoegaze
column9: the Jesus and Mary Chain-- Weekend's music felt so much more visceral than their peers'. At the same time
column10: Sports' charm boiled down to one idea executed very well
column11: and it wouldn't be unreasonable to worry if they had the depth to do that again.

column1: So it's encouraging to hear Weekend making significant alterations to their formula on the Red EP. Offered as a teaser for an as-yet-untitled
column2: upcoming LP
column3: Red finds the band operating in a much cleaner
column4: dreamier mode and mostly pulling it off. In addition to cutting back on the background screech that dominated Sports and drawing out more melody
column5: the big difference is how the band treats frontman Shaun Durkan's voice. Previously a croaky drone used as an accent
column6: Durkan's vox is richer
column7: recorded higher in the mix
column8: and able to carry a song on its own.

column1: The best place to hear Weekend's more direct approach is on standout ""Hazel""
column2: a killer shoegaze-pop number that has a lot in common with swirling 1990s classics like Catherine Wheel's ""Black Metallic"". Set over an insistent
column3: post-punk drumbeat and throbbing bass
column4: the track becomes nicely un-tethered
column5: letting guitars spin in and out of focus. There's great dark/light tension between its tight construction and looser elements
column6: and Durkan's vocal strings it all together with a warm pop hook. The band hits similar high notes on ""Sweet Sixteen"" and ""The One You Want"". The cool thing about these songs is that while they aren't as threatening as some of the Sports stuff
column7: they're no less dark-- it's just a more pensive and mysterious kind of noir.

column1: Red is only five tracks long
column2: and two of the cuts-- ""Your Own Nothing"" and the weirdly titled ""Golfers""-- are a little slight
column3: so there's only so much you can take away from it. But it's an important release for Weekend
column4: one of those classic transitional EPs-- Deerhunter's Rainwater Cassette Exchange and Abe Vigoda's Reviver spring to mind as recent examples-- where a band takes stock of its strengths and starts to pivot in a new direction. Maybe even more important is that it shows this band as much more agile and nuanced than some previously thought
column5:
able to make noise one part of its attack instead of the primary focus.

It's easy to picture Bryan Hollon casting a few interested glances at Ford & Lopatin earlier this year
column3: particularly when the duo gained acclaim for embellishing their work with overt 1980s pop references on Channel Pressure. Hollon
column4: better known by the Boom Bip moniker he's recorded under for more than a decade
column5: had already covered vastly territory in 2008 through his Neon Neon project with Super Furry Animals singer Gruff Rhys. But his work there and as Boom Bip has been characterized by a restless desire to keep his sound in flux
column6: to constantly seek out fresh collaborators and remixers
column7: to help pull away from any set patterns he may be settling into. Even Neon Neon
column8: which bustled with future potential
column9: quickly went quiet after Stainless Style was released.

column1: Hollon's work as Boom Bip has also fallen into protracted periods of silence-- this is the first full-length release under that name since the 2005 album Blue Eyed in the Red Room. The fastidious arrangements that proliferate throughout Zig Zaj suggest he's spent much of that time laboring over these tunes
column2: getting everything just right and slotting new collaborators into the fold. Hollon is primarily a producer of instrumental electronic works that grab from a range of disparate influences in that field. But he's also well known for the collaborators he brings into the fold. Rhys and Nina Nastasia featured on Blue Eyed; Alex Kapranos
column3: Money Mark
column4: and Josh Klinghoffer from the Red Hot Chili Peppers all worked on Zig Zaj.

column1: This one lacks a cohesive narrative in the same way that last Boom Bip full-length release did-- that's to be expected from an album with such a diverse crew on board. It's a world that takes some adjusting to
column2: especially when you get a great lurch from the Grizzly Bear-like
column3: chain-gang grind of ""All Hands"" to the broody noir-esque pop moves of the Kapranos-fronted ""Goodbye Lovers and Friends"". In fact
column4: casual listeners could be forgiven for thinking they had stumbled onto an outright indie rock record at certain points
column5: especially after a cursory listen to the verse-chorus-verse structure (complete with grinding guitars) of the latter song. On ""New Order"" Klinghoffer and Empire of the Sun vocalist Luke Steele garishly clash to push the Boom Bip sound closer to the kind of pop-metal-techno hybrid the Prodigy were practicing in their heyday.

column1: ""New Order"" is particularly jarring here and is likely to be a divisive and confounding track for Hollon's fans. It's a shame he found the need to bludgeon us so hard
column2: as his real forte comes from gradually layering on elements
column3: either in subtle
column4: slow-build movements (""Reveal"") or through steely
column5: Ladytron-esque grooves (""Automation""). It would be wrong to complain that Hollon doesn't know what he wants Boom Bip to be
column6: as he's always operated in this manner. But Zig Zaj feels like he's straining a little too hard to make every song different from the last
column7: where he’s actually become pinned down by the ""eclectic"" reputation he's accrued
column8: forcing him to make unwise decisions just to keep a certain degree of diversity afloat in his work.

column1: Fortunately
column2: there aren't too many other clangers in the vein of ""New Order"". The Boom Bip sound really flourishes when Hollon happens upon a suitable meshing of his dual interests in indie rock and electronica-- on Zig Zaj that point occurs on the wonderful ""Pele""
column3: which bears a heavy load of austere electronics that are gradually flipped out of the picture by some distinctly Cure-like flanged guitar riffing. It's got that refined power of suggestion the higher quality Boom Bip tracks possess
column4: which makes it doubly mystifying that he's occasionally happy to swap all that out and resort to sheer brute strength. But the individual songs on this record will find more color when extracted from the constraints of the album. It's not hard to see ""Goodbye Lovers and Friends"" getting a decent lease of life as a pop single
column5:
whereas here it feels like a malformed part of the puzzle that won't quite slot into place. No doubt Hollon wouldn't have it any other way.

"|15829.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15829-zig-zaj/|6.6|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16968/homepage_large.1b281b61.jpg|Again Into Eyes|29696.0|S.C.U.M.|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute']|2011-09-21 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:15.135775|"

Look up any review of S.C.U.M. in the British music press
column2: and you're likely to encounter the phrase ""little Horrors
column3: a diminutive comparison to the band that put out this year's fine LP Skying. This was S.C.U.M.'s first handy hook for the NME-- not only because bassist Huw Webb is the younger brother of the Horrors' Rhys Webb
column4: but also because the bands share traits on the musical and magazine-ready haircuts-and-cheekbones levels. This seems like the sort of tag the younger quintet would be eager to shake off
column5: the better to stand on their own feet
column6: but it's a lineage S.C.U.M. can't entirely lose on debut album Again Into Eyes.

column1: In the two years since their formation
column2: S.C.U.M. have followed a strikingly similar path to that of their elders: Both began as brash
column3: noisy outfits-- the Horrors as goth garage shriekers
column4: S.C.U.M. with a reputation for no-wave noise-making live shows-- and have arrived in 2011 at an atmosphere-heavy
column5: 1980s-influenced rock sound that's less abrasive and vastly more ambitious than those origins might've predicted. That tends to mean impeccably produced moody
column6: mid-tempo rock songs
column7: swaddled in vaporous synth textures
column8: and led by seductively fainting singing. In S.C.U.M.
column9: the singing's done by Thomas Cohen
column10: whose breathy
column11: soft moaning smears across the rhythms on ""Summon the Sound""
column12: drifting over the edge of the beat as it fades into the distance. It's a familiar effect
column13: but Cohen's singing sounds less affected and more skillful than that of the Horrors' Faris Badwan.

column1: Another important distinction: While the Horrors recently rounded off the edges of their guitar tones (to the point of largely obscuring the instrument's original sound)
column2: S.C.U.M. have done away with guitars almost entirely in favor of keyboards and synthesizers. (A less commonly mentioned but perhaps more interesting family tie is that S.C.U.M. keyboardist Samuel Kilcoyne is the son of Add N to (X)'s Barry Smith-- one imagines him inheriting a pile of pristine-condition Moog synthesizers for his 16th birthday.) One six-string features on single ""Amber Hands""
column3: and there may be some more deep in the mix elsewhere (band member Bradley Baker is credited with ""machines
column4: press
column5: which leaves room for some ambiguity). Either way
column6: the band relies less on sharp
column7: mix-piercing leads than on amorphous washes from which the melodies gently emerge-- it's an accomplished sound

When Will Wiesenfeld recorded a Daytrotter session under his Baths moniker earlier this year
column3: he chose to include three piano ballads in his four-song set. There's a certain logic at work there
column4: considering the emotionally charged material on his debut full-length
column5: Cerulean
column6: from last year
column7: but it's still not a move that most beat-obsessed bedroom producers would have the balls to try out. Wiesenfeld's post-Cerulean career has partially been shaped by a series of left turns
column8: whether it's through his desire to work in piano balladry and on his more passive Geotic project
column9: or in his affable banter with audiences during his live shows. During the Pitchfork Music Festival in July
column10: he seemed to spend most of his non-stage time wandering among the crowds with his shirt off. Wiesenfeld clearly doesn't care to be bracketed
column11: either personally or professionally
column12: and Pop Music / False B-Sides is his latest attempt to crush all those competing sides of his personality into song.

column1: What's most impressive about Baths is how that all-embracing approach never devolves into sloppiness or identity loss. Wiesenfeld is always careful to string recognizable
column2: Baths-like traits through his sound so that the listener never comes completely unshackled from his world. Sometimes it's through those stringy beats that he's so adept at constructing (""Seaside Town""); at others it's when he drenches a song in bathos via a few twists of his immaculate falsetto (""Iniuria Palace""). Frequently both of those elements are deployed
column3: such as on the standout ""Pop Song"". This isn't supposed to be a proper follow-up to Cerulean-- it's a collection of tracks Wiesenfeld has worked on since that album was released
column4: originally made available to fans who attended a tour from earlier this year-- which illustrates the strength in depth he has at his fingertips when something as appealingly frail as ""Pop Song"" is buried here.

column1: If this is an indication of where Wiesenfeld is heading
column2: it feels like a spot somewhere between Geotic and Baths
column3: with a greater emphasis on traditional instrumentation. Strangely
column4: it's often reminiscent of work by artists who have walked backwards into the electronic world and assimilated some of its elements after wringing all the inspiration out of the guitar-bass-drums format. ""Somerset""
column5: for instance
column6: skews close to the kind of dolorous studio experimentation Blur were tooling around with on 13
column7: all tied to a looping
column8: post-rock bassline that could have been uprooted from Tortoise's Millions Now Living Will Never Die. That material points to Baths' future
column9: although there are still a few ties to the Cerulean comfort zone (on the jumpy ""Seaside Town"" and the fuzzed-out ""Damnation"") that make Pop Music / False B-Sides feel like a passing of the baton from old to new.

column1: That could be how this album is viewed in the Baths' discography in future years
column2: depending on where Wiesenfeld heads next
column3: which is another testament to his sequencing skills. There are no huge stylistic leaps here
column4: just a subtle testing ground laid out so new ideas can be unwrapped and worked into the sound. It's clear that Wiesenfeld has progressed as a lyricist too
column5: with tracks like ""Nordic Laurel"" and ""Iniuria Palace"" easily among the best song-oriented works he's produced. There are occasional misfires
column6: particularly when Wiesenfeld channels his inner Robert Smith on ""Tatami""
column7: but in the context of this release he can be cut a little more slack than if this were Baths' actual second album. For most of this record
column8: he's still wrapped up in those sci-fi lullabies that made his name
column9:
while also gently prodding his surprisingly malleable aesthetic into welcome new territories.

Blitzen Trapper's sixth album is named for a touring motorcycle meant for long hauls down endless highways
column2: not short joy rides or joyless commutes. The Portland band means to create music that evokes the wind blowing your hair back
column3: the miles falling away behind you
column4: and quite possibly bugs getting stuck in your teeth. Frontman Eric Earley has explained that the album was inspired by the ""inescapable past"" and the eternal call of the open road-- the latter a specifically American idea that is almost necessarily soundtracked with American music.

column1: To their considerable credit
column2: Blitzen Trapper eschew the spray-on grit of contemporaries like Dawes
column3: Deer Tick
column4: or Dr. Dog. Instead
column5: they embrace a broad definition of Americana that covers the Dead
column6: Kiss
column7: and Pavement. In the past they've shown little hesitation mixing and matching rambling
column8: country-rock melodies against heavy-rock riffs and slack-rock rhythms
column9: creating an anything-goes sound that seemed obstinately determined not to close off any musical avenue
column10: but to roll down every street.

column1: Their early albums
column2: up to and including Wild Mountain Nation
column3: sounded both lively and studious
column4: fresh and familiar. After signing with Sub Pop
column5: however
column6: Blitzen Trapper have been whittling all of those possibilities down to a not-so-sharp point. Goldwing rides the same familiar roads we've been down so many times before
column7: yet even a decade into their career
column8: Blitzen Trapper sound less like denizens of the road than tourists snapping pictures of rock-historical monuments.

column1: After a brief but promising burst of squealing distortion
column2: ""Fletcher"" settles into a genial ramble
column3: sketching out a hitchhiking character ""drinking whiskey from a jar through his teeth"" and randomly shooting pistols for fun. These are concrete details
column4: but never pertain to anyone found on the actual road. Instead
column5: the title character comes across as an over-romanticized archetype
column6: a stand-in for the band's infatuation with the America of classic rock rather than the America of 2011. That impression is only reinforced by the ramshackle sound
column7: which is cribbed almost wholesale from the Band-- not from their Big Pink days
column8: but from their less fruitful California period.

column1: In other words
column2: we've been down this road before
column3: with Blitzen Trapper and with so many acts before them. There's no adventure here
column4: no real wanderlust. Even when they try to change things up
column5: it never comes across especially well. The hoedown that opens ""Your Crying Eyes"" segues abruptly into an ascending riff not too dissimilar to Big Star's ""In the Street"". While it's a relief that Trapper don't follow that coda through to its logical nu-old-time conclusion
column6: the transition sounds jarring and overthought.

column1: Still
column2: songs like ""Your Crying Eyes"" and ""Street Fighting Sun""
column3: with their muscle-car guitars and passing-lane momentum
column4: at least rev up American Goldwing a bit. The album stalls during midtempo numbers ""My Home Town"" and ""Girl in a Coat""
column5: which showcase Earley's hangdog vocals and roadside imagery. Ultimately
column6: the trip they're taking us on isn't into America
column7: but into the past
column8:
and they show too much reverence for their forebears.

King of the Beach was a quantum leap for Wavves

column1: Unfortunately

column7: 3rd-gen grunge suggests he found that Poe anthology right next to a used copy of Frogstomp. And though ""Destroy"" is a well-intentioned collaboration in the name of break-shit punk
column8: once Pink Eyes' vocals give Williams the bum's rush

column10:

At the end of the video for Veronica Falls' ""Bad Feeling""
column4: Roxanne Clifford

column3: ethereal

column5: actually

column8: I'll touch your shoulder

Clifford sings over the mounting tension of a furiously strummed guitar. It's the Veronica Falls aesthetic in miniature: the ghosts of pop past conjured convincingly and intimately enough to feel like flesh and blood.

column8: hooks like ""give us all your money... love everybody"" from ""Brand New Dance"" are the sound of their losing interest in real time. If they're kidding
column9: it's an entry-level joke aimed at...I dunno

column11: rattling off disconnected thoughts not too different from the avalanche of their Twitter feeds-- stray jokes
column12: pan-cultural namedrops
column13: the occasional astute observation
column14: and a slew of repurposed praise
column15: but no real context to prove broader points. After delivering some of the sharpest cultural criticism in any field on Sit Down and Shut Up
column16: when they swipe at low-hanging fruit like ""rapgenius.com is white devil sophistry/ Urban Dictionary is for demons with college degrees
column17: there's little insight

column1: So then what's Shut Up
column2: Dude's ""Rainbow in the Dark"" doing here? It's still a mindblowing piece of work and welcome in any form
column3: but the fit couldn't be more strange-- both the beat and the lyrics have a generosity in spirit that sheds light on an issue that you can lose sight of while focusing on its attitude or production choices: they're hardly rapping at all here. And when they do
column4: it's almost like 10th-season The Simpsons
column5: where the sheer dropoff in quotability is actually uncomfortable to endure. It's understandable that they'd want to move beyond mere applause for being as handy with Marina Abramovic as they are with Rick Ross' ""9 Piece""
column6: but they've thrown out their entirely unique point of view-- still their greatest resource-- with it.

column1: While they've made great use of deconstructive syntax
column2: repetition
column3: gibberish
column4: and in-jokes in the past
column5: too much of Relax simply feels like dead air: the clock-watching countdown of ""Happy Rappy""
column6: the last minute and a half of the title track that sounds like a cackling Autotune meeting its death in a food processor
column7: ""Celebration"" and ""The Trick""'s listless singing
column8: and ""Punjabi Song"" tripping over its drunk reiteration all merely pass time during tracks already stripped to the bone on a very short record. And while I won't begrudge Das Racist for wanting to make straight-up dance tracks like ""Girl"" or ""Booty in the Air""
column9: compared to ""Shorty Said""
column10: ""Irresponsible""
column11: or the many other songs they've made that worked as well in Gchat nerd-out sessions as they did in house parties
column12: it's tough to give these one-note riffs the benefit of the doubt. They can do better
column13: but do they even want to?

column1: To this point
column2: they've answered the question of ""are they really serious?"" in the affirmative or made it a moot point-- whether you just liked the Big Punisher quotes
column3: casually accepted being called a white demon for the greater good
column4: or both
column5: their work could be enjoyed on any number of levels. But Relax feels like it's hovering over a more pernicious escape clause-- ""you don't get it."" Interpreted through telling lyrics like ""when you see me on the streets
column6: don't bother me
column7: ""I don't know why people think we give a fuck so often
column8: or
column9: as the closing argument in ""Celebration"" goes
column10: ""you could ask what it is
column11: but I still wouldn't tell you
column12: the title of Relax feels more like a statement of aggression
column13:
Das Racist shifting the blame to the listener for their own lack of commitment.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16933/homepage_large.db20d8a2.jpg|Portamento|28199.0|The Drums|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Frenchkiss'
column3: the Drums know drama. At the tail end of 2010
column4: guitarist Adam Kessler left the band under circumstances that were clearly less than amicable; the band's website stated that the remaining members were ""devastated"" and were ""keeping to themselves and friends at this time."" Two weeks later
column5: lead singer Jonathan Pierce told NME that the band had composed ""the best song we've ever written"" the day after Kessler's departure. It was only a few months' time before Pierce was referring to Kessler's departure as a ""blessing in disguise"" in UK newspaper The Independent: ""We don't know what he's doing or anything. I'm not interested in knowing what he's up to.""

column1: In the leadup to the release of the Drums' second album
column2: Portamento
column3: Pierce has sounded dismissive of the band's general career trajectory
column4: claiming that they don't ""have a very long shelf life as a band"" and that they came close to breaking up this past June following ""a lot of shouting matches."" Accordingly
column5: that grim outlook is reflected in their most recent work. Throughout Portamento's 12 songs
column6: there are 11 references to death or dying
column7: the most notable arriving on ""Days"" when Pierce testifies to his past devotion to a broken relationship by casually tossing out the revelation that he ""killed myself."" Obsessing over mortality is nothing new in indie pop
column8: let alone within the Drums' catalog thus far. Remember
column9: this is a band whose first album kicked off with a song called ""Best Friend"" that started like this: ""You were my best friend/ And then you died.""

column1: Clearly
column2: Pierce's ego has been well-fed-- his recent quote-worthy nature in the press reflects that of the leader of a prototypical British buzz band (fittingly
column3: despite Brooklyn ties
column4: the UK has welcomed the band with open arms
column5: more so than the States). Which is why it's surprising that Portamento sounds and feels like a smaller
column6: more intimate album than last year's self-titled predecessor. After all
column7: it's not like they did anything drastically different this time around-- like The Drums
column8: Portamento was largely recorded in a band member's apartment (Pierce's)
column9: as well as a few studios in NYC and upstate Woodstock. (For those who bemoaned the production value of the first LP
column10: be warned: Portamento very much sounds like it was recorded in someone's apartment.)

column1: The lack of ""bigness"" on Portamento most likely owes to the fact that the Drums aren't on a major label anymore (in the U.S.
column2: anyway). Here in the States
column3: they've gone to Frenchkiss
column4: a more suitable home considering its strong roster of bands-that-sound-like-a-lot-of-bands. In case you haven't noticed by now
column5: the Drums do sound like a lot of bands
column6: taking in everything from the Beach Boys' controlled falsettos to the loving cloyingness of late Swedish indie-pop greats the Honeydrips. As it turns out
column7: the new surroundings are more beneficial for them: There's not as much pressure to be extroverted for the sake of courting a larger audience. This means that there's no ""Me and the Moon"" or ""Forever and Ever Amen""-- two big
column8: great songs that would sound too anthemic and overblown if they were on this record. In the place of anthems
column9: though
column10: are carefully constructed gems making up a sequencing run so solid it takes a few listens to pick out the exact drop-off point (""In the Cold""
column11: in case you were wondering). From the saxes and Theremin-like squeal in ""What You Were"" to the heart-tugging kickoff of ""Hard to Love""
column12: it's the small
column13: detailed moments that take you by surprise here-- kind of like life
column14: really.

column1: And
column2: despite all the drama and tortured sentiments
column3: that's what the Drums are all about: real life
column4: and the pains and pleasures (mostly pains) that come along with loving while you still have fresh breath in your lungs. Yes
column5: Pierce talks about selling a gun in ""Money""
column6: but the song is basically about how he doesn't have enough money to buy a lover a nice present. Being broke (and feeling inadequate because of that) is something we can all relate to
column7: no matter how embarrassing it might be for a bunch of major-label refugees to admit. It's time to stop begrudging these guys for being stylish and faddish
column8: because real emotions like the ones they work in are ugly and petty and hard to bear in public. You can get as many haircuts and buy as many trendy outfits as you want
column9: but you're not going to change the fact that it'll never be cool to feel upset
column10: angry
column11:
and alone.

But Only I Can Do It|27648.0|Omar S|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['FXHE']|2011-09-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:20.664014|"

The last time I saw Omar S DJ
column3: I was in a coffee shop in downtown Detroit drinking screwdrivers out of 5-oz plastic cups. We'd shown up early to an afterparty for the Movement Electronic Music Festival
column4: Detroit's big-for-America electronic-music showcase. On arrival there were 15 old heads dancing to a pre-Omar set on a still coffee-shop-y dance floor
column5: tables and chairs tucked neatly into corners. The booze
column6: we were told
column7: was in the back
column8: and we were led by an elderly woman past the employees-only area
column9: behind the DJ booth to a folding table with three handles of Popov
column10: four cartons of orange juice
column11: and a donations shoebox (these somewhat unofficial venues being legally unable to charge for drinks).

column1: Omar (Alex O. Smith) probably wasn't intimately involved in that night's planning
column2: but he could've been. Everything about the long-running house producer feels local and homemade (to wit: when his self-run label FXHE Records finally released t-shirts last year
column3: the design was a ""D""-- for Detroit
column4: presumably-- fashioned out of 12"" labels; he wore one at that coffee shop). <i>It Can Be Done
column5: But Only I Can Do It is Omar's second full-length for FXHE; his profile-raising mix for London's Fabric club and his recent (free) High School Graffiti EP for
column6: of all companies
column7: Scion (last time he bothered talking to the press
column8: Omar worked for Ford) notwithstanding
column9: he still prefers to release his music at his pace
column10: for his label.

column1: Omar's style remains his own: construction-paper house
column2: dance music in which the materials seem crude but the product is crafty and confident. He operates differently from most producers
column3: worrying little about mood or architecture. Omar remains refreshingly uninterested in the unspoken pissing contest that is every producer's attempt to make the ""deepest"" record in the DJ crate. The core elements of any given Omar track-- modest
column4: cymbal-heavy rhythms
column5: orbital synth lines-- are those necessary to inspire them most movement with the least cognitive interference. His music isn't soulful by way of signifiers-- though he does feature the occasional Motown sample or muffled diva-- it's soulful via its hardscrabble grooves and undeniable mettle. He isn't interested in replication
column6: in tuning knobs until he has the finest approximation of a Rhodes piano or sawing strings; every element here is slightly indelicate
column7: remnants of its synthesis scattered about. You aren't meant to recognize the elements of Omar's music; you're meant to dance to them.

column1: Though obviously indebted to artists like Theo Parrish (a frequent collaborator) and Carl Craig
column2: one of the greatest achievements of It Can Be Done is how easily it avoids feeling retro. Nor
column3: though
column4: does it imagine the future; It Can Be Done is the rare techno/house album that feels inimitably of its own time. This is born of Omar's indelible style
column5: the way he dials rhythms into his sequences and lets trace hints of melody come to him. They always do
column6: too: the title track finds a vaguely Kraftwerk-ian groove-hook
column7: while ""Supported Solely"" casually alternates between prickly treble and roiling bass. When he does offer a transparent genre plug-- ""Here's Your Trance Now Dance""-- he does so with verve and enthusiasm: ""Trance"" is 10-plus minutes of uncharacteristically major-key sunshine.

column1: It's all too simple to tie Omar's sound to his native city (if not necessarily its trad dystopian techno sound): both offer utility in the face of style and a shabbiness that's easy to love for those of the right disposition. Maybe he likes it this way-- he certainly seems smart enough to change this perception (though whether he is aware enough is up for debate). It Can Be Done won't increase Omar's stature or change the landscape of electronic music; he is a cantankerous
column2: secluded (by choice) artist
column3: arrogant enough to make music for himself but expecting you to dance to you it. Those patient enough to play by his rules probably will.

column1: (Note: Omar's distribution is notoriously spotty; the best place to find his music
column2: especially on CD
column3:
is through the FXHE website.)
