Slow Club's first album
column2: Yeah So
column3: was a twee
column4: hyper-romantic delight
column5: full of charming little indie folk songs ideally suited to mix tapes and teen television soundtracks. The Sheffield
column6: England duo could have kept going in that direction indefinitely with potentially great commercial rewards
column7: but instead they've opted to make a second album
column8: Paradise
column9: which dials down their perky sweetness and emphasizes rhythm and atmosphere with lyrics confronting more emotionally complicated subject matter.

column1: This isn't to say that Slow Club have become unrecognizable. One of the most impressive things about Paradise is the way the band have retained so much of their character while shifting their tone considerably. A few of the songs here-- the rollicking ""Where I'm Waking"" and the wistful ""Hackney Marsh""-- would have made sense on Yeah So
column2: but for the most part
column3: the melodic and lyrical sensibility of that record has been filtered through a different set of influences. There is still a sweetness to their sound
column4: but it's balanced out with a range of more difficult emotions and a darker tonal palette.

column1: The most drastic difference between Yeah So and Paradise is that Charles Watson and Rebecca Taylor have largely abandoned close harmonies. Instead
column2: Taylor has asserted herself as the dominant vocalist
column3: with her voice taking the lead on nearly every track
column4: while Watson provides complementary harmonies or focuses on his guitar. This was a brilliant decision on their part. Watson has a pleasant tenor
column5: but Taylor's voice is much more colorful and expressive. Though she supplied the high points of previous singles ""Trophy Room"" and ""Giving Up on Love""
column6: her vocal performances through Paradise are a revelation: Her phrasing is consistently thoughtful and surprising
column7: full of subtle cues that invest her straightforward lyrics with remarkable depth much in the same way a great actress can draw rich character detail out of a threadbare script.

column1: Taylor's best performances-- and not coincidentally
column2: Paradise's two best songs-- take her voice in very different directions.  The ballad ""You
column3: Earth
column4: or Ash"" is so stark and delicate that her voice often seems naked
column5: barely accompanied by the minimal plucking of Watson's guitar. She sounds wounded and fragile
column6: but her tone is very adult and dignified; she gracefully transitions from moments of self-assured beauty to sounding as though she could spontaneously break down into tears. She is more girlish on ""Two Cousins""
column7: the set's percussion-heavy opener
column8: leaning hard on her upper register and reaching up further still to underscore particularly anguished lines. The song
column9: about a pair of estranged family members
column10: cycles through two choruses-- the first one carried by a trebly
column11: diagonal synthesizer part and the second more focused on her voice
column12: which rings out with heart-breaking clarity as she sings the tune's gutting conclusion: ""I look into your eyes/ You don't know who I am.""

column1: In both songs
column2: and throughout Paradise
column3: Slow Club display remarkable skill in tugging at heartstrings
column4: but they do it without being particularly manipulative or overly saccharine. Led along by Taylor's confident voice
column5:
the duo has evolved from being among the best of an indie pop field overcrowded with cutesy duos to carving out a distinct niche for itself that opens up further opportunities for creative growth.

When delving into the backstory of Fungi Girls
column2: the word ""precocious"" comes to mind. This is not to say they're sheet-reading music theory nerds worshipping Philip Glass
column3: but you do get the feeling that the members of this particular trio-- none of them old enough to legally buy cigarettes in America-- are well beyond their years. Of course
column4: they're teenagers in the 21st century: They've had far greater access to underground music than older fans. Regardless
column5: it's not a stretch to say a group that got together in their preteens and who credit 13th Floor Elevators and ? and the Mysterians as influences should rightfully be considered as having advanced tastes.

column1: Since forming
column2: the Texans have shared stages with Hunx and his Punx and Wavves. They've recorded ""Dream of Oz""
column3: the best Jesus and Mary Chain song since Liars' ""Freak Out"". They've garnered praise from the likes of Psychedelic Horseshit's Matt Whitehurst-- a man far more generous with insults than he is with compliments. It's easy to see why: Their debut LP
column4: Seafaring Pyramids
column5: was an infectious blast of noisy effects-pedal-rock
column6: shoegaze for people who wear the same pair of holey
column7: filthy Vans every day. Interestingly
column8: the straightforward garage of sophomore collection Some Easy Magic serves as a complete stylistic overhaul.

column1: Instrumental opener ""Sabana Breeze"" and vintage toe-tapper ""Honey Face"" are good enough songs
column2: but the album doesn't really kick into gear until about 12 seconds into the title track
column3: where the descending chords and boundless energy is reminiscent of the threadbare
column4: hanging-off-the-hinges rock of garage punk legends Thee Oh Sees. Only
column5: where most bands (Thee Oh Sees included) would use a song like this to fulfill every garage-rock frontman's desire to howl at the moon and spit beer all over the microphone
column6: vocalist Jacob Bruce sings an addictive melody in his best inside voice
column7: turning what would normally be a chaotically fun moment into a tightly wound ball of nervous tension.

column1: As a singer
column2: Bruce never really goes for the jugular on the record: Each song is marked by his calmly and effortlessly spouting off brilliantly simple melody after brilliantly simple melody
column3: employing vocal restraint where you'd least expect it. Like most well-adjusted small-town teenagers
column4: his lyrics are often about boredom (""nothing to do"" is a combination of words used more than once on the album)
column5: and he aptly delivers them with a disaffected croon
column6: bored to the point of numbness. This would normally be a red-flag
column7: but Bruce has such a natural flair for melody that the songs quickly burrow into your head. When he steps away from the mic for the album's instrumentals
column8: there's a vibe-heavy presence-- like entering a dive bar where folks go because it has cheap pitchers and a functioning jukebox.

column1: Garage-rock is the province of the young and the young-at-heart. How else can you explain the slovenly strummed chords that feel like a sloppy
column2: drunken kiss? Or the barreling drums not as concerned with fancy fills as they are the simple task of sorta keeping tempo? Or the romance of sweat
column3: spilled beer
column4: spitting in the air
column5: and catching it with your mouth? Garage has always been a genre that's gotten by on fuck-all primitivism and giddy demolition. (There's a reason Shayde Sartin of the Fresh & Onlys cites Personal and the Pizzas as the platonic ideal of garage-rock bands.)

column1: The peculiar thing about Some Easy Magic is how efficiently it's delivered
column2: how its players work through their songs like a trio of cool session players rather than pack of bloodthirsty punk kids-- especially when considering that most of the wilder bands they've played shows with are easily double their age. But their natural introvertedness doesn't hinder their ability to play simple but exhaustively catchy tunes
column3: nor does it take away from the fact that Some Easy Magic is one of the most enjoyable garage albums of the year
column4: a pure-pop record for the Terminal Boredom set. With as much promise as this record exhibits
column5:
it's scary to ponder how good they'll be once they're old enough to drink in the bars they've played in.

Some people laugh at chillwave precisely because so many of its practitioners lack a sense of humor. But Alan Palomo is an exception. In 2009
column3: the Texas-raised musician's Neon Indian project debuted with the excellent Psychic Chasms. Like a lot of young musicians
column4: the then-21-year-old Palomo was inspired by Ariel Pink
column5: and he certainly shared that art-pop oddball's sense of irreverence. Below the static and sneakily intricate synth patterns
column6: Psychic Chasms was a funny
column7: playful record
column8: with goofy
column9: drugged-out moments exemplified by song titles like ""Laughing Gas"".

column1: As the buzz around Psychic Chasms increased
column2: the narrative shifted. Neon Indian attained a surprising level of popularity that was bolstered by a rocking
column3: party-ready live show
column4: drawing in fans of populist acts like Passion Pit and MGMT. After that raised profile
column5: Neon Indian's second album
column6: Era Extraña
column7: shows a commitment to tighter
column8: wide-reaching songcraft and appeal. The production value is at a higher level
column9: with additional mixing by big-name studio guy Dave Fridmann (the Flaming Lips
column10: MGMT)
column11: who forgoes his usual noise-bombing style for a more subtle approach. Those drawn to Psychic Chasms' warped view of pop or outré work like the difficult
column12: abstract EP with the Flaming Lips last year may be disappointed; Era Extraña instead builds on Neon Indian's one-off single with Green Label Sound last year
column13: the straightforward ""Sleep Paralysist"".

column1: Reflecting the shift
column2: there's an increased focus on streamlined melodies; the vocal gasps and moans that streaked previous highs like ""Terminally Chill"" are still here
column3: just not as suffocating. The wordless chorus of ""Hex Girlfriend"" is all but set to rock a festival stage or two
column4: while ""Halogen (I Could Be a Shadow)"" is a rush of life-affirming
column5: upwards-moving melodic optimism. The music itself is intricate and accomplished
column6: with dizzying layers of synth arrangements and stray sounds crammed into even the most big-tent cuts-- we're talking rocket-ship noises
column7: phone conversations
column8: lasers
column9: and visceral video-game samples. Despite the kitchen-sink arrangements
column10: the results are taut and defined. Palomo is anything but sloppy and he seems focused on the album as a unified whole: one of his finest songs yet
column11: the melancholy
column12: remix-ready ""Arcade Blues""
column13: was given bonus-track status because he felt it didn't fit in with Era Extraña's overriding themes.

column1: Era Extraña is partly about love. It may not be ""breakup album
column2: in the strictest sense
column3: but the record sounds romantic and lovesick and looks toward sounds that bring these feelings to mind
column4: from the sugary crunch of Isn't Anything-era My Bloody Valentine (""The Blindside Kiss"") to Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark (""Fallout""). The feel of Era Extraña is expansive and lonely
column5: like someone staring at the night sky in solitude (he recorded the bulk of it solo in Helsinki
column6: Finland during the dead of winter
column7: where
column8: according to a recent Pitchfork interview
column9: he was often on the verge of losing his shit mentally.)

column1: Another topic touched on in that interview was the album's sense of longing
column2: and ""Future Sick"" conveys the feeling of growing older in a world that's growing faster than you are. Palomo bemoans having to look towards past the present under seasick synths
column3: singing mid-volume under his own creation's drunken abstraction and promising to ""wake when things start to get peculiar"".

column1: Palomo feels more comfortable when looking to the past than turning his gaze to the uncertain future. While Era Extraña still contains the familiar warm glow of old television sets and half-remembered memories of the 1980s
column2: Palomo is more than adept when utilizing short-term memory to evoke some of modern indie's more memorable 2000s-era fashions. The insistent pulse of ""Suns Irrupt"" is reminiscent of LCD Soundsystem's ""Someone Great""
column3: ""Halogen (I Could Be a Shadow)"" is the near-double of M83's teenage epic ""Kim and Jessie""
column4: and the sweetly lackadaisical verse structure of ""Polish Girl"" recalls the similarly unspooling inner monologue that runs through Stars' ""Reunion"". Coincidentally
column5: those three songs of the not-so-distant past all deal with the loss of something-- a friend
column6: youth
column7: and irresponsible love
column8: respectively. Amidst the bleepy synths and swooning melodies
column9: Palomo's simply attempting not to lose himself
column10: as he sighs through processed vocal effects on ""Suns Irrupt"": ""Gone/ But I'm waiting to be someone."" Two albums in
column11: he remains a compelling songwriter. The scrappy charm of Psychic Chasms was hugely appealing from the jump and its brilliant initial flash faded just slightly over time. This is a far more serious record than its predecessor
column12:
but Palomo isn't always as assured in rendering the darker material.

The majority of unsigned bands never have their failure to upend the music industry held against them
column2: but... you already know the deal with Clap Your Hands Say Yeah. The excitement surrounding their 2005 self-titled debut and its DIY success was certainly warranted

column9: Birdmonster

column1: As hard as it is to believe that anything featuring a vocalist of Ounsworth's piercing timbre can be considered background music

column5: Bill Callahan

column7: CYHSY work within a far narrower range of dynamics

column12: and that even the most jarring experiments from Some Loud Thunder were for their own good. If you've got a jones for no-qualifiers-necessary indie rock ca. 2005
column13: you can get a proper fix from the title track
column14: ""Idiot""
column15: and ""Yesterday
column16: Never""
column17: where snares snap in double time
column18: chords resolve in the most predictable fashion
column19: and Ounsworth's melodies stride and stutter-step through familiar patterns. Still
column20: it's tough to tell whether they impress on their own merits or whether they obtain some sort of halo effect due to their hard proximity to ""The Skin of My Yellow Country Teeth"".

column1: So you're left to grasp for trimming: the horn charts on ""Maniac"" that shed Hysterical's rhythmic straitjacket and hearken to Ounsworth's New Orleans fetish from Mo Beauty
column2: the humid Mellotron strings and puzzling melody on the lonely ""In a Motel""
column3: the gnarled guitar that corkscrews it way through the middle of ""Into Your Alien Arms"". But if you cut Hysterical
column4: what does it bleed? At the very least
column5: you'd think ""Ketamine and Ecstasy"" or ""Misspent Youth"" would offer some sort of insight based on titles alone
column6: and judging by a teasing Eurythmics quote or a stray line about ""trading sex for drugs
column7: maybe they do. But the words themselves rarely linger for effect
column8: instead getting smeared over by Ounsworth's oily melismatics and distended diction.

column1: Look
column2: even those who fell hard for ""In This Home on Ice"" or ""Is This Love?"" wouldn't be too surprised by the way things would turn out by 2011-- Clap Your Hands Say Yeah may have a confrontational edge about them
column3: but outside of straight-up indie rock
column4: they're not the types you'd confuse for firebrands. The disappointment is in how it sounds like their years apart have needlessly chastened them into fast-forwarding through the idiosyncratic streak they showed on Some Loud Thunder instead of embracing it
column5:
coming out of the wilderness only to end up smack dab in the middle of the road.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16955/homepage_large.4eb48bae.jpg|Feast or Famine EP|28818.0|DaVinci|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['SWTBRDS']|2011-09-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:24.240660|"

In the internet era
column2: standing out from the hip-hop crowd often requires youthful immediacy
column3: extreme novelty
column4: and a willingness to throw anything at the wall in hopes that something sticks. This isn't a bad thing-- a lot of times
column5: it's what makes keeping up with hip-hop so exciting. But confident artists
column6: artists with a strong sense of self
column7: should be celebrated for adhering to modest ambitions. If anything
column8: in order to have a career that lasts these days
column9: this kind of long-term consistency will become a necessity to combat the hype-backlash loop. Bay Area rapper DaVinci's new Feast or Famine EP
column10: which follows last year's The Day the Turf Stood Still debut
column11: is a release that refines an existing formula
column12: relying on a distinctively wistful production aesthetic and the kind of rapping that feels like a labor of love
column13: from an artist who sees hip-hop as a career.

column1: Party-rap single ""Beer
column2: Bitches
column3: & Bullshit"" is an immediate standout
column4: although atypical of the record's sound: Over chugging production
column5: DaVinci is joined by scene-stealing Roach Gigz and rapper C-Plus for a song about drunken misadventures. But the bulk of the record has a glossy
column6: carefully-crafted professional sheen. As on his previous record
column7: his vocals are proficiently musical. He has a sixth sense for rhythm and rhyme patterns
column8: which largely overcomes a vocal style that otherwise operates as a detached flatline. As on The Day the Turf Stood Still
column9: his lyrics offer a lot to close reading
column10: if you're that type of rap fan. His worldview is thoughtful and nostalgic
column11: affecting a nuanced sense of melancholy one moment balanced with hopefulness the next.

column1: This is a step up from his previous release primarily because of the production. Where The Day leaned on the predictable reliability (and ideological baggage) of classic boom-bap to frame DaVinci's lyrics
column2: Feast or Famine has a more consistent
column3: unique production style. In keeping with the relaxed pace of his music
column4: the beats are svelte
column5: all smoothed edges and rolling momentum. It conveys the immersive thrill of speeding down the highway with the windows up
column6: the same feel of comfort and control
column7: observing the passing images of an inescapable world outside. The record has a warm
column8: welcoming feel but doesn't shy away from the kinds of real-world dilemmas of the thoughtful street rap archetype. It's an introspective
column9: therapeutic quality
column10: like the internal monologue of a person reflecting privately on the tangled problems he's been forced to confront.

column1: The album's climactic moment epitomizes this contradiction between lush comfort and the ugliness of the outside world. With a propulsive bassline and muted trumpet samples
column2: the incredible ""Paying for my Past"" refers briefly to a life of drug dealing (""I used to hide my bundle in a laundromat lint trap..."") but primarily zooms in on the uglier side of drug addiction
column3: a world where you most viscerally confront your past decisions on a regular basis. DaVinci's expressionless vocals help balance the emotive content of his words and the immediacy of the production
column4:
packing a wistful emotional punch.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16956/homepage_large.32e712e6.jpg|Blueprint: The Best of 808 State|1304.0|808 State|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Salvo']|2011-09-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:24.706082|"

In the late 1980s
column2: 808 State asked themselves a couple of important questions: Was it possible to get the masses to rise up and embrace instrumental beatscapes? Could a couple of guys with a couple of keyboards become a pop group without ever really writing pop songs? Should a house or techno act even bother releasing an album aimed at a general audience? There was no real evidence that the answer to any of these questions was ""yes
column3: but 808
column4: along with a handful of other ambitious crossover types
column5: persisted anyway. Thanks to a mixture of luck
column6: timing
column7: and skill
column8: 808 actually succeeded. And more than an any other crossover 1990s dance act
column9: they stayed true to both their club and avant-electronic roots. The career-spanning Blueprint proves that 808 did have a certain commercial instinct almost from the start. What's more surprising is how big they scored with the stuff on Blueprint that sounds the least commercial.

column1: 808 came up in the early days of British rave by making intense and dense compositions that represented club music at its furthest-out
column2: anticipating the kind of abstract hardcore electronica that didn't quite exist just yet. It's a thrillingly manic and claustrophobic sound
column3: enough so that it inspired more than a few future IDM tyros. On the other hand
column4: it's unsurprising that the caustic acid maximalism of ""Flow Coma"" never charted. 808's next single
column5: however
column6: hit in the biggest possible way. Relaxing a bit
column7: like rave as a whole for a brief second
column8: they scored massively with the platonically placid ""Pacific State"". The tune that helped to enshrine both the saxophone and the birdcall as part of the softer side of dance music's vocabulary
column9: ""Pacific"" still has enough of techno's antic bounce to make it seem like a great lost direction for pop
column10: where hippie relaxation vibes and bright video game funk are not incompatible.

column1: An accountant probably would have told them to ride their status as chill-out pioneers until it stopped being profitable
column2: which could have lasted at least until Moby smothered the trend stone-dead with the success of Play. Instead 808 released a few charmingly clunky takes on hip-house that are left out on Blueprint. That certainly helps the collection's flow
column3: even if it does underline why the group calls this their ""greatest bits"" rather than a complete overview. When they finally rebounded
column4: creatively
column5: it once again paid off commercially. ""Pacific"" and their Brit-rap adventures had clearly given them an appreciation for ideas of beauty and fun that conformed to 99 percent of humanity's. But they never quite lost their taste for the robots-in-meltdown fierceness of ""Flow Coma"". ""Cubik"" and ""In Yer Face"" were among the 808's biggest non-""Pacific"" hits
column6: but they were also among their rawest tunes. The difference is that the intensity now felt brash and joyful rather than hermetic and kinda creepy.

column1: But the fact that one of 808's albums was called Gorgeous should give you an indication that their sympathies ultimately lay more with ""Pacific State"" than ""In Yer Face"". Gorgeousness as an end in itself sometimes led 808 to slick and forgettable tracks like ""Plan 9""
column2: which has as much passion and inventiveness as the house-as-high-end-hotel-muzak they unfortunately helped inspire. But even ""Plan 9"" doesn't outstay its welcome. Early adopters of the ""radio edit"" approach to taking electronic dance into the mainstream
column3: even 808's opulent ambient stuff almost always has an instrumental earworm to get you humming. So
column4: in addition to being just damn listenable
column5: front to back
column6: Blueprint's also fascinating as a look at one group's answer to Brit dance culture's warring impulses in the 90s. 808's most memorable music is never split between opulent ambiance designed for the laid-back appreciation of connoisseurs and rugged slabs of computer madness to pump the adrenaline of young folks juiced on rave's novelty. The two are almost always mixed up into the same tunes
column7: the wild beat constructions complimented by a real musical richness. That's probably why they've endured
column8:
while so many one-note singles from 808's peers have faded away.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16948/homepage_large.8e75d517.jpg|Chartreuse Bull|4508.0|Vaz|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sleeping Giant Glossolalia']|2011-09-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:26.179145|"

In a recent issue of the Village Voice
column2: an article by music journalist Christopher R. Weingarten suggested that New York City was in the midst of a ""pigfuck"" renaissance. The colorful term was first coined by critic Robert Christgau as a way to describe the misanthropic ruckus created by mid-1980s indie rock progenitors like Sonic Youth
column3: Big Black
column4: and the Butthole Surfers
column5: among others. Weingarten revived the term in honor of a handful of like-minded New York area groups like the Men and White Suns. Brooklyn-based Vaz are another fine band in this sphere
column6: but a couple of things separate them from their name-checked contemporaries.  For one
column7: the group has been around for over a decade
column8: though Bull marks both their first album in five years and their first album as a trio. Second
column9: before Vaz was formed
column10: its members were part of a musical institution that helped shape the sound that's slowly coming back into vogue.

column1: Back in the 1990s
column2: members of Vaz were in North Dakota trio Hammerhead. While they weren't able to cash in for big bucks like Helmet
column3: or stick around long enough to achieve elder-statesmen status like the Melvins
column4: Hammerhead did carve out their own neglected little niche
column5: albeit in a fashion that had more in common with their Touch and Go contemporaries-- Shellac
column6: Jesus Lizard
column7: etc.-- than any of their kissing cousins on AmRep.

column1: When two-thirds of Hammerhead-- vocalist/guitarist Paul Erickson and drummer Jeff Moordian-- went on to form Vaz following the former's break-up
column2: they hit the ground running on 2001's Demonstrations in Micronesia. Displaying a melodic knack that Hammerhead only hinted at
column3: and managing to punch even harder despite not having a bassist
column4: the album found the duo nearly matching the ferocity and focus of their Load Records labelmates Lightning Bolt
column5: all while barbing their hooks with just the right amount of paranoia and menace (thanks to Erickson's reverb-and-doom-laden vocal stylings). Such an accomplishment
column6: coming when it did
column7: earned them the adoration of a passionate few and
column8: sadly
column9: little else. Their subsequent releases
column10: prior to Bull
column11: didn't pack nearly the same punch
column12: exchanging the stylistic precision of their first album for a hit-and-miss see-what-happens wanderlust that
column13: while enjoyable in its own right
column14: wasn't nearly as effective-- check out ""Give Us the Creeps""
column15: from Dying to Meet You
column16: for one such oddball digression.

column1: If the raucous and raunchy Bull takes after any previous Vaz record
column2: it's thankfully Micronesia. With second guitarist Tyler Nolan as its third member
column3: the band muddies up their sound in the best possible way. The album comes off like it was recorded for a cassette release
column4: but that sonic crudeness is a plus in this scenario.  Nolan and Erickson don't complement each other as guitar players so much as antagonize or taunt.  When Moordian enters the fray
column5: he does so with reckless abandon
column6: setting a breakneck pace that he's seemingly perpetually in danger of losing.  Yet despite of all these chaotic collisions
column7: Vaz never veers off-course
column8: instead banging out no-hold-barred rock tunes that mete their righteous fury with a sense of song. They're still nowhere near being the Next Big Thing
column9: but with this record getting slightly more exposure
column10: and with a slew of like-minded contemporaries banging the same drum
column11:
there's a good chance another Vaz album might come a little quicker next time.

On Sleater-Kinney's 2005 single ""Entertain""
column3: Carrie Brownstein summed up her dissatisfaction with pop-cultural stagnation and new-wave nostalgia by asking
column4: ""Where's the black and blue?"" She repeats the question three times in succession
column5: each one increasingly maniacal
column6: as if to illustrate her own point: Art can evolve only when it pushes forward
column7: provokes
column8: and leaves bruises. Alas
column9: in the five years since Sleater-Kinney fell silent
column10: nostalgia has become such a pervasive condition in pop culture that entire books are now devoted to analyzing the phenomenon. But Brownstein has not relented in demanding her black-and-blue
column11: whether using her NPR Monitor Mix blog to <a href=""http://www.npr.org/blogs/monitormix/2009/11/the_end_of_the_decade_skidding.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">lament the preponderance of sensitive
column12: soft-rockin' beardos in contemporary indie
column13: or skewering hipster fauxhemia alongside SNL's Fred Armisen on the IFC comedy show Portlandia. So for a vocal cultural critic-- and shit-hot guitar player-- like Brownstein
column14: the act of forming a new band isn't a simple matter of course; it's a declaration of war. But rather than point fingers from the sidelines
column15: with Wild Flag she's leading by example.

column1: The name Wild Flag amounts to more than just a distant echo of similarly imposing Black and Pink varieties; it represents something to rally around
column2: at a time when the internet has broken down traditional musical allegiances in favor of all-you-can-eat consumption. As per its members' pedigrees (Brownstein is joined by fellow S-K veteran Janet Weiss on drums
column3: ex-Helium front-woman Mary Timony on second guitar
column4: and Rebecca Cole of Elephant Six affiliates the Minders on organ)
column5: Wild Flag variously invoke first-wave punk
column6: post-hardcore indie rock
column7: 1960s girl-group pop
column8: Nuggets-vintage garage
column9: Stonesy FM-radio raunch
column10: and even flashes of proggy psychedelia. But Wild Flag aren't so much trying to relive a particular era or movement as re-stoke the kind of passion
column11: commitment
column12: and fandom in listeners that allowed those movements to coalesce and flourish in the first place.

column1: Brownstein and Timony previously collaborated in late-1990s side project the Spells
column2: but where their voices tended to blend together within that band's lo-tech indie-rock sound
column3: here their personalities are much more pronounced and distinct. For much of Sleater-Kinney's existence
column4: Brownstein played the more mild-mannered foil to lead shrieker Corin Tucker
column5: before asserting herself more forcefully on 2002's One Beat and 2005's The Woods; on Wild Flag
column6: she essentially picks up right where she left off on ""Entertain""
column7: pushing her voice toward more brash
column8: flamboyant extremes. Timony
column9: meanwhile
column10: sounds as if she's still immersed in the fantastical reveries of Helium's 1997 swan song The Magic City
column11: her familiarly conversational tone having an infectiously calming effect on the band.

column1: But in their own peculiar ways
column2: both singers strive to express their irrepressible awe for the power of music and the effect it has on them-- nearly every song here hinges on the connection between sound and movement
column3: and the relationship between what happens between the ears and below the belt. Brownstein's ""Romance"" and ""Boom"" are impassioned testaments to rock'n'roll's sensuous allure
column4: translating inner desire into public manifesto; Timony sings of music's essence in more mythic terms
column5: equating it to a magical artifact (the psychedelic set piece ""Glass Tambourine"") or cult ritual (""Electric Band""
column6: as in: ""Come on
column7: join our…"") as if she were the friendly fairy godmother on some subversively trippy Saturday-morning kids' TV show.

column1: The considerable contrast between the two singers gives Wild Flag a somewhat predictable ebb and flow
column2: with a song-by-song trade-off between Brownstein's rambunctious
column3: locomotive rockers and Timony's more quirky
column4: complex compositions. Credit Weiss and Cole for effectively mediating between these disparate sensibilities: Wild Flag never sound more together than when they're being led off the rails by Weiss' Keith Moon-worthy breakdowns and Cole's wandering ""Sister Ray""-style organ lines
column5: as they push the wiry ""Short Version"" and charmingly cheeky ""Racehorse"" into joyous full-band jams and sing-along chants. For all the ideological intent fuelling the Wild Flag mission
column6: the band rarely sacrifices the rock'n'roll fun-- they no doubt deliver that elusive black-and-blue
column7:
but it's a hit that feels like a kiss.

"|15798.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15798-wild-flag/|8.0|Stuart Berman

Years from now
column2: we might look back and try to pinpoint exactly when Curren$y became one of the best rappers working
column3: and wonder how we missed it at the time. Since his 2010 breakout Pilot Talk
column4: the New Orleans rapper has reliably released a high-quality new mixtape or full-length album every couple of months
column5: but he's remained perplexingly easy to overlook: as  befits a rapper heavily indebted to weed culture
column6: he seems less young-and-hungry and more like the guy who was always just around somehow. Committed
column7: in a noncommittal sort of way.

column1: But don't let the hangdog pose fool you: it takes ferocious inner steel to put out this much consistently good music in so little time
column2: and the fact that he's done so without disrupting the heavy-lidded calm of his pose only makes it more impressive. His latest release
column3: the DJ Drama mixtape Verde Terrace
column4: isn't his best work this year
column5: or even in the last six months: that would be last June's Weekend at Burnie's. Like many recent DJ Drama mixtapes
column6: it sags beneath some lazy or obvious beat selections. The boilerplate
column7: rushed-feeling song titles reflect minutes of thought: ""My Life is a Movie""
column8: ""Run Dat Shit""
column9: ""High Tunes"". It contains the world's most unnecessary remake of Biggie's ""Ten Crack Commandments""
column10: delivered entirely by Curren$y's Russian-doll miniature sidekick Young Roddy.

column1: And yet Curren$y has burnished his star to such a warm
column2: hazy glow that whenever he appears on it
column3: things snap immediately into focus. His weed talk has grown so metaphorically florid that it's entered its own realm: If you're a rapper who writes about getting high and you hear Curren$y say he gets ""lifted like sanctions
column4: how do you even begin to respond? His puns and double entendres continue to boast sneaky layers
column5: à la ""She puts the phone in her lap and when I call she comin'."" Verde Terrace boasts fewer of these quotables than recent performances
column6: but he still proves he can spin your head with startling ease a dozen or more times.

column1: Indeed
column2: what often gets shortchanged in Curren$y's ""weed rapper"" label is the compelling slipperiness of his mind: ""Nonchalant
column3: but I'm very aware of what's going on
column4: he assures us on ""Pinifarina"". His default mode is ""easily unimpressed
column5: an attitude surely honed from doing time in shifting rap regimes from No Limit to Cash Money. ""I'm from New Orleans
column6: I stunt/ In a blue moon once... But I don't be doin' too much
column7: he raps on ""Ways to Kill Em""
column8: a side-note observation that indicates the warily careful philosophy behind the bored facade: keep your head down
column9: keep rapping.

column1: Verde Terrace doesn't break any new territory for Curren$y
column2: but ""new territory""  isn't really part of his M.O.-- he is digging a groove
column3: one into which he settles more comfortably each year. It's a technique he might have soaked up from his one-time mentor Lil Wayne
column4: who chased the same six metaphors single-mindedly until they yielded delirium. Like Wayne
column5: Curren$y is refining the contours of his tiny universe so that it resembles no one else's. The point is driven home on Verde Terrace's outro ""Smoke Sum n""
column6: when Wayne appears for a guest verse. It's the first time the two have collaborated since parting ways four years ago
column7:
and the ships-passing-in-the-night moment is telling: Wayne very much sounds like a visitor in Curren$y's territory now. And Curren$y sounds like no one's idea of a sidekick.

"|15820.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15820-curreny-verde-terrace/|7.3|Jayson Greene

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16926/homepage_large.74cd525c.jpg|Gravity the Seducer|2408.0|Ladytron|['Rock'
column3: and Ladytron are certainly capable of resisting it. The Liverpool mainstay's fifth album is titled Gravity the Seducer
column4: but Newton's discovery clearly struggles to seal the deal throughout. During their dozen-year career
column5: the band's refused to outright repeat themselves-- 2002's Light & Magic was a glossier
column6: more robust update on the toy-store analog work of the previous year's debut
column7: 604
column8: while 2008's underrated
column9: overstuffed Velocifero added a menacing stare and at-times mismatched experimentation to the void-creating shoegaze synths of 2005's game-changing The Witching Hour. For Gravity the Seducer
column10: they've taken off the cinder block that Velocifero applied to the gas pedal
column11: opting for a floatier
column12: airy feel that often sounds as if its creators' feet are barely touching the ground. Hired gun Alessandro Cortini (Nine Inch Nails) returns to lend an extra hand
column13: but his touch is less heavily felt than on Velocifero
column14: where
column15: more often than not
column16: throttling industrial rhythms prevailed.

column1: Change is good
column2: right? Well
column3: here's the rub: Ladytron aren't quite content to let go of the since-perfected Witching Hour sound that won them attention beyond the Cobrasnake crowd
column4: so the push-and-pull between their new-look sound and the blank-eyed electrogaze of the past creates an unfortunate tension. ""Ace of Hz"" and ""Mirage"" are boilerplate
column5: late-aughts Ladytron
column6: right down to the charging synth melodies and vague political-naturalistic lyricism
column7: and the former's shoulders-shrugged ordinariness is driven home when its melody is redone on the instrumental LP closer ""Aces High"". Earlier on the album
column8: another sorta-instrumental rears its head in the form of ""Ritual""
column9: a limp faux-rocker that
column10: if nothing else
column11: makes for an easy ""Roxy Elevator Music"" joke.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: the weightless pomp of Gravity the Seducer's fresher material is more impressive. Opener ""White Elephant"" is a sneaky-good song with a swaying melody that belongs in the Great Ladytron Songs canon
column3: while the drum machine-kissed ballad ""Ambulances"" bucks the band's trend for blush-worthy
column4: Tolkien-esque lyricism in favor of a worrying plea in the name of lost love. Still
column5: even when Ladytron attempt to fully escape the past
column6: it haunts them: the melodic structure of album highlight ""90 Degrees""
column7: in all its glistening beauty
column8: can't help but recall Witching Hour closer ""All the Way...""
column9: a song that's of the band's most directly affecting works to date and certainly more substantial than the majority of what's here.

column1: So Gravity the Seducer is a transitional album bearing the growing pains and separation anxiety that we usually associate with bands that are in between periods of true inspiration. It's not a bad record
column2: but it is an upsettingly uneven one
column3: especially considering the flashes of greatness that Ladytron are still capable of. I'm tempted to give them the benefit of the doubt
column4: though
column5: based on their longevity alone. In his review of last year's greatest hits collection
column6: Best of 00-10
column7: ex-Pitchfork editor Scott Plagenhoef made an excellent case for why Ladytron demand more than a light dismissal-- and
column8: let's face it
column9: considering the flash-in-the-pan electroclash ""movement"" that first gave them recognition
column10: it's a pleasant shock that they've stuck around this long and still manage to evolve. ""Points for showing up"" usually carries negative connotations
column11: so how about we give Ladytron ""points for surviving."" After all
column12:
simply sticking around without growing totally stale is a feat that's not easily pulled off these days.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16953/homepage_large.a8fed289.jpg|A Winged Victory for the Sullen|29727.0|A Winged Victory for the Sullen|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky'

'Erased Tapes']|2011-09-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:28.046839|"

When I heard Adam Wiltzie
column3: known for his ambient work with Stars of the Lid
column4: and Dustin O'Halloran
column5: a Berlin-based pianist/composer and member of the dream pop band Devics
column6: were teaming up for a new project
column7: I knew what to expect. Which isn't a bad thing. Wiltzie makes sonorous and droning music with static harmonies in Stars of the Lid (and has played in Windsor for the Derby); O'Halloran writes melancholy piano music built around the repetition of chords and phrases. A Winged Victory for the Sullen
column8: it turns out
column9: is an exact halfway point between the two.

column1: What's interesting about the sound they've hit on isn't so much what the two musicians bring to each other's styles
column2: as it is what each sacrifices from his own. In Stars of the Lid
column3: Wiltzie and Brian McBride have a particular way of massing instruments into a big
column4: pulmonary drone-- the individual timbres of the instruments rarely rise out of the overall shape. You can hear him do some of this on A Winged Victory for the Sullen
column5: making new sounds out of many sub-sounds
column6: but he also lets certain individual tones take over. It creates small
column7: noticeable details in otherwise large
column8: fairly monolithic compositions.

column1: O'Halloran is a synesthete
column2: and I wonder what this music looks like to  him. Certainly
column3: it has different colors from his own work
column4: though his  usual palette is present. He's used to the repetitive harmonic structures favored by Wiltzie
column5: but in his own music there is typically more movement. When his music includes more than piano
column6: he's usually chosen those  instruments for their unique timbres. Here

column13: and backing vocals borrowed from classic rock and placed exactly where you would expect them to be. And tying it all together is the production from Doug Boehm and the band
column14: which sounds ""old"" simply because it sounds so incredibly good. This is one of the best-sounding rock records in years
column15: redolent of a time when there was more money to spend in getting the basic tracks perfect
column16: better ears to figure out which microphone should be used and precisely where it should be placed
column17: and no pressure to make the mix ultra-hot for digitally-driven radio.

column1: But if Father were merely an exceptionally recorded album built on obvious nods to the past
column2: it wouldn't add up to much. Instead
column3: the record comes alive with color and personality largely thanks to Girls' singer and songwriter Christopher Owens. He has a preternatural gift for turning clichés into into deeply affecting songs
column4: and as they jump from one style to the next
column5: from delicate acoustic balladry to noisy rave-ups
column6: Owens' voice and point of view ground the record and make it distinctive. He is the center. As long as he is writing and singing
column7: no matter what else is going on and being referenced
column8: the music will be utterly his.

column1: A lot of that is up to the timbre of his voice. On Album
column2: Owens often had the pinched
column3: clogged-sinus tone of Elvis Costello without the sneer
column4: but here his vocals are warmer and softer
column5: often bringing to mind the whispery tone of Elliott Smith. It's a testament to the care of the recording that even when he seems to be cooing into the microphone while the sometimes-thick arrangements grow around him
column6: every word is clear and in balance. His voice exhibits both weariness and innocence and manages to convey hope and despair in equal measure. It also has an androgynous quality that fits the themes of Girls' music.

column1: Owens' songs often seem to have an undefined and undirected desire for love and sex and friendship that exists outside of any one idea of sexuality. It's about feelings first
column2: and the object of them second; who or what the singer wants is less important than the fact that the yearning is there
column3: and it's unfulfilled
column4: and that hurts. The lack of specificity can give Owens' songs a narcissistic slant
column5: but it feels most like the self-obsession of early childhood
column6: where lines between the self and the outside world aren't clear. ""I can see so much clearer when I just close my eyes
column7: he sings at one point
column8: and it feels like the work of someone who has done a lot of thinking in the dark.

column1: Indeed
column2: so much about Owens' lyrical outlook
column3: from how he uses shopworn imagery to the disarming simplicity of his declarations
column4: conveys the sense of a child feeling around
column5: discovering for the first time things we all found and absorbed years ago. So when he sings ""My love is like a river/ She just keeps on rolling on"" and ""Lay my burden down by the river's edge"" in ""Love Like a River""
column6: it sounds like someone starting from the simplest conventions of the pop song and working inward to see if life actually functions the way that the songs tell us it does. Not since Jonathan Richman has there been a songwriter so willing to convey honest and deep feelings through the most basic pop syntax
column7: and Owens also shares Richman's desire to use familiar song forms to get these essential messages across.

column1: On Album
column2: it was easy to hear the words and focus on Owens' backstory
column3: which included being raised in a cult whose belief system contributed to the premature death of his brother. But these songs feel too essential and relatable to connect it to Owens' life alone. It's more about what we make of it as listeners and less about the damage of his early years. There's also a layer of awareness in his delivery
column4: and he's able to tweak his own naïvteté in interesting ways. On the opening song
column5: ""Honey Bunny""
column6: he sings about how his mother loved and accepted him and told him that ""everything will be all right"" and then follows by saying
column7: ""I need a woman who loves me! me! me! me!""

column1: This lyrical simplicity shouldn't obscure the fact that these are sharply constructed songs that take unusual turns. One of Girls' specialities is their willingness to go completely over the top but somehow keep us right there with them. Early single ""Vomit"" is one such epic
column2: folding in soulful organ and the kind of wailing gospel-like vocals that signified ""authenticity"" when the Stones and Floyd ruled the world; but
column3: with Owens' wounded voice in the middle of it all
column4: even this bombastic song feels personal and even intimate. ""Just a Song"" begins with a gorgeously basic nylon string guitar figure and slowly drifts into a whispered refrain that stretches endlessly
column5: Owens intoning
column6: ""Love
column7: it's just a song
column8: in his softest way as flutes swirl around him. He seems to be slipping into a widening hole that's half oceanic bliss and half fade-out death
column9: and that combination nods to Spiritualized
column10: an influence that was there on Album and is sometimes present here
column11: particularly in the way Girls don't shy away from repetition and mix sonic decadence with wide-eyed spiritual yearning.

column1: The largest canvas of all stretches across ""Forgiveness""
column2: the eight-minute song that serves as the album's emotionally exhausting peak. It builds slowly and winds around in circles as Owens offers homilies about love and fear and redemption
column3: and then it explodes into a melodic and moving guitar solo that releases the considerable tension. It's a big moment on an album that has so many they're almost hard to pick out
column4: and it also happens to contain some of Owens' most straightforward writing: ""You'll have to forgive me brother/ You'll have to forgive me sister/ And I'll have to forgive you if we're ever going to move on/ No one's going to find any answers/ If you're looking in the dark/ And looking for a reason to give up."" He's right
column5: but while there's nothing remotely new here
column6:
somehow the way Owens sings these words makes it feel like we're hearing them for the first time too.

Now that there's little choice but to treat chillwave as an actual genre

column1: There's no better example of the genre's catholic origins than Toro Y Moi mastermind Chaz Bundick. Last year's Causers of This established Toro Y Moi as one of the mini-scene's leading figures
column2: with the post-crash economic reality of lead single ""Blessa"" (""I found a job
column3: I do it fine/ Not what I want
column4: but still I try"") aligning the album with Neon Indian's ""Deadbeat Summer"" and Washed Out's High Times-- and Bundick's full-length debut had a warmly nostalgic electro-R&B aesthetic
column5: to boot. But by then he had already released 2009's Body Angles tape
column6: which
column7: yeah

column9: but mostly emphasized scuzzy guitars. And Bundick has said he actually recorded this year's garage-pop ""Leave Everywhere"" single in 2006. In the meantime

column7: Bundick soothes on the title track

column9: how much more chillwave can you get
column10:
right?

No matter how much Hella have juggled their lineup
column3: the music has always sounded the same. The Sacramento-bred spazz-rock duo's done the OutKast split-solo album thing (Church Gone Wild/Chirpin' Hard)
column4: given its songs the coffee-shop open-mike treatment (Acoustics)
column5: and revamped itself into a five-piece supergroup (There's No 666 In Outer Space). Yet through all of these rearrangements and reinventions
column6: the band has rarely deviated from its staple schtick: shreddy guitars
column7: frenetic drumming
column8: and hooks scavenged from the Power Glove era of Nintendo gaming. Sometimes it was hard to tell if they were dedicated to a singular vision or stuck within one.

column1: Following a four-year hiatus
column2: Tripper finds Hella back to their original two-piece incarnation
column3: with founding members Spencer Seim and Zach Hill on guitar and drums. It's business as usual: spastic pounding
column4: warp-speed scalar runs
column5: and various math-rock feats of strength. Tripper is a more focused effort
column6: but only in comparison to the wanton schizophrenia of other Hella records. On ""Long Hair"" Seim gets more melody out of fewer notes
column7: sticking to single riffs for longer stretches of time. On ""Yubacore"" Hill plays with dynamics
column8: interrupting his constant stream of abstract fills with a few simple
column9: spacious grooves. Hella are never relaxed
column10: but they no longer sound like they're sprinting to get to the end of the record.

column1: For all of the sweaty battering and calculated sloppiness
column2: Hella's music always retained an inorganic feel. They make high volume but emotionally distant music. The band's main muse
column3: in spirit if not in sound
column4: is Devo. That hasn't changed on Tripper. Hella's peers-- art-school shredders like Mick Barr (Orthrelm
column5: Krallice) and Lightning Bolt-- found their inspiration in hardcore punk and more extreme strains of metal. Though their playing is repetitive and mechanical
column6: it's framed as a quasi-spiritual pursuit and
column7: in Lighting Bolt's case
column8: done in the hopes of producing a sweaty moshpit meltdown. Hella's intent is more arch. The song titles-- ""Kid Life Crisis""
column9: ""Psycho Bro""-- are meaningless goofs. The music's unpredictable and schizophrenic architecture subverts earnest headbanging. On Tripper
column10: Hella's instrumental chops are better than ever
column11: but riffs aside
column12:
there's not much to think about.

It's well documented that plenty of oddities were snapped up and issued by major labels during the grunge era
column3: but the fact that DGC released four albums by post-punk artists the Raincoats (including re-releases of their first three records and the then-new Looking in the Shadows) remains a confounding footnote of that time. David Geffen clearly didn't swell his already sizable bank balance by reissuing the band's second album Odyshape
column4: as it quickly became as hard to find as the original 1981 Rough Trade version. It must be frustrating for the group to have their music fading in and out of time like this-- the preceding The Raincoats and the following Moving have been treated in the same manner-- but it helped cultivate a mystique around Odyshape. That feeling is partially shaped by the distinctly un-rock approach
column5: with the core trio of the band (Ana Da Silva
column6: Gina Birch
column7: and Vicky Aspinall) occasionally utilizing African instruments including a balophone and a kalimba to get the job done.

column1: A big part of Odyshape's charm is derived from its backwards construction
column2: with the band leaning away from the spikiness that made The Raincoats such an inviting listen
column3: and writing many of the songs without percussion. The tribal drumming of original member Palmolive was forcibly removed from the mix-- she quit the band by the time of this record
column4: causing percussion to be added after the fact by a variety of guest players including Robert Wyatt and This Heat's Charles Hayward. Coloring in the songs in that manner might sound like the band were shoving a square peg in a round hole
column5: but it undoubtedly contributed to the uniquely disorienting air that Odyshape thrives on. It's from a place where the Raincoats' best ideas stem-- throwing orthodoxy out of the window
column6: playing on instruments with which they weren't familiar
column7: assembling all the parts back to front because the standard way of doing things held little or no interest.

column1: As such
column2: it fits into that basic post-punk tenet of rejecting everything that came before to test out new ways of doing things. This album has little in common with anything else around at the time
column3: other than the feeling that you're hurtling relentlessly forward into a previously unmapped musical space. There may be a little Scritti-esque hue to the guitar scratch on the pushy ""Only Loves at Night""
column4: but much of Odyshape is positioned in a peculiar place somewhere between the earth and the sky. Sometimes a discordant violin howl is pitted against dreamy vocal pining (""Dancing in My Head"")
column5: at others the relationship is reversed and the singing takes on an earthy tone while the instrumentation is positively otherworldly (""Shouting Out Loud""). Occasionally those two impulses are conjoined
column6: such as on the title track
column7: where Birch delves into body dysmorphia over stop-start rhythms that feel like two different songs colliding.

column1: That schizoid shift can partly be explained by all the instrument swapping going on in the band
column2: but it's also an escape and an embrace of the circumstances in which the band found themselves. Holed up in a squat in London
column3: which Birch admitted (in Simon Reynolds' Rip It Up and Start Again) had mushrooms growing out of the toilet wall
column4: they found a release in Ornette Coleman and Miles Davis albums
column5: and the transformative tones of the unconventional instruments that ended up being scattered all over this record. England wasn't a peaceful place during 1981; riots prevailed
column6: the economy was in dire shape
column7: and the rise of Thatcherism gained a stranglehold on the country. Fast-forward 30 years later and Odyshape is being released again
column8: in much the same climate
column9: acting like an acute reflection of all that hurt and the contrasting desire to block it out for a while.

column1: That divide between the oblique and the real is what separates Odyshape from the ideas the Raincoats' post-punk peers were pushing toward
column2: many of whom went one way or the other but rarely met in the middle. It's a very intimate recording
column3: full of sounds they wisely never tried to recreate again
column4: and vocal takes that are often inflected with a heart-crushing vulnerability. There's no easy category for this record to slip into; sure
column5: you can sometimes hear hints of reggae
column6: and at times there's a folky tinge to a few of the songs. The latter is particularly unusual in the post-punk scene
column7: but makes sense here when you consider how these tracks were initially conceived
column8: and the fact that Robert Wyatt (also a keen jazz fan and with a distinctly English folk-iness all of his own) was drafted in as a collaborator. It's telling that Kim Gordon was brought in to provide sleeve notes but doesn't say a single word about the album
column9: and no demos
column10: outtakes
column11: or other ephemera are included. Despite living in an era where almost all music is available on tap
column12:
Odyshape still feels like a self-contained secret floating out there waiting to be uncovered.

In the early 2000s
column2: it was not terribly uncommon to meet a punk kid with a soft spot for the Mates of State. Though I'm sure the word ""joycore"" was often stammered in justification
column3: it actually made a lot of sense: There was an unmistakable DIY spirit to the band's earliest material. Husband-and-wife duo Jason Hammel and Kori Gardner's voices joined in imperfect
column4: occasionally overripe harmony
column5: and their songs were patchwork pieces with seams proudly showing (""We attach parts together until they make a whole song
column6: they once confessed)-- all of which added to their debut record's unique and infectious charm. Unlike much of the impersonal
column7: digitized pop that was emanating from the radio waves or your little sister's primitive
column8: brick-sized mp3 player at the time
column9: My Solo Project was pop music that felt transparently and exhilaratingly human.

column1: A decade later
column2: certain core facts remain: Kori Gardner and Jason Hammel are still happily married
column3: they are still an organ-and-drums two-piece
column4: and you'd still convulse in a fit of sugar shakes if you found a way to bite into one of their songs. But a funny thing happened somewhere between 2003's rollicking Team Boo and the AM-gold glimmer of 2006's Bring It Back: Gardner and Hammel became pretty great pop songwriters. Their harmonies got more technically sound
column5: their songs moved more fluidly-- basically
column6: the seams don't show anymore. Bring It Back proved that this wasn't necessarily a development for the worse. But the band's last effort
column7: 2008's Re-Arrange Us
column8: was a misstep
column9: not just for the much-cited reason that Gardner traded in her electric organ for a bland-sounding piano
column10: but because the record's overall energy was inert. And if the damn Mates of State can't muster the energy to sound enthusiastic about anything
column11: heaven help the rest of us.

column1: Mountaintops brings on an immediate sigh of relief: Its opening minutes are not just a return to form
column2: but one of the most zinging 1-2 punches in the band's catalogue to date. ""Palomino"" is celestial pop with a chorus as big as the sky
column3: and the warped synth groove of ""Maracas"" is irresistibly catchy. Suffice to say that if you don't get ""Maracas""
column4: you don't really get this band
column5: because it manages to cram almost every single reason the Mates are such a perennially charming guilty pleasure into a single song: holler-along lyrics that don't make a lick of sense (""Wooo-oooh/ Syncopated breathing!"")
column6: posi-energy to burn
column7: and even a totally gratuitous Queen Latifah reference for good measure (""I've got your back/ U-N-I-T-Y!""). But if you can see past its feel-good vibe
column8: ""Maracas"" also hints at the record's overall thematic maturity.

column1: Some more core facts about the Mates of State: Gardner and Hammel quit their day jobs 10 years ago (teacher and a medical researcher
column2: respectively)
column3: they have spent the past decade in the record-tour-record state of eternal return
column4: and they have been raising two children all the while. Mountaintops is the first of their records to grapple with the everyday tribulations and banality of spending your entire adult life in a band-- with your Mate
column5: nonetheless. ""Basement Money"" is a surprisingly honest exploration of something few indie bands are brave enough to sing about: the necessity of making money off your art. ""At Least I Have You"" pulls the veil back even further. It's a song not just about feeling disconnected from old friends and familiar places
column6: but the realization that the music you've devoted your life to playing is the only thing that can bring you release.

column1: Much has been made of the Mates' cheerful music as a testament to how completely and adorably in love they are
column2: but Mountaintops intrepidly explores themes of isolation
column3: codependence
column4: and the things lost from operating for years with-- to quote ""Basement Money""-- ""a doublemind."" The chords that play out final track ""Mistakes"" are bittersweet
column5: and there's something unsettling about the lingering last words of its refrain: ""I need you/ But it's not normal if I refuse to be by myself.""

column1: Mountaintops is not without valleys: the breathy balladry of ""Unless I'm Led"" is a bit too maudlin even for the Mates
column2: and the Motown-meets-glee-club sugar rush of ""Total Serendipity"" is divisive at best. But overall
column3: Mountaintops finds the Mates taking the more nuanced emotional tenor of Re-Arrange Us and splaying it across the mural-sized pop canvases we've come to expect from them. Impervious to trends and refreshingly uncool
column4: Mates of State have managed to progress and mature within the confines of their own self-made niche. All of which is pretty punk
column5:
when you get right down to it.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16924/homepage_large.d5d5c774.jpg|Re: ECM|29917.0|Ricardo Villalobos and Max Loderbauer|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ECM']|2011-09-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:34.352153|"

Ricardo Villalobos is the undisputed winner of the last decade's minimal techno movement. He released two of the period's finest long players (Alcachofa and the still underrated Thè au Harem d'Archiméde) but also established himself as an in-demand festival-packing DJ. Unlike his incredible run between 2004 and 2006 (when Ricardomania was so obvious that Philip Sherburne made note of it
column2: mid-review)
column3: his releases these days are thin on the ground
column4: limited to a single here
column5: a remix there. His work has grown more historical as it's grown scarcer. It's not his own history he's concerned with
column6: but the varying strands of musical DNA comprising his ropey
column7: winking techno. ""Enfants (Chants)"" featured communal chanting
column8: while this year's excellent Joli Chat EP was conversational and punchdrunk. His last ""album"" was a pre-mixed LP of his own productions. He's collaborating more. It's as if
column9: having found his perfect beat
column10: he's seeking its perfect context.

column1: Re: ECM sees Villalobos reach out to longtime experimentalist Max Loderbauer (who has a host of credits to his name; recently and notably he has played in the Moritz Von Oswald Trio). At issue is the varied output of fabled Munich jazz/out music label ECM (Edition of Contemporary Music). The two artists were given full access to ECM's vast catalog
column2: and label founder Manfred Eicher oversaw the mastering process. The ""Re:"" (""regarding"") in the work's title is important: These are not remixes but rather compositions that suggest and converse with ECM's history. Villalobos and Loderbauer make no attempt to tie the works to beat-driven techno. The catalog is a quarry of sounds from which the duo extract loops and beats that range from ornament to animal.

column1: It's not necessary to be intimately familiar with ECM's catalog to enjoy Re: ECM (your reviewer is not); suffice to say that the label has housed most permutations of jazz and improvisational music since its inception in the late 1960s. Jazz and electronic music make natural partners; it's a pairing that many have explored previously
column2: from Moodymann's dusty Black Mahogani releases to Four Tet's work with drummer Steve Reid. Both styles fascinate themselves with sustained textures and place a premium on sublimating the artist to the form (both also lack rock music's obscene physicality
column3: which has allowed jazz musicians and electronic producers to stay creative late into their careers).

column1: Villalobos and Loderbauer don't seem interested in jazz's harmonic infrastructure so much as the vast array of tones used to produce it. Hissing hi-hats
column2: voluminous stand-up bass
column3: and damp woodwinds are placed decoratively next to one another. If I'm feeling cynical I start to think of Re: ECM as aural feng shui
column4: its 2xCD
column5: two-hour structure better suited for inattentive mood-setting than true exploration. But there's nothing easy or simple here; the artists' restraint provides plenty of airy space
column6: but between that air are sounds that are almost uniformly rich and complex. It feels minimal but unbalanced. If Re: ECM were to soundtrack a dinner party
column7: it would have to be of the newfangled
column8: slightly sadistic variety in which the chefs have lots of tattoos and serve mostly foie gras and bone marrow.

column1: Re: ECM stands out not just for its depth but for its variety
column2: for the sheer number of musics it incorporates. Jazz is the primary focus-- it has been for the label-- but the duo also touches on tribal blues (""Reannounce"")
column3: choral (""Rekondakion"")
column4: Eastern drone (""Requote"")
column5: and lounge (""Recat""). If Villalobos has ported over one element from his techno work
column6: it's an uncanny ability to fashion rhythms that are both crisp and deep; the sounds here will buzz and twitch with his unmistakable style
column7: but they'll do so less predictably.

column1: Applaud ECM for letting Villalobos and Loderbauer run amok; this album is a symptom of a process that has allowed ECM to remain relevant since its inception. For Villalobos
column2: it's another tie
column3: however oblique
column4: to the musics that birthed his style. As a new generation of electronic producers-- notably Nicolas Jaar-- takes cues from his seminal works
column5: Villalobos continues to reach backward. If he makes the past seem half as thrilling and rewarding as he once made the future seem
column6:
the next generation won't be the only one that owes him a debt.

The introductory video on the DVD half of this reissue talks about the legacy of the Art of Noise-- mentioning Daft Punk
column5: the Chemical Brothers
column6: and Massive Attack. It's easy to see why the group would be proud of such lustrous descendants
column7: but it actually sells them short. What's interesting about Art of Noise-- certainly the first phase of their project
column8: which culminated in this debut album-- isn't so much their children but their parents. This was a pop band named after a 1913 art manifesto
column9: deliberately aspiring to inherit the explosion of early 20th century conceptual creativity and make Futurists and Dadaists rub shoulders with b-boys and clubbers. The group's own arch-conceptualist
column10: music writer Paul Morley
column11: apparently planned an album that would be a grand collage of the century's sounds-- what he actually got was an acrimonious split.

column1: Morley may
column2: in his words
column3: have only ""made the tea"" in Art of Noise
column4: but he dominates the visual half of this reissue: introducing videos
column5: reading out essays onstage
column6: continually playing the ideas man and provocateur even if his incessant wordplay's an acquired taste. The group's videos are proof that this apparent pretension came with a smart payoff. ""Beat Box"" is recast as the soundtrack to a city with lively
column7: evocative footage of 1980s London cut to its rhythm. ""Moments in Love"" mixes dancers and tortoises
column8: grace and absurdity. And most famously ""Close (to the Edit)""
column9: the dream-logic realization of the group's ideals
column10: with a creepy punker kid commanding anonymous wreckers as they smash cellos and pianos to pieces.

column1: ""Close (to the Edit)"" reminds you that Art of Noise were trying to be funny and sometimes scary-- neither of them standard pop ambitions in 1984 or now. In fact
column2: what's striking about this album is the range of moods and effects it musters
column3: while remaining an intensely playful record. It follows the savage
column4: martial arrangement of Cold War bricolage ""A Time for Fear (Who's Afraid)"" with a teasing version of ""Beat Box"" where the track's purposeful electro keeps getting diverted by shiny new sounds. On the title track
column5: a snooty voice asks
column6: ""Can I say something?"" and the music refuses to let it even say that
column7: gleefully slashing the sample to ribbons. The album flirts with annoyance and even boredom-- the way the stately
column8: repetitive beauty of ""Moments in Love"" lulls you before unwinding itself into stranger places. But they could also be thrilling. Their immediate context was hip-hop
column9: but their kind of funk-- best experienced on ""Close (to the Edit)""-- has a brash rigor to it
column10: calling to mind tireless pistons and marching feet.

column1: ""This limited circle of pure sounds must be broken
column2: Luigi Russolo wrote in the manifesto that inspired the band
column3: ""and the infinite variety of noise-sound conquered."" But the technological limits to sampling in 1984 meant that Art of Noise were stuck with a very finite variety of noise-sound
column4: constantly worrying at and reusing snippets of samples. The only problem with the many reissues of early Art of Noise is the group's endless recycling of its two key tracks. ""Beat Box""-- of which ""Close (to the Edit)"" is a cousin-- and ""Moments in Love"" were on their first EP
column5: then issued as separate singles
column6: appeared on every compilation
column7: dominated this debut album
column8: and now appear-- counting the DVD-- six times each on this reissue.

column1: For diehard fans
column2: the incessant tinkering is part of the fun-- for listeners less caught up in the band's process
column3: it's easy to get a little weary with the radio sessions and alternate video edits collected here. Stick with the core album and videos
column4: though
column5: and you realize the reason Art of Noise kept returning to these songs: Both are superb
column6: anchoring a record that's as sly
column7: stirring
column8:
and occasionally infuriating now as it was on release.

The first performance of WTC 9/11
column2: Steve Reich's memorial to September 11
column3: took place at Duke University-- 500 miles south of Ground Zero. From there
column4: it traveled to L.A.-- nearly 3
column5: 000 miles west of the attacks it commemorated-- before touching down in Carnegie Hall a month later. It was an oddly circuitous cross-country tiptoe for a work by a native New Yorker about the collapse of the towers he lived four blocks from
column6: but it spoke to the fearsome difficulty in addressing 9/11 headlong. There is still
column7: 10 years later
column8: an instinctive flinch mechanism built into our communal central nervous system surrounding the  day
column9: and it presents a forbidding hurdle for artists attempting to speak to it.

column1: Reich
column2: as unofficial American composer laureate and a quintessentially New York City figure
column3: would seem more outwardly qualified than most
column4: which only makes his failure all the more disheartening. WTC 9/11 takes the same form as Reich's Different Trains
column5: another piece that treated an atrocity-- in that  instance
column6: the trains transporting Jews to concentration camps-- with a sorrowful Zen gaze. Like Trains
column7: WTC pairs the Kronos Quartet with manipulated recorded voices
column8: the strings accompanying the recordings to draw out the anxious unheard music in their intonation and rhythm. It's a spectacular compositional technique
column9: bridging the invisible gap where words become music.

column1: Within minutes
column2: however
column3: WTC 9/11 rams up against an unavoidable problem: These raw materials are
column4: well
column5: simply too raw. The voices Reich highlights in his music are a mix emergency dispatches from 9/11 and interviews conducted in 2010 with his close friends. Much of what they say is nearly unbearable to hear
column6: even a decade on. If there is a way to subsume a 9/11 survivor saying
column7: ""Three thousand people were murdered. What's gonna happen here next?"" into a larger musical work
column8: Reich didn't find it. The words burn through the music's fabric  like tissue paper
column9: leaving you jarred but neither enlightened nor transformed.

column1: The smaller moments in the piece
column2: painting the texture of daily life on the morning of the attacks
column3: ring true with tension and foreboding. The conversational
column4: lilting swing of ""I was sitting in class. Four blocks north of Ground Zero""
column5: for instance. A sobbing cello catches the falling note of plaint in the phrase ""Nobody knew what to do."" At the intonation of ""We all thought it was an accident"" (spoken by Reich’s  friend and colleague
column6: Bang on a Can co-founder David Lang)
column7: the strings allow a brief glint of a major key to peak in
column8: a moment of fugitive hope. Unfortunately
column9: the moments that freeze you in place -- lines like ""debris engulfed everybody that was there
column10: or a desperate shout of ""I'm trapped in the rubble""-- owe nothing at all to Reich's music; indeed
column11: they all but erase your awareness of the music around them.

column1: The Nonesuch recording of WTC 9/11 is rounded out by other recent-vintage Reich pieces
column2: and to spend time in their company  after the heightened
column3: jagged WTC is a relief. His 2009 Mallet Quartet is a delicate and ringing interlocking of marimbas that feels as cleansing as spring rain
column4: while Dance Patterns
column5: for a battery of vibraphones
column6: xylophones
column7: and pianos
column8: plays like a glistening
column9: fond medley of Reichisms. The framework of Reich's pieces feels well-worn by now-- his ""fast-slow-fast"" structure now has a ""loud-quiet-loud
column10: ""verse-chorus-verse"" inevitability to it. The shifts in key midway through movements feel less like the blooming of an  unexpected thought now than slides in a ViewMaster clicking duly into  place. You smile and nod knowingly
column11: but the goosebumps are gone.

column1: These low-key joys are reminiscent of latter-day Neil Young or Sonic Youth albums-- a master operating comfortably within his groove. They are modest
column2: but they feel honest in their serene confidence. WTC 9/11
column3: on the other hand
column4: feels marred by miscalculation and overcompensation. This uneasiness found public expression when Nonesuch revealed the album's original cover art: a photo of the smoldering Towers
column5: with the second plane zeroing in. The stark image was surrounded by a woefully cheap-looking graphical treatment
column6: and prompted an immediate outcry. Nonesuch swiftly replaced the image
column7: but the  episode made its impression. Unfortunately
column8: it could stand in as a  diagnosis for the piece itself
column9: a project conceived in noble intentions but hobbled by confused
column10:
muddled execution.
