column3: Gotye (stage name of Australian musician Walter De Backer) hearkens back to a time when the crop of middlebrow male pop stars wasn't so lousy with simpering troubadours or assembly-line idols. Instead
column4: the ranks were populated by guys like Peter Gabriel
column5: George Michael
column6: and Hall & Oates
column7: who sang forcefully and made bold pop hits with intelligent
column8: grown-up themes. Artists who also had broad sonic appetites and arty predilections
column9: guaranteeing their work would sometimes frustrate
column10: but would remain intriguing.

column1: On his last solo album
column2: 2006's Like Drawing Blood
column3: Gotye achieved the abstraction and restlessness of good art-pop
column4: but failed to bring enough actual pop to the equation. The album was an inspired
column5: dense blend of globe-spanning sounds
column6: yet it meandered far too frequently. Many of the songs stretched between five and seven minutes long
column7: and found him stitching together multiple sounds and ideas at the detriment of shape or focus
column8: eschewing pop's vital sense of urgency. Fortunately
column9: with his newest release
column10: Making Mirrors
column11: Gotye has figured out how to remain sonically voracious while still giving his listeners a sturdy foothold. He finds room here for psych-rock
column12: soul
column13: earnest balladeering
column14: creepy retro-futurism
column15: electronic and Tropicalia touches
column16: and
column17: yes
column18: scads of serious-minded 1980s pop. It's in that last category that most of album's best moments reside. Without ever settling in one spot too slavishly or lengthily to come off like a mere imitator
column19: Gotye deploys his sincere
column20: powerfully expressive voice (under-utilized on Like Drawing Blood) in evoking those bombastic 80s pop architects referenced above. ""Somebody That I Used to Know"" and ""Eyes Wide Open"" dramatically convey the acrimony and finality of a shattered relationship
column21: while ""In Your Light"" and ""Save Me"" offer up the redemptive side of the coin.

column1: These declamatory studio-pop moves don't just represent many of Making Mirrors' highlights; their shared style and tone also really helps hold the album together
column2: compensating for Gotye's scattershot attention span elsewhere. Admittedly
column3: some of these one-offs are very good – the Cee-Lo/Jamie Lidell-approved retro-soul of ""I Feel Better"" is the kind of thing that actually works far better as an isolated detour than an organizing principle. The same is true for the guileless ""Giving Me a Chance"" (which somehow manages to favorably evoke Travis) and the ""Drive My Car""-styled acid-rock blast ""Easy Way Out"". Only occasionally does Gotye wander too far off the reservation
column4: but by that point he's earned his quirks
column5: and so the bizarrely pitch-shifted
column6: suburbia-tech nightmare ""State of the Art"" and eerily whispered
column7: Reznor-ish ""Don't Worry
column8: We'll Be Watching You"" feel more like an endearingly loopy sidebars than self-indulgent
column9: momentum-derailing bores. Gotye's exemplary pop sense may be the big revelation of Making Mirrors
column10:
yet it's his arty restlessness that will continue to keep him interesting.

1977 is-- to quote Terius Nash himself-- an ""Internet album."" Nash (aka The-Dream) released it for free on his website on August 31
column2: with the begrudged blessing of his bosses at Def Jam. It's his fourth solo album
column3: but his first released in this manner
column4: and it raises the question of whether or not we are supposed to alter our expectations. Is this a tossed-off re-packaging of demos? Is he merely trying to satiate a fanbase waiting for an album that he promised to drop this past June? We don't know the answers to those questions (although my guesses would be ""no"" and ""maybe"")
column5: but it would seem foolish to hold 1977 to a lower standard. It's no longer unusual-- especially in the world of rap
column6: and to a lesser extent R&B-- to put a full album on the Internet for free. If Nash had included a way for fans to pay what they wanted for the album
column7: he would've been adopting a strategy utilized in previous years by Radiohead and Girl Talk.

column1: And yet
column2: Nash is asking us to adjust our expectations. Crucially though
column3: he's not asking that we alter our notions of what we expect of him
column4: just what we expect from him. 1977 represents not a conscious change in quality
column5: but a conscious change in style and sound
column6: at least for the time being. A few days before he released the album
column7: he tweeted
column8: ""When I'm 40 ill write Myself a Pop Smash just so I can Perform on National TV. Not that hard to do. But that's not who I am right now."" True to his word
column9: 1977 often strays far from Nash's few solo pop smashes. Instead
column10: it is a deeply personal and presumably therapeutic album. It's one that he fought with his label to release
column11: that he's putting out under his birth name and titled for his birth year
column12: and for which he has put the lyrics of every song up on his website. Though he was predictably coy about the subject
column13: the specter of his divorce from singer Christina Milian looms over it.

column1: In its sparseness and unrelenting directness
column2: the album's most recent precedent is Kanye West's break up opus 808s & Heartbreak
column3: and much like that record
column4: it's already proven to be a divisive if misunderstood album. It showcases a bitter and angry Nash
column5: and though he has previously dabbled in acidic and unflinching break-up songs
column6: 1977 is his first album to largely focus on something other than his sexual prowess. Like West
column7: his vitriol is mostly spewed outward
column8: with seemingly little regard for the feelings or reputation of whoever is on the other side. There is Spanish guitar
column9: as if Nash imagines himself readying for a duel. There is acoustic guitar
column10: as if to accentuate his confessionals. And there is guitar feedback
column11: as if his heart were screaming out.

column1: As a portrayal of a broken relationship
column2: 1977 at its best is as vivid as it is one-sided. ""Wake Me When It's Over""
column3: which effectively utilizes the glacial R&B of Drake and his producer Noah ""40"" Shebib
column4: opens the album with a wrenching portrait of a romance falling apart in plain view of friends and the public. As Nash coos the chorus we find him frozen in amber
column5: unable to shake a break up for which he claims he would've taken bullets. Even tracks like ""Rolex"" and ""Wish You Were Mine""
column6: which don't hew as close to the theme as others
column7: have a spitefulness that hint at an intense desire to throw your recovery in your ex's face.

column1: But of course
column2: writing songs from this point of view presents some problems. Mainly
column3: one has to be able to stomach the one-sided bile and Nash's likely half-truths. To that end
column5: like West's 808s
column6: functions best as a look inside the mind of a man wrecked by a trying relationship and a worse break up. His failings should not be excused
column7: but the feelings exist
column8: and have likely existed inside most of us at some point (regardless of gender)
column9: and to that end
column10: they're understandable even if they're not completely acceptable.

column1: There are also essential moments on the album where Nash perhaps unwittingly reveals the more aggressively resentful songs to be a sort of Pyrrhic victory. One is on ""Form of Flattery""
column2: where he addresses the ex he hates and seethes
column3: ""I'm not better than that."" Another is ""Wedding Crasher""
column4: the absolute standout here
column5: wherein Nash shows up at his ex's wedding and admits
column6: once and for all
column7: that his attempts to replace her have been futile. Sonically
column8: it recalls the buoyant lightness of Love King's ""Florida University""
column9: though it's less cloying
column10: and this time he's basically saying
column11: ""fuck you"" back at himself.

column1: All that said
column2: Nash still misses a huge opportunity. One of the legitimate criticisms of 808s was that West's ex had no forum to respond to the album. While it's obviously impossible to expect Nash to cede space on 1977 to Milian (or whomever)
column3: there is a critical difference between himself and West. Nash is a songwriter by trade who made his name writing from the perspective of people (mostly women) other than himself
column4: including what may be the biggest female empowerment single of the past decade. When Nash does give the floor completely to a female voice
column5: it's for the relatively unknown Casha to sing a cover of Deniece Williams' 1981 hit ""Silly"". As a tune
column6: the song itself is fine
column7: but framed by Nash's wrath it sadly comes off as pleading and passive. How great would it have been for Nash to use that spot on the album to turn the pen on himself
column8: if only for one song?

column1: Still
column2: 1977 itself is a success
column3: even if it doesn't stand up completely to his three previous releases. As a standalone depiction of a deteriorating relationship and miserable break up
column4: it's engrossing and
column5: even to a fault
column6: extremely honest. As a piece of music
column7: it eschews the richness and lushness of those albums
column8: a sound that's felt on the verge of becoming stale. 1977 could be called a palate cleanser
column9:
but it's way too torn-up to be that. It's more like a shot (or three) of whisky. Sometimes that feels like exactly what you need.

column10: more important

column4: to fight in a war that is not yours?"") seem to describe the Normandy landings in WWII. But then Rosenthal punctuates her spoken words with the mouthed sound of mortar shells exploding-- ""Ka-bough! Ka-bough!"" It's the kind of thing that looks questionable on paper and that most would have been embarrassed to try in the studio
column5: but it winds up working brilliantly
column6: evoking a child storyteller's description of a horror. Another surprising turn comes during ""Shooting Stars""
column7: an achingly slow
column8: mournful
column9: and ultimately gorgeous piano ballad
column10: when Rosenthal moans and wails wordlessly at the end of every stanza
column11: her vocalizations expressing what her words cannot.

column1: As moving as I find this record
column2: it's not an easy sell. It's such a weighty thing
column3: exerting a constant pressure that is only occasionally relieved. But as harsh and despairing as Red Sugar can be
column4: there's also a yearning for warmth and humanity

the more it opens up.

The Oakland
column2: California DIY hip-hop duo Main Attrakionz couldn't have come at a better time. It's no news that the indie rap spectrum is beginning to widen and mutate

column5: ramping up demand for astrally fogged bedroom producer Clams Casino's beats and grabbing up page space for up-and-coming outsiders like Harlem's ASAP Rocky. It's no surprise then that Main Attrakionz are being lumped into the same discussions (after all
column6: they've worked with the latter three aforementioned artists)
column7: and in turn are well on their way to gaining the similar levels of notoriety. At the end of last month-- hot off their new mixtape 808s & Dark Grapes II-- the pair headed East and rocked Manhattan's New Museum as part of its ""Get Weird"" series

column1: ""Weird
column2: however

column4: you'd be left with glassy synths and watery textures that one could easily classify as ambient
column5: rappers Squadda B and MondreM.A.N. seem simply to be products of their environment. And we're not necessarily talking about Oakland. While as prolific
column6: as unafraid to integrate leftfield influences into their music
column7: and as happy to keep things subwoofer-friendly as their Bay Area peers
column8: most of their success and musical inspirations call cyberspace home. And in the case of 808s-- the fourth freebie mixtape full-length that these barely 20-year-olds have released in the past year (not including their solo efforts)-- Main Attrakionz seem to be neither the rule nor the exception
column9: but rather a well-meaning
column10: well-balanced rap act that has a sound that's both very ""now"" yet convincingly true-to-self.

column1: As rappers
column2: Squadda and Mondre at first seem unremarkable. Thematically
column3: it's weed
column4: women
column5: and ambition
column6: mixed with some mild introspection and broad sloganeering (""Ain't shit gon' change
column7: but yo' ass can
column8: goes the hook on ""Nothin' Gonna Change""). So while some might write the two off in the rhyme department
column9: it's important to note that the rhymes aren't really the draw here. Instead
column10: the simplistic approach reads like a mantra of self-disciplining restraint (or as Mondre explains on ""Paperwork""
column11: ""I keep the music simple so any nigga can see""). Though lacking Lil B's bizarro free-associative style
column12: it becomes pretty clear that
column13: if their work ethic and output wasn't evidence enough
column14: these guys are just constantly rapping: You can almost imagine them rhyming their way out of a speeding ticket or through a city council meeting (see: ""Rap Junkies""). Which is to say
column15: it blends perfectly with the zoned-out production. And the fact that Squadda and Mondre aren't exactly foils-- I wouldn't have noticed that each rapper takes a solo cut here had I not had the tracklist glowing back at me-- everything on 808s seems to emulsify almost effortlessly.

column1: As the title suggests
column2: this is music that will have you scrolling through your contacts to see if anyone's holding. Tracks like the new age-y ""Perfect Skies"" and the excellent ""Chuch"" spread out with a Zen-like grace that
column3: coupled with Squadda and Mondre's fluid back-and-forth
column4: invites you to melt into it. So
column5: no
column6: Main Attrakionz won't be spared the ridicule of jockeying the hipster zeitgeist-- after all
column7: opener ""Bossalinis & Fooliyones Pt. 2"" samples Glasser's ""Treasury of We""-- but these idiosyncratic pairings offer insight into where these guys are coming from.

column1: Main Attrakionz have often been described as ""lo-fi rap
column2: and while 808s & Dark Grapes II itself is sonically tight and clean
column3: it reeks of homemade qualities. Just because you can't hear the vocals reverberating off the tacky wood paneling in some basement doesn't mean you don't get a feel for how it was made. These guys are very much of the digital age and clearly feel most comfortable between the hinges of their laptops-- never mind that when the two are backed by more traditional
column4: blocky programmings

column6: Main Attrakionz synthesize their influences and source material uniquely and offer an endearing voice where others simply troll. Or
column7:
to paraphrase another popular internet parlance: They're doing it right.

The 2006 arrival of Sao Paulo novo-wave sextet CSS couldn't have been better timed
column3: coming as it did in the wake of a pervasive post-punk revival in indie-rock
column4: a burgeoning Diplo-led interest in gritty Brazilian dance music
column5: and a broadband-enabled globalized mode of music consumption that allowed record labels to perform international A&R scouting from their desktops. And CSS were more than happy to seize the moment

column1: However

column3: Donkey
column4: failed to generate the same amount of dancefloor traction-- and following a subsequent split from their North American boosters at Sub Pop-- CSS know it's going to take a lot more than a Death From Above 1979 reunion tour to make them relevant again. And so on La Liberación

column6: as Pitchfork's Eric Harvey said in his review of Donkey

column1: Musically speaking
column2: CSS can evolve only as much as lightning-rod frontwoman Lovefoxxx allows
column3: and on La Liberación
column4: she's only game to break from her potty-mouthed party-girl persona about half the time. That Lovefoxxx is aware of her own vacuity doesn't make it easier to take-- the remedial
column5: call-and-response chorus of ""I Love You"" (all together now: ""I love you/ I love you
column6: too"") may very well be a comment on the transactional nature of relationships
column7: but
column8: in the absence of a proper hook
column9: it feels more like lazy songwriting. And the would-be empowerment anthem ""City Grrrl""-- an unapologetic celebration of revealing outfits and one-night stands-- feels like a forced attempt to fly the freak flag for club kids sick of dancing to ""Born This Way"".

column1: And yet as much as these songs play right into well-worn CSS themes of vanity and self-gratification
column2: on La Liberación
column3: the band sounds genuinely torn between pandering to the sort of hopped-up hedonists who want to rip off Lovefoxxx’s clothes when she does a stage dive
column4: and a desire to dial down the crassness and redefine their character. Their experiments don't always yield useful results-- the downcast
column5: acoustic-guitar-powered ""Partners in Crime"" comes awkwardly decorated with free-form piano rolls that trip up rather than propel the song's momentum. But there are moments when CSS find a way to successfully evolve without alienating their base
column6: particularly on the playful
column7: Afro-funk-inflected pop of ""Echo of Love"" and the ""Paper Planes""-fashioned
column8: tropical slow-burner ""Hits Me Like a Rock""
column9: a winning duet with Bobby Gillespie (returning the favor after Lovefoxxx's guest appearance on Primal Scream's 2008 release Beautiful Future). In light of these developments
column10:
the sax-squawked nihilism of the closing ""Fuck Everything"" feels all the more empty: There's enough evidence on La Liberación to suggest CSS actually do care about being a band you'll still respect in the morning.

The title of the Field's third album
column2: Looping State of Mind
column3: might have you thinking that producer Axel Willner is getting back to basics. Especially after he strayed
column4: with only intermittent success
column5: from his instantly recognizable template on his 2009 sophomore record
column6: Yesterday and Today. After all
column7: at its simplest
column8: techno is music that can be built with just a few loops. And Willner's first few records certainly made effective use of the form
column9: layering shimmering loops of voice and synth and guitar on each track until he'd built a fluffy and infinitely soothing wall of sound.

column1: Immersive and repetitive
column2: the Field's first singles and 2007 debut album
column3: From Here We Go Sublime
column4: were like ambient records disguised as both experimental techno and luscious pop. So is Looping State of Mind a return to that sound
column5: the one that made the Field a crossover favorite with rock kids a few years back? Not exactly. In a few instances it's barely recognizable as ""the Field"" at all. It may be still be built from loops
column6: but Willner's never orchestrated so many of them so artfully into such dense and infinitely listenable soundscapes.

column1: Good thing
column2: too
column3: because the last few years have seen a lot of bedroom producers become briefly famous for ambient records disguised as pop
column4: for amorphous electronic doodles disguised as songs. Instead of coasting
column5: as one of the inadvertent models for the current ""chill"" thing
column6: a producer who'd probably earn infinite props just for repeating himself
column7: Willner decided to put 99 percent of his acolytes to shame here. True
column8: there are still tracks
column9: like ""It's Up There""
column10: that recall Willner's best-loved stuff
column11: but even they feel richer
column12: like the early Field in 3D and high-def. ""Arpeggiated Love"" is on the one hand a dead-ringer for the propulsive
column13: ecstatic sound-wash of From Here We Go Sublime. But Willner now fleshes it out with shiver-inducing soul music harmonies that owe less to sleek German techno than gospel-tinged American house. True
column14: he was quoting classic soul group the Flamingos as early as Sublime
column15: but he's never been so overt in dipping into dance music's global history.

column1: As that might suggest
column2: Looping often strays far from the Field we know
column3: into territory that recalls deep house
column4: post-punk
column5: shoegaze
column6: noise-rock
column7: and cosmic techno. And he manages to swirl them all together in a way that makes his earliest attempts to fuse ambient and trance feel like gorgeous apprentice work. Yesterday and Today sometimes sounded hesitant
column8: as if Willner didn't quite know how to make his music fresh for a second time. On Looping he packs all seven tracks with curveballs
column9: and each new direction feel successful
column10: vital
column11: surprising.

column1: At one point on opener ""Is This Power""
column2: everything drops away except for an eerie bass twang that recalls Joy Division or the Cure circa ""A Forest""
column3: but when the boogie bass finally drops back in
column4: you're not only reminded that this is dance music
column5: it's easily the funkiest Field tune you've probably yet heard. The rhythms on Looping are more varied than anything the Willner's done before. Though he hasn't entirely abandoned that programmed motorik pulse that drove Sublime
column6: his work with live bands over the last few years has clearly fed into Looping. ""Then It's White"" summons a Yorke-less Radiohead
column7: with the way the drums subtly mesh human fluency and digital tech. And that's not even counting the Amnesiac-like mix of pensive piano and mournful
column8: computer-warped vocals.

column1: Despite the sometimes winning simplicity of his music
column2: Willner was no slouch as a producer before. Yet listening to this album
column3: there's no doubt he's grown way more assured and inventive over the last two years. And he's brought all his skill to bear on Looping
column4: as composer and arranger and texturologist
column5: in order to build something this simultaneously sweeping and subtle
column6: deep and immediate. It could still alienate those perpetually pining for copies of ""A Paw in My Face"" or ""Sun and Ice"". But if they listen more deeply
column7:
they might just hear Willner’s masterpiece-to-date.

Cymbals Eat Guitars have followed Why There Are Mountains
column3: their self-released debut of 1990s indie rock alchemy
column4: with a difficult and likely divisive sophomore LP. Which isn't all that surprising-- these things happen when the ""next step"" involves signing to a label
column5: hiring a venerated producer (John Agnello
column6: who also worked this year with alt-revivalists Male Bonding)
column7: turning over half of your personnel
column8: and releasing an 8 1/2-minute song as the ""first single."" Here's the thing: Lenses Alien doesn't really sound all that different from Why There Are Mountains
column9: which is a tribute to how fully formed and musically tight CEG were right out of the gate. Perhaps the most challenging thing about Lenses Alien is how it makes what it sounds like fairly unimportant: Like last time
column10: almost none of its sonic touchstones exist outside of the Clinton administration
column11: but Joseph D'Agostino takes an enormous leap of faith by doubling down on his brick-thick verbiage during a lyrics-first record that puts more confidence in the listener's attention span than pretty much anything else I've heard this year.

column1: It's become something of a cliché to praise an ""album in the mp3 age
column2: and while Lenses Alien certainly isn't intended to be strip-mined for singles
column3: it's meant to be experienced on a remarkably micro level. It's actually more ambitious than the already grand Mountains
column4: but it doesn't manifest in Byzantine song structure or far-flung sonic touches. While there's a peripheral shift from the more blue-collar
column5: populist likes of Built to Spill
column6: Modest Mouse
column7: and the Wrens into the deconstructive and unfairly less celebrated Cap'n Jazz (when it's loud) and the Appleseed Cast (when it's quiet)
column8: the craft is evident in how every lyric and riff is exactingly honed to be of near equal importance.

column1: The rest of Lenses Alien doesn't take after the sprawl of ""Rifle Eyesight (Proper Name)""-- it's about twice as long as anything else-- but it lays out the record's rules of engagement. I've talked with others who consider its flow to be somewhat clunky
column2: which is understandable considering what listeners typically expect from a song of that length
column3: particularly an opener. There's not an epic build or a cataclysmic blowout: D'Agostino occupies the mind of an unstable
column4: possibly predatory narrator
column5: changing perspective and mood from verse to verse
column6: the extended floods of physically punishing guitar feedback acting as outbursts of mental anguish linking unorthodox yet accessible and sprightly vocal lines. I'll call it anticlimactic as a compliment: Over an ugly
column7: gnarled cluster of notes
column8: D'Agostino asks
column9: ""What former police sits at the bus stop offering rides?” and the song ends abruptly like a stunning reveal. After eight minutes of psychodrama played out in his head
column10: the camera pans out for you to imagine the yellowed teeth or cold
column11: vacant stare of its main character.

column1: So many of Lenses Alien's enduring moments come from these mergers of sensation-- the chorus of ""oh-whoas"" from tired passengers on the cunningly catchy ""Shore Points"" underlining an abrupt change of plans along the Jersey coastline; a picture of motorboats and Styrofoam coolers amidst the burst of crowd-pleasing guitars during ""Keep Me Waiting"". Then there's the liquid
column2: unsteady near-instrumental of ""The Current"" stopping to make a brief and lucid prayer for a universe free of physical suffering
column3: while ""Gary Condit"" offers the record's final grasp at understanding: ""Is it teeth-shaking polyphony
column4: grace
column5: and completion or nothing?"" delivered as an unholy
column6: desperate cry for help.

column1: The need for release runs throughout Lenses Alien
column2: as it condenses the spacious travelogues of Mountains into claustrophobic ruminations on the metaphysical
column3: moving cars
column4: and D'Agostino's mind existing as purgatories. ""Plainclothes"" opens suggesting a True Crime story
column5: but it's a passing thought during a paranoid drive up a New York highway interspersed with startling
column6: vivid details-- the tricks cops pull on unsuspecting drivers during initiation season
column7: the sensation of being haunted by ghosts of past partiers in a guest house. This unsettling otherworldliness continues through ""Definite Darkness""
column8: a mysterious police investigation causing a sleepless night that fades out on a coda of wearied sighs.

column1: Considering all the paranoia and fleeting revelations
column2: drugs unsurprisingly play a big role here
column3: particularly psychedelics whose side effects are less about hedonism than discovery. D'Agostino and friends have relatable freak outs and puke in sand dunes
column4: pass out with their shoes on
column5: roll down hills on skateboards
column6: and remark upon how ""dried mushrooms taste a lot like communion wafers."" They’re disarmingly naïve about worlds opening up to them
column7: seeing gas leaks
column8: air force bases
column9: and the suburban and rural expanses of the northeast United States as reflections of celestial significance.

column1: The downside is how the music occasionally buckles under the weight of its own restlessness and D'Agostino’s words-- a slightly skewed ratio of visceral immediacy to cerebral satisfaction making it a slight notch below Why There Are Mountains. While packed with forceful riffs and quirky melodic turns
column2: ""Another Tunguska"" and ""Secret Family"" are such slippery compositions that D'Agostino's backing can sometimes feel incidental. But once you stop looking for the hooks and choruses as they might be defined traditionally
column3: dozens of inventive melodies emerge: Is the elegant
column4: Elliott Smith-esque melody of ""Shore Points"" less sticky because there’s no chorus? Do the soulfully swooping harmonies of ""Wavelengths"" constitute a chorus even though the lyrics don’t repeat?

column1: I suppose it's indicative of Lenses Alien's strange magnetism that it raises as many questions when it's catchy as it does when it's inscrutable. After all
column2: it's so thick with overlapping images
column3: memories
column4: stray thoughts
column5: and second guessing that I sense D'Agostino's asking us throughout: How real are our own emotions? Are you guessing at your own feelings? It's heavy stuff
column6: never answered in an easy way
column7: and can really feel out of step with their peers who treat lyrics as placeholders and thoughts as fact. More than the sound of the 90s
column8: Lenses Alien recalls
column9: at least to these ears
column10: the way we might’ve interacted with those records at the time: poring over the lyrics sheet
column11: having a real sense of investment.

column1: It's no slight to say Lenses Alien isn't at the level of Perfect From Now On or The Moon and Antarctica -- it's not a masterpiece. But while Why There Are Mountains reminded me of what those records sounded like
column2: Lenses Alien does something more difficult by reminding what it felt like once they were over and you were left to wonder if you just stumbled upon a cosmic
column3:
philosophical treatise disguised as an indie rock record.

For those curious how this refurbished and remastered version of a previously released EP can be given a lower mark than the orginal
column3: please note that the score is more about the release than the band. As someone smitten with the original and Memoryhouse's ""ambient shoegaze
column4: I was hoping the update would be a promised ""new and improved"" version. To be clear
column5: the EP is technically all new material: Three tracks from the old EP (""Sleep Patterns""
column6: ""Lately (Deuxième)""
column7: ""To The Lighthouse"") were re-recorded and the pleasant interlude ""The Waves"" is replaced with two song-like tracks
column8: ""<a href=""http://pitchfork.com/forkcast/15945-modern-normal/"" target=""_blank"">Modern
column9: Normal"" and ""Quiet America"".

column1: The new tracks-- the hook for folks that have the original The Years-- are pleasant
column2: if unsurprising.  Other than the appearance of live drums on ""Modern
column3: Normal""
column4: they offer a slightly different variation on what Evan Abeele and Denise Nouvion have done previously.  Ironically
column5: it's on the old/new tracks where The Years shows the group spreading its wings
column6: though not necessarily in a becoming manner.

column1: Of the three returnees
column2: only ""Sleep Patterns"" comes through sounding like its previous version.  There are small yet noticeable changes made to the arrangement-- the addition of strings (or string-like sounds) being the most apparent. The track sounds more robust
column3: but it's otherwise about the same. While ""Lately"" loses the cassette-tape ambiance that dovetailed nicely with its Eternal Sunshine score sample
column4: it's also not unrecognizable. That said
column5: the exchange of that home-recording coziness for some bright and shiny opulence is a bit disconcerting. Then there's ""To the Lighthouse""
column6: which undergoes an extreme makeover:  The group swaps out the original's shimmering intro and its relaxed yet propulsive trip-hop-like gait for some kids-at-play found-sound samples and a decidedly less jaunty pace.  As a result
column7: the track that stood out for the change of pace it offered now falls in line with Memoryhouse's primary M.O.

column1: Despite my own misgivings about these re-recordings
column2: these new versions aren't bad by any stretch-- they just seem unnecessary. While it's nice to hear what Memoryhouse would've done with these older tracks if they were produced  in a proper studio
column3: the end result is akin to a more famous attempt at an after-the-fact fine-tuning: filmmaker George Lucas' seemingly endless tweaking and CGI-ing of the original Star Wars trilogy. The band makes mention of Lucas on its blog
column4: while promising that this EP isn't on the same level as Lucas' compulsive tinkering. But the question that  Star Wars fans continually ask themselves is a question that some fans of The Years might also have: Why go back and fix something that wasn't broken?

column1: To fuss over those old tracks
column2: especially in light of how little the band has actually recorded
column3: seems regressive.  The overall intent of this release-- to put an actual
column4: physical copy of  The Years out into the world for folks who aren't up to speed on their online music research-- is understandable
column5: and even justifiable
column6: on many levels.  But for folks who have been living with these songs for over a year
column7:
offering two passable new tracks next to these three remakes isn't nearly good enough.

In a recent interview with the New York Times Magazine blog (tagged: ""culture;"" previous post: ""The Novelty Knit"")
column3: 23-year-old Claire Boucher proudly described the music she makes under the name Grimes as ""post-Internet."" ""The music of my childhood was really diverse because I had access to everything
column4: she said
column5: and this omnivorousness is apparent in her eccentric
column6: dreamy sound
column7: which draws upon everything from dubstep to disco
column8: Eastern music to 1990s R&B.

column1: Even before that interview
column2: it was clear Grimes knew her way around a web browser. She first attracted an audience outside Montreal's DIY art and music scene when she put her earliest recordings online for free
column3: and since then she's cultivated an online presence that makes equal room for her music and haunting visual art. She's even issued preemptive strikes against critics' misguided games of Spot the Influence (""I don't listen to Kate Bush
column4: nor have I ever
column5: she tweeted a few weeks ago-- a delightful bit of sacrilege from an artist who's probably never read an article about herself that didn't contain the word ""weirdo""). Whatever she’s doing
column6: it's working: at the beginning of last year she was uploading to her MySpace the DIY bedroom recordings that would comprise her debut album
column7: and now she and her art school haircut are posing in couture for Times online subscribers. (Just ask Salem-- shit doesn't get more post-Internet than that.)

column1: Now that debut album
column2: Geidi Primes
column3: is getting a good old fashioned CD/LP rerelease on the UK-based label No Pain in Pop. (Previously its only physical release was a limited-run cassette on Montreal’s flourishing experimental pop imprint Arbutus.) Coming on the heels of her terrific material on the tantalizingly brief Darkbloom split EP
column4: the Geidi Primes' re-release is a wisely timed holdover for the months before her next LP comes out early next year. But Geidi Primes is much more than a quaint indicator of how far Grimes has come in the past year and a half. Despite its modest production values and relative simplicity
column5: it's a cohesive
column6: enchanting
column7: and surprisingly assured debut.

column1: Even though it clocks in at a slight 30 minutes
column2: Geidi Primes is a wholly immersive listen. The melodies are hooky and sweet
column3: but each track has a throbbing undercurrent of menace that pulls you in like a riptide. It's hard to pinpoint exactly from where this pervading element of darkness springs-- especially since
column4: on paper
column5: most of the lyrics read like valentines. (Pretty much every discernable chorus revolves around the word ""heart."") The hypnotic standout ""Feyd Rautha Dark Heart"" begins with a simple Casio-style beat and an ostensibly sugary hook-- ""I won't break your heart in the dark""-- but the track builds into something decidedly eerie: chilly synth hits
column6: zombified vocals
column7: and percussion that sounds like rattling bones. By the end
column8: even the sweet refrain sounds less like an expression of devotion and more like a chant meant to put you under some kind of spell. Which
column9: you come to realize
column10: is Geidi Primes' main objective.

column1: Perhaps Geidi Primes' greatest virtue is its resourcefulness: It excels at crafting evocative moods from deceivingly simple sonic materials and song structures. Nowhere is this more apparent than on the simple
column2: looping bassline of ""Rosa""
column3: the brightest and most unabashedly straightforward song on the record
column4: and also the one most likely to stay lodged in your head for days. Then there’s the brief
column5: wordless ""Gambang"" making utter gorgeousness from nothing more than a slightly warped sample and breathy falsetto curlicues.

column1: As a vocalist
column2: Grimes knows how to work her range. Though she's become known for her impressive falsetto (which she pushes to rapturous
column3: Donna Summer-like heights on the Darkbloom single ""Vanessa"") and she can occasionally pull of a spooky low tone that's faintly reminiscent of Karin Dreijer Andersson
column4: she spends much of Geidi Primes in mid-range
column5: tuneful deadpan
column6: which lends wry humor to the lines she coos to a lover on ""Zoal
column7: Face Dancer"": ""Everybody thinks that I'm boring/ Many people think I've got no clue."" Just because she's spacey-- yes
column8: nerds
column9: those are Dune references scattered throughout the track listing-- doesn't mean she's without earthly wit. It takes a pretty good sense of humor to write an utterly gorgeous closer and call it ""Beast Infection"".

column1: Given her restlessly prolific creativity (she followed up Geidi Primes with another solid 2010 release
column2: Halfaxa) and the bounding artistic strides she's displayed with her recent singles
column3: Grimes could very well be poised for a meteoric rise with the release of her next full length. But Geidi Primes shows that even her earliest recordings displayed a distinct point of view and an oddly mesmerizing quality. There’s something refreshingly ""post-Internet"" about that too-- a dreamy soundscape that invites an escape from the glitchy universe
column4:
a brief provocation to let go and just bliss out.

For their 2010 debut Inter-Be
column2: Peter Pisano and Brian Moen of Peter Wolf Crier sat down and
column3: in one night
column4: churned out a series of solid
column5: vintage-sounding folk songs. Then
column6: the Minneapolis duo played 100 shows in a six-month span and-- with ""a new-found footing of confidence and experimentation
column7: according to the press release-- sat down and recorded Garden of Arms. The confidence in their new record is clear
column8: if only because their vocals sound more boisterous than ever
column9: but for the most part
column10: the experimentation is the problem.

column1: Keep in mind that ""experimentation"" for Peter Wolf Crier doesn't mean a Steve Reich or some dense soundscape. Instead
column2: they needlessly streamlined their sound
column3: creating the feel of a locationless
column4: generic rock band. They've effectively replaced the old radio warmth of Inter-Be's ""Crutch & Cane"" with an emotionless electric guitar on ""Beach"" that brings to mind Audioslave-era Tom Morello. For percussion
column5: they've opted for a militaristic snare that does little more than distract from every other layer. And while the vocals are more confident
column6: the melodies are interchangeable.

column1: The opener
column2: ""Right Away""
column3: sets the tone with its repetitive
column4: claustrophobic vocal treatment. The lyrics offer a collage of emotions that never seem to connect: Lines like ""All the inches flow"" and ""Right away you are the one"" hint at something meaningful
column5: but never taking the time to provide actual meaning. Even when the emotions are clear
column6: Pisano's melodramatic belting detracts from the weight of the heartbreak. High drama seems to be the aim of Garden of Arms
column7: especially when you consider the majority of the lyrics are comprised of over-the-top emotional imagery like ""Lonely gardener it is time you woke the knight/ Kiss divine and hold his lips to your own light."" (Song titles like ""Haunt You"" don't help.)

column1: There are some welcome turns. ""Beach"" features an overarching percussion that sounds like swishing water
column2: and the most satisfying moment on the track ""Hard Heart"" comes at the end
column3: where a chorus of ethereal vocals serve as percussive accents. ""Cut a Hand"" makes a return to the muffled guitar warmth of their debut
column4: and Pisano's vocals are markedly toned down
column5: but again
column6: the song is covered in Moen's heavy snares. Conversely
column7: one of the best songs
column8: ""Settling It Off""
column9: tempers the melodrama of the lyrics with quiet percussion
column10: tender vocals
column11: and a simple fingerpicked guitar.

column1: It isn't until the final two tracks that their departure from Inter-Be pays off. On ""Never Meant to Love You""
column2: Pisano sounds exhausted
column3: perhaps from all the belting. There are still poetic analogies-- dead leaves and drought to evoke the end of a relationship-- but the instruments gradually get quieter. His vocals fade
column4: and his regret turns to silence. The final track ""Wheel"" features even fewer instruments: The song's mainly backed by ghostly moans
column5: the album devolving into a quiet static shuffle. It's a far cry from the clutter of ""Right Away"" and a welcome respite from the melodrama
column6:
making clear that the band is capable of great things in its new form.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16910/homepage_large.7d91a8cd.jpg|In the Grace of Your Love|3529.0|The Rapture|['Rock'
column3: the Rapture's legacy is as a galvanizing force for the underground
column4: busting indie rock's standstill so mightily that we're now embarrassed to be the guy not dancing. They never seemed like a good bet to break dance music to the mainstream audiences
column5: though
column6: no matter how hard iTunes insists that the closing track on my copy of 2006's Pieces of the People We Love is titled ""Best Buy Exclusive."" Pan-pop conspiracy theorists might note that the Rapture reached fever-pitch in New York in 2003
column7: or right around the time that Lady Gaga was enrolling at NYU
column8: but if the Rapture hadn't stopped their own momentum
column9: someone would have stopped it for them: likely labelmate/mentor/producer James Murphy
column10: whose LCD Soundsystem offered the same funk-punk grooves but had better jokes (well
column11: had jokes period) and a more explosive live presence
column12: with pathos to boot. The Rapture were too nervy and out-of-sync to ascend the ranks.

column1: None of that changes the fact that the Rapture return
column2: minus a surly Youtube non-sensation
column3: at a time when house and disco are more fashionable than at any time since the early 1980s. See Gaga
column4: see Hercules and Love Affair
column5: see couture Daft Punk Lego dolls
column6: see the fact that Chris Brown knows a French guy. The Rapture
column7: always medium opportunists
column8: aren't interested in taking advantage of this. They've become what they've always threatened to become: an art-rock band with predilections for boogie and dippy lyrics. Grace sounds like the Rapture without retreading past successes
column9: a nifty trick that underscores the band's hard-won identity.

column1: The Rapture are a pretty good art-rock band
column2: too: Grace is fleshier than its predecessors
column3: with horns
column4: needlework guitar
column5: and Jenner's brash voice filling the negative space the band used to gift to the dance floor. They deftly respond to choral background vocals
column6: funky synth slabs
column7: and tasteful guitar fills. A group that was once a combustible ball of energy is now a functioning nervous system with a keen sense of pace and texture. You can hear notes of U2's propulsive anthems (""Sail Away"")
column8: Talking Heads' agitated funk (""Can You Find a Way"")
column9: and XTC's ballast pop (""Rollercoaster""). You can forgive them for envying Cut Copy's hot-knife-through-butter crowd uniters (""Children"").

column1: Grace is the band's mature album
column2: by their own reckoning: Press for the record has almost unanimously focused on the members' stroller-pushing benders
column3: how frontman Luke Jenner spent time playing softball
column4: attending church
column5: and coping with the loss of his mother. Stability and love dominate its themes
column6: the title cutting think-pieces off at the pass by invoking grace directly: This album is about sustained
column7: earned love
column8: as well as the forgiveness inherent in it.

column1: When it clicks
column2: it's triumphant. My two favorite songs are two of the most explicitly groove-oriented
column3: ramped to tempos at which Jenner's alkaline voice can't help but cast hooks. ""Miss You"" attempts to reconcile with his mother
column4: while ""Never Die Again"" pleads for a healthy relationship
column5: topics flung far from dance music's typical fare. Of course
column6: if the songs were about Lunchables or macroeconomics
column7: I'd love them just them same; such is the draw when Jenner turns his nasal pipes to siren.

column1: Therein lies the fallacy of the Rapture's maturity: Jenner has always played peek-a-boo with God and serenity (previous albums included songs titled ""Love Is All""
column2: ""Live in the Sunshine""
column3: and ""Open Up Your Heart""
column4: not forgetting that the name of the band is the Rapture). On Grace he does so with more explicit inspiration
column5: but he's a fumbling lyricist
column6: better suited for tunneling into our Nikes than our hearts.

column1: Jenner used to scrap and cluck for our attention more often; he's had better luck wrangling sentiment out of a yelp than a platitude (the best disco singers handle both). His finest moment is on lead single ""How Deep Is Your Love?""
column2: the galloping
column3: piano-driven tour de force that so many Chicago house revivalists have failed to nail. Here
column4: the rollicking pianos match his devotional pitch
column5: the wilding sax echoing his hallelujahs. Still
column6: Jenner can feel like a man without a country. He doesn't have the pipes for the sustained howling of ""Sail Away""
column7: ""Blue Bird""
column8: or the title track (a misplaced
column9: tedious centerpiece). Nor does the sentiment of soul-sided closer ""It Takes Time to Be a Man"" lend itself to his tonal irreverence and pizzazz. Of all the naughties indie giants thinking hard about domesticity (LCD
column10: Animal Collective
column11: the National)
column12: the Rapture's medium is least primed for the message.

column1: This isn't the Rapture's fault
column2: necessarily. ""House of Jealous Lovers"" is such a totem amid the last decade of indie that it's easy to forget they began as a somewhat (no pun) catholic punk band. In the Grace of Your Love takes two large steps back from ""dance punk."" Nearly a decade after ""Jealous Lovers""
column3: they're a patient
column4: skilled rock band unafraid to look uncool. If they sound extra comfy here it's probably because discomfort pervaded their best work so completely. The band's personal choices-- to abandon rock iconography for smaller
column5: more fulfilling family units-- will be Grace's fate as well: a record without broader narratives
column6: meant for those who grew up with the Rapture
column7:
or want to.

The story of music is largely a story about machines. Just as developments in recording and broadcasting technologies drove 20th-century pop
column2: the Internet and accessible music software are driving something new in the 21st century. Its contours are getting clearer as the first generation to grow up with it comes of age. These musicians are sweeping away the vestiges of generic lineage and regional identity. Unselfconsciously mingling the prefab
column3: the pilfered
column4: and the original
column5: they have none of their elders' qualms about samples and virtual instruments. Many live outside of major culture centers
column6: and thrive online rather than onstage
column7: working with sophisticated editing tools in relative isolation to construct their idiosyncratic visions.

column1: The production duo Elite Gymnastics is a perfect example of this diaspora of younger musicians. James Brooks and Josh Clancy live in Minneapolis
column2: but this tells us little about them-- the Internet is their habitat
column3: not a conduit. Their music is proudly unaffiliated
column4: cobbling together influences that will probably strike older listeners as disparate and younger ones as perfectly concordant. The band's name comes from a song by power electronics pioneers Whitehouse
column5: and noise terrorism is latent in their churning tone and freighted lyrics (which are barely audible but have an evil vibe). The drum breaks come from jungle and hip-hop
column6: the radiantly smeared textures from shoegaze and drone-rock
column7: the samples from video games. They're comfortable mixing Waka Flocka Flame or Ryuichi Sakamoto
column8: chopping Final Fantasy theme music into Balearic house or tending to ghostly
column9: blackened whirrs. According to the band
column10: they used chillwave to Trojan Horse these diverse sounds into complacent earbuds.

column1: Whether or not you buy that line
column2: the only chillwave thing about RUIN 1 is how miscellaneous listening habits dissolve in a solution of over-stimulated memory and prodigious sonic options. There's nothing slackened or balmy about it
column3: no pink Christmas lights or plastic palm trees. It's a rugged
column4: mercurial terrain with heatwaves blasting off it. Jungle drums slice through dark
column5: grainy atmospheres flashing with techno synths (""So Close to Paradise"")
column6: and the only thing separating throbbing Spacemen 3-style rock (""Little Things"") and gentle vintage shoegaze (""Omamori"") is the fizzy electro of ""Here
column7: in Heaven"". The through-line is a pitched
column8: exciting contest between aggressive percussion and emotive melody. The drums are often taut and frantic
column9: but great floating swaths of texture provide a nebulous weight. Besides the frequently inconsequential vocals
column10: the only downside is some murky mixing
column11: with lots of uncompressed clutter. Blurry but lucid is a very tricky sound to nail
column12: and Elite Gymnastics are getting good mileage out of raw energy while they work it out.

column1: That's why RUIN 2-- which basically borrows the idea of chopped and screwed remix discs from rap-- is more than a supplement. It actually improves some of the original mixes by clearing out the dense thatching
column2: letting them breathe. The original version of ""Here
column3: in Heaven"" sounds flat compared to the second
column4: a yawning chasm that evokes the ambient dub of Brock Van Wey. ""Little Things"" also gains distinction with its vocal hung between huge
column5: skeletal pulses and silvery curls of ambiance. But this isn't to say that Elite Gymnastics should only make cored-out dub: ""Minneapolis Belongs to You"" lets some light and air into RUIN 1 with refreshing results. And do you also detect a tacit ""(But Not to Me)"" after that title? If folk music's domain was regional and pop's was global
column6: this music lives beyond the world
column7: where ideas floating through waves and wires take on an independent
column8:
hermetic life.

Shimmering Stars are a trio from British Columbia who certainly have the sounds of the past down pat. The band was founded after its figurehead
column3: guitarist Rory McClure
column4: binged on old performance footage of the Everly Brothers. The swaying melodies and dippy
column5: falsetto-speckled vocals on the band's debut LP
column6: Violent Hearts
column7: are the marks of that influence. But as the title suggests
column8: though
column9: this stuff veers from swooning romanticism. They make pleas for self-medication and express vague emotional confusion throughout. One of the album's most optimistic songs
column10: ""I'm Gonna Try""
column11: begins: ""Walking down the street/ And I wanna kill everyone I meet."" Later
column12: when Shimmering Stars complain about ""Dancing to Music I Hate""
column13: it seems like a comparatively uncomplicated personal problem.

column1: Like a lot of young bands lately
column2: Shimmering Stars' affectations can be easily traced back to Deerhunter
column3: another group that filters experience through sounds and textures plucked from music's past. And if Shimmering Stars don't quite reach the same level of noisy euphoria anywhere on Violent Hearts
column4: the surprising consistency of the record as a whole-- if you're a sucker for one song on here
column5: you're a sucker for all of 'em-- is more than enough to make up for any lack of assertiveness.

column1: As a full-length listening experience
column2: Violent Hearts is a little much-- it runs just under a lean half-hour
column3: but the relative lack of stylistic breadth covered makes a front-to-back spin feel longer. Another issue is the production value; Violent Hearts was self-recorded by McClure in his parents' garage (cheekily referred to in the album's liner notes as ""The Garage Mahal""). While the homespun charm adds some ghostly distance to these songs
column4: it's frustrating to imagine what they would sound like with some better mics (and maybe a real recording studio
column5: too). There's no shortage of emotional bloodshed here
column6:
but any horror geek will tell you that blood just doesn't look as good in black-and-white.

In 1983
column2: at age 16
column3: Kristin Hersh was hit by a car. She landed on her head and lost a lot of blood. When she was recovering in the hospital she started
column4: for the first time
column5: to hear songs-- ""sonic hauntings
column6: as she called them in her 2010 memoir
column7: Rat Girl. Initially humming
column8: mechanical tones
column9: they quickly organized themselves into the familiar grammar of guitar chords
column10: drum beats
column11: basslines
column12: and surreal melodies. She didn't feel quite right until she got them out of her head: ""As soon as I give a song a body in the real world
column13: it stops playing and I breathe a sigh of relief
column14: in precious silence."" She played the chords herself and taught the other parts to her friends Dave Narcizo and Leslie Langston and her stepsister Tanya Donelly
column15: and they became the earliest material recorded by their band
column16: Throwing Muses.

column1: It's a hell of a creation myth
column2: but an easy one to believe: pretty much every song Throwing Muses ever recorded sounds like an exorcism. Though indebted to punk's passion
column3: fury
column4: and occasional goofiness
column5: the Muses were punks only in the spiritual sense of the word: Even by their teens
column6: the original four were all accomplished musicians well-versed enough in music theory to create the weird
column7: irregular chords and erratic time signatures that would become hallmarks of their sound. There was something almost Zen-like about the band's approach: Dump the contents of your busy brain out onto the street
column8: and see what sounds they make on impact. The offspring of hippie idealism (Hersh grew up living on a commune and calling her dad ""Dude"") and post-punk disillusionment
column9: the Muses' rhetoric was not about breaking the rules so much as transcending them completely. In a recent interview
column10: Hersh said of her earliest days in the band
column11: ""I realized that in order to play with the voice you would have if you grew up on a desert island without a radio you need to forget rules.""

column1: Anthology
column2: the first retrospective collection of Throwing Muses material
column3: comes to us on the 25th anniversary of their (first) self-titled record
column4: a stammering
column5: brutal masterpiece that managed to capture both late adolescent angst and feelings well beyond its years. Producer Gil Norton made Hersh's most intimate moments of near-delirium sound epic: like portions of someone's diary blown up to billboard size. Ever wary of commercial appeal
column6: the band said it didn’t want to make anthems
column7: so before its next record its label 4AD passed Norton onto the opening act on the Muses' European tour
column8: fellow Bostonian scenesters Pixies
column9: who were looking for someone to record their next album
column10: Doolittle. Though the histories of the two bands are deeply
column11: famously entwined
column12: the Muses have enjoyed a fate harder to identify than the burden of being hugely influential (even though they were in certain corners: It's almost impossible to imagine the visceral bleats of singers like Corin Tucker or Marissa Paternoster without Kristin Hersh). This moment of reunions
column13: reissues
column14: and boundless nostalgia seems a good time to ask: where did Throwing Muses fit in?

column1: Anthology doesn't quite answer this question. Neither an exhaustive box set nor a greatest-hits collection
column2: Anthology is more like mixtape personally compiled by the band
column3: making a very characteristically Muses argument for the personal over the canonical
column4: for a song’s appeal as something that's more subjective than objective. Though it eschews chronology and omits some of their most popular tracks (there’s only one song on here from 1991’s The Real Ramona-- and it’s the deep cut ""Two Step"")
column5: Anthology is still an accessible entry point to the band’s formidably deep catalogue-- for the already initiated
column6: it’s a relatively taut refresher.

column1: The first disc is 21 tracks culled from major Muses releases
column2: skewing heaviest on their late-80s output-- over half of the material comes from a three-year run that spanned the exquisitely dank Chains Changed EP to the somewhat brighter Hunkpapa in 1989. There are classics (""Fish""
column3: ""Hate My Way""
column4: ""Marriage Tree""
column5: ""Bright Yellow Gun"") and a few surprises (""Mr. Bones""
column6: ""Two Step""
column7: ""Pretty or Not"")
column8: but there’s a remarkable cohesion to the collection’s flow. When the band released its 2003 self-titled album after a long absence
column9: even its biggest fans were kind of astonished at how well the group had been able to capture the sound and spirit of its earliest recordings. Two songs from that ""reunion"" album made the cut here: I'd bet anything that Anthology listeners coming to the band for the first time wouldn't be able to pick them out of the bunch without peeking at the liner notes.

column1: Naturally
column2: the B-sides and rarities disc is spottier-- I could live comfortably in a world without the tepid version of ""Amazing Grace"" or the instrumental ""Manic Depression""
column3: which could pass for the interstitial music on an old Ken Griffey baseball video game. But once you get to the material from the Firepile EPs
column4: it offers a killer middle stretch: ""Snailhead"" (featuring one of the most blistering Hersh vocals on the whole collection) segues into the smoldering slow-burner ""City of the Dead"". I’ve actually found myself spinning Disc 2 more than Disc 1
column5: probably just because most of the material is fresher to my ears. It's not the most essential entry in their discography
column6: but it's solid.

column1: To some people
column2: the word Anthology might promise something bigger or more definitive than what the Muses have given us here
column3: but most fans will appreciate the personal flourishes all over this collection (especially Hersh's always poetic liner notes). Anthology isn't exactly a totemic bookend to Throwing Muses' long and lively career
column4: but as the band’s 2003 record and upcoming reunion tour suggest
column5:
maybe there’s still too much life in them for a definitive ending.

Bands that find their voice quickly are the lucky ones. Of course
column4: you run a greater risk of repeating yourself in the future
column5: but by and large the hardest part is already out of the way. HTRK (pronounced ""Hate Rock"") aren't what you would normally consider lucky
column6: both professionally and personally. Formed in 2003
column7: the trio's no wave-leaning art noise found them playing alongside deities like Alan Vega and Lydia Lunch. In 2009
column8: their debut LP
column9: Marry Me Tonight (co-produced by ex-Birthday Party member Roland S. Howard)
column10: landed them a few high-profile opening slots for the likes of Yeah Yeah Yeahs and Liars.

column1: And it made sense: Marry Me is doomy and romantically languid
column2: with a pop-smart crispness that spoke of potentially good things to come. But when bassist Sean Stewart took his own life in March of last year
column3: vocalist Jonnine Standish and guitarist Nigel Yang were  left to pick up the pieces and push forward with their second full length
column4: <i>Work (work
column5: work). While dark and otherworldly
column6: much of Work doesn't feel like it has much to do with death
column7: but everything to do with sex. But they've shifted their sound
column8: and in the current climate they come over as zeitgeist chasers without much character.

column1: The music of the past year or so has been hot for dark and moody sounds
column2: from the fleeting pulses of the witch house craze to the dread-stoked
column3: depressive underpinnings that pervade various electronic and R&B offshoots. HTRK also seem to have noticed
column4: inflecting their sound with creepy
column5: crawling signifiers that feel currently cool or just past their expiration date. The crucial distinction is that HTRK have a noticeably minimal sound
column6: funneling  their groaning and clanking through no wave and coldwave instead of the viscous twitch-and-bounce of witch house proper (though the drum  programming suggests the Three 6 Mafia presets came stock) or the lurid
column7: lukewarm comeliness of jj or the xx (though both of these artists are good for a name-check at just about any moment on the album).

column1: So needless to say
column2: Work is heavy on atmosphere
column3: and while  the attention paid to those aforementioned post punk totems could have set them apart (at times it feels as if HTRK could pull off a lounge-y  mix-up of Sade and Suicide)
column4: there simply isn't enough to sink your teeth into. Occasionally constructed of some interesting parts (the processional G-funk organ squiggles on single ""Eat Yr Heart""
column5: the pressure-crunched submarine hull moans of ""Slo Glo"")
column6: nothing seems properly supported. The music feels unappetizingly narcotized and drab
column7: not to mention uncomfortably claustrophobic despite all of the aimless sprawling and spreading the music does. The pair seems to have been so focused on creating a mood that they forgot to attach any songs along the way.

column1: Perhaps most anesthetizing of all is Standish
column2: whose coquettish
column3: layered vocals make all the chic disaffection feel even more purposefully (and problematically) clouded. There's nothing especially bad here
column4: but once the smoke clears from their bland
column5: bassed-out ambiance
column6:
HTRK are another band without a sound to call their own.

column8: or come off like a display of pure skill with little heart behind it. But Stephen ""Thundercat"" Bruner seems more interested in using his well-honed chops to turn out sunny (if bogglingly detailed) ear-candy than he is in crafting big statements (despite the album's portentous title).

column1: Co-produced with Brainfeeder major domo (and Thundercat pal) Flying Lotus
column2: Apocalypse has the digital sheen of many FlyLo productions. But Bruner’s experience as an in-demand rock and soul bassist gives the album a live band's freedom of movement
column3: one that's closer to the fusion records that reared him than the sequenced rhythms that have come to define dance music
column4: even at its most out-there. After a silly and nostalgia-inducing sample from the 1980s cartoon that gave Bruner his pseudonym
column5: ""Daylight"" is the album's true opener
column6: another in Brainfeeder’s line of shouldn't-work-but-does experimental beat confections. It merges the bustling energy of 21st-century left-field electronic music (crunchy mutant techno rhythms
column7: a mix saturated with whimsical sound effects) with the floating-on-a-cloud airiness of 1970s soul (vaporous falsetto vocals
column8: bright-but-wistful melodies). It really does feel like a long lost Mouse on Mars track
column9: as if that most playful of German electronic acts had called up a member of the Soulquarians camp at the same time that Common decided to collaborate with Stereolab.

column1: That's all a bit of bait-and-switch
column2: though. There's no doubt plenty of Brainfeeder's psychedelic and IDM-like attention to sonic detail at various points on Apocalypse
column3: along with nods to the fractured rhythms of London's broken beat scene and the earlier West Coast post-rap experimentation of Stones Throw. But like the latter L.A. pioneers
column4: Thundercat takes avant electronic music's futuristic sound-sculpting and reconnects it with the history of African-American pop. He's particularly smitten with that moment in the 70s when soul music got looser and smoother and more electronic
column5: and electric jazz started taming the wildness of improvisation with the slickness and structure of the pop song. Bruner's not beholden to the days of fusion past
column6: of course. He takes detours into smoothly gliding 80s synth-funk (""Walkin'"") and queasy prog ambience (""Mystery Machine [The Golden Age of Apocalypse]""). But still
column7: know that this is more of a jazz album than an electronic music album
column8: and more of a soul album than either.

column1: And it's on the third track
column2: ""Fleer Ultra""
column3: that Bruner's true loves finally leaps to the fore
column4: because that's the first time the bass really goes bananas. Bruner is undoubtedly what was once called a ""musician's musician
column5: a practice-space hound who reveres good playing. He's unashamed of his talent
column6: but he also knows it's better put to use making hooks. And throughout Apocalypse it's Bruner’s exceptionally fluid bass work that ties together the new millennium computer madness and the cuts that feel like they could have been laid down in the analog days of 1974. Even the drowsiest songs here pop with super-animated basslines. His already justly lauded cover of George Duke’s ""For Love I Come"" turns the tempo of the original down a few notches
column7: letting most the of song play out as an amorphous but silky swirl of electric keyboard and his echo-warped voice-- he makes sure to bring out those bass chops for the climax. As a singer
column8: Bruner is much better than he has to be
column9: considering his musical inventiveness is already plenty attention-grabbing
column10: but while his fluttery
column11: heartsick vocals lend Apocalypse much of its charm and memorability
column12: it's those basslines that are the real earworms.

column1: So this isn't really a song album
column2: at least not in the sense that it’ll give rock or even R&B fans looking for verse-chorus-verse much to chew on. As with FlyLo
column3: it's still best to approach Apocalypse as instrumental head-trip
column4: albeit one that's occasionally got tunes you can hum. But like his fusion heroes
column5: Bruner wants it all: the future shock of electronics
column6: the tightly edited pleasures of pop
column7: the love-sick opulence of quiet-storm soul
column8: and the show-stopper instrumental breaks of jazz. The fact that he's mostly pulled it off
column9: with a record that's serious in intent while playful in execution
column10:
is pretty astounding.

Escher quality to irreverence for music that was already irreverently dramatic. But it is still a fresh enough aesthetic move to feel novel now

column9: it's about the dancefloor as an escape
column10: while on another
column11:
it winks at the group's time travels.

column3: god
column4: love

column1: In an era when the surfeit of garage-rock bands need to push personality and melody harder than ever

column10:
the Boys' retrograde sneer and strut proves a bit too safe and samey.

column12: ""Police Station"")
column13: I'm With You is simply a continuously futile pursuit to figure out what the fuck he's actually talking about.

column1: On ""Factory of Faith""
column2: spiritual intransigence is described as such: ""All my life
column3: I was swingin' for the fence/ Always lookin' for the triple/ Never playing good defense."" Then
column4: before you know it
column5: he's quoting Dirk Diggler (""feast on this""). He falls in love with a stripper on ""Look Around""
column6: explaining ""Hustle here/ Hustle there/ Hustle me bitch and you best beware/ It's emotional/ And I told you so."" (This is before Fayetteville-- North Carolina? Arkansas?-- gets a shout out… because it rhymes with ""say it will."") The tricky funk rhythm of ""Ethiopia"" stoically withstands Kiedis singing a scat version of ""Old McDonald Had a Farm""
column7: while on ""Even You Brutus?"" he yawps like David Byrne and courts a young lady by namedropping Steve Miller and Stevie Wonder in the span of fifteen seconds.

column1: Thing is
column2: he can shut off that Funky Monk mode in time for the choruses
column3: and if I'm With You proves anything for the Peppers
column4: it's that a one-step solution to making this a better
column5: even enjoyable record is to cut out the verses entirely. Sounds like a good enough idea
column6: but it'd only make it more obvious that they've been writing minor variations of the same exact (admittedly effective) chorus for the past decade: four repeating chords boxing in Kiedis' maxed-out soul croon as Flea and Chad Smith dutifully swing
column7: wondering when they'll finally have a chance to let loose. (When they do during the frenetic coda of ""Brendan's Death Song""
column8: it's a damn revelation.)

column1: Some of us will be making “Sir Psycho Sexy” jokes to our grave
column2: but many still have a soft spot for the wild abandon of Blood Sugar Sex Magik because it found space for rock songs that rocked
column3: funk songs that were funky
column4: and ballads that were truly affecting. But they've become so stuck in their Peppers-Mk-II ways that 2006's Stadium Arcadium turned out to be possibly the least adventurous double album ever
column5: and I'm With You does even less to pursue sonic diversity. Much of the blame lies with Rick Rubin: As with Stadium and 2002's By the Way
column6: he produces I'm With You entirely without nuance or dynamics. Whether it's the midtempo acoustic ballads (""Brendan's Death Song"")
column7: the midtempo piano masher (""Happiness Loves Company"")
column8: or the midtempo rockers (nearly everything else)
column9: they're all equally loud and flat. As a result
column10: the sequencing of the 14 tracks feels arbitrary
column11: the hour-long runtime intentionally superfluous: It feels as if even they don't think anyone will play this in its intended order after the first listen.

column1: As far as arena-dominating radio rock goes

column4: the Minutemen
column5: and George Clinton through them. And occasionally
column6: the punk-funk still rings true: I'd love to see an intrepid mashup junkie lay Luke Jenner's vocals from In the Grace of Your Love over these instrumentals and vice versa. After all
column7: Flea sounded great in Thom Yorke's Atoms For Peace project while actually playing more slap-bass than he does here

column9: I'm With You's hip thrusts and gyrations simply go through the motions
column10: the work of a band with all kinds of capital to blow but no incentive to do anything differently. After all
column11:
it's a Red Hot Chili Peppers album.

What sets The World Is Just a Shape to Fill the Night apart from a lot of what gets called ""folk"" these days is that it is fiercely unsentimental. But if you gaze back a little further
column2: Jesse Lortz's obsession with pistols
column3: poisons
column4: drownings
column5: and all-consuming spiritual darkness is part of a great tradition; the Anthology of American Folk Music has a notoriously high body count. Even though nobody dies during The Night
column6: it flickers with a constant barrage of unsettling images: knives being sharpened on hearts
column7: blood mixing with saliva mid-kiss
column8: and an address to a lover that begins
column9: ""You lifted up your skirt and took a piss right in the street/ You shook it off your thigh and your eyes said
column10: 'I know you're watching.'"" And that's the love song on the record.

column1: None of this macabre humor should come as a huge surprise to those familiar with Lortz's old band the Dutchess and the Duke-- especially if you've seen the video for ""Mary""
column2: at the end of which he and bandmate Kimberly Morrison become rather gleeful-looking cannibals. After the Seattle duo's 2010 break-up
column3: Lortz's first solo effort under the name Case Studies is unremittingly bleak. As far as contemporary kindred spirits go
column4: Lortz's human-sized expressions of cosmic loneliness call to mind Bill Callahan's recent Apocalypse
column5: while his penchant for raw
column6: naturalistic guitar tones evoke the Tallest Man on Earth. Lortz is blessed with neither Callahan's God-sized baritone nor Kristian Matsson's ambulance siren bleat
column7: but what he lacks in an immediately identifiable vocal signature he makes up for with the distinctness of his sparse
column8: evocative songwriting.

column1: Right from the start
column2: The Night is a portrait of people's fumbles toward connection. (Spoiler
column3: though all the minor chords provide some clues: they are often totally futile.) Quietly haunting opener ""From the Blade of My Love"" begins with an image of Lortz awake and restless while the girl beside him sleeps contentedly-- the first suggestion of the insurmountable chasm that's sprung up between them. Things go from bad to worse on the terrific post-break-up ballad ""My Silver Hand""
column4: on which he confesses
column5: ""I'd like to still be in your bed/ But I would settle for your life instead
column6: with the shattering plaintiveness of somebody who knows that even the lesser of those two things probably won't happen. Beneath Lortz's pleas
column7: a backing female vocalist provides tepid consolation with a few ""la-la-la""s
column8: but she even sounds chillingly distant
column9: as though she's singing from another room.

column1: The World is Just a Shape to Fill the Night is preoccupied with both the surface of things and the ugly disorder that lurks beneath them. On ""From the Blade of My Love""
column2: the smoothness of his lover's skin belies the ""war inside raging
column3: while the electric twang of ""Lies"" spells out a lengthy itemized list of things you're better off never bothering to ask your lover (""How many days will I love you?"" ""Will I ever hurt you again?"") because the truth deep down ""will only make you cry."" But believe it or not
column4: there's respite-- of sorts. After the slight lag of ""California Ghost Story""
column5: the closer ""The Day We Met""-- a starkly recorded guitar and vocal track-- is  a dark and strangely tender love story between two outsiders that ends with this pontification: ""It's the way of the world/ People come
column6: people go/ People mark each other up and sometimes get to love awhile."" Which
column7: coming off the weighty darkness of the previous 10 tracks
column8: doesn't sound like such a bad fate after all.

column1: The Night was recorded by Greg Ashley of the psych rock band Gris Gris
column2: and he and Lortz are certainly not the first 21st-century folkies who have tried to conjure the ghosts of Harry Smith's America. But the textured and purposefully naturalistic production on The World Is Just a Shape to Fill the Night never feels like an affect; it's a fitting sonic reinforcement for the record's musings on detachment
column3: distance and isolation. The Night is a record uncomfortable with all the trappings of the corporeal world-- time
column4: words
column5: its own skin-- and occasionally
column6: improbably
column7:
it actually breaks free of them all.
