Tucked into some remote woods in Georgia
column2: Rachel and Grant Evans have created a kind of mom-and-pop drone factory. Between their duo Quiet Evenings
column3: Grant's Nova Scotian Arms
column4: and Rachel's Motion Sickness of Time Travel
column5: they've spun reams of drone
column6: mostly on small-run cassettes and CD-Rs. Of the three projects
column7: MSOTT leans most toward song-like structures.

column1: Though her work is often meditative and abstract
column2: filled with busy synths and widescreen reverb
column3: Evans has a knack for shaping subtle rhythms
column4: slow crescendos
column5: and the wordless phrasings of her own voice. That voice is more prominent than ever before on Luminaries & Synastry
column6: the best MSOTT effort to date. It's not quite right to say Evans' singing is the center of these songs-- each piece is too unified to let any element dominate. But there's something uncanny about the way her voice melts with her drifting tones
column7: as if it's both responding to the music and spawning it. (That effect is mirrored in the fluid visual montages Evans made for ""Day Glow"" and ""Late Day Sun Silhouettes""). Such circular motion produces the feel of a sonic Möbius strip
column8: with each song looping in on itself until time seems to stand still.

column1: This illusion of timelessness might suggest that the name Motion Sickness of Time Travel (taken from William Burroughs' novel The Soft Machine) is inappropriate
column2: but in fact it's quite apt. Though her soothing atmospheres are never exactly queasy
column3: Evans' way of making time elastic-- unpredictably stretching and shrinking it-- produces a kind of mesmerizing disorientation. Often it feels like she's re-enacting the fuzzy
column4: time-defying boundary between consciousness and sleep: Drift into her music
column5: and you might feel like you’re drowsily blinking to make out figures in the dark
column6: or waking from a nap-long dream that seemed to last a day.

column1: Which might be why
column2: despite being relatively short for drone pieces
column3: the songs on Luminaries & Synastry feel as long and developed as those of any previous MSOTT work. So a track like ""Ascendant""
column4: with its misty tones that cast even dewier shadows
column5: can come as close to infinity in six minutes as
column6: say
column7: Spacemen 3's epic ""An Evening of Contemporary Sitar Music"" can in 45. It might seem like a stretch to place MSOTT in such lofty company so soon
column8:
but Luminaries & Synastry sounds ready and willing to stand the test of timelessness Evans made for it.

Cosmin Nicolae committed what for many young electronic producers is a cardinal sin: He changed. Quite a bit
column2: actually: his name (from TRG to Cosmin TRG)
column3: his home base (from Romania to Berlin)
column4: his label(s)
column5: and most notably
column6: his sound. Since 2007
column7: his run of singles for A-list labels like Hessle Audio
column8: Hotflush
column9: Tempa
column10: and Rush Hour has made it impossible to pin him to a specific scene or style. This isn't a sin in and of itself
column11: but amidst the shifting sands of electronic music
column12: it's helpful to have reference points: ""Aphex Twin makes IDM"" is easy to remember
column13: and even if it's only partly true
column14: it's simpler to sort the details out later. Cosmin's constant shapeshifting has made it difficult to identify him with a scene or sound
column15: and his career has seemed diffuse as a result.

column1: The first time I heard Nicolae's debut full-length
column2: Simulat
column3: I gave myself a signpost: dubstep. Nicolae's label history warranted the nonchalant tagging
column4: and
column5: moreover
column6: the album's thickly dug bass grooves were what stuck with me. Nicolae
column7: perpetually in motion
column8: is exactly the type of artist who makes these quick-hit bindings unwise. Simulat certainly borrows the rich
column9: tonal bass of dubstep-- as well as its tendency to drift off when not explicitly pushing forward-- but its grooves are more straightforward
column10: shuffling instead of circling
column11: the work of an artist who has internalized the narratives of modern dance without bending to them. Nicolae instead looks to the recent history of Berlin techno-- Marcel Dettmann and Ben Klock-- and further back to Detroit-- Robert Hood and especially Richie Hawtin-- for Simulat's roadmap.

column1: What this means: linear grooves
column2: prickly synth arpeggios
column3: and sweeping strings/organs or fake-strings/fake-organs. Never a producer of marathon tracks
column4: Nicolae is smart to keep his compositions in the manageable 4-to-5-minute range: Simulat clocks in at a lean
column5: replayable 47 minutes. He stitches it together with moments of meditation and calm
column6: his keyboards seeping through the floorboards to inhabit ghostlier environs and tempos.  I like tracks like ""Want You to Be"" and ""Form Over Function"" most: They offer easy-to-tap rhythms and mallet-simple keyboard thwacks
column7: manageable menace that makes me want to bob and weave in my headphones instead of sinking into them. The album's lead single ""Fizic"" gallops along on the type of UFO-on-cruise-control futurism Juan Atkins pioneered.

column1: Nicolae's tracks don't evolve
column2: so much; they arrive
column3: mature quickly
column4: and exit. Simulat is an album concerned with suggested mood instead of sustained groove
column5: but it uses the building blocks of rhythm-- four-on-the-floor drum kicks
column6: bass pulses-- to construct those moods. At his best Nicolae offers the dystopic vistas of techno with an off-center hint of warmth: I've never really wanted to dance to a Plastikman track
column7:
but I find it hard to sit still during ""Ritmat""'s tricky home-appliance palpitations. This distinguishes Simulat from a legion of too-serious Berlin techno stalwarts and renders snap judgments about Nicolae's present-- or future-- silly.

I remember the year 2000. I remember how we called it Y2K
column4: which sounds more like the name of a virus than a year
column5: like something that might make you rethink where you get your meats and produce. I remember a global panic about data that might be lost on computers programmed to interpret years as only two digits instead of four. When we hit 2000
column6: they would just read ""00
column7: as if God's finger slipped on the reset button. Ironically (and of course)
column8: it was all our fault. But then January 1
column9: 2000 came
column10: and I remember it being like every other day. Some slot machines at a racetrack in Delaware stopped working
column11: and a little after midnight
column12: an alarm at a nuclear power plant in Onagawa
column13: Japan went off in the dark.

column1: I remember how in 1999 Grandaddy were like a lot of other decent underdog indie bands that I had an indefensible soft spot for: mopey and withdrawn
column2: with a few mixtape-worthy songs. Then they released The Sophtware Slump in early 2000
column3: and all of a sudden they sounded like they had a particular perspective
column4: a particular substance. Their gift is that they still managed to sound insubstantial. The sadness that sounded like passivity on 1997's Under the Western Freeway turned into philosophy on The Sophtware Slump: nonchalance as a way of isolating yourself from what bothers you. Not that The Sophtware Slump is in any way major-- being major is the work of artistes
column5: and part of Grandaddy's appeal was that they just seemed like low-key guys from central California tooling around in the basement.

column1: Most of the album sounds like countryish Neil Young songs coated in synthesizer gloss-- a style that borrows a little of Young's earthy tenderness
column2: a little of Pavement's studied indifference
column3: and a little of the switched-on melancholy of an ELO ballad. They sang about national forests filled with broken appliances and robot friends who woke up drunk in parks. The text on the cover of the CD booklet was spelled out in letters from an old PC keyboard over a grassy meadow with mountains in the background. Flip through to the last page
column4: and you'll see a cowboy walking into the sunset with a Casio under his arm.

column1: Basically
column2: The Sophtware Slump is the point where the deflated myth of the American West met the deflated myth of technological salvation. The fear isn't that computers would destroy us
column3: it's that we'd end up living in a futuristic world but still have the same old problems. It's like how David Bowie released ""Space Oddity"" 10 days before Neil Armstrong walked on the moon: Somehow
column4: he knew people would get lonely up there
column5: because people get lonely no matter where they go. If Radiohead captured a feeling of pre-millenial tension
column6: The Sophtware Slump captured the feeling of disappointment that came afterward-- the feeling that life was going to be more or less the same as it had been
column7: only now we'd have to live with the fact that we once thought it'd be so different: the feeling of January 2

column1: At the time
column2: Grandaddy weren't the only band that played sparkly
column3: cinematic indie music: Mercury Rev's Deserter's Songs had come out in 1998
column4: and the Flaming Lips' The Soft Bulletin came out in 1999. The difference is in both scale and character: Unlike the Flaming Lips or Mercury Rev
column5: Grandaddy were a five-person band that sounded like five people playing together in a room
column6: not five people using the studio to make the sound of a hundred. Even when they use synthesizers to replicate orchestral instruments
column7: it has a miniaturistic quality
column8: like the grandeur of early Hollywood trapped inside a snowglobe.

column1: Lyrically
column2: the album is just as contained. Instead of singing about the grand and tearful breakup between man and nature
column3: Jason Lytle sings about wanting to lie down and sleep under a single tree. Fluffy
column4: abstract lyrics like
column5: ""I dream at night of going home some day
column6: are grounded by concrete ones: ""Tire scraps on federal roads look like crash-landed crows
column7: a metaphor that uses one tactile
column8: breakable thing to describe another.

column1: Does the album sound quaint now? Sure. It sounded quaint then
column2: too. Grandaddy's image-- crunchy guys with trucker hats and beards-- was instantly rustic. Their sound was irrelevant. Blowing minds and challenging conventions takes hard work and ego
column3: and Grandaddy never seemed like they had a real capacity for either. But being as essentially easygoing as they are is also what makes all the thematic material here so approachable
column4: if you buy into it at all: Most of the time
column5: it just doesn't sound like they're trying to prove a point-- a sense of modesty that made them feel more seductive and appealing to me than artists who showed up with grand statement in hand.

column1: It's funny to me that this album is being given the deluxe reissue treatment only 10 years after first being released
column2: but I guess nostalgia is kicking in sooner these days. Deserter's Songs was reissued recently too
column3: along with records by Sebadoh and Archers of Loaf-- records that don't feel like they were gone all that long. The sound is clearer and better delineated here than it was on the initial release
column4: and the bonus material-- which includes demos and a couple of EPs released around the same time-- is interesting to listen to once or twice but never gives me the feeling that they could've made The Sophtware Slump any more focused and consistent than it is.

column1: And sad
column2: too. What a sad
column3: sad album. There's not a happy song on it
column4: really. But there's no angst or despair either
column5: because angst and despair are exhausting emotions. Most of the time
column6: Lytle sounds like the archetypal 90s slacker: observant
column7: slow-moving
column8: dulled by a suburban kind of pain he can't shake. Beck in 1994
column9: without panache or a flair for Art. Beck comes up once
column10: actually
column11: in ""Jed's Other Poem (Beautiful Ground)""
column12: a lyric supposedly written by their robot friend
column13: Jed: ""I try to sing it funny like Beck/ But it's bringin' me down."" Cheer up: It didn't get better
column14: but it didn't get much worse
column15:
either.

Last King 2: God's Machine bears an unfortunately portentous title for what it delivers: essentially
column3: it's a mixed grab bag of Big K.R.I.T.'s various guest spots over the last year

column1: On ""The Big Payback""

The name doesn't jibe --  there's nothing particularly pharaonic about his presence-- but  the touch of self-mythology  is a reminder of the fascinating transition  K.R.I.T. is undergoing. Over the past year or so
column3: he has been slowly  embracing his role as the savior of the conscious-rap underground. It  shows signs of suiting him nicely

column5: generic country-rap-tune bangers about candy paint and mentions of  pimping split time awkwardly with powerful
column6: impassioned treatises like  ""Another Naive Individual Glorifying Greed and Encouraging Racism"". The  impression was of an artist stranded in uncertainly between the UGK  revivalism he started with and the early-era Common figure he might become. A  more combustible on-record personality might be able to fuse  these strands

column9: low-key guy

which will hopefully clear up in time for Live From the Underground's main event.

column3: the anticon. collective emerged as a unique label dedicated to bursting the boundaries of what could be reasonably considered hip hop: Battle freestyles reconstructed as abstruse beat poetry
column4: hip hop production smeared into ambient drone
column5: rap cadences and phrasings bent to indie folk ends. They were leaders with
column6: at first
column7: few followers. But as anticon.'s own recombinant styles began to calcify-- as Why? became more of a straightforward indie rock band
column8: say

column10: hyper-syllabic ass-- the label began to seem less like leaders and more like merely idiosyncratic outliers.

column1: Even as one of anticon.'s founding members
column2: Alias has always maintained a decidedly low profile on the adventurous label: just a guy and his drum machines holed up in the home studio in Maine. And that's not only compared to big personality MCs like Doseone or Why?'s Yoni Wolf
column3: but even to other in-house producers
column4: such as the relatively flash
column5: TV Carnage-abetted analog screwball Tobacco. Alias seems to relish a certain hermitic anonymity-- right down to the blank-faced moniker-- and it's an attitude reflected in his beats: moody
column6: introspective tracks whose athletic drumming and melancholy melodies make for heavy head-nodders but that can begin to feel a bit faceless.

column2: and the change of course feels less like a visionary renewal than it does a well-played catch-up. From the first beat drop

column5: bass hits low and leaves space in its wake

column1: Deeper into the album
column2: amidst the adaptation
column3: Alias teases out some of his typically thick grooves and understated but staying melodies-- culminating with the one-two combination of the in-the-pocket acoustic drum break that lights up the latter half of ""Dahorses"" and gives way to the dreamy ""la-di-da"" vocal echoes of ""Lady Lambin'"". Elsewhere
column4: and to lesser effect

column6: monosyllabic nasal wail to the chunky beat routine of ""Boom Boom Boom""
column7: while Pierson plays keys and sings lead on the bloodless R&B drift of ""Talk in Technicolor"".

column1: So
column2: no

Recently

column5: Jay-Z
column6: Patrick Wolf
column7: Ryan Adams
column8: and on and on)
column9: this one really does feel permanent
column10: which is tragic. Campbell has had one of those impossible careers that sound more like the stuff of outrageous fiction than rock biography: An Arkansas native and music prodigy of sorts
column11: he moved to L.A. and played in a band called the Champs (Tequila!) and worked as a member of the infamous Wrecking Crew
column12: a group of studio musicians who backed Elvis Presley and Simon & Garfunkel and played on Phil Spector's infamous wall-of-sound recordings. That's him laying down licks on Pet Sounds
column13: while he was a touring Beach Boy. In the late 1960s and throughout the 1970s
column14: he scored huge hits with ""Wichita Lineman"" and ""By the Time I Get to Phoenix"" (both by Jimmy Webb
column15: long overdue for a retrospective). Often dismissed as a practitioner of slick country-pop
column16: he favored florid strings
column17: stately vocals
column18: and an interpretive approach most likely informed by his experience as a sideman. ""Rhinestone Cowboy"" pretty much sums up the contradictions of his music
column19: which is simultaneously country but urbane

column1: Perhaps because he was a Nashville outsider but not a Nashville outlaw
column2: Ghost on the Canvas sidesteps all the current conventions of country farewell albums
column3: a growing subgenre that found its apotheosis in Johnny Cash's later recordings and Kris Kristofferson's recent pair of affairs-settling records. This is no tastefully solemn acoustic affair
column4: with a hushed tone communicating a kind of easy-read mortal gravity. Instead
column5: Campbell conveys a certain nostalgia for that defining sound of his prime-- or at least a nostalgia for a time when that sound was popular. ""It's Your Amazing Grace"" and ""A Thousand Lifetimes"" deploy the same tricks he's been using for decades-- those ornate string arrangements and prominent guitar themes that recall fellow Wrecking Crew member Jack Nitzsche-- but they sound fresh on these tracks
column6: even at times adventurous. The short
column7: instrumental interstitials are distracting as Campbell tries to cover every corner of his history
column8: but the the presence of Billy Corgan
column9: Cheap Trick's Rick Nielsen
column10: and all the Dandy Warhols on Ghost suggests that the influence of this style has been
column11: at the very least
column12: broad.

column1: Campbell is still taking stock of his life and career (""Sometimes I get confused
column2: Lord/ My past gets in my way"")
column3: and that sounds odd only because it's not something he has not historically been inclined to do: He's more renowned as a sensitive vocalist than as a confessional songwriter. So songs like ""A Better Place"" and ""There's No Me… Without You""
column4: both co-penned with producer Julian Raymond
column5: sound perhaps a bit too direct for Campbell
column6: although his voice remains strong enough that he doesn't need your pity to put these songs across
column7: no matter how silly some of their sentiments. Anchoring Ghost is a handful of covers that are perhaps only slightly less adventurous than those on his 2008 album
column8: Meet Glen Campbell. The title track and ""Any Trouble"" are lesser Westerberg
column9: but they fit the album's theme all too well. Likewise
column10: ""Hold on Hope"" is an obvious GBV choice (what
column11: you expected ""Tractor Rape Chain""?)
column12: but Campbell owns its schmaltz as well as its simple optimism
column13: suggesting that Bob Pollard wrote the line ""there hides the cowboy"" with Campbell in mind. Ghost is nowhere near his best
column14: most consistent
column15: or most durable album
column16: but that's ultimately not even the right way to measure its modest accomplishment. Instead
column17: it's a surprisingly upbeat retirement album
column18:
one that never stoops to self-pity and very modestly reminds you of past triumphs.

Like a sleepless night in an intemperate climate
column3: Sun Araw's undulating edgeless psychmares stick to your clothes and leave chemtrails in your periphery. Ancient Romans
column4: SoCal seeker Cameron Stallones' latest LP  under the Sun Araw name
column5: is another fever dream of dub-mottled organ  grind and guitar squiggle
column6: at once elemental and futuristic. Romans proves less departure from than refinement of his 2010 breakout On Patrol
column7: a primordially textured slow-going ooze not unlike Excepter doing Earth covers over a skipping disc of Agharta. On Romans
column8: Stallones continues rendering colossal structures in sound
column9: dialing the scale of its predecessor back ever-so-slightly while retaining both its massive scope and its wide-eyed searcher's gaze.

column1: With a touch more space between its sinewy guitars
column2: warbly keyboards
column3: and omnitextured bass thump
column4: Romans doesn't immediately inspire the same awe the impossibly grandiose
column5: oppressively humid On Patrol did. Those slowly mutating tunes
column6: even when they tipped in at a quarter-hour
column7: felt almost  immaculately composed
column8: each craggy instrument and edge-of-perception  toneshift perched against the others just so. Though all of Stallones'  music is built around improv
column9: Romans feels a mite looser
column10: more  free-flowing than its predecessor
column11: its individual movements less  choreographed
column12: its overall mood a bit more relaxed. Yet Stallones maintains  his incredible compositional economy and precision; with all its moving  parts
column13: Ancient Romans can sound a bit haphazard at first
column14: but each gurgle and whirr  works in brilliant tandem
column15: and one more element could tip any of its scales. Romans' sandstorm soundscapes and Afrobeat-indebted underwater funk are panoramic
column16: deliriously detailed visions beamed in from some untapped back-of-the-mind vista.

column1: Romans begins slowly
column2: the reedy ""Lucretius"" rolling out like a fog.  ""Crown Shell"" matches its dubby bass nausea to flittery desert guitar
column3: with Stallones imparting illegible wisdom over top. What vocals do pop up on Ancient Romans are used to enormous effect; whether it's conspiratorial chants of indoctrination or chants of earthen ecstasy
column4: Stallones' populating of his sound world with these indecipherable  characters leaves them feeling at once more alien and more habitable.  You can almost make out the very edges of pop song structure in the  warped Zapp-and-Fela bootleg of ""Crown Shell"" and the snaky
column5: sunbaked  gospel ""Lute and Lyre""; though Stallones' epic-length music resists  hurry
column6: it doesn't skimp on form
column7: and even with Romans' somewhat looser feel
column8: he never lets his instrumental wandering take him too far from the compositions.

column1: It ends with ""Impluvium""
column2: which flips the trance-like qualities of  Araw's eyelid-movie music into something else entirely. Easily the  danciest track in Araw's arsenal
column3: ""Impluvium"" knocks
column4: riding a  chant-laden
column5: clanky 4/4 groove off into some equatorial sunset. Up against the rest of Romans' slowmo dub-sludge
column6: a track like  ""Impluvium"" could well be an overreach
column7: but Stallones' vision for Sun  Araw is both so carefully controlled and so wide-- and ""Impluvium""
column8: like  everything that precedes it
column9: so roughshod and naturalistic-- the tune becomes like an ideal disembarking point for Romans' steamy night-on-the-river. It's one of Stallones' finest moments to date
column10: yet another reminder that there are few people making music either this all-encompassing or this enveloping. The mighty On Patrol brought together many of the disparate strands in Stallones' work (both as Sun Araw and his stellar Magic Lantern) into a dazzling whole
column11: and though Romans' textures are grittier and its gaze more inward
column12: the ground it surveys isn't too far afield from that of its predecessor. But if Romans is something of a lateral move where innovation's concerned
column13: it's by no  means a step down in quality. In the last couple years
column14:
Stallones continues to carve out what feels like uncharted territory; hard to blame him for wanting to survey the scenery a little while longer.

A lot of rappers show a lot of love for Lil Wayne on his new album. ""Thanks for giving us a whole 'nother classic with Tha Carter IV
column4: huffs Busta Rhymes. ""It's important that you are more than welcome to Tha Carter IV
column5: and y'all enjoy it

column8: eight months for that pistol/ But at least they had some bad bitches workin' in that shit hole."" The man born Dwayne Carter never needed to be propped up like this before. During his Untouchable Era-- from the December 2005 release of Tha Carter II through 2008's Tha Carter III
column9: with several classic mixtapes in between-- Wayne was The Best Rapper Alive because he said he was
column10: and then rhymed his brain off to prove it. He doesn't claim that world-beating title once on Tha Carter IV. And no one else claims it for him.

column1: We accepted last year's duo of disappointments-- the aggravated rock turn Rebirth and the unfocused stop-gap collection I Am Not a Human Being-- because they were mere anomalies or appetizers. This summer's Sorry 4 the Wait mixtape was passable
column2: but slight compared to previous off-label bounties like Dedication 2
column3: Da Drought 3
column4: or No Ceilings. So while there hasn't been much recorded evidence to support Wayne's hip-hop supremacy over the last three years

column1: Almost everything about Wayne is relaxed
column2: regurgitated
column3: or regressing here. Most noticeable is his slowed-down flow
column4: perhaps a capitulation to the booming arenas he now plays to regularly
column5: where intelligibility often trumps quick wit. But whereas the only permanent aspect of Wayne's cadence used to be its shiftiness
column6: his delivery has slackened
column7: severely deadening his ferociousness in the process. The falloff is made more apparent by a couple of guest shots from two of rap's most exuberant fast talkers

column1: On ""Interlude""
column2: Tech N9ne and an oddly uncredited André 3000 reel off two of the album's best verses
column3: perfectly setting up its star for a clean-up finale. But Wayne never shows on that track
column4: or the star-studded ""Outro""
column5: as if he'd rather play curator than be the focus of some of the highlights on his own album. His trepidation is understandable considering how Drake and Rick Ross easily overshadow him on recent singles ""She Will"" and ""John""
column6: respectively. In fact
column7: one of Wayne's more spirited moments on the album comes when he forgoes a third verse on ""She Will"" and just hollers and mugs behind Drake's hook instead; he just sounds excited to be in the background.

column1: After an epic run
column2: it seems as though Wayne has finally run out of inventive ways to say he's on drugs
column3: or great at sex
column4: or extremely interested in making money. Because after you've been ""so motherfuckin' high
column5: I can eat a star
column6: as he claimed on Da Drought 3
column7: being ""so high
column8: I get star-struck"" just doesn't pack the same oomph. Elsewhere
column9: he's found a new love for the type of faux-profundity he rarely had time or patience for before. ""I'm searching for today
column10: instead I found tomorrow/ And I put that shit right back like
column11: 'I'll see what I find tomorrow
column12: '"" he blankly philosophizes on ""Nightmares of the Bottom""
column13: itself a downgrade of Tha Carter III's brilliantly soulful ""Let the Beat Build"". Once joyously freewheeling
column14: Tha Carter series has gotten to the point where it comes with its own hip-hop tropes and rules: a combination of East Coast lyricism
column15: West Coast violence
column16: and a distinctly Southern rhythm and flair. That singular formula has served Wayne well in the past
column17: but some of this album's most enjoyable moments do away with it altogether.

column1: The squelching T-Pain duet ""How to Hate"" is a paradoxically gorgeous kiss-off that finds the pair heart-worn and a bit pissed. ""She used to always say
column2: fuck my niggas/ And when I went to jail
column3: she fucked my niggas
column4: well..."" laments Wayne in a coaxing purr. As usual
column5: T-Pain plays a permanent resident of the friend zone
column6: while Wayne lashes out in the most charming way possible; the track makes you wish the rumored T-Wayne project would actually get off the ground. Even softer is that song's R&B rejoinder

column8: Wayne's most mature song to date. And while it's a little jarring to hear the guy behind ""Lollipop"" and so many Gremlins references attempt a legitimate grown-up ballad
column9: the 28 year old's tough love feels earned. Without a fierce beat or screaming guitars backing him
column10: Wayne's sing-rap croak is caught out there on the track
column11: and it results in one of the few Carter IV performances that doesn't sound like a canned retread.

column1: Recently
column2: Lil Wayne spoke out on the topic of retirement. ""I want to become a better father and a better man to my woman
column3: and those things take time
column4: he told MTV. ""And time takes away from [music]. So the honest answer to that [retirement] question is
column5: I don't know. Maybe so."" Even back in his hallowed heyday
column6: on Dedication 2

column8: so I could never retire out
column9: even when I stop rapping
column10: he said in an interlude. ""Hopefully
column11: I'm known for something different-- not different
column12: but known for something else
column13: also."" It's a nice thought. And
column14: after all
column15: this album's uncharacteristic R&B anomalies stand out most. While Tha Carter IV isn't the first indication that Wayne's finest verses are behind him
column16: it is the most glaring. Still
column17:
he seems smart enough to know that for every Jay-Z there are scores of rappers-- including several guests on this very album-- trying to relive past glories on a daily basis. Wayne has floated the notion that Tha Carter IV could be his last album. The threat makes sense.

From an early age
column2: boys are taught to avoid wearing their hearts on their sleeves. The more you open yourself up
column3: the greater the chance that you'll get yourself hurt. Male Bonding like to explore the tension between TMI and musical aggression. They kick up dust and make a lot of noise but then write of pain
column4: jealousy
column5: depression
column6: and loss. The title of their fine Sub Pop debut
column7: Nothing Hurts
column8: was a succinct summary of their contradictions.

column1: It took some time to get the whole picture on Nothing Hurts-- for one
column2: you had to get past the heavy British accents (to say nothing of the album's trashcan production values). The band's songwriter
column3: John Arthur Webb
column4: and co-singer/bassist Kevin Hendrick had problems with speaking up
column5: too
column6: obscuring some of their scattered thoughts. Some have cited this unintelligibility as a telltale sign of Male Bonding's lack of personality; while that's an understandable conclusion to reach
column7: their distance ultimately comes across as a self-defense mechanism-- emotional armor
column8: if you will.

column1: Considering the circumstances that surround Male Bonding's second album
column2: Endless Now
column3: you'd assume the stage for this self-hatred and confusion would be a little more well-lit. The record was produced by 1990s-throwback-indie producer du jour John Agnello (Dinosaur Jr.
column4: Kurt Vile) and recorded in Woodstock
column5: New York's Dreamland Recording Studio
column6: a converted 19th-century church. The results are (slightly) more polished
column7: with more room for the band's bashing guitars to stretch their legs. As a songwriter
column8: though
column9: Webb hasn't changed-- if anything
column10: the new sonic spread just provides more hiding places
column11: the dense thickets of melodic hum that drive ""Can't Dream"" and early single ""Bones"" functioning as curtains to sing behind. His cloudy outlook is still noticeable-- despite its title
column12: ""Tame the Sun"" is about not being able to tame the sun-- but it takes some digging through the sheets of noise in ""Bones"" to unearth its futile core: ""Be careful what you dream about/ There's not always ways out.""

column1: Lest you think Endless Now sounds like one big pity party
column2: it's not. Nothing Hurts had a big
column3: beating pop heart underneath its scrapes and bruises
column4: and here the hooks are plentiful
column5: to the point where touring guitarist Nathan Hewitt was enlisted to handle the overflow of sweet
column6: sticky stuff. The phrase ""pop-punk"" has been thrown around with these guys
column7: and with good reason (besides those Rivers Cuomo recording sessions
column8: that is); if you took the swaying chorus on ""Seems to Notice Now"" and plunked it in the middle of a pre-misery-and-maturity Blink-182 album
column9: I'm not sure how many would know the difference. A possibly more apt comparison would be Thirteen-era Teenage Fanclub or even vintage Fountains of Wayne in terms of sparkly power-pop goodness
column10: with just a little grit (fittingly
column11: the band's been known to do a cover of FoW's ""Radiation Vibe"" every now and then).

column1: Comparisons to such bastions of relative ""uncoolness"" is a surefire way to break out of the ""lo-fi"" holding cell that the band complained to Pitchfork about earlier this year. Although the outgoing sonics of Endless Now represent a considerable leap in sound
column2: it's those same qualities that could very well repel those drawn in by the burnt-ends glory of Nothing Hurts-- not because that previous record is necessarily better
column3: though. It's just... different. And there's nothing wrong with that if you approach Endless Now with an open mind. Bands grow and evolve
column4:
and that means shedding some old habits for new ones-- even if they're not ready to drop all of their defense mechanisms just yet.

When considered as a cultural figure
column4: Patti Smith is as amazing as they come: an ecstatic poet who turned herself into the bolt connecting New York City's fine art and punk rock scenes in the mid-1970s
column5: and an underground freak who not only scored an enduring pop hit (""Because the Night""
column6: co-written by Bruce Springsteen) but has kept her flag flying well into her sixties. Lou Reed is maybe the only other figure of her kind and caliber
column7: and Smith's a better writer than Reed
column8: at least as far as words without music go.

column1: Unlike Reed
column2: though
column3: Smith isn't the kind of pop musician whose work lends itself to anthologizing and cherry-picking. Her one real earlier stab at a retrospective
column5: got over by supplementing its greatest hits with live stuff
column6: demos
column7: and outtakes-- the interstitial
column8: idiosyncratic material that's a crucial part of Smith's weird gift. But now that she's won a National Book Award for her extraordinary memoir Just Kids
column9: a just-give-us-the-good­-songs-c'mon one-disc thing was apparently called for.

column1: Hence this straight-ahead
column2: chronologically arranged collection of singles and standards. Thirteen of its 18 tracks appeared on the greatest-hits half of Land
column3: and two of the others are lead-limbed covers of ""So You Want to Be a Rock N Roll Star"" and ""Smells Like Teen Spirit"". As Simon Reynolds points out in Retromania
column4: Smith's declaration that ""I don't fuck much with the past but I fuck plenty with the future"" couldn't have been further from the truth: Very few artists from the punk wave have been so persistently
column5: deeply devoted to a pre-punk idea of rock. (The A-side of her first single was a cover of ""Hey Joe"".) If she has an Achilles' heel as an artist
column6: it's not that she overreaches (she does
column7: but that means she grabs the stars occasionally)
column8: it's that she relies too much on what Spinal Tap called ""the majesty of rock
column9: the mystery of roll.""

column1: And when you strip away most of Smith's maddening and brilliant experiments
column2: her passionate stumbles and ungainly glories-- when you reduce her to a greatest-hits entity-- what's left is a rock'n'roll throwback that's sturdy but not particularly flexible. She simply isn't a singles artist
column3: ""Because the Night"" and maybe 1988's ""People Have the Power"" (with production that now makes it sound like a cousin of ""Don't You Forget About Me"") notwithstanding. To understand Smith's power
column4: you have to take the tunes and the sprawling poetic gestures together; Horses' ""Free Money"" topples over unless it's got the nine-and-a-half minutes of ""Land"" near it.

column1: For Smith's first four albums
column2: Outside Society is an abridgement that doesn't really do her justice. For the six that followed them
column3: it's a salvage job
column4: and not a convincing one (2000's ""Glitter in Their Eyes"" still sounds pretty good
column5: though). If the idea of a great poet fronting a rock band appeals to you
column6: and you've somehow never heard ""Dancing Barefoot"" or ""Gloria""
column7: make haste to do so
column8: and be aware that they initially appeared on better albums than this. But when an artist famously begins her first album by bragging about how the old orthodoxies don't apply to her
column9:
it's not entirely surprising that some of her own work doesn't age well.

Hand it to Tim Cohen: He's got his routine down. Perched high above the streets of San Francisco in the group-house tower that serves as his bedroom and recording studio
column2: the Fresh & Onlys front-man whips off three-chord pop songs with the kind of habitude that normal people reserve for coffee drinking

column4: and ""Law & Order"" re-runs. With every change in the weather a new set of songs arrives

column1: Except
column2: not this time. The Glad Birth of Love breaks the steady solo-record routine that Cohen has established over the last several years. Rather than a smattering of scruffy psych-pop cast-offs
column3: it's a record of long-form suites-- four songs in 45 minutes. The fuzz guitars are
column4: mostly
column5: absent. Another change: It's billed under the name of his live backing band
column6: Magic Trick

column1: In the past
column2: Cohen's solo material has been raw and off the cuff-- a steady stream of downcast sing-alongs jammed out straight to tape and passed on to the world with minimal afterthought. But The Glad Birth of Love is more intricately arranged
column3: slipping from baroque picking to mystical oud-fueled zone-outs. Cohen handles most of the instruments

column6: the Sandwiches' Grace Cooper (vocals)

column1: Between the multi-movement song cycles and the oboe overdubs

column3: Cohen's epic ballads are basically just a bunch of his regular songs
column4: only strung together stream-of-conciousness style. On ""Clyde""-- a sort of surrealist father-and-son tale-- Cohen keeps the mood mellow
column5: skipping through an endless series of finger style guitar figures
column6: never looking back to a melody or motif once discarded. It peaks in the middle
column7: with Clyde's sea-born demise
column8: where Cohen-- who
column9: despite his stoney demeanor
column10: is strangely accomplished at channeling biblical wrath-- shouts
column11: ""God's great everlasting realm is forever
column12: over a single thundering chord. At 13 minutes
column13: album opener ""Cherished One"" is just one really
column14: really
column15: really long love song.

column1: In both his solo work and his songs with the Fresh & Onlys
column2: simplicity was key to Cohen's charm. He had a perfect grasp on just how many riffs it took to make a snack-size lo-fi garage rock song sound huge. Even in his solo work
column3: there was always a chorus on the horizon. The Glad Birth of Love throws everything out on the table. It's a summation of Cohen's music-- his psych-rock output
column4: but also the out-folk exercises of his old
column5: unheralded band
column6: Black Fiction. Sing-along moments are scarce
column7: and sometimes the narrative gets foggy. But The Glad Birth of Love's scale gives Cohen room to stretch
column8:
letting his weirdo lyrical ambitions run wild amid a jumble of pastoral plucking.

When Seattle's Big Business were still a bass-and-drums duo

column6: 2007's Here Come the Waterworks was a piece of larger-than-life fists-up power-rock that would've nevertheless fit in just fine in any of the nation's finer dusty DIY noise-rock warehouses.

column1: Since that album
column2: Big Business have doubled their personnel-- one guitarist joined before 2009's Mind the Drift; another jumped on board last year. But on both Mind the Drift and the new Quadruple Single EP
column3: Big Business' mission remained admirably unchanged
column4: its focus squarely on the thudding
column5: juddering roar of that Warren/Willis attack. On Quadruple Single
column6: the guitars seem to be largely extraneous-- tinny squiggles that only take away attention from the primordial scuzz that still anchors the mix. If anything
column7: the new guys seem to be on board for backing-vocal duty more than anything else. And when opener ""Always Never Know When to Quit"" bursts into a gloriously hooky bridge
column8: the extra voices succeed in making an already-huge sound even bigger.

column1: On the first three tracks
column2: though
column3: those skyward melodies don't come quite often enough. Like recent tourmates Torche
column4: Big Business know how to balance melody and sludge with aplomb
column5: but sludge and strained time-signature gymnastics win out just a bit too often on the new tracks. It's still perfectly effective fuzz-metal
column6: but it's coming from a group of guys who have done seriously indelible work with the same ingredients
column7: so it comes off a bit too slight.

column1: What really redeems the EP
column2: though
column3: is the elementally dumb final track
column4: a platonic-ideal snarl anthem called ""Guns"". The entire lyrical content of ""Guns"" is as follows: ""Guns! Guns! Guns are better than everything else!
column5: repeated over and over. If that sounds like a fun goof
column6: it is
column7: but it's also something more. The track starts out as a ferocious martial stomp and builds from there
column8: slapping on layer after layer of scratchy
column9: brutal rock-noise and building into a dizzy roar of directionless animosity. In the right context-- the end of a shitty day
column10: say
column11:
when my car stereo is cranked all the way up-- you could convince me that ""Guns"" is the single greatest thing Big Business have ever recorded.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tri Angle']|2011-08-29 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:21:59.004243|"

The rapid emergence of micro-genres has a long history in music
column3: but the Internet has intensified the process. Online communication creates a situation where young artists
column4: separated by geography but brought together through the web
column5: can share the same obsessions and quickly develop remarkably similar aesthetics. The umbrella of music sometimes called witch house is perhaps the most obvious example of this in the last few years
column6: since it combined musical concerns (moody synths
column7: slow tempos
column8: warped vocals
column9: allusions to Southern rap) with a specific visual aesthetic (anonymous producers shielded by hoodies
column10: Christian imagery
column11: deep knowledge of the computer keyboard's symbol keys)
column12: and so many artists with these exact qualities appeared simultaneously. Unusually
column13: the bulk of the movement could be traced to precisely one source
column14: Salem
column15: demonstrating how much sway that sometimes reviled outfit had over the minds of budding young producers who spend way too much time online.

column1: Once a scene or sound crystalizes
column2: you can bet that the most interesting artists to emerge from it will quickly set off on their own and develop an individual voice. Balam Acab
column3: the project of 20-year-old Pennsylvanian Alec Koone
column4: was rightly slotted with witch house when he released his See Birds EP in 2010. He has the warped voices and the slow tempos
column5: he was on the right label
column6: and his IRL identity had a cultivated air of mystery. But the careful construction of See Birds hinted that his musical ear was a cut above
column7: and now his excellent full-length debut
column8: Wander / Wonder
column9: confirms it. This is a personal and distinctive record with its share of current reference points that nonetheless doesn't need a scene to prop it up.

column1: A few things set Balam Acab apart from the pack
column2: first being the overall mood. The post-Salem ""dark and creepy"" crawl became a cliché in record time
column3: but Wander / Wonder
column4: despite the spectral voices that take the lead on every track
column5: has no hints of nightmares or grim violence. Instead
column6: its primary concern is simple aesthetic beauty
column7: the way a small and specific combination of sounds
column8: carefully arranged but given room to breathe
column9: can have a deep emotional impact. It's pretty
column10: in other words
column11: but its prettiness never feels manipulative or overbearing. It's the sort of music that exists at the intersection between art and design
column12: but it manages to avoid feeling sterile.

column1: There are eight tracks here in 37 minutes
column2: the perfect length given the consistent mood. They have vague titles like ""Apart"" and ""Now Time"" and ""Oh
column3: Why"" that serve as a light tint but don't really point to anything in particular. In fact
column4: differentiating between the tracks seems sort of beside the point
column5: since so many of the same motifs pop up over and over again: The album feels very much like one sustained thing. The basic elements are twinkly keyboards and music-box chimes
column6: dusty crackles floating on sounds of shifting liquid
column7: and deep basslines bumping into the occasional drum machine clap. Floating above it all are the voices
column8: pitched up to accentuate their delicacy and set loose in a cloud of echo. While the current vogue is for sampled vocals that allude to R&B
column9: Balam Acab's mostly have a classical feel
column10: sounding like they are pulled from recordings of ancient hymns and airs. Accentuating the ""chamber dub"" qualities are liberal samples of orchestral sections and nylon string guitar. But the most important instrument of all is silence
column11: which frames every note and brings it to the foreground.

column1: Where the ghostly dubstep of Burial
column2: an obvious antecedent
column3: has a crucial connection to the urban street
column4: Wander / Wonder is pastoral
column5: more likely to bring to mind sunlight slanting through a window that overlooks a rural garden. And you can't have a garden without water. As anyone who has ever knocked over a cup next to a computer knows
column6: water is the digital sphere's mortal enemy
column7: the thing that can bring our precious electrical circuits down in an instant. In line with recent productions by Clams Casino and AraabMuzik
column8: Wander / Wonder has has an obsession with the sound of the life force: Laced throughout are samples of lapping currents
column9: slow drips
column10: and light splashes. These accents reinforce both the bucolic feel and
column11: with the complexity of the natural world that computers still envy
column12: liberates the music from the computer grid. They also make Wander / Wonder an immersive experience
column13: like something you lower yourself into
column14: inch by inch. And in the end
column15: that seems to be the overriding idea: This is functional music that highlights the simple pleasure of artfully arranged sound
column16:
the kind of gorgeous and evocative record that fills up the room and shifts your perception for 37 minutes and then brings you gently back to the surface.

When Game got himself kicked out of G-Unit in 2005
column3: he effectively became a ward of the record industry. He existed
column4: so somebody needed to take care of him. That responsibility fell on the shoulders of the Interscope/Geffen tandem
column5: who
column6: like bad foster parents
column7: decided to remedy their problems with him by throwing unseemly amounts of money in his direction. In theory it might make sense
column8: as Game's career has long been based on a simple formula: Surround him with artists more talented and famous than him
column9: provide him with an envious selection of beats
column10: then get out of the way and hope for the best. Up until about 2009
column11: you could actually tack ""profit"" onto the end of that list
column12: but the last few years haven't been too kind to rap's foremost tragic clown.

column1: Game last released an album three years ago
column2: and like The R.E.D. Album
column3: it seemed destined to be a commercial failure. But along came ""My Life""
column4: a Lil Wayne collaboration that became Game's biggest hit since 2005
column5: and so the project
column6: and his career
column7: were salvaged. But that was a time when pretty much anything Wayne touched ended up making somebody some money
column8: unless you were Brisco or Cassie. It was the Lil Wayne Feature Bubble of 2008
column9: and unfortunately for Interscope
column10: Game has turned out to be Pets.com.

column1: The R.E.D. Album arrives in stores as a monument to the twisted logic and dire business practices of the modern rap industry. It has cycled through as many ""lead singles"" as the total number of radio hits that Biggie had in his whole career (yes
column2: including posthumous releases). Its Wikipedia page could almost be printed and published as a 33 1/3 book. At a mere 21 tracks long
column3: and featuring 17 different artists
column4: the final product is one speedboat away from being a DJ Khaled album. Guests include Drake
column5: Young Jeezy
column6: Snoop Dogg
column7: Rick Ross
column8: Lil Wayne twice
column9: Dr. Dre five times
column10: and Nelly Furtado
column11: who must've wandered into the wrong recording studio and froze up like George Costanza when she tried to find an excuse to leave. It's almost as if the rap and R&B world got together to do a benefit album
column12: although considering the state of Game's career
column13: that might not be too far off.

column1: On one side of the coin is a work that's an utter monstrosity
column2: and whose best moments appear very sporadically. The other side is an album that is almost-- almost-- too big to fail. Where some collaborations here feel like the result of Game spinning a prize wheel and taking his stuffed Lloyd
column3: ""Heavy Artillery"" (featuring Ross and Beanie Sigel) and ""Speakers on Blast"" (with Big Boi and E-40) sound like they were conceived with consideration to how the artists might sound together and how the tracks would fit into Game's gritty aesthetic. In what might be the album's two greatest successes
column4: ""Martians vs. Goblins"" finds Game putting on a worthy audition for Odd Future (complete with a hilarious Lil B crack) and ""Drug Test"" rides a beat that thrillingly turns the clock back to when G-Unit wasn't merely an investment firm.

column1: The perverse thing about The R.E.D. Album is that amidst this unsightly storm of star power is the backbone of what could've been a coherent album. A number of tracks lean on soulful production that provides an appropriate (though maybe too on-the-nose) backdrop for Game's hyper-personal verses. Others dip into storytelling or flesh out a bit of Game's personal history. At the very worst the album wouldn't feel like one of those fake leaks that haphazardly packages together an artists' singles and random features into one large .rar file. But of course
column2: Game's whole career is based on the hypothesis that he can't sell records on name or talent alone. So instead
column3: the album smothers itself in R&B choruses sung by people like Chris Brown and Mario
column4: and nobody wants to hear that
column5: including
column6: surely
column7: Chris Brown and Mario.

column1: The R.E.D. Album will likely fade into obscurity immediately upon arrival
column2: but if it doesn't raise some eyebrows around major label offices
column3: then this is a failure of not just one person
column4: but also of an entire industry. As Watch the Throne lords over the genre
column5: its antithesis is here: a strategically and artistically directionless album
column6: built around a desperate
column7: forgotten MC
column8: foisted upon a public that has made it very clear that it wants nothing to do with him. Game told MTV's Shaheem Reid that the album's title referred to his re-dedication to hip-hop but
column9: in a taunting
column10: delicious bit of irony
column11: it more appropriately reflects the project's balance sheet. We can pretend the album never existed
column12: or better yet
column13: joke about it for years to come. Jimmy Iovine
column14: on the other hand
column15:
isn't so lucky.

In southeastern Algeria
column2: there is a vast plateau set aside as a national park called Tassili N'Ajjer. It's close to the border with Libya
column3: and years ago
column4: in the 1980s and early 90s
column5: it was a place of relatively safe passage for Kel Tamashek fighters moving between the refugee camps in Libya and the battlefront in northern Mali. To look at it in satellite images
column6: you might think you were looking at he surface of some distant moon
column7: long ago scarred by geologic activity but now barren and strangely beautiful. It wasn't always this way. Thousands of ancient cave and rock paintings dating from 8
column8: 000 to around 1
column9: 700 years ago depict a place of plenty that slowly dried to become the modern desert. There are lost religions and civilizations out there.

column1: The Tassili N'Ajjer covers some 45
column2: 000 square miles. Near the southern rim of the plateau is a town called Djanet
column3: and it's out in the rocky desert near this town that Tinariwen chose to record its fifth album. The group would have preferred to record near its homebase
column4: Tessalit
column5: in northern Mali
column6: but the security situation was too precarious. The re-flaring of a conflict the group hoped was put to bed clouds some of the album they made-- the first couplet on the album
column7: sung in weary Tamashek by Ibrahim Ag Alhabib
column8: translates to
column9: ""What have you got to say
column10: my friends
column11: about this painful time we're living through?"" It's not only about the new conflict
column12: though. From there
column13: the song calls out to people who have given up the nomadic life of the desert
column14: lamenting that they've left but seeming to understand why they have.

column1: These complex emotions run through the album
column2: and the predominant feeling that comes out of them is longing
column3: for home
column4: for peace
column5: for old friends
column6: for a way of life whose place in the modern world is uncertain. Tinariwen have mostly put aside their electric guitars for this album and returned to the acoustics they first played together
column7: backing the rhythmic playing with small hand drums and clapping. They've invited in a few friends as well. Nels Cline contributes a beautiful wash of ambient guitar to opener ""Imidiwan ma Tennam""
column8: two members of the Dirty Dozen Brass Band add rough
column9: sonorous texture to ""Ya Messinagh""
column10: and TV on the Radio's Kyp Malone and Tunde Adebimpe
column11: who traveled out to the desert recording site
column12: are on hand on five songs
column13: adding subtle backing harmonies and even a bit of lead vocal on one song.

column1: The invitation of outsiders into the songs is in one sense a measure of the confidence the band has in the integrity and singularity of its sound
column2: and also a reflection of where they've been recently. Tinariwen has toured the world and will be in North America again this fall. Some of the longing for the desert in these songs undoubtedly stems from the band's travel schedule
column3: and when Alhabib asks others why they left
column4: he may in part be doing it to remind himself that it's worth the challenge of staying. Meanwhile
column5: Tassili is a very different album from any Tinariwen have recorded before
column6: and they're proving to be a band of considerable range as they build a catalog of varied and excellent albums. Only time will tell where they're able to record the next one
column7:
but their retreat to the Tassili seems to have left them creatively refreshed.

column3: the man behind Purling Hiss
column4: has tapped into a trashy aesthetic that's part of rock'n'roll's DNA. He's got introspective druggy tunes and riff-heavy party songs
column5: both of which romanticize the brilliance of a burnout. But that's not Polizze: He's a Philadelphia friend of Kurt Vile's-- he played guitar on the Childish Prodigy tour-- who started out in Birds of Maya and made scuzzy rock records as Purling Hiss for Permanent and Woodsist before putting out this EP on Mexican Summer. But ""burnout"" is as good a word as any to convey his brand of rock grit
column6: which is slathered in cruddy production and with a hard emphasis on shredding.

column1: Lounge Lizards' six tracks serve as a logical follow up to the sound and feel of last year's Public Service Announcement
column2: which was also a meeting of catchy hooks and awful production quality. Of course
column3: the sound is presumably intentional and serves a few purposes on the EP: it dampen screams
column4: accents enormous guitar solos
column5: adds density to an already dark song
column6: and muffles instruments' sounds so they bleed together. The effect defines Purling Hiss' sound. This time around
column7: the production doesn't completely warp the tuning in the middle of a song like it did on Public Service Announcement; instead
column8: he opts to make everything sound vaguely smothered.

column1: Just past the muffled noise
column2: there are some bold
column3: well-executed tunes. ""The Hoodoo"" serves as the instant earworm of the record
column4: offering a power chord-driven hook
column5: a far-away percussion stomp
column6: a note-perfect guitar solo
column7: and a stupidly catchy and simple melody of dudes singing ""HOODOO!"" between verses. On ""Karaoke Nite""
column8: beneath completely unintelligible vocals
column9: you can hear the muddy shouts of ""whoo whoo"" reminiscent of the ones on the Stones' ""Sympathy for the Devil"" and a fluidly harmonizing guitar. There are dozens of well thought-out
column10: off the cuff
column11: immediately catchy elements like this on Lounge Lizards
column12: and it's clear Polizze has become more than adept at crafting great rock songs.

column1: There's also a lot in the way of mood-- like in the heavy
column2: deliberately paced trudge of ""Voices""
column3: a track that finds Polizze stoned and hearing voices in his head. He's not frantic or frightened-- he delivers the song with a lazy whine
column4: which pushes forward one brand of actual
column5: not-stereotypical stoner paranoia (""I don't want to be alone/ Don't want to be stoned""). Meanwhile ""City Special"" lets Polizze stretch out into doomier territory. He still throws dynamic guitar accents into the mix
column6: but keeps most of the elements to a drone.

column1: Sometimes Polizze gets overindulgent. On ""Midnight Man""
column2: he offers an urgent riff and what sounds like an army of metalheads shout-singing
column3: ""I am the midnight man."" And while the intimidation comes through
column4: it wears thin halfway into the track. Ultimately
column5: it's a shortcoming that's easy to overlook when it's sandwiched between two high-flying guitar monsters like ""The Hoodoo"" and ""Been Teased"". And really
column6: ""Midnight Man""
column7: both literally in track placement and in its ominous lyrical mantra
column8: is the centerpiece of the burnout savant aesthetic that Lounge Lizards pushes. If you're stoned and hooked on a groove
column9:
sometimes you just keep going.

Some may deem it premature for a band whose debut album isn't even a year old to be releasing a B-sides/rarities compilation this early in its career. But it's important to remember that PS I Love You essentially began life as a B-side: tucked away on the back half of a split 7"" with Diamond Rings' ""All Yr Songs""
column2: PS I Love You's heart- and-face-melter ""Facelove"" proved to be every bit as affecting and addictive as its more celebrated A-side
column3: and the heretofore unknown Kingston
column4: Ontario
column5: indie rock duo subsequently parlayed that momentum into a well-received full-length album (2010's Meet Me at the Muster Station) and a non-stop international touring itinerary. So the hasty appearance of Figure It Out represents more than just a stop-gap measure to maintain visibility in an increasingly crowded playing field; more than most bands
column6: PS I Love You understand how a B-side can pave the way to the A-list
column7: and how thin the line is between a forgotten song and a fondly remembered one.

column1: The purpose of Figure It Out is ultimately two-fold: Its first side shines a light on the band's pre-Muster Station origins
column2: while the second brings us up to date on what the band has been up to since the album's release. Though singer/guitarist Paul Saulnier and drummer Benjamin Nelson had previously played together in a Kingston quartet called Magic Jordan
column3: PS I Love You initially began as Saulnier's one-man project
column4: and the five solo demos collected here-- pulled from a CD-R sold at early shows-- stands in stark contrast to the boisterous noise-pop jams heard on Muster. On click-tracked confections like ""Subtle and Majestic"" and ""Actually (I Am a Monster Now)""
column5: Saulnier plays with a delicacy that suggests he's being extra careful not to wake up his neighbors
column6: laying off his distortion pedal and singing in an uncharacteristically soft tremble
column7: while the Neil Youngian acoustic ditty ""Notes and Stuff"" suggests a few dues paid at coffeehouse open-mic nights. We also hear skeletal
column8: drum-machined versions of two future Muster Station standards
column9: which are ultimately more interesting as historical artifacts than stand-alone tracks-- though the instrumental arrangements for ""Facelove"" and ""Scattered"" are more or less mapped out already
column10: you can hear Saulnier stretching the limits of his one-man-band set-up
column11: and begging for a more bombastic treatment that he just can't achieve on his own.

column1: Side two brings us back to familiar
column2: present-tense territory. PS I Love You confidently navigate the spectrum from the ridiculous to the righteous
column3: shifting between the endearingly stoopid Pixies karaoke of ""Starfield"" (which celebrates what is presumably the ultimate sci-fi geek fantasy of ""fuck-fuck-fucking on the back of a flying space lion"") and the gleaming
column4: majestic Diamond Rings collaboration ""Leftovers"". In tandem
column5: these songs reinforce what PS I Love You do so well: They handle the silly and serious stuff with equal conviction and drown them both in so much volume and distortion that you're not sure which side they're playing on anymore.

column1: Figure It Out's two cover selections may seem unlikely
column2: but they adhere to the same fuzzy logic. On a sandblasted makeover of Madonna's ""Where's the Party"" Saulnier yelps out the chorus with the creepy suggestiveness of someone who's probably been blocked from the Facebook invitation list. And though Rush's stern-faced
column3: suburban-outcast portrait ""Subdivisions"" fits right into PS I Love You's thematic wheelhouse
column4: their reasonably faithful version actually works best as a comedic exercise in how freakin' hard it is to cover a Rush song-- Saulnier and Nelson variously leave out certain changes altogether or add in extra bars as if they needed more time to catch their breath. Though Figure It Out's title is taken from ""Starfield""
column5: its sentiment rings most true here: Saulnier and Nelson know they're no Alex Lifeson or Neil Peart
column6: but as their career up to this point has shown
column7:
they sure know how to make the most of their limited means.

Danny Brown is a Detroit rapper with a strangled yap of a voice that you could politely call ""distinctive."" Depending on the moment
column2: he either resembles a Doberman whose paw has been stepped on or a cross between Jello Biafra and South Park's Terrence & Philip. For a rapper
column3: choosing an abrasive honk like this as your instrument is an audacious move; it all but demands that you come well-equipped with compelling reasons for your listeners to hang on.

column1: But Danny Brown is an unusually audacious rapper. He proudly rocks skinny jeans that
column2: to hear him tell it
column3: cost him a G-Unit label deal all by themselves
column4: and he has lately settled on the kind of wildly asymmetrical haircut that can invite savage beatings in certain areas. He belongs
column5: in other words
column6: to a proud lineage of mangy underground-rap weirdos. There are many rappers vying to claim this spot
column7: but none of them is as talented or as three-dimensional as Brown

column1: That universe is haunted by drugs

column5: loose-cannon  insanity

column8: he catalogs the various undignified ends he expects to meet
column9: invoking Keith Moon
column10: Jimi Hendrix
column11: and others and leering
column12: ""Experimented so much it's a miracle I'm livin'.""

column1: His penchant for depravity might remind listeners
column2: at least initially
column3: of Odd Future. But Brown's depravity
column4: unlike OF's
column5: comes burdened with real-life stakes;  at age 30 (the mixtape's title indicates Brown's age besides suggesting sex and drugs)
column6: Brown has lived through some genuinely awful-sounding shit. On ""Scrap or Die""
column7: he flips the chorus of Jeezy's ""Trap or Die"" so that it becomes about stripping houses for scrap metal to sell to factories. He takes a perverse joy in grabbing your neck and shoving your face in some vividly unpleasant places: ""I done served fiends on they menstrual/ Ain't even had pads
column8: stuff they panties with tissue!"" he yelps on ""Monopoly"". His shock rhymes on XXX are like horrorcore stripped of cartoon fantasy
column9: and they carry the moral weight of experience. On ""Pac Blood""
column10: he calls his lyrics ""shit so personal my mom can't listen to
column11: and you believe him.

column1: If XXX was nothing but debauchery and desperation
column2: it would quickly devolve into an endless slog. Thankfully
column3: Brown is also hilariously funny
column4: an endlessly inventive rapper driven to cook up outrageous variations on standard rap boasts. At one point
column5: he claims to be getting as much pussy as Teen Wolf-era Michael J. Fox; at another
column6: he brags he can ""get pussy like loofahs."" On ""Adderall Admiral""
column7: he tells a rapper he is ""softer than Flanders' son."" In a recent interview with writer Andrew Nosnitsky of Cocaine Blunts
column8: he revealed himself as an omnivorous rap nerd
column9: the kind of guy who went through heavy No Limit and Def Jux phases
column10: and his palpable joy in his craft is infectious. ""Words that rhyme together just appear all in my head
column11: he raps on the title track
column12:
sounding astonished and grateful. His gleeful love of words not only elevates some pretty heavy subject matter; it also helps distinguish XXX as one of the most compelling indie rap releases in an already strong year.

column8: and currents of rumbling post-dubstep sound design. Grossi's strong yet ethereal voice-- its corners neatly squared by a childhood spent in choirs-- masses and hovers
column9: imparting an elevated piety to the music. The slick
column10: timely aesthetic is appealing
column11: but works at slight odds with the timelessness Grossi cultivates.

column1: If you enjoyed how harps and beats entwined in a glittery haze on Active Child's Curtis Lane EP
column2: you'll enjoy You Are All I See
column3: which is similar but runs on finer gears. The EP's fairly rigid boundary between dance numbers and atmospheric ones has become much more porous
column4: creating a subtler flow that carries us smoothly from the frosty soul and coiled percussion of ""Hanging On"" to the expansive art-pop of ""High Priestess"" and ""See Thru Eyes""
column5: where jagged but spare synthetic drums and holographic tone colors make Grossi's voice seem to tower even higher. It all sounds like the work of someone whose computer expertise is catching up with his instrumental chops.

column1: With this welcome refinement of style comes a minor downside
column2: namely
column3: that it feels overly familiar. This isn't to say that Grossi is ripping anyone off-- at a time when music is so instantly responsive to its own immediate context
column4: his recombinant approach is routine. But on You Are All I See
column5: craft edges out personality. The allusions to modern trends are so well-realized that it at least creates a slightly numbing impression of opportunistic pastiche
column6: even if the similarities were unintentional. If you enjoyed the experimental soft-pop moods of Bon Iver's recent album and are looking for more spiritually glamorous music
column7: step right up. Pacesetter How to Dress Well
column8: who mines a vein similar to Grossi's but more ghostly
column9: guests on the excellent ""Playing House""
column10: while ""Hanging On"" sounds like a heartfelt synthesis of ""Lady Luck""
column11: ""The Boy Is Mine""
column12: and ""Pony"". To top it off
column13: ""Way Too Fast"" and ""Shield & Sword"" both have the prayerful
column14: hollowed out turbulence of James Blake. With a figurative dugout like that
column15: it's hard to go wrong in 2011.

column1: Nothing wrong with a low-stakes success if it sounds this good. But it's odd when a record that puts such a high premium on the personal feels so formal and emotionally opaque. Grossi's lyrics about longing and engulfing isolation have been polished to the point where they are immaculately vague
column2: and sometimes
column3: precious. They project plenty of emotional grandiosity. What's missed are more specific details
column4: which might have led to something more relatable. As it stands
column5: the sound of Grossi's voice is much more eloquent and moving than his words. Taken together
column6: You Are All I See still can't help but feel like an old cathedral-- easy to admire in awe
column7:
but somehow cold and remote; hard to really make your own.

As a member of short-lived dance punks Test Icicles

column5: orchestral-tinged folk-pop in the vein of Okkervil River with his solo project Lightspeed Champion. There have been growing pains at every step along the way

column9: Blood Orange. Coastal Grooves is all about what's missing-- it's a highly stylish album that frequently forgoes things like melodies
column10: energy
column11: and vocal choruses in favor of slinky
column12: solitary guitar lines and seductively spare
column13: post-punk atmospherics.

column3: ""Complete Failure"")
column4: Coastal Grooves is also largely propelled by strong
column5: strutting rhythmic foundations
column6: while Hynes' vocals remain appealingly florid throughout.

column1: The problem is there are almost no payoffs. Far too often
column2: Hynes lays intriguing groundwork for a sexy
column3: indie-funk jam or a sweetly kissed pop song
column4: arrives at the chorus
column5: and gives us only a stark guitar line or plinky little rhythm. I suppose this minimalist approach is in keeping with the album's artfully space-conscious post-punk leanings
column6: and sometimes the device is evocative (particularly on first single ""Sutphin Boulevard"")
column7: but it gets to a point with Coastal Grooves that you halfway start expecting to hear Hynes mumble
column8: ""Chorus goes here
column9: during some of the seemingly placeholding moments. Subsequently
column10: the few songs that have genuine vocal refrains-- like ""Forget It"" and ""The Complete Knock""-- end up feeling more fleshed out and dynamic than they really are.

column1: Hynes is the type of demonstrative
column2: emotionally engaging artist who definitely feels more at home being messily overambitious than coolly restrained. The sounds he pursues here as Blood Orange might be more hip than his work as Lightspeed Champion
column3: but the end results are less satisfying. Ideally
column4: a blend of the two styles would be best
column5: the artfulness of one project with the human connection of the other. So which sounds better: Blood Champion
column6:
or Lightspeed Orange?

Most of what I said about Damon McMahon's last album as Amen Dunes

column4: Through Donkey Jaw. He's still making muffled
column5: eerie pop akin to the private visions of Syd Barrett and Skip Spence and the homemade pop of New Zealand artisans Alastair Galbraith and Graeme Jefferies. His voice is still central

column1: There's something different about Through Donkey Jaw
column2: though. Its 14 songs are sharper and fuller
column3: with quicker access to your brain's pleasure center. The simple explanation would be that McMahon formed a band upon moving back to America from China after the release of DIA
column4: which would iikely make his songs sound bigger. But my guess is his improvement comes from something even simpler-- just by keeping at it

column1: Whatever the reason
column2: Through Donkey Jaw's forward steps are apparent immediately on hypnotic opener ""Baba Yaga"". Over a trembling guitar line and primitive drumming
column3: McMahon moves gradually from a solemn moan to a possessed croon. ""You know that I
column4: I lie
column5: he howls

column1: A classic group that Through Donkey Jaw evokes even more often is the Velvet Underground. (The album ends with a 10-minute song actually called ""Tomorrow Never Knows""
column2: but its wordless noise is more like a VU jam than the Beatles' original). There are a few specific instances to point to-- ""Gem Head"" sounds like a bedroom-recorded version of ""Run Run Run""-- but where McMahon most connects with the VU is in using repetitive rhythms and raw edges to turn hooks into mantras. Take ""Jill""

column4: even when he closes with the desperate chant
column5: ""I don't want to give in."" Again
column6:
introspection is key; McMahon catches your brain by inspecting his own. Think of Through Donkey Jaw as an out sound from deep within.

column3: especially in the Internet era
column4: show up with such a well-developed aesthetic (a very foggy
column5: of-the-moment variation on mainstream radio's slow jams) and something as self-assured as the House of Balloons mixtape. And those that do probably don't have a Drake co-sign and such a carefully managed cloak of anonymity. Months later
column6: all we really know about the Weeknd is that there's a singer named Abel Tesfaye with an earthy The-Dream-like voice and a lecherous persona that's both repellent and compelling. We've seen a few smoky
column7: black and white photos disseminated via Tumblr that perfectly fit the music's bad vibes; there have been a couple of live dates; and apparently
column8: the project has two associated producers helping to craft a sprawling
column9: drugged-up R&B sound: Doc McKinney

column1: Though there's less breathing space on Thursday

column3: it still feels of a piece with House of Balloons. There's the same ineffably skeezy vibe and a genuine sense of the album-as-journey
column4: brought upon by smart sequencing and Tesfaye's willingness to complicate his devilish
column5: drug-addled Lothario persona. The production is slightly harsher and streaked with violence
column6: befitting the lyrical content-- ""Life of the Party""

column9: sung as he casually convinces a girl into a group-sex situation. Other songs are tinged with similarly abrasive sounds: drill'n'bass noises rattle around in the background of opening track ""Lonely Star""; ""Rolling Stone"" begins with a blustery chunk of heavily processed guitar; and the final track
column10: ""Heaven or Las Vegas"" (not a Cocteau Twins cover) features a late-song interruption by screeching effects and heavy echo. For contrast
column11: the only jarring touch to the production on the fairly one-note House of Balloons is the title track's Siouxsie and the Banshees sample. So the world here
column12: in addition to being more sonically varied
column13: feels just a little darker and a little more dangerous.

column1: Oh yeah-- and Drake shows up on this one. He delivers an end-of-song verse on ""The Zone""
column2: very much in his ""I'm on One"" mode. Which means he's full of confidence and rapping in a manner that lurches forward and then slows-up
column3: teasing his melodic
column4: every-dude croon but never giving into those R&B impulses. The Weeknd and Drake have been linked for a while now
column5: first through a series of blog and Twitter co-signs and now as proper collaborators
column6: so it's interesting to finally hear the superstar step into this far more debauched world. Surprisingly
column7: he remains himself
column8: talking about not having fun at a strip club (""Whoa
column9: all these broken hearts on that pole"") and later on
column10: advising a groupie to ""be you."" Even when Drake seemingly stumbles into an encounter in which he does indeed
column11: fuck ""your girlfriend
column12: he isn't devilishly smiling about it
column13: and there's no question of consent as there often is on many of the Weeknd's drug-fueled seduction songs. The introduction of anything resembling an ethical point of view is jarring and underlines the stark differences between these collaborators.

column1: Drake gets mileage out of being conflicted and in over his head
column2: while Tesfaye sings from the perspective of an unabashed creep who doesn't care what people think
column3: and waits for the moment when everything's at a tipping point and people's guards are down. Part of the odd appeal to the Weeknd's music is that by spending this much time with a predator
column4: the vulnerable inconsistencies in an image trying hard to armor itself with coke
column5: pills
column6: and cynicism start to show through. Repeating the days of the week on ""Thursday"" slowly comes off as pretty pathetic
column7: even a tad OCD
column8: and ""Gone""
column9: a hypnotic
column10: purposefully stagnant epic
column11: feels a lot like being at a party near a guy content to tell you how fucked up he is
column12: over and over again. The gorgeous ""Rolling Stone"" contains meta references to Tesfaye ""smoking til' [he] can't hit another note"" and concerns that his mystery is fading. It's almost sympathetic
column13: though it's just as likely that this is some new

column5: however

column7: and so

column13:
dysfunctional relationship with their damaged R&B will start all over again.
