I Break Horses' name tells me they listen to Smog. Their debut LP
column2: Hearts
column3: does not. Late-period Smog-- and
column4: by extension
column5: Bill Callahan's solo albums-- are often built upon earthy instrumentation
column6: understated vocals
column7: emotional stoicism
column8: and a wry sense of humor. All of these qualities are absent from Hearts. On Hearts
column9: the Swedish duo of Maria Lindén and Fredrick Balck immerse themselves in homemade shoegaze
column10: the kind that's made by computers for computers. It's an approach and sound that's crossed language barriers for the past 20 or so years as bands strive to approximate Loveless without the benefit of a label they can bankrupt in the process.

column1: The form had something of a rebirth with M83's Dead Cities
column2: Red Seas & Lost Ghosts: At the time of its release
column3: the beauty the album achieved with seemingly cheap synths felt shockingly novel. As Matt LeMay wrote: by 2003 ""a gorgeous wall of melodic guitar noise just [didn't] seem so impressive anymore."" I Break Horses can do this sort of pretty
column4: and you'll view Hearts as frustrating or effortlessly pleasing depending on your ability to see doing only ""pretty"" as an admirable endgame. However
column5: the album's first two tracks do provide a legitimately thrilling and visceral experience.

column1: Opener ""Winter Beats"" fades in on a trebly arpeggio that spins like an LED pinwheel over sustained
column2: 8-bit major chords: Until Lindén's heavy-lidded vocals enter
column3: it's nearly a chiptune revival. Soon thereafter we get the anticipatory thwack of the first synth snare-- the part
column4: toward the end
column5: where it locks into a near-double-time beat. That
column6: coupled with an echo of MBV's glide guitar
column7: add up to an emulation of controlled flight that has me thinking of how roller coasters work on an elemental level
column8: how meticulously engineers leave no hairpin turn or stomach-rattling drop to chance. It's a marvel of aerodynamic design. The title track
column9: on the other hand
column10: has more of a pulsating build
column11: one that's no less overwhelming
column12: Lindén and Balck swathing themselves in sumptuous sonic fabrics only to tear it all apart. It's not entirely without precedent-- in addition to Dead Cities
column13: there's the lo-fi abstraction of 4-track dream-pop projects like Astrobrite or the points on Fuck Buttons' Tarot Sport where the catharsis of noise and rave dovetailed. For about nine minutes
column14: I Break Horses achieve a similarly fanged beauty.

column1: Then there's the moment where ""Hearts"" fades out and ""Wired"" introduces itself with a guitar entirely shorn of processing. ""Wired""'s hardly a bum track-- it's got something of a roadhouse blues bump that's every bit as surprising as the sudden pitch-shifting that warps the final minute-- but it is a turning point. The rest of Hearts simply swims with the current using a kind of aerobicized take on shoegaze that streamlines the sawtooths into soft curves
column2: and merges emotional polarity into a constant and generally pleasant buzz. It's music you might hear in a CB2 furniture store-- languorous and luxurious in tempos and tone
column3: but without any sort of sentiment outside of the swooning used to implant the idea in your brain that you might have sex or do drugs on that reasonably priced but fashionable couch.

column1: Lyrics rarely mean anything in this realm
column2: but you can take titles like ""I Kill Your Love
column3: Baby""
column4: ""Pulse""
column5: and ""Empty Bottles"" as guidelines. And
column6: as if echoing the album title
column7: a near-constant kick drum thump serves as a sonic equivalent of the heart at the center of these songs
column8: tracks that pump steadily without being upset by much. The snare rattles that punctuate ""Cancer"" gives the impression that it's on the verge of some sort of breakthrough
column9: but not enough tension builds to take it there. Later
column10: as closer ""No Way Outro"" starts to ramp itself up with a minute of regal drum rolls
column11: Hearts just fades out.

column1: I'd hate to think that I Break Horses' capacity for magic is contained completely within their distortion pedals
column2: but ""Winter Beats"" and ""Hearts"" sound marooned from the majority of the record
column3: sort of like a pair of oddly placed remixes (as well as cruel reminders of heights never again achieved). Really
column4: considering the majority of Hearts' unbothered lushness
column5: I Break Horses' adoption of the name of one of Smog's most intense songs doesn't seem quite right. Judging from the material we get after those first two tracks
column6:
""Butterflies Drowned in Wine"" would've been a more appropriate way to show their appreciation.

When you're reading about San Francisco space-rockers Wooden Shjips
column2: certain other bands' names come up over and over again: the Stooges
column3: Suicide
column4: Hawkwind
column5: Spacemen 3. On a certain level
column6: that's inevitable. There's nothing new about what Wooden Shjips do
column7: and we can hear the quotation marks in the band's music even if they didn't intend to put them there. All the bands named above
column8: in one way or another
column9: made visceral
column10: forbidding rock that drew much of its power through stretching-to-infinity repetition. When I hear it
column11: another name springs to mind: Lungfish
column12: if the great Baltimore astral-punk band had made music for the Camaro-cruising goons in Dazed and Confused (and if they'd had a way less distinctive singer
column13: but that's another story). Wooden Shjips turn the crunchy choogle of 1970s boogie-rock into isolation-chamber space-out fare. When it connects
column14: that's a powerful formula
column15: though it's still a formula.

column1: For a band that thrives on eternal repetition
column2: Wooden Shjips have made some impressive strides toward approachability from album to album
column3: and West is by far their biggest leap yet. On previous records
column4: the band would be content to ride a single chord long enough to turn your brain into goo. But the tracks on West are comparatively compact (the longest top out around seven minutes)
column5: and they often come equipped with riffs and melodies that don't sound too terribly far-removed from classic-rock radio fare. The recording itself is warmer and cleaner than anything they've done. Most of the songs blast off into glorious solos near the end. I'm pretty sure I heard a tambourine on at least one song. In short
column6: it's the first Wooden Shjips record that your stoner uncle might not hate.

column1: Still
column2: the band is very much doing what it does on West. Even with its increased focus on classic-rock virtues
column3: the album isn't really a collection of riffs and wails and choruses; it's more a muscular sort of vibe-out-- badass ambient music
column4: if you will. As hard as the band can rock
column5: expansive nod-out music is still its focus
column6: and the album works best when you give yourself over entirely to its pounding grandeur. Frontman Ripley Johnson sings in a narcoleptic mutter that never displays the slightest bit of feeling
column7: and his numbed monotone never disturbs the mood by leaping out of the mix to grab you. The band deserves credit for sticking to the simple purity of its own sound
column8: but its music seems unlikely to cause the sort of life-changing epiphanies sometimes created by those bands I listed in the first paragraph.

column1: In a perfect world
column2: the album might end with ""Flight""
column3: its best and longest track
column4: a deep fuzzed-out groove with a nagging organ line that builds to a cathartic guitar-solo flare-up. It's the track that most perfectly exemplifies the band's sound
column5: and it works well enough to leave you dazed by the time it's over. But the album keeps going for two more songs-- the relatively sprightly ""Looking Out"" and the vaguely puzzling ""Rising"". Now
column6: I'm not sure if all of ""Rising"" is played backward or if it's just the vocals and the drums. I'm guessing it's probably the whole thing. It's like the band challenged itself
column7: not by varying its usual zone-out style but by seeing if it could achieve that same effect when the tape machine is running backward. And the weird thing is that they basically get there. ""Rising"" is by no means the best song on the album
column8: but it won't cause you to jump up and turn it off when it comes on
column9:
either. So that's Wooden Shjips for you: a band more inclined to come by its signature sound through ridiculous means than to switch up that sound more than a little bit.

column11: The Ornament

column1: The label affiliation provides the opportunity for a family affair

column3: the record carries shades of Quever's own distant
column4: faded brand of indie  pop-- only
column5: Olsen's compositions sound rounder and warmer than anything  Papercuts have ever released. The fact that the album opens with the  immense

It usually takes years of practice and several albums for bands to reach the crestfallen state Brooklyn trio Widowspeak showcase on their debut. Here
column2: the music's poignant rush came quickly: We're told their debut single ""Harsh Realm"" was recorded after the band played a total of six shows. column3: as Hamilton's phrasing is often nearly identical to her most obvious influence
column4: but there's enough variation in mood and texture to give this project a weight and balance all of its own.

column1: Much of the credit is due to the versatile guitar lines traded between Hamilton and Robert Earl Thomas. At times there's a hollowed-out starkness and foreboding to the playing reminiscent of Ennio Morricone's spaghetti western soundtracks (""Puritan""); at others there's a meshing of hippy idealism and influences extracted from bad-vibes garage rock not dissimilar to Love at their peak (see the pleasingly atonal guitar solo that ripples through ""Nightcrawlers""). The latter even bears a moody 1950s tenor that sounds like Alex Zhang Hungtai of Dirty Beaches with the filth cleaned out of his fingernails. Anyone looking to wallow in 1990s nostalgia will find much to gorge on
column2: too-- touchstones from that decade come thick and fast.  For instance
column3: when Hamilton's not channeling Sandoval
column4: and when the band crawls out of the doldrums into more upbeat territory (""Gun Shy""
column5: ""Half Awake"")
column6: she often resembles Madder Rose singer Mary Lorson.

column1: The skill with which Widowspeak assimilates those parts into alluring song structures is what prevents this from being an exercise in tributary. There's an ache to ""Harsh Realm"" that's all their own
column2: the central vocal line (""I always think about you"") bearing a downplayed creepiness that suggests Hamilton knows a thing or two about the ill effects of obsessive love. The one-two punch of ""Gun Shy"" and ""Hard Times"" are where the band hits its peak
column3: the former combining their natural wistfulness with bouts of polished-up Link Wray guitar twang that wouldn't sound out of place on the soundtrack to Tom DiCillo's Johnny Suede. On ""Hard Times"" they bend everything around a featherlight pop framework that provides a perfectly melancholy backbone to Hamilton's naturally listless demeanor: It has the right amount of sun and shade much of Widowspeak possesses
column4: the lightness of touch in the arrangement preventing the songwriting from toppling over into unpalatable sorrow.

column1: Sometimes they don't get that balance right-- on ""Fir Coat"" it sounds like the song is racing away from Hamilton
column2: and the closing ""Ghost Boy"" is built around the kind of Moe Tucker-inspired drumming that feels tired in the wake of legions of Brooklyn bands mining the sound over the past few years. But this is clearly the work of a group still finding its way
column3: hammering out the kinks in public view. There's a potential here that could lead to something with a great deal more gravity. It's to Widowspeak's credit that they do make this first taste a brief peak behind the curtain: Five of the 10 songs don't go over the three-minute mark
column4: and the entire runtime's barely half an hour. The economical use of space makes Widowspeak feel like a chance meeting with a pining stranger
column5:
one who spills their guts then vanishes from sight just as they're beginning to make an impression.

simply getting to wet your head with Wigry's misty ambiance makes it worth a dip.

column6: and he managed to embed most of his ad-libs in the genre's collective consciousness. Standing in stark contrast

column8: and his choruses are often him just shouting a phrase or two-- no less catchy
column9: but still an altogether different tactic. And where Gucci's beats were highly musical
column10: Waka's are often loud and seemingly best fit for head banging. If Gucci painted pictures
column11: Waka looks at a blank canvas and dumps a can of red paint on it. Then maybe breaks it over his knee.

column1: But here's the dirty secret about Waka and Gucci: They've never worked well as collaborators. Though they've now been on dozens of songs together
column2: none ranks in either artist's upper echelon
column3: and many have been an outright bore. On paper
column4: their styles do not mesh
column5: and in practice they don't either. They both sound awkward and out of place on each other's tracks-- Gucci blunts Waka's raw emotion
column6: and Waka leaves little room for Gucci's writerly leanings. That trend doesn't change on Ferrari Boyz
column7: their official commercially released collaborative album.

column1: Most of their collaborations arrived after Waka really blew up
column2: and they've found Gucci heavily drawn to his aesthetic. That can probably be chalked to staying with the hot hand-- basically everyone in rap is flocking to the beats of producers Lex Luger and Southside (who partly owe their success to Waka's)
column3: so why go in a different direction? And truly
column4: if you took Gucci's contributions off Ferrari Boyz and replaced them with Brick Squad underlings
column5: you'd probably be looking at something close to Flockaveli's follow-up.

column1: But that raises another question: If Gucci is worlds better than guys like YG Hootie and Kebo Gotti
column2: shouldn't Ferrari Boyz be as good
column3: if not better
column4: than Flockaveli? Theoretically
column5: yes
column6: but it's missing most of the elements that made Waka's solo album so great and so invigorating. Namely
column7: it lacks the manic energy that is Waka's calling card: If it's possible to go through the motions while still mostly shouting
column8: Ferrari Boyz would be a prime example. The album can also get drearily monotonous-- though at times the beats will switch out of the album's minor key template
column9: Ferrari Boyz desperately lacks the standout outliers like ""Fuck the Club Up"" or ""Grove St. Party"" that help buoy Flockaveli.

column1: The album does pick up near the end: ""Too Loyal"" rides a blippy beat that's maybe the record's most fun production
column2: and it also finds  Gucci retaining some of the playfulness that's always been a part of his  music. ""So Many Things""
column3: the real keeper
column4: is a fluttery track that  finds Gucci singing the album's best hook with an endearingly amateur  whine. (It should come as no surprise as to who is behind both: Fatboi
column5: a frequent Gucci cohort.)

column1: Though guys like Hootie couldn't hold Gucci's rhyme book
column2: they fit perfectly into Waka's aesthetic-- even if they don't rock   anti-skill as a skill nearly as well as he does
column3: they're at least   willing to sound animated. Gucci
column4: in contrast
column5: puts little effort into   his writing here
column6: which is made all the worse by him sounding profoundly   bored
column7: tired
column8: stoned
column9: or some combination of the three. It's a problem   that has plagued a lot of his music recently
column10: but it's a bigger issue   now that he doesn't have the appropriate production to perk
column11: or prop
column12: him up. That said
column13: Ferrari Boyz is far from dire-- it's largely just disappointing. Gucci and Waka still don't sound at home together
column14:
and it's of little comfort that their clashing styles are what made them great in the first place.

I saw Cut Off Your Hands live in 2007. They had just lost a gig on a children's TV show in their native New Zealand because of their name. When they were booked for the performance they'd been called Shaky Hands
column2: but a threat of legal action by the Portland band Shaky Hands forced them to change it. Their somewhat sarcastic choice of a new moniker cost them a payday. It either didn't phase them or motivated them
column3: because when they got on stage
column4: they were nearly out of control. Vocalist Nick Johnston likes to get into the crowd
column5: and his performing style amounts to a cardio workout.

column1: They've grown up quite a bit since then
column2: and though I've heard they're still wild on stage
column3: the music they make in the studio has moved on from their post-punk roots. Hollow
column4: their second LP
column5: sounds much closer to the late-1980s/early-1990s work of British rock bands in the vein of Kitchens of Distinction
column6: the House of Love
column7: and the Trash Can Sinatras. There's a distinctive
column8: clear-toned chime to the guitars
column9: an airy drum sound
column10: and the occasional backing vocal joining Johnston in unison-- it all adds up to something with the feel of that era. It has a dash of classic punk-informed NZ pop like the Bats
column11: too
column12: and should be right in the wheelhouse of anyone who pines for the long-ago days of classic college rock (or simply likes indie rock with a little sweep to it).

column1: The band opens the album deceptively
column2: with a shuffling drum beat similar to the one from Sweet's ""Ballroom Blitz"". When the rest of the band comes in
column3: it turns to be a soft-hued and propulsive bit of swooning jangle pop
column4: not some kind of rave-up. ""Hollowed Out"" offers an idea of what Echo and the Bunnymen might have sounded like in the mid-80s if Ian McCulloch had taken a less operatic approach to singing
column5: while the band as a whole is at its finest on the slightly psychedelic ""Nausea"": Johnston's slightly flat singing on the verse sets up the key change and lighter tone of the catchy chorus surprisingly well.

column1: ""Nausea""'s easy-moving rhythm highlights one of the band's strengths-- they never sound plodding or like they're struggling to push the songs along. The airy recording aids the band's light touch
column2: too-- the album glides by like it's on skates
column3: its 34 minutes whipping by in an instant. The songs on Hollow are modest-- there's no closing epic
column4:
and the choruses are catchy but don't aim to be anthems-- but the band seems to have found its true strength here in a sound that's pretty far removed from the implied violence of its name.

For a minute there

column3: the quartet
column4: lead by seasoned indie sideman Eric D. Johnson (Califone
column5: Vetiver
column6: the Shins)
column7: eked up the tempo-- sidelining folksier impulses in favor of gently driving guitar pop that channeled Rumors-era Fleetwood Mac. Two years later

column4: favoring spacious and spacey songwriting that sets the lyrics front and center. It's a record full of stories

column2: not enough to buoy Tripper's soft and moody music. Conflict
column3: resolution
column4: and character development often slip by unnoticed

column1: Johnson fares better when he takes a more casual tone
column2: as on ""Tangie and Ray""

column4: by the sound of it
column5: certain doom. ""Now they're one with the dirt
column6: and the mouldering bones and litter leaves

it helps that Johnson is keeping a straightforward narrative. He's better with rogues and riffs than heady prose.

The first song on Norwegian indie-pop outfit Razika's debut
column2: Program 91
column3: is titled ""Youth"". It's an exercise in writing what you know. The band is made up of 19-year-old girls who have known each other since they were six and have been making music together since they were 14. Razika recorded Program 91 over the course of one year on weekends
column4: to work around their school schedule. They've had the privilege not only of being compared to the Slits
column5: but also of pointing out that the comparison's kind of sexist
column6: since they sound nothing like the Slits. If you're the type who wonders why you weren't more proactive when you were younger
column7: avoid this album.

column1: Program 91's basic makeup is spiky
column2: sharp
column3: post-punk-inflected pop
column4: executed with laser-precise accuracy (and a re-contextualized cover of ""Why We Have to Wait""
column5: a song by 1960s Norwegian pop group the Pussycats). In the record's back half
column6: slight dub touches and ska-worthy rhythmic figures enter the mix; the former is squint-your-eyes noticeable
column7: while the latter explicitly serves the band's unassailable sense of time-keeping. The interlocking syncopation is strong enough to suspect that Gorilla Glue plays a part in holding everything together-- that
column8: or lead singer Marie Amdam
column9: who hugs her syllables tightly and with added zest (on ""Vondt I Hjertet""
column10: you can practically feel the spit from her inflected accent hitting your face).

column1: Like a lot of indie-pop albums
column2: Program 91 is relatively quick and dirty. But despite its brevity
column3: the album's second side drags a bit
column4: as the skanked rhythms begin to bleed into each other with a lack of individual distinction. Stick around
column5: though
column6: for the album's gorgeous
column7: windswept closer ""Walk in the Park""
column8: an airy slice of melancholia that addresses an open-book relationship while closing out this band's first chapter. After all the peppy guitar lines and young-at-love-and-life razmatazz that one's heart could handle
column9: Program 91 melts down to gentle strums and layered ""ba-da-da""s
column10:
saying farewell in the ""we'll meet again"" way that only the best of friends do.

As we spend the next nine years critically dissecting and reassessing the 1990s
column3: let's agree to make one historical revision: The lo-fi auteurs of the era-- your Malkmuses
column4: your Pollards
column5: your Elephant Sixers-- were not in fact ""slackers
column6: despite the prevailing label/insult of the the day. Truthfully
column7: their lack of studio polish was not a matter of laziness
column8: ironic aesthetic
column9: or poverty
column10: but a coping mechanism for the unstoppable torrent of melodies
column11: words
column12: and ideas exploding from each songwriter's brain. No time for getting that song exactly right-- on to the next one.

column1: That first-draft immediacy can fade with success
column2: creative fatigue
column3: or that demon ""maturity."" In the case of Malkmus
column4: the transformation took the flavor of just wanting to play his damn guitar-- a mid-life crisis where sports cars were replaced with extended solos
column5: ornate riffs
column6: and long songs that felt even longer. But if the recent rash of alt-rock reunions were meant to cash in on audience nostalgia
column7: perhaps some happy memories ricocheted back onto the bandleaders as they revisited their ragged
column8: spontaneous greatest hits.  To put it plainly

column10: but it is a rewind to a less perfectionist Malkmus
column11: packed with the most mischief and weirdness he's displayed since his eponymous solo debut. It also has the most songs since Wowee Zowee. Like that declaration of independence from the confines of a successful band
column12: Mirror Traffic possesses a relaxed
column13: spontaneous feel befitting his earlier days in NoCal.

column1: Despite originally wanting to title the album L.A. Guns and putting the hard-rocking ""Senator"" forward as the first single
column2: Malkmus largely lays off the Guitar Hero: The fretboard theatrics are used more sparingly and deployed to much greater effect on ""Forever 28"" where a ""Mr. Blue Sky"" bounce is interrupted by Thin Lizzy runs
column3: or in the thrilling summertime riff of ""Stick Figures in Love"". Only three songs break the five-minute barrier
column4: and these feel far less claustrophobic than the extended tracks on the last three Jicks records. ""Share the Red""'s shambolic waltz
column5: for instance
column6: goes down easier than the 10-minute-long interlocking duets of ""Real Emotional Trash"".

column1: Songs also move in unexpected directions
column2: like the Go! Team-ish coda of ""No One Is (As I Are Be)"" or the slingshot tempo changes of ""Spazz"". Even a brief interstitial like ""Jumblegloss""-- with cosmic guitars and unidentifiable auditory objects whirring by-- is a refreshing bit of spontaneity to rinse after the album's most Jicks-like rocker
column3: ""Brain Gallop"". The less serious vibe better suits Malkmus' still intact sense of humor and menagerie of oddballs (opening here with a nudist in Birkenstocks and ending 15 songs later with a cousin ""down with soft rap"").

column1: Happily
column2: celebrity producer Beck doesn't employ the heavy hand he showed earlier this year on Thurston Moore's Demolished Thoughts
column3: which re-enacted Sea Change with the Sonic Youth frontman on vocals. Here
column4: Beck's fingerprints are lighter-- he plays enabler to Malkmus' quirks
column5: leaving in mid-vocal laughs
column6: adding subtle lap-steel on ""Tigers"" and ""Long Hard Book""
column7: and fuzzing out the punkish ""Spazz"" and ""Tune Grief"".

column1: Whether he likes it or not
column2: Malkmus is the indie-rock version of a Dylan or Simon or U2
column3: artists who will forever be blurbed as making ""their best album since ____."" Competing with his younger self is definitely not a priority for Malkmus
column4: who went through Pavement's reunion tour like he was punching a clock. Any resemblance to earlier days is likely unintentional
column5: but for the aging hipsters of the world
column6: even an accidental flashback is a good contact high. Mirror Traffic tickles that nostalgia without sacrificing maturity
column7:
discovering that ""playfully relaxed"" is a valid third route between ""slacker"" and ""manic.""

Take a blind taste test of the slip-sliding bassline and group-hug harmonies on ""Wild Window"" or the quacking guitar effects of ""Street Clothes""-- none of it would sound too out of place between a Red Hot Chili Peppers or Sublime track on a KROQ superset.

column9: and the title track to be sorted out by a matter of increment. And while Top's lyrics concerning the bothersome pace of modern life generally create friction against their serotonin-boosted arrangements

Boiling down the work of any group that spanned three decades is never going to be easy. For German avant gardists Popol Vuh
column2: it's practically impossible. The band was founded by Florian Fricke in 1969 and largely remained his vision throughout
column3: albeit with useful accomplices picked up along the way. Popol Vuh are often slotted into krautrock/kosmische musik categories
column4: but their work also variously edged close to prog
column5: new age
column6: and ambient. They are perhaps best known for providing the soundtracks to many of Werner Herzog's feature films
column7: and this year the SPV label put out a box set gathering some of those. ""Florian was always able to create music I feel helps audiences visualize something hidden in the images onscreen
column8: and in our own souls too
column9: said the director in Herzog on Herzog. Here
column10: SPV again pays tribute to Fricke on the 10th anniversary of his death
column11: gathering strains of the band's original recordings and completing the package with a disc of remixes.

column1: This is the kind of release that will have longstanding Popol Vuh followers raising an eyebrow at what's not included-- the monolithic drone piece ""Vuh"" from In den Gärten Pharaos is missing
column2: and there's nothing from the classic 1972 release Hosianna Mantra. It's heavy on the soundtrack work and sequenced in non-chronological order
column3: beginning with the stirring ""Aguirre I - Lacrima Di Rei"" from Herzog's 1972 feature <i><a href=""http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0068182/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Aguirre
column4: the Wrath of God. The synergy between Herzog and Fricke comes from a place where malevolence
column5: beauty
column6: and eminence are vying for equal space. ""Aguirre I"" features peals of artificial choir sound
column7: played by Fricke on a mellotron-like device called a ""choir organ"" that triggered tiny loops of field recordings. It's a colossal sound that feels both daunting and alluring
column8: something to fear and rejoice in at the same time
column9: where the real and the unreal seem to seep into one another.

column1: Fricke's Aguirre soundtrack is among the best work he produced in his career
column2: but there's such scope to the Popol Vuh sound that it scarcely matters that the bar is raised so high so early. The lengthy title track from the band's debut record Affenstunde (1970) documents Fricke's fascination with folksy percussion and the mantra-like possibilities that emerged from sustaining single notes on a Moog. That space between artifice and actuality is where Popol Vuh's music finds its muscle
column3: adding to the feeling of something arching across ancient and contemporary worlds
column4: with Fricke jostling between earthy textures and the inter-planetary visions of his krautrock contemporaries. ""Affenstunde"" is paired with the similarly epic ""In den Gärten Pharaos"" on Revisited & Remixed
column5: which forms another placid divide between pulsing synth noise
column6: primitive hand percussion
column7: balmy Rhodes-like plinking
column8: and sounds extracted from the natural world.

column1: It might have been better to follow ""Affenstunde"" with the much darker ""Vuh"" instead of ""In den Gärten Pharaos""
column2: just to show off the great surge of energy they were capable of summoning. But there are so many sides to Popol Vuh that it's no surprise some are missing on this release. Instead
column3: a couple of superior cuts from the soundtrack to Herzog's Nosferatu the Vampyre are among the highlights. Here Fricke again explores the dichotomy between the real and the unreal and the primitive and the present
column4: through throaty voice manipulations
column5: contemplative acoustic plucking
column6: raga-like drones
column7: and playful baroque arrangements. It's difficult to listen to Popol Vuh's career broken down in this way
column8: dislocated from the strange trajectory they followed. Lurching from the ambient precursor ""Ich Mache Einen Spiegel"" to the sweeping drift of the Cobra Verde soundtrack feels messy and unfocused. Instead
column9: this record is best seen as a jumping off point for the uninitiated
column10: a way to point travelers in the right direction instead of a singular piece in its own right.

column1: The second disc is an uneven selection of prosaic remixes
column2: with few highlights. Haswell & Hecker's reworking of ""Aguirre I/II"" taps into that extraordinary otherworldly quality of the original piece
column3: building it into a towering wall of shifting noise then shattering it apart as though they've taken a hammer to glass. Elsewhere
column4: too many of the artists sound like they're attempting to assimilate sounds into their own catalogs: Mouse on Mars' version of ""Through Pain to Heaven"" is an incongruously heavy handed club jam
column5: while Stereolab's take on ""Hosianna Mantra"" papers over all the peculiar elements that make Popol Vuh such an alluring listen. Thomas Fehlmann's version of ""Schnee"" works better
column6: with its piston-like rhythm veering closer to Fricke's world. Perversely
column7: what the remixes lack-- risk
column8: pomposity
column9: refinement
column10:
transformative power-- is everything Popol Vuh's original recordings feed off to find their mettle.

Revivalism and surprise might not always be mutually exclusive
column2: but combining the two is tricky. It's been done

Another decade's worth of experience spinning other people's records meant he had his ear finely tuned when it came time to make his own-- so far his career's been a fair-minded exercise in consolidating a sprawl of electronic dance music history into a loosely-tied catchall that covers grime
column8: dancehall

column9: one-note ""WHOMP""'s. The opening title track's a tenuously Prince-ly 80s funk-rock cut that rides on live (or live-sounding) drums and slap bass-- and doesn't sound a damn thing like any of the other songs on the album.

column2: naggingly vague and detached from any chronologically or historically tangible movements

column5: while intricate

column1: In the past week

Watch the Throne is no exception: its release on the same day as yet another catastrophic stock market downturn has led some critics to conclude that the pair's boasts of obscene wealth is out of step with the times. That's a fair case to make. But one of the striking things about Watch the Throne is how often Jay and Kanye address matters beyond their bank accounts. On ""Why I Love You""
column4: it's  Jay's dismay at past crewmates' betrayals. On ""Murder to  Excellence""
column5: it's black-on-black crime and the scarcity of people of  color at society's highest seats. On ""Made in America""
column6: it's the hardships of youth and coming of age. ""New Day"" is framed as a letter to the pair's imagined sons
column7: a  device that mostly gives them a chance to soul-search and self-criticize. On ""Welcome to the Jungle""
column8: Jay
column9: never a tortured pop star
column10: actually says
column11: ""I'm fuckin' depressed."" Despite all the triumphant  bravado these two bring to practically everything they do
column12: they work overtime here to bring a sense of empathy to this  enterprise. Once in a while
column13: they even sound vaguely humble.

column1: These subtler moments are admirable
column2: but they don't always work. Consider
column3: for example
column4: the song ""That's My Bitch""
column5: on which Kanye and his collaborators flip the classic ""Apache"" break into a devastating dance-rap monster with synths zooming off in every direction and Justin Vernon making the aforementioned sweaty soul moves. It's a vicious song
column6: catchy as fuck
column7: but it turns out to be weirdly awkward. Despite the title
column8: Jay's verse is all devotional-prophet; it mostly concerns the way American beauty standards so often work against women of color. The sentiment deserves respect
column9: but his laidback delivery
column10: on a track with production and structure that call for ferocity
column11: drains his ideas of force.

column1: Watch the Throne works best when Jay and Kanye are just talking about how great they are. The single ""Otis"" is dizzy fun
column2: with Jay and Kanye rapping hard and swapping mics like hungry  kids. ""Niggas in Paris"" rides an impossibly propulsive synth riff  and gigantic drums and gives Jay a chance to display the technical rap  wizardry he still has in him. (It also features this great Kanye moment
column3: ""Doctors say I'm the illest because I'm suffering from realness/ Got  my niggas in Paris
column4: and they going gorillas
column5: followed by a sample of Will Ferrell in Blades of Glory talking about how awesome shit doesn't have to mean anything.) ""Gotta Have It"" unites Kanye and the Neptunes to crazily chop up James Brown vocal samples and Eastern flute melodies. And ""Who Gon Stop Me"" finds Kanye cussing in Pig Latin while turning dubstep-rap into a viable subgenre.

column1: If you buy Watch the Throne from iTunes-- the only place you can buy it at the moment-- you'll notice that it's credited to ""JAY Z & Kanye West"" (capital letters and missing hyphen unexplained). But while Jay might be billed first for seniority's sake
column2: Kanye is this album's obvious guiding force.  Throughout
column3: he displays levels of unequaled audacity. On  ""Otis"" and ""Gotta Have It""
column4: he reduces Otis Redding and James Brown to  simple grunts
column5: then builds rhythm tracks out of them. On ""New  Day""
column6: over a beat co-produced by RZA
column7: he actually runs Nina Simone through Auto-Tune. On ""No Church in the Wild""
column8: he authoritatively vows
column9: ""You will not control the threesome."" The musical scope of Watch the Throne is a tribute to his distinctive taste and sense of style. The whole thing sounds huge
column10: and even the sillier moments (""Made in America""
column11: especially
column12: reminds me of the inspirational ballads of late-period  Michael Jackson) succeed on pure orchestral excess. Jay and Kanye  debuted the album in a private listening session at a New York planetarium
column13: a setting which made perfect sense: even if it never approaches the grandeur or character-study complexity of Twisted Fantasy
column14: this is still exploding-star music.

column1: So: two long-reigning titans make a relatively quick album which
column2: despite their best efforts
column3: still winds up being a  monument to their own grandiosity. Should we  care? Well
column4: yeah. Kanye doesn't have a cruise-control switch
column5: and when  he's around
column6: neither does Jay. On Watch the Throne
column7: they  push each other and have fun doing it
column8:
and the result is a stadium-sized event-rap spectacle that still sounds like two insanely talented guys' idiosyncratic vision. That's worth celebrating.

"|15725.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15725-watch-the-throne/|8.5|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16845/homepage_large.17dc09da.jpg|Gainsbourg Percussions|4810.0|Serge Gainsbourg|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4 Men With Beards']|2011-08-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:23.521394|"

In English-speaking countries
column2: there is a tendency to put Serge Gainsbourg in a very small box. The box is labeled something like ""dirty old Frenchman who liked to drink."" We credit or debit him to varying extents for being brave/gross enough to make an album about statutory rape or a song about incest with his very young daughter
column3: for being a lover to both Brigitte Bardot and Jane Birkin (and using the opportunities to make innovatively raunchy music)
column4: for making an ass of himself on European talk shows in the 1980s
column5: for being unapologetic about all of this. He is
column6: in effect
column7: reduced to a whispering
column8: occasionally drunk lothario by people who don't speak French
column9: his often brilliant wordplay and punning sense of humor hidden behind a language barrier. His musical innovation? Often not discussed at all.

column1: The simple fact is that most of his work remains obscure outside of France. It's only when you pull back from ""Je T'Aime... Moi Non Plus"" and Melody Nelson and look at his entire career that it becomes apparent how massively influential he was to the body of French song. He started out in the late 1950s making records backed by Alain Goraguer and his orchestra in a style that was little different from the modern chanson that dominated French music in the mid-20th century
column2: but he very quickly began to incorporate elements of American bebop and cool jazz
column3: the first of many such stylistic deviations that helped form the landscape upon which modern French pop and rock grew.

column1: In 1964 Gainsbourg was well-known but still not the giant he was to become. His first brush with major controversy-- France Gall's risqué Gainsbourg-penned hit ""Les Sucettes""-- was still two years away. The Serge that English speakers tend to know hadn't been invented. Gainsbourg was working then on more purely musical inventions
column2: and Percussions is an invention of sorts. It's not the first album to directly merge Latin American and African music with Western song styles
column3: but it was unique at the time for the way it did it
column4: essentially grafting chanson onto African and Latin drum patterns and choral styles to create one of the earliest ethno-beat records. Think of it as an ancestor of Paul Simon's Graceland
column5: a record whose approach to mixing African music and Western song is quite similar.

column1: Gainsbourg didn't take an entirely hard road to this fusion. Three of the album's songs
column2: ""Joanna""
column3: ""New York
column5: and ""Marabout"" are built directly on carbon copies of songs from Babatunde Olatunji's 1959 Drums of Passion LP
column6: with the Nigerian chants replaced by French lyrics and Gainsbourg's new melodies and verses laid over the top. This theft is not hidden at all-- it's totally obvious to anyone familiar with Drums of Passion-- though no credit was given to the source. France was just then beginning to close its Colonial chapter
column7: so the idea of a French musician co-opting the music of a Nigerian drummer for his own purposes certainly has an element of ugliness.

column1: That said
column2: I suspect Gainsbourg knew some people would spot the lifts
column3: and I think in a way he hoped they would: Across the LP's 12 tracks
column4: he makes no audible attempt to sanitize the African
column5: Brazilian
column6: Caribbean
column7: and bebop rhythms at the heart of the songs
column8: the direct theft functioning somewhat like a coded announcement of their authenticity. On ""Les Sambassadeurs""
column9: Gainsbourg does samba so effectively that the difference between his version and the real thing is mostly one of language and instrumentation (I think the tuba completes a pun in the lyrics). If we explore the album for insight into Gainsbourg's thought process while he was making it
column10: a definite (and rather anti-colonial) theme of embracing people across race lines emerges. ""Couleur Café"" does this directly with its declaration of ""I love your coffee-colored skin."" It sounds sort of unremarkable-- and maybe even condescending or at least un-PC now-- but in its day
column11: it would have been a provocative sentiment to the exact people Gainsbourg liked to needle.

column1: For all the ethical ambiguity surrounding its creation (in this way it's similar to Paul Simon's Graceland)
column2: Percussions is still a very powerful record. Discounting even its musical concept
column3: it is an uncommonly cohesive and consistently great LP for 1964. It is beautifully recorded
column4: too. The female choirs backing Gainsbourg are vividly captured and lively
column5: the percussion tracks have unusually sonorous low-end (they sound especially good on this vinyl reissue)
column6: and the guitar sound on ""Ces Petit Riens"" is uncannily modern. This is something Gainsbourg doesn't get nearly enough credit for-- outside of its sometimes outrageous content
column7: his music was always progressive
column8: and he never was content to stay in one place for too long.

column1: This is one reason he never created another LP like Percussions. He came closest on the two reggae LPs he did in Jamaica with Sly & Robbie in the late 1970s and early 80s
column2: but even those lack the Percussions' accessibly experimental scope and cultural curiosity. In 1965
column3: France Gall won the Eurovision Song Contest for Luxembourg with ""Poupée de cire
column4: poupée de son""
column5: a song written by Gainsbourg. It elevated him to another plane of fame
column6: one where he couldn't make an album as casually innovative as Percussions and remain under the radar. Instead
column7: he pointed himself elsewhere musically and became the Serge we know best. On Percussions
column8: though
column9: we can hear the Serge that the salacious details sometimes obscure
column10: the musical experimenter hungry for new sounds
column11: out in the open
column12:
innovating if not inventing.

"|15717.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15717-gainsbourg-percussions/|8.2|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16823/homepage_large.fc8fc6d7.jpg|Bad Vibes|28501.0|Shlohmo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Friends of Friends']|2011-08-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:24.224411|"

Establishing a sonic personality without lyrical assistance or some unique personal backstory can be tricky
column2: especially when you're in the middle of a room crowded with your peers. The space in question is the one with a ""for fans of Flying Lotus"" sign posted over the door
column3: and there hasn't been a ton of vacancy in there lately. Those who've broken out have done so by tweaking the sonic imprint of decaying beats and melting analog chords until they come across as distinctly tactile things
column4: humid and slippery
column5: blown-out and elastic.

column1: Reaching out to clutch the music on Shlohmo's Bad Vibes might cause it to crumble in your grasp-- and then cut the hell out of your fingers. The L.A. producer's sophomore full-length comes after a handful of singles
column2: EPs
column3: remixes
column4: and compilation appearances
column5: as well as last year's disorienting debut
column6: Shlomoshun Deluxe. And in that short yet busy time
column7: Shlohmo has dredged up something strange: an aesthetic that's jaggedly delicate
column8: filled with melodic beauty but jostled by abrasive percussive hitches
column9: undercut with sandpapery patches of ambient fuzz. It's a deft merging of gentle
column10: wafting electronic tones and intricately beat-to-shit rhythmic atmosphere
column11: the sounds of old technology trying to reconcile its former gloss with its fading functionality.

column1: The cynical ears that still can't get past the nostalgic surface of chillwave might have their own bone to pick with the cassette-deck/VHS fidelity of Bad Vibes
column2: which stands out pretty prominently in hissy tracks like ""Same Time"" and ""Parties"". But instead of celebrating corroded
column3: neon-pastel magnetic-tape detritus for its own sake
column4: the music on this album leans closer to an appreciation of the actual rhythmic counterpoints
column5: quirks
column6: and resonant qualities of white noise. Alongside the moments that seem to revel in the flutter and crackle of old equipment are stretches that draw similar vibes from the sound of literal rainfall (""Seriously"") or birdcall-strewn field recordings (""Big Feelings"")-- not to mention the texture you can get from good old-fashioned feedback
column7: like the keyboard squall of ""Trapped in a Burning House"".

column1: The beats themselves are striking enough
column2: whether they're the distant trickling clicks of ""Sink"" or the sharp
column3: crisp snap-thump grooves that push along cuts like ""Places"" or ""Same Time"". Yet even the moments where the beat feels secondary to the other instrumentation have a pulse to them
column4: run through floaty guitars or humming synthesizers that converse with the ambient hiss in compelling ways. Still
column5: neither the melody nor the ambience overwhelms the other. It's easy to hear the silky
column6: billowy tones through the dying-battery distortion
column7:
but hard to picture what they'd sound like without it.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16846/homepage_large.c2f3c838.jpg|GIVING|5703.0|Collections of Colonies of Bees|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hometapes']|2011-08-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:24.910973|"

Milwaukee's Collections of Colonies of Bees has been called a side project to Pele
column2: the post-rock band that guitarist Chris Rosenau and drummer Jon Mueller founded in 1997. But those roles look pretty shaky now that Pele is defunct and CCB is still going strong. Founded almost concurrently with Pele
column3: the project began as an outlet to explore folk and bluegrass in a post-rock context
column4: and while its purview quickly expanded
column5: those origins are still vestigial in new album GIVING. They're tangible in the bright banjo plinking behind the guitar cascades of ""Lawns""
column6: and they spiritually inform the conversational disposition of the instruments. Though the songs are as sprawling and segmented as the band's name
column7: CCB brings a touch of relaxed humanity to a style of music that can be unduly grave.

column1: While peers such as Explosions in the Sky worship sheer trajectory
column2: CCB seem more interested in the vistas that open up along the way. Downtown minimalism and ambient electronics have become pervasive influences
column3: and during tiered ascents that take in the molten guitar waves of Rhys Chatham (with whom Mueller has worked) and the spectral patterns of Steve Reich
column4: the band often wanders off-course to linger in Eno-inspired electronic wildernesses. Their adventurousness earned them a devoted fanbase
column5: and their stock really took off in 2009
column6: when they hooked up with Justin Vernon to create the widely admired Unmap as Volcano Choir. The four-song
column7: half-hour GIVING is their first new record since then
column8: and finds them saying hello to new fans while bidding goodbye to two outgoing members
column9: Mueller and pianist Thomas Wincek. It feels both triumphal and valedictory
column10: bypassing spacey tangents in favor of CCB's hard-charging live sound.

column1: Though GIVING may be an unusually eyes-on-the-prize record for CCB
column2: they still have more in common with questing
column3: omnivorous post-rock bands like Jaga Jazzist than with the single-minded crescendo hunters of the world. Variations of force and expression derive less from rhythmic and harmonic changes than from the accumulation and development of soulful ostinati
column4: woven in and out of freer
column5: more ""rock"" chord progressions. Though a guitar may occasionally break off for an expressive flight of fancy
column6: there's seldom a single musician carrying the moment-- instead
column7: they each lean into repetitive fragments that gradually coalesce into organic
column8: blossoming wholes. At the deepest level
column9: a collectivist honeycomb pattern prevails
column10: and the one-note lead seared across alternating bars of the crunchy climax of ""Vorm"" is the closest thing you'll hear to a killer solo.

column1: This is rock music that has come almost completely unstuck from the blues
column2: with a sleek
column3: relentless drive subbing in for swing. Mueller's almost motorik-style percussion sows accents in the intricate layers of pattern
column4: so that similar instrumental passages take on different feelings of loping
column5: staggering
column6: or soaring. Still
column7: it doesn't quite save the album from a somewhat monolithic quality
column8: which is clearly intentional but can be a trifle wearisome. ""Lawn"" is the obvious anthem; ""Vorm"" is bucolic and churning; ""Lawns"" is moodier; and ""Vorms"" is the rangy epic. These cosmetic adjustments to one hypnotically bruising ideal only go so far
column9: and if you're not in the mood to hear dudes being really stoked about their guitar playing
column10: it can make for a long half-hour. But all in all
column11:
it's an exciting victory lap for a band whose confidence is highly palpable in this hard-earned moment of high visibility.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16847/homepage_large.b5cf6552.jpg|Breaking the Frame|4004.0|Surgeon|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dynamic Tension']|2011-08-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:25.525155|"

Surgeon's DJ mix for Fabric was one of last year's finest
column2: in part because it was so furiously banging
column3: and in part because it captured so elegantly the current zeitgeist for the post-Jeff Mills school of hard-edged minimal techno. Scowling ferociously in the corner
column4: techno seems blessed by its own misanthropy: Never the crossover dance music of choice
column5: it's accorded a certain fearful level of respect and admiration regardless of what might be today's story and (inevitably) yesterday's news. (It's the perennial ""real shit"" for the cognoscenti with a more discerning understanding of the infinite shades of variety afforded by a stoically pummelling kick drum.)

column1: Techno seems to be ""back"" at the moment
column2: largely due the partial absorption of dubstep influences into its high-pressure bloodstream
column3: its lacerating percussive attack tending more toward syncopation and snare-heavy swing than in the bad old days of stentorian four-by-four pound. The shift is less one of wholesale transformation than a kind of magnetic realignment
column4: dubstep's clattering and clanking syncopation inspiring a reemphasis of those same qualities always already lurking in techno proper.

column1: Breaking the Frame
column2: the first new album from the British producer (real name Anthony Child) in a decade
column3: isn't nearly so gregarious: Surgeon's return to the artist full-length foregrounds the chilly austerity associated with the veteran producer's name throughout the late 1990s. Think of it as the Arctic cousin to the more passionate explosions of Surgeon's DJ mixes
column4: a series of twisted rock formations left behind by the frozen lava of a sweaty night out on the town. But for all that
column5: the album remains bang up to date
column6: with nearly every groove structured around the absent centre of a 4/4 kick drum
column7: that punishing pulsation eschewed in favour of either a halfstep lurch (""Transparent Radiation""
column8: ""Remover of Darkness"") or hectic breakbeat assault (""The Power of Doubt""
column9: ""Radiance""). Only on ""Those Who Do Not""-- by some distance the least memorable moment here-- does Surgeon succumb to the kick-drum's wearied trudge.

column1: Almost entirely devoid of anything you might call a tune
column2: Surgeon's productions nonetheless place a high premium on narrative development
column3: plunging from the surface of rigorous acid chugs to clattering rhythmic undercarriages to the rising panic of synthesiser chords so gracefully and organically that the effect is like a microscope training its gaze from the impenetrable solidity of skin to the frenetic molecular activity that secretly comprises it. One can describe these qualities endlessly and barely come closer to pinpointing what it is that makes Breaking the Frame so unexpectedly listenable for the uninitiated: For all that a tune like ""Radiance"" may sound like two continental shelfs grinding past one another
column4: for instance
column5: its forbidding assault is executed with a compositional neatness
column6: clarity
column7: and vibrance that seems to leap out of the speakers.

column1: Even more so
column2: the iridescent hum of ""Presence"" glowers and shudders with the compressed heat and intensity of an angry star in the moments before it collapses into a black hole. It's typical on an album whose structures throw shadows of bleak
column3: inhuman grandeur: Enormity
column4: rather than velocity
column5: defines the best work on Breaking the Frame
column6:
and there's a masochistic pleasure in being made to feel very small as you lose yourself on the dancefloor.

"|15720.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15720-breaking-the-frame/|7.2|Tim Finney

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16828/homepage_large.55a358df.jpg|Family of Love EP|28774.0|Dom|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Astralwerks']|2011-08-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:27.195397|"

At first glance
column2: Dom don't come across as particularly ambitious. During our Rising interview with the Worcester indie-pop outfit last year
column3: their eponymous frontman mentioned that one of the benefits of living in the Massachusetts town was the lax laws on weed possession. About a month later
column4: they put an ad on Craigslist for what essentially sounded like a band babysitter. In the year and a half leading up to Dom's second EP
column5: Family of Love
column6: they released their debut Sun Bronzed Greek Gods EP twice
column7: the most recent reissue coming from big-dog label Astralwerks. If you didn't get the idea from <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvdFnINlN6Q&feature=player_embedded"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the bratty
column8: debauched video for ""Living in America"" (again
column9: the second clip for the song in less than a year's time)
column10: the story about how Dom (the person
column11: and band frontman) got lost on tour while tripping on ecstasy should clue you in to how these guys like spending their time.

column1: So
column2: yeah
column3: not exactly the picture of industriousness
column4: these ones
column5: which also means Family of Love's brevity-- five songs in just under 17 minutes-- doesn't exactly encourage high expectations out of the gate. The real (and very welcome) shock
column6: then
column7: is how well-honed those five songs sound. This stuff is packed with detail
column8: both silly (the telephone keypad solo on ""Telephone"") and ambitious (""Damn""'s sea of golden guitar lines). A few songs bleed into each other
column9: like parts of a larger whole; the album's most straightforward synth-pop cut
column10: ""Happy Birthday Party""
column11: dissolves into rumpled noise and fluttering flutes towards its close. These are rich
column12: dense-sounding compositions.

column1: The element that makes Family of Love sound like the work of an almost entirely different band is the massive leap in production value. For all its pop acumen
column2: the stumbling point of the homespun Sun Bronzed Greek Gods EP was its scrappy
column3: waterlogged sound
column4: which emphasized the band's juvenile delinquencies at the expense of showcasing the songwriting. This time around
column5: Dom worked with reputed producer Nicholas Vernhes in his NYC-based Rare Book Room studio. His touch lends these slyly complicated pop confections the expansive treatment they clearly deserve
column6: turning the aqueous title track into a stretchy jam reminiscent of the sophistipop outfit Sea and Cake (a band that I would have never thought I'd compare Dom to
column7: but there you go). It's tantalizing to imagine how Dom's previous work would sound through this airy filter-- throwing on Sun Bronzed Greek Gods after listening to this one definitely does the former a disservice.

column1: The improved fidelity also helps with understanding the lyrics. ""Telephone"" turns a simple cellular connection into something between eroticism and euphoria (""I come alive when you pick up the line"")
column2: while ""Damn"" expounds on the malevolent self-centered attitude previously explored on ""Burn Bridges"". Potential suitors are tossed aside for the one that got away (and
column3: seemingly
column4: isn't coming back) in the balmy
column5: bar-piano jaunt ""Some Boys""
column6: which features fellow one-name guest vocalist Emma and works much better than the band's last tepid experiment with outside vocals
column7: ""Bowl Cut""
column8: with Cults' Madeline Follin. Most emotionally revealing
column9: though
column10: is the EP's floaty title track
column11: which eschews problems of the heart for sentiments on protection and safety through friendship. As is lore
column12: Dom's frontman grew up as an orphan and spent most of his adolescence bouncing around foster homes; ""Family of Love"" is the first time that he's let the sugary facade crack to reveal his own battered beginnings
column13: as well as his wish for a better
column14: more stable life.

column1: On the other end of the spectrum is ""Happy Birthday Party""
column2: a call back to the synth-pop glories of their previous work and a silly natal-fixated trifle that will most likely end up soundtracking an episode of iCarly in the near future. The song is goofy and sort of disposable (catchy as hell
column3: too)
column4: but it makes perfect sense
column5: since Dom are prone to acting out whenever they can. Living forever is a desire often explored in pop music; I'm not sure that the boys in Dom want to exist for eternity-- if they keep behaving the way that they allegedly do
column6:
they won't even come close-- but they're clearly set on making the most of their time while they're here.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16832/homepage_large.4923945b.jpg|Greneberg|29854.0|Greneberg|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Decon']|2011-08-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:27.753962|"

See if you can keep up here: Rapper/producer the Alchemist is a Beverly Hills native who started out in a teenage major-label rap group with Scott Caan and who has somehow gone on to become one of the most reliable producers of dusty
column2: bloodthirsty NYC crime-rap
column3: crafting things like Prodigy's masterful Return of the Mac album. Rapper/producer Oh No is the younger brother of California backpack-rap overlord Madlib and a restless stoner-rap mind in his own right; he's fond of crazy undertakings like releasing an entire album where he only samples Greek and Middle Eastern psych-pop. Together
column4: Alchemist and Oh No linked up last year to form a duo named Gangrene and to release the underrated Gutter Water album
column5: a dizzy pileup of broken-sounding samples and willfully disgusting sound-clips. Rapper/producer Roc Marciano
column6: meanwhile
column7: is a 1990s-era Queens holdover and a veteran of Busta Rhymes' Flipmode Squad. Last year
column8: he released the excellently dense and grimy self-produced solo album Marcberg
column9: a welcome reminder that there's still life in the old Carhart-and-Tims Mobb Deep model.

column1: On their own
column2: these guys are all cranking out impressive work that happily exists within a long
column3: proud backpack-rap lineage without ever really reaching toward larger audiences. And right now
column4: both Gangrene and Roc Marci are labelmates; all three guys are on Decon Records. So really
column5: it just makes sense to put all three together onto an EP
column6: letting them all rap over each other's beats and seeing what happens. Greneberg-- its title an amalgam of Gangrene and Marcberg-- is a jumbled pileup of three talented artists who all exist on the same wavelength. It's a split EP
column7: with Roc handling the first three tracks and Gangrene doing the next three. But it's also a collaboration
column8: as all these guys flit in and out of each other's tracks
column9: contributing beats or verses where needed.

column1: ""Don't give a fuck about the current direction of rap
column2: says Alchemist on ""Sewer Gravy""-- a bold statement from a guy who still works as Eminem's tour DJ. But the quote holds true
column3: since these guys basically combine to form their own aesthetic universe. In this trio's vision of rap
column4: choruses never need to show up
column5: and beats sputter and ripple as often as they thump. The production on Greneberg sounds like what might happen if you threw late-1960s soul and psych into a malfunctioning blender; it's a beguiling fog of horn-stabs and organ sighs and guitar flutters. It sounds chaotic
column6: and that's fine
column7: since the three rappers sound most at home in chaos of their own making.

column1: The EP works best when Roc Marciano is rapping; his threats pack a whole lot of lyrical inventiveness into a few terse
column2: sneery lines. On ""Jet Luggage"": ""Dress spiffy/ Finesse the Mac-11 out the Dickie/ Let off a dozen rounds into ya Crown Vicky."" On ""Momma Told Me"": ""My discography's godly/ Biters copy while I pull one out the crime rhyme glossary/ Before I pop your meat like Luca Brasi."" Oh No and Alchemist can't compete with that
column3: but they try
column4: and it's fun to hear their attempts. (Alc on ""New Shit"": ""Rockin' a jamboree
column5: Barry Manilow piano man/ Freely perform compositions randomly."") And even when the verses don't click
column6: it's worth it to hear all three producers push their vision of what rap is to its logical extreme. This is some hard
column7: dusty
column8: uncompromising underground rap
column9:
and there's always room for some of that.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Double Six']|2011-08-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:28.252079|"

Steve Mason is always in a state of transition. The Beta Band
column3: destined for both greatness and record sales
column4: found label trouble and wrote a white-boy rap so terrible that people remember it. They were constantly about to peak until they were obviously releasing post-peak albums. When Mason's post-Beta King Biscuit Time work (and his album as Black Affair) failed to catch on
column5: he disappeared and fans worried for his mental health. He was rumored to be in debt. His career
column6: his life even
column7: began to resemble his voice: wispy
column8: elusive
column9: sad.

column1: Last year's Boys Outside
column2: Mason's first album under his own name
column3: was the first Mason product to suggest stability. A blanched
column4: graceful folk-rock album
column5: it was placid like a heart trauma victim begged by his family to settle down for the good of his health. I mean this musically: Mason's track record on his most spastic work is spotty. He returns to this material on Ghosts Outside
column6: working with UK-based dub veteran Dennis Bovell (whose previous production credits include Mason-friendly touchstones like the Pop Group and Orange Juice) to re-work Boys Outside's 10 tracks into classically echoing dub pop.

column1: Anyone waiting for a playful
column2: Mason-esque twist can stop. Ghosts Outside is a sober
column3: catholic dub remix album: one new mix for each track
column4: re-branded with a ""dub"" title (e.g. ""Hound on My Heel"" is now ""Dub on My Heel""
column5: ""Am I Just a Man"" now ""Dub I Just a Man""). Mason was one of the late-90s pop chameleons
column6: so he's no stranger to Reggae and dub music (a personal favorite)
column7: but Ghosts Outside represents the first time he has lain himself prostrate before a genre. Possibly in deference to Bovell
column8: possibly because Ghosts Outside is an exercise as much as it is an album
column9: Mason has no interest in coloring outside the lines.

column1: Still
column2: there are gains to be had. Dub is the rare technique that feels both transgressive and cliché
column3: and it fills both roles here. Bovell scatters Mason's vocals
column4: which untether his songs in interesting ways. ""The Letter""
column5: so deliberate in Mason's hands
column6: stalks aimlessly under Bovell
column7: its chorus suddenly ascendant. Bovell's treatments cause the song structures to dissipate but stratify the productions
column8: providing layers through which Mason's voice filters (a crucial function of the best Beta Band compositions). The robust horn charts of ""Lost and Dub"" and especially ""Yesterday Dub"" swallow Mason whole and provide a rigid counterpoint to his gummy croon. While I wish Mason and Bovell had found a way to do this without resorting to the trope-iest of dub tropes-- chirpy guitar chords
column9: reflective drums
column10: pliable basslines-- the effect is
column11: at times
column12: enlightening.

column1: The Mason Fan Club (we meet Wednesdays at 7; dues are collected quarterly) will want this. It is novel
column2: in its way: Mason
column3: who once seemed capable of inventing a new genre with each track
column4: reverently bowed before dub reggae
column5: a staple fetish of Western European pop (see also: Serge Gainsbourg
column6: the Clash
column7: the Police). You're forgiven if you find the idea underwhelming
column8: but it wasn't so long ago that the prospect of any new Mason material seemed doubtful. He's returned
column9: calmer
column10: still exploring
column11:
but doing so carefully.

The liner notes to this reissue of hippie harpist Carol Kleyn's 1976 debut would make a great period film
column2: perhaps with Zoe Kazan in the lead. In prose that evokes a sense of discovery and excitement
column3: Kleyn describes her introduction to the counterculture as a freshman at UC Santa Barbara
column4: where she wrote songs for her poetry class before dropping out to concentrate on music full-time. Kleyn shacked up with one-man psychedelic band Bobby Brown
column5: who brought her a harp for her birthday one year. Rather than take lessons at the university
column6: she taught herself to play the instrument and promised to perform her own songs exclusively. Soon she was lugging that harp-- which was nearly as big as she was-- in and out of buses
column7: down streets and alleyways
column8: and across fields to busk for passersby at street corners
column9: community fairs
column10: and Renaissance festivals all over California.

column1: This musical coming-of-age story eventually becomes a Zelig-style romp through 1970s pop culture
column2: as Kleyn toured with Gregg Allman and hobnobbed with the Eagles
column3: Frank Sinatra
column4: Liza Minelli
column5: and Sly Stone
column6: among many other contemporaries. She came close to signing with a label
column7: specifically Allman home base Capricorn
column8: but instead she released three self-funded albums on her own. Rather than achieve success as defined by the music industry
column9: Kleyn went on to become a legend among crate diggers and harp-folk enthusiasts. The twist ending: Reading these liner notes
column10: it's clear Kleyn prefers her relative anonymity to anything else that might have been.

column1: The epilogue: More than three decades after self-releasing her debut
column2: Kleyn signed her first record deal with Drag City
column3: which means she now shares a label with that other indie harpist
column4: Joanna Newsom. Kleyn's first proper release is this reissue of Love Has Made Me Stronger
column5: a collection of original songs that translate strummed hippie folk music to the plucks and glissandi of the harp. It's a product of its time and place
column6: made by a social and musical free spirit who gently tested the strictures of West Coast pop music not only in her choice of instrument but also in her relentlessly sunny disposition. This is the sort of album you might identify with Laurel Canyon in the late 60s
column7: not with the post-Watergate bicentennial.

column2: that mountain child sensibility may seem a little naïve
column3: especially when Kleyn sings
column4: ""Come on
column5: let's sing the world a love song
column6: on ""Blackbird""
column7: before performing a hiccupping imitation of birdsong. And yet
column8: that performance-- which sounds like Buddy Holly at a commune-- is so whimsical as to be both endearing and commanding. Love Has Made Me Stronger is fascinating as a pop artifact that's more extroverted than Vashti Bunyan's Just Another Diamond Day and more insular than Judee Sill's Heart Food
column9: but its true impact derives from the sheer force of Kleyn's personality
column10: which makes hippie cheer feel brave.

column1: Kleyn displays an intriguing cross section of styles and influences
column2: a range that ostensibly results from her being self-taught. She strums and picks her harp like a guitar on ""Baby Come Close"" and ""Love's Goin' Round""
column3: and on ""Street Song""
column4: she plays the instrument almost like a dulcimer
column5: percussively plucking countermelodies that sound both tender and slightly foreboding. When Kleyn trades the harp for keys on the album's second half
column6: however
column7: she loses some of what makes her distinctive. On songs like ""Well Glory Be"" and ""You Know I Love You""
column8: Kleyn's keyboard playing is more rudimentary than inventive
column9: more technically constrained than artistically free. More often
column10: though
column11:
Love Has Made Me Stronger's rough-around-the-edges imperfections only allow Kleyn to convey her spirited optimism all the more forcefully. That sort of music boldness never goes out of style.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16844/homepage_large.30a45822.jpg|Cult of Youth|29401.0|Cult of Youth|['Folk/Country'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2011-08-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:29.381146|"

Cult of Youth's eponymous LP is the group's second full-length
column3: but it might be better (especially for newcomers) to treat it as a debut.  For one
column4: it's their first album as an honest-to-goodness group: previous Cult of Youth recordings (including the official full-length debut
column5: Dais Records' <i>A Stick to Bind
column6: a Seed to Grow
column7: currently out-of-print) were exclusively the work of frontman Sean Ragon.  On these earlier works
column8: Ragon didn't invite comparisons to neofolk progenitors like Death in June and Current 93 so much as demand them. The combination of Ragon's strident and sepulchral vocals -- which could bear a striking resemblance to those of Swans' Michael Gira-- with vigorously-strummed acoustic guitars and semi-industrial backing beats often made for an arresting experience
column9: but even those attuned to Ragon's particular wavelength might find the original version of Cult of Youth hard to take for more than a few songs at a time.

column1: The four-person configuration presented on Cult of Youth goes a long way toward smoothing over those rough edges. During the album's first few tracks
column2: it sounds like Ragon's simply found a way to successfully translate his previous work to a full-band setting.  As the album progresses
column3: though
column4: it becomes clearer that this version of Cult of Youth (with the help of producer Chris Coady) has taken on an air associated with that small bundle of first-wave post-punk groups who opted to account for more rustic musics within their angles: think pre-Breakfast Club Simple Minds and (especially on ""Through the Fear"") or ""Cattle and Cane""-era Go-Betweens. Replace Ragon's indomitable vocal presence on a song like ""Casting Thorns"" or ""Weary"" with a more soothing presence-- Marissa Nadler or Alela Diane
column5: for example-- and you might think those songwriters were the ones responsible for writing the track.

column1: The updated
column2: re-recorded version of A Stick to Bind track ""Cold Black Earth"" provides a perfect contrast between Cult of Youth's past and present. Originally
column3: the song featured a multi-tracked Ragon bellowing the would-be anthem in a stiff and martial fashion
column4: accompanied only by guitar and bass.  On the new album
column5: the track is given a propulsive rolling drum beat
column6: which inspires Ragon (now singing by himself) to speed up his pace and lighten his touch. The addition of well-placed violin flurries (courtesy of Zola Jesus string arranger/full-time Cult member Christiana Key) also helps
column7: turning a lugubrious dirge into something much more spry and palatable.  However
column8: those afraid Ragon has lost his edge amidst these more flattering surroundings don't need to worry:  If anything
column9: as his unhinged performances on ""The Dead Sea"" and ""Weary"" illustrate
column10:
he's more willing to risk absurdity as a vocalist now that he has a more robust musical backing to soften the blows. That goes double for Ragon and friends as musicians: It's hard to not listen to the band take the ""The Lamb"" from its modest acoustic introduction to its expansive semi-psychedelic end and think of what Cult of Youth could accomplish once they reconvene to make their second album.
