Pulp's announcement of a reunion and return to touring in late 2010 told two lies: first
column2: that it was the original lineup reuniting
column3: and second that they'd be playing songs from every era of the band's career. The current sextet is nowhere close to the original lineup-- 22 other people had to come and go before that group solidified. The setlists from the reunion shows haven't dipped back before 1992. This version of events sets up a narrative that has Pulp arriving fully formed with their last single for Fire Records
column4: 1992's ""Countdown""
column5: and conquering the charts in short order. It glosses over the longer
column6: much more interesting story of the band's origins and lurching path to fame.

column1: I'm not saying Pulp ought to be playing songs from their early days in their current shows
column2: and I'm definitely not saying they should have gotten the real original lineup back together
column3: but it seems odd to position the reunion as they have-- it has the effect of disowning the fits and starts of their awkward stage. Perhaps that's their intention
column4: but the band's ignored history won't exactly be buried
column5: because Fire's reissued all of it. The music Pulp made from 1983 to 1992 is in no way on the level of the music they made after that
column6: but you can hear all the seeds of His 'N' Hers and Different Class dropping into place
column7: even as the band digresses and fails.

column1: Pulp were formed by Jarvis Cocker and his friend Peter Dalton at the City School in Sheffield in 1978
column2: when the two were in their teens. Dalton was still in the group three years later
column3: when they cut their first Peel Session
column4: a four-song set that shows them torn between hard-edged post-punk and New Wave. Dalton's father forced him to leave the band (he threw a plate of food at him and told him he had to go to university)
column5: and by the time Cocker got them signed to Red Rhino and back in the studio
column6: it was 1983 and the band had completely turned over
column7: apart from its gawky front man and drummer Wayne Furniss. The album this version of Pulp recorded
column8: It
column9: almost completely abandons the sound of that first Peel Session in favor of a folkier setup and a generally cheerful disposition.

column1: The first thing anyone familiar with classic
column2: 90s Pulp will probably notice while listening to It is that Cocker hadn't yet developed his stage persona. There's no hint of the lasciviousness
column3: class awareness
column4: or cultural appetite that defined his best-known work. As a vocalist
column5: he's adequate but not yet himself as we know him-- basically
column6: he sounds like he listened to the Chameleons a lot. That in mind
column7: It is a nice indie pop record
column8: but the songwriting seams show. For instance
column9: the waltzing ""Joking Aside"" finds him stretching out certain words awkwardly to make the melody more interesting-- it just sounds odd. ""My Lighthouse""
column10: on the other hand
column11: is pretty accomplished
column12: and its turns of phrase point toward what lay ahead. On release
column13: It sank without a trace
column14: but Cocker soldiered on
column15: getting the band signed to Fire Records. Keyboardist Candida Doyle and guitarist/violinist Russell Senior both joined
column16: putting in place part of the classic 90s lineup of the band.

column1: On the recordings from 1985 to 1988
column2: you can hear Pulp figuring out the kind of band it wants to be. Freaks
column3: the album they released in 1987
column4: is a 180-degree turn from the happy pastoralism of It
column5: and the pair of EPs and two non-album B-sides gathered on the reissue's bonus disc (which has almost the same track selection as the mid-90s compilation Masters of the Universe) move similarly into the dark. In some ways Cocker seems less certain of the kind of singer he'd like to be than on It. Senior takes lead vocals twice on Freaks and once on a B-side
column6: while Cocker wavers between developing his own identity
column7: imitating Ian Curtis
column8: and trying to beat Mark E. Smith at his own game. He sometimes does this a bit tunelessly.

column1: Still
column2: though most of these directions were best abandoned
column3: this is an immensely interesting period for the band
column4: and often an entertaining one. Senior's lead on Freaks opener ""Fairground"" is hilariously demonic
column5: and the band builds a carnival atmosphere around his maniacal laughing. Cocker's unsteady grip on the key of ""Being Followed Home"" is actually an asset
column6: as his flat singing intensifies the paranoia of the lyrics. Getting in key a little more strongly could have made ""I Want You"" Pulp's first big pop moment-- I'd love to hear him sing it today. His Ian Curtis impression on ""Master of the Universe"" is a little painful
column7: but Cocker and the band very nearly equal the Fall at their own game on the eight-minute B-side ""Tunnel"". This material may be uneven
column8: but it points to a band growing more confident and willing to take risks.

column1: The failure of Freaks and its satellite singles prompted Cocker to move to London to study film and very nearly ended the band
column2: but he connected with bassist and fan Steve Mackey in London
column3: and Pulp reconvened with the lineup that would finally put them over the top. Mackey's interest in house music rubbed off on Cocker and proved decisive to the sound of their next LP. Separations was recorded between 1989 and 1991 but not released until 1992. In the meantime
column4: two of its songs
column5: ""My Legendary Girlfriend"" and ""Countdown""
column6: had been released as singles
column7: and these afforded them their first significant critical and commercial traction.

column1: The first half of Separations frankly sounds like songs the band would have placed on B-sides just two years later-- the sound and feel are there but the tunes largely aren't. Side two
column2: though
column3: is Pulp's long-awaited artistic breakthrough. It begins with ""Countdown""
column4: the band's first full-on foray into disco (or something like it) and also the first prolonged glimpse we get of Cocker at his sexed-up and observational best. ""My Legendary Girlfriend""
column5: which NME made its Single of the Week in early 1991
column6: is even better
column7: foreshadowing the acidic whispered monologues of ""I Spy"" in its icy verses. In four songs (and a couple of bonus B-sides)
column8: we hear Pulp reinventing themselves as the band that made His 'N' Hers and Different Class. In spite of its lack of consistency
column9: the LP is worth hearing by fans for that alone.

column1: Given that the band is almost entirely ignoring these records in its current reunion
column2: now is as good a time as any to revisit them (or visit  them for the first time
column3: as the case may be). They are each flawed in  different ways
column4: but at the very end of the chronology the  classic Pulp-- the Pulp the band prefers to remember-- emerges
column5:
glistening.

column4: or cultural appetite that defined his best-known work. As a vocalist
column5: he's adequate but not yet himself as we know him-- basically

column7: It is a nice indie pop record
column8: but the songwriting seams show. For instance
column9: the waltzing ""Joking Aside"" finds him stretching out certain words awkwardly to make the melody more interesting-- it just sounds odd. ""My Lighthouse""
column10: on the other hand
column11: is pretty accomplished
column12: and its turns of phrase point toward what lay ahead. On release
column13: It sank without a trace
column14: but Cocker soldiered on
column15: getting the band signed to Fire Records. Keyboardist Candida Doyle and guitarist/violinist Russell Senior both joined
column16: putting in place part of the classic 90s lineup of the band.

column1: On the recordings from 1985 to 1988
column2: you can hear Pulp figuring out the kind of band it wants to be. Freaks
column3: the album they released in 1987
column4: is a 180-degree turn from the happy pastoralism of It
column5: and the pair of EPs and two non-album B-sides gathered on the reissue's bonus disc (which has almost the same track selection as the mid-90s compilation Masters of the Universe) move similarly into the dark. In some ways Cocker seems less certain of the kind of singer he'd like to be than on It. Senior takes lead vocals twice on Freaks and once on a B-side
column6: while Cocker wavers between developing his own identity
column7: imitating Ian Curtis
column8: and trying to beat Mark E. Smith at his own game. He sometimes does this a bit tunelessly.

column1: Still
column2: though most of these directions were best abandoned
column3: this is an immensely interesting period for the band
column4: and often an entertaining one. Senior's lead on Freaks opener ""Fairground"" is hilariously demonic
column5: and the band builds a carnival atmosphere around his maniacal laughing. Cocker's unsteady grip on the key of ""Being Followed Home"" is actually an asset
column6: as his flat singing intensifies the paranoia of the lyrics. Getting in key a little more strongly could have made ""I Want You"" Pulp's first big pop moment-- I'd love to hear him sing it today. His Ian Curtis impression on ""Master of the Universe"" is a little painful
column7: but Cocker and the band very nearly equal the Fall at their own game on the eight-minute B-side ""Tunnel"". This material may be uneven
column8: but it points to a band growing more confident and willing to take risks.

column1: The failure of Freaks and its satellite singles prompted Cocker to move to London to study film and very nearly ended the band
column2: but he connected with bassist and fan Steve Mackey in London
column3: and Pulp reconvened with the lineup that would finally put them over the top. Mackey's interest in house music rubbed off on Cocker and proved decisive to the sound of their next LP. Separations was recorded between 1989 and 1991 but not released until 1992. In the meantime
column4: two of its songs
column5: ""My Legendary Girlfriend"" and ""Countdown""
column6: had been released as singles
column7: and these afforded them their first significant critical and commercial traction.

column1: The first half of Separations frankly sounds like songs the band would have placed on B-sides just two years later-- the sound and feel are there but the tunes largely aren't. Side two
column2: though
column3: is Pulp's long-awaited artistic breakthrough. It begins with ""Countdown""
column4: the band's first full-on foray into disco (or something like it) and also the first prolonged glimpse we get of Cocker at his sexed-up and observational best. ""My Legendary Girlfriend""
column5: which NME made its Single of the Week in early 1991
column6: is even better
column7: foreshadowing the acidic whispered monologues of ""I Spy"" in its icy verses. In four songs (and a couple of bonus B-sides)
column8: we hear Pulp reinventing themselves as the band that made His 'N' Hers and Different Class. In spite of its lack of consistency
column9: the LP is worth hearing by fans for that alone.

column1: Given that the band is almost entirely ignoring these records in its current reunion
column2: now is as good a time as any to revisit them (or visit  them for the first time
column3: as the case may be). They are each flawed in  different ways
column4: but at the very end of the chronology the  classic Pulp-- the Pulp the band prefers to remember-- emerges
column5:
glistening.

column11: and well-considered Buckner album in the last decade

column9: organs
column10: electric guitars
column11: electronics

column8: Buckner sings

column10: Our Blood seems to be an album about making better decisions in adulthood-- learning how to hold a job that doesn't hold you down
column11: discovering how not to let bad friends and bar rooms ruin your life
column12: realizing that the best days deliver something you'd never even considered. Buckner's voice feels experienced and empathetic
column13: then
column14: like a knowing pat on the back from a parent or an old friend that recognizes weakness yet pushes you ahead. He sings of ""shaking in the coldest hours
column15: ""forgetting to forgive
column16: and being ""caught in the lights
column17: left again
column18: like a veteran or a guide.

column3: impressionistic writing style demands that most of those 37 minutes be heard
column4: studied
column5: and reconsidered. After all

column15: too young to fall."" They're the kinds of phrases that cause the listener to pause mid-song
column16:
the rest of it flying by before a meaning's been teased out. These songs store well more than a half-hour of reward and intrigue-- appropriate enough for a record that had to be made three times.

For the past few years

column1: Ever since his old crew Roll Deep first flirted with the UK Top Ten in 2005

is still the one to get.

column6: in the case of his slight trembles of ""Santa Fe"" and ""Goshen""

column9: not too long ago

column13: he's a commanding presence

column1: Despite Condon's clear development

column3: clocking in at just over 33 minutes)

column1: The good-natured piggybacking coheres into a unified and direct whole. In fact
column2: while at times these tracks feel like extraterrestrial Neil Young ballads
column3: the most gratifying thing about Trouble Books is how completely immersive it is
column4: especially album centerpiece ""Local Forecast"". A play on ""Forecast"" and ""Extended Forecast"" from McGuire's 2009 record A Pocket Full of Rain
column5: the track exemplifies how even the most crowded McGuire/Trouble Books composition is still an exercise in transfixing clarity.

column1: Both Freund and Lejsovka sing on nearly every cut here
column2: and while their calm
column3: flat vocals may prove a little too distracting for some
column4: they help reinforce the album's lackadaisical
column5: daydream-like feel. Their vague
column6: oddly graceful observations can be simplistic
column7: but they provide a nice contrast to the sheer lushness of the music. Trouble Books brings together people who have an unusual knack for finishing each other's thoughts
column8:
and the result is an uncompromisingly pretty record.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16840/homepage_large.adcf1634.jpg|You Were a Dick|2074.0|Idaho|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Idaho Music'
column2: 'Talitres'
column4: Jeff Martin sings at the beginning of You Were a Dick
column5: ""that I disappear like that."" He turns out to be addressing a photo of an old acquaintance on a computer screen
column6: but those words also serve to extend an olive branch to his fans. It's been six years since The Lone Gunman
column7: a somewhat out-of-character record heavy on cinematic instrumentals. A whole decade has passed since Levitate
column8: the last Idaho album to feature the kind of slowcore they helped to define alongside bands like Low and Red House Painters. Between Martin's journeyman status and his quiet recent years
column9: you wouldn't be surprised to find him in an aimless experimental phase by now. But instead
column10: this charming comeback sounds like the work of a guy who knows exactly what he's good at doing.

column1: Jeff Martin and John Berry were in high school when they formed Idaho in 1992
column2: and they soon issued their Caroline Records debut
column3: the dark and baleful Year After Year. Over the ensuing decades
column4: Idaho began to release their own records
column5: and the lineup shifted around the stable center of Martin
column6: who now goes it alone. While the laidback cadence and emotively minimalist instrumentation of You Were a Dick are vintage Idaho
column7: Martin's angst has mellowed into a pensive melancholy with a wry twist. His vocals radiate a welcoming warmth
column8: with just enough coarseness not to float away. No longer straining against high notes
column9: he sings right into the grain of his natural voice
column10: which fits the gentle recriminations and consolations of his lyrics perfectly.

column1: The music comes over as tiny and detailed. Most songs are structured around supple webs of cleanly chiming and pedal-sculpted guitars
column2: or simple piano phrases
column3: lightly dressed in electronic keyboards. But Martin draws many different aspects out of these common elements
column4: from the ramshackle elegance of ""Reminder"" to the soft pastoral glow of ""Structure"". On the title track
column5: what sounds like an EBow misplaced on a fret sends a shimmering buzz coursing through one of the guitar parts
column6: imbuing its clockwork regularity with something a little nervous and wild. Martin is known for using custom tenor guitars
column7: and in this spare context
column8: those four strings resound like a miniature orchestra. He really lets us hear how his fingers move
column9: with impulsive shifts in phrasing and inflection. The unique
column10: unreplicable emotional character of each note and the snowflake-like differences between similar chords shine out in high definition.

column1: These little loose threads keep the soothing vibe from getting monotonous
column2: as do periodic wake-up calls like the quick-and-dirty instrumental ""Impaler"" and the booming pop-punk of ""The Space Between"". Thanks to the internal consistency of Martin's time-honed tone
column3: the mystical Neil Young-ish folk of ""Someone to Relate To"" can sit comfortably next to a shaggy anthem like ""Up the Hill"". Again
column4: he knows what he's good at. But even more importantly-- judging from this familiar yet fresh return to form-- he still believes in it
column5:
too.

Past recordings by the Advisory Circle sometimes felt like long-lost Cold War transmissions held in reserve in case the British government needed a reason to assure the general public that everything was okay. Jon Brooks
column2: who has functioned under this moniker since the mini-album Mind How You Go in 2005
column3: plugged into the fear and paranoia induced by such declarations. If you feel the need to assure people that everything is alright
column4: they're going to wonder what caused you to tell them that in the first place. Or
column5: as Brooks put it in an interview: ""Everything's fine
column6: but there is something not quite right about it."" Brooks is obsessed with the government-sponsored enmity that flows through many of the public information films (PIFs) Britain produced in the 1970s and 1980s
column7: often recreating the stern
column8: authoritarian tones of their announcers at certain points in his albums. As the Crow Flies
column9: his third record as the Advisory Circle
column10: also begins that way
column11: with a female voice claiming: ""The Advisory Circle. We make the decisions so you don't have to.""

column1: Another album modeled on such austerity might feel like Brooks was over-egging an idea that partially helped inspire the hauntology sub-genre. So instead he's slowly evolved the Advisory Circle sound
column2: bringing in acoustic instrumentation to supplement the banks of old analog equipment that remain his primary source tools. This pushes As the Crow Flies a little closer to the kind of darkly pastoral electronic work Boards of Canada were tinkering with on Geogaddi. But this has more conceptual weight than that record
column3: with Brooks concocting a series of songs inspired by the dueling qualities of stasis and change that cycle through the changing of the seasons. It's even got some wonderfully apt sleeve notes by Ronald Hutton
column4: the head of History at Bristol University
column5: who points out the various merits of seasonal festivals in Britain. Like most Ghost Box releases
column6: the attention to detail is impressive
column7: with designer Julian House completing the package via a series of images of an imagined TV title sequence
column8: aimed at dredging up damaged memories of barely remembered children's dramas from yesteryear.

column1: On listening to As the Crow Flies it's easy to picture Brooks fully taking to his task. You can almost see him clad in a thick wool sweater
column2: watching the droplets of snow amassing on his window frame as he prods at an old synthesizer during the wintery ""Now Ends the Beginning"". On the sci-fi fantasy ""Learning Owl Reappears"" it feels like he's been gazing up to a star-filled sky through a telescope on a long autumnal evening to find inspiration. This is a less foreboding record than prior Advisory Circle outings
column3: but it's no less sad. ""The Patchwork Explains"" might be one of Brooks' most impressive pieces yet
column4: with its icy synth tendrils spiking away at a plodding Kraftwerkian throb
column5: somehow managing to be both playful and quietly beautiful. That it's dedicated to the memory of Broadcast singer Trish Keenan couldn't be more appropriate
column6: reflecting her group's sense of wonder and love of offbeat pop.

column1: Brooks carefully varies the character of the album as it progresses
column2: nudging the listener down a subtly shifting stylistic gradient that takes in a Renaissance era lament (""Ceridwen"")
column3: steely Europop with prog intonations (""Modern Through Movement"")
column4: and a lone vocal venture reminiscent in mood of Air's underrated 10
column5: 000 Hz Legend (""Lonely Signalman""). It's evocative
column6: touching
column7: and nostalgic
column8: with the simple keyboard melodies often making it feel like this is all being experienced by a child blinking in bewilderment and amazement as the concept of the natural world is explained to them. But mostly there's a strong sense of discovery
column9: of someone attempting to make sense of their surroundings
column10: with Brooks cast as a voyager trampling through vast stretches of the British countryside
column11:
crisp leaves crinkling underfoot as he expertly funnels everything he sees and feels into song.

The world of fashion is marked by endless new trends rapidly becoming obsolete
column5: then cycling around again-- that's why it's called fashion. Operating a music label like a fashion line is a dicey proposition-- for every success at merging the two worlds (Fischerspooner
column6: Gaga
column7: Urban Outfitters
column8: Odd Future)
column9: there are infinitely more unmemorable attempts. One way to succeed is to stamp your brand on a ton of different things
column10: and count on the fact that the value accrued by the very good outweighs the hits you take from the bad. That's been Kitsuné's goal
column11: it seems
column12: since opening for business in 2002. For a brief minute last decade
column13: it seemed that the label that packaged its first compilation with a pasta recipe was actually going to win the big-club dance music sweepstakes through sheer number of releases alone-- James Murphy
column14: remember
column15: was losing his edge to ""the kids from France""-- but their batting average quickly dipped. By 2007
column16: Pitchfork's Tim Finney could claim the label had experienced ""a meteorite fall-from-grace.""

column1: Which brings us to 2011
column2: and Kitsuné's latest attempt to merge the worlds of dance and rock music with London trio Is Tropical. They certainly lean more toward style than substance-- they wear bags over their head in promo photos
column3: their band name and debut album title both sound like they were clipped from the middle of sentences in fashion magazines-- but that doesn't mean there's nothing to like on Native To. Like so many of the incalculable number of beachy New Order re-orderings that've cropped up over the past couple of decades
column4: the album packs a bit of catchy disco slickness (""Lies"")
column5: more than a few moments that would work well as jingles for travel adverts (opener ""South Pacific"")
column6: and approximations of moody
column7: guitar-heavy Brit rock (""Oranges"").

column1: While current American indie artists prefer their surf-and-sand music to echo vague
column2: blurry memories of hitting the beach
column3: Is Tropical aim to pack dancefloors. It's certainly easy to imagine them becoming the next Big UK Band
column4: as well
column5: playing festival gigs and massive club dates and making a fairly good living at it for a few years-- many worse things have happened. ""I'll Take My Chances"" may be a straightforward ditty about going for it with a girl
column6: but it holds the best statement of purpose for the band's M.O. of keeping their music uncluttered and uncomplicated: ""Any idiot knows that simplicity wins."" Indeed
column7: Native To is packed with well-executed
column8: hummable stuff
column9: but it wears thin quickly. To use a style comparison
column10: it's like buying clothes from discount Euro-style mall retailer H&M: They look great on the rack
column11:
but you're lucky if they last you through the season.

Will Oldham has already released several singles and EPs this year with different collaborators and all in different styles. Like Bill Callahan-- another artist who came out of Drag City's mid-1990s bumper crop-- Oldham makes music that implies intimacy while evoking so many personalities that an overview of his work is more like a cubist painting than a candid photograph.

column1: He's worked at this pace for nearly 20 years now
column2: and what's amazing isn't that he's managed to maintain consistency
column3: but that he's made inconsistency part of his artistic identity. In the past two years
column4: he's worked with David Byrne on film scores and remixed Hot Chip. He starred in a short film that made it to Sundance (Pioneer) and made a brief appearance in Jackass 3D alongside a gorilla. Even when his records arguably don't turn out well-- like the Tortoise-assisted covers album The Bold and the Brave or Greatest Palace Music
column5: where he gave high-gloss treatments to his earliest
column6: most rustic material-- the point is that Oldham threw out his ego and recorded them anyway.

column1: But an artist's generosity can be a fan's chore
column2: and a lot of Oldham's releases end up being markers of time more than anything else. Of his recent offerings
column3: ""There Is No God"" b/w ""God Is Love""
column4: released as a benefit for two Gulf-oriented charities
column5: Save Our Gulf and the Turtle Hospital
column6: is most in line with what Oldham has done well in the past few years: Joyful
column7: barefoot Americana at some unfixed intersection between folk and rock. Oldham's last two solo full-lengths (2009's Beware and 2008's Lie Down in the Light) are clever and diverse
column8: working with sounds so familiar that the music's idiosyncrasies-- a bizarre key change
column9: a clarinet or flute solo
column10: a few extra bars of a verse where a more traditional song would've moved to the chorus-- melt into the overall impression of the music. It's an approach that Oldham has probably absorbed from country
column11: a genre with enough clearly delineated rules that the fun part becomes how to bend or break them without becoming something unrecognizable: The innovation is in the craft
column12: not the concept.

column1: ""Must Be Blind"" and ""Live in Muscle"" are two songs Oldham wrote with Matt Sweeney
column2: the former Chavez singer he last collaborated with on 2005's Superwolf album. Musically
column3: they're more stoic and musky than ""There Is No God""-- an influence of Sweeney's that brings out the fist-on-chest Appalachian Oldham explored on 1999's I See a Darkness
column4: still probably his best-known album. There are Will Oldhams for every occasion; this is the Oldham to bring out when riding alone in the frozen fields before dawn or burying your first-born in the rocky plot behind the outhouse. Personally
column5: I prefer the shroom-eating
column6: big-grinned porchsitter he's become in the past few years
column7: but his sobriety is tense and convincing
column8: and probably the mood people associate him with the most.

column1: The Mindeater is the most atypical thing he's released this year in part because he gave up musical control to the Phantom Famliy Halo
column2: a psych band formerly based in Louisville
column3: Kentucky
column4: where Oldham is from and has lived for most of his life. Three of the four songs are woozy and minimally arranged; one-- a cover of the Everly Brothers' ""I Wonder If I Care as Much"" featuring Slint's Todd Brashear-- becomes a an archetypal hard-rock jam dominated by Dominic Cipolla's electric guitar about two minutes into it. The recording of Oldham's voice sounds thin and grainy by design
column5: which is a shame because of how full and expressive it's become over the past five or so years. In general
column6: it's not a bad release
column7: just one that doesn't play to his strengths-- or
column8: at least not strengths he's developed so far. Still
column9: when I started following Oldham's music after buying Palace's Lost Blues and Other Songs around 1997
column10: I wouldn't have expected him to become as polished and celebratory as he is now-- some evidence that if there are roles he doesn't convincingly fill
column11:
it might just be a matter of time and a few more loose collaborations before he figures them out.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16830/homepage_large.3b0622c6.jpg|"Plays ""High Gospel"""|29658.0|Efrim Manuel Menuck|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2011-08-05 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:38.081024|"

There were a lot of peculiar things about the recent Godspeed You! Black Emperor reunion: the unexpected
column2: out-of-nowhere timing of it; the uncannily ageless
column3: I-can't-believe-it's-not-2000 quality of the band's performances; the inclusion of ""Weird"" Al Yankovic on their curated All Tomorrow's Parties bill. But perhaps the strangest thing was seeing Efrim Menuck recede back into the role of silent
column4: anonymous
column5: ensemble player. More than any other member associated with the Montreal orchestro-rock collective
column6: Menuck has spent much of the past decade deconstructing the mythology and challenging the assumptions surrounding Godspeed (take your pick: they're anarchists; anti-social; humorless; Luddites; squat-dwellers; etc.). Not only has Menuck's offshoot band Thee Silver Mt. Zion emerged over the past decade as a lyrically direct
column7: increasingly aggressive rock band
column8: Menuck has both made himself more readily available to the press and
column9: in concert
column10: become a rather hilarious stage banterist.

column1: So perhaps it's no mere coincidence that Menuck's re-immersion into the Godspeed regimen coincides with the appearance of his first solo album
column2: Plays ""High Gospel""
column3: a record that
column4: in spirit if not sound
column5: recalls another solo album released in the shadow of a monolith: John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band. Both albums are consumed by matters of love
column6: loss
column7: abandonment by maternal figures
column8: and spirituality; both showcase the respective artists at their somberly tender and uncompromisingly abrasive extremes; and both are emotionally raw
column9: deeply personal works greatly distinguished from the bands that earned their makers renown. (And
column10: come to think of it
column11: Menuck's wiry wail of a voice is pitched about halfway between Lennon's elocution and Yoko's anarchic shriek.)

column1: If Plastic Ono Band's psychic terrain was mapped out by the death of Lennon's mother and his blossoming romance with Yoko
column2: on ""High Gospel""
column3: the emotional goal posts are set by the birth of Menuck's son and the 2009 suicide of his friend/collaborator Vic Chesnutt. And as to be expected from a record recorded over two years in (according to Menuck) ""scraps and hiccups
column4: the song-to-song shifts in mood can be disarmingly severe
column5: moving from the churchly organ tones
column6: defiantly celebratory choral vocal
column7: and synth starbursts of opener ""Our Lady of Parc Extension and Her Munificent Sorrows"" to the frosty
column8: electronic chill of ""A 12 Pt. Program For Keep on Keepin' On""
column9: which sounds like a séance conducted via shortwave radio
column10: with a cacophonous
column11: click-tracked surge of percussion intensifying the feel of impending doom.

column1: However
column2: as ""High Gospel"" plays out
column3: such jarring transitions seem to be less the result of random
column4: grab-bag sequencing and more a manifestation of the album's central theme: that moments of joy and sorrow often come without warning and
column5: in some cases
column6: are triggered by one another. The beautifully desolate piano ballad ""Heavy Calls & Hospital Blues"" presents a peaceful portrait of a sleeping child that's shattered by an ominous late-night call from the infirmary
column7: while the mantric
column8: ecstatic closer ""I Am No Longer a Motherless Child"" works the other way
column9: as Menuck comes to terms with the pain of losing a parent by becoming one himself.

column1: But it's the seven-minute centerpiece ""Kaddish for Chesnutt"" that best exemplifies ""High Gospel""'s attempt to reconcile happiness and sadness
column2: confusion and comfort
column3: living and dying. Menuck has obliquely referenced his Jewish roots in the past
column4: from the ""Mt. Zion"" in his band's name to the Hebrew script that graced the cover of Godspeed's Slow Riot for Zero Kanada EP. But here
column5: his invocation of the Kaddish-- a prayer chanted during Jewish funeral services-- proves quite literal
column6: as a mournful electric-guitar soundscape yields to a solemn
column7: repeated group vocal (courtesy of Menuck and some Silver Mt. Zion mates)
column8: not unlike that of a temple congregation praying in unison. Though traditionally recited to commemorate those who have passed
column9: the Kaddish makes no explicit mention of death
column10: and likewise
column11: ""Kaddish for Chesnutt"" makes no direct allusion to Vic Chesnutt. Rather
column12: its repeated
column13: increasingly impassioned invocation of the Old Testament's ""tree of life"" is Menuck's means of elevating the late singer to the realm of the eternal
column14:
lifting his skinny fists like antennas to heaven.

No contemporary R&B singers approximate the elusive stomach-butterfly rush of infatuation as consistently as Lloyd. ""Lay It Down""
column3: King of Hearts' peak moment and a lead single that predates the record by nearly a year
column4: is an exemplar: Its innocent
column5: almost naïve earnestness is married to a preternatural sense for R&B vocal acrobatics
column6: giving dimension and believability to his devotion. A distinctive talent
column7: Lloyd often let his vocals dance around the periphery of a song
column8: giving his best tracks a spacey
column9: removed quality. As a whole
column10: the LP takes a major step toward streamlining his sound
column11: pushing Lloyd's voice to the center and making a bid for a higher level of recognition in the R&B world. Despite a few missteps
column12: it is a major success
column13: in large part due to the chemistry of Lloyd with producer Polow Da Don.

column1: Lloyd's knack for endearing romanticism is a vehicle for great music
column2: and when the record falters
column3: it feels like a misunderstanding of how his talent operates. The superfluous intro track can be forgiven thanks to its brevity and a surprisingly clunker-free verse from the Game. But ""Dedication to My Ex (Miss That)""
column4: the first full song on the album
column5: is bizarre and clumsy. The generic
column6: faux-Motown beat frames the track as a joke
column7: along the lines of Cee Lo's ""Fuck You"". Perhaps the right performance could have saved lyrics that fetishize the vagina as a relationship's vestigial remnant
column8: but it's hard to buy the tongue-in-cheek self-deprecation of a line like ""I'm about to kill this bitch!"" from an artist typically so wrapped up in enthusiastic sincerity. Aside from this misstep and a platitudinous track aptly titled ""World Cry""
column9: King of Hearts seems perfectly matched to fit Lloyd's strengths.

column1: Polow clearly understands those strengths. Outside the occasional producer's flourish-- like the grinding bass break that opens Young Jeezy's verse on ""Be the One""-- his work is primarily devoted to underlining Lloyd's vocals for maximum impact. On ""Naked""
column2: Lloyd's performance has a dreamy distance from the physical reality of sexuality; instead
column3: his vocals are draped in softly descending washes of guitar and muted trumpet lines
column4: giving a sensuous texture to this awestruck ode to beauty. Single ""Cupid""'s exuberant chorus baits cynical listeners: It works so well as a radio single because
column5: through mild repetition
column6: the hook's infectious idealism overwhelms any resistance.

column1: The heart of the record
column2: though
column3: are tracks like the euphoric headrush ""Jigsaw""
column4: where Lloyd's sense of rhythm lets his vocals dance confidently in the subdivisions of the groove
column5: balancing sugary enthusiasm with deft physicality. Many of the album's best songs seem to inspire comparisons with dancing: There is a connection to the idea of dance as liberation here
column6: as Lloyd's blushing sincerity builds up potential energy
column7: the nimble performance acts as a release valve. In an echo of Aaliyah's ""Loose Rap""
column8: album highlight ""Shake It 4 Daddy"" finds Lloyd dancing atop a vocal shadow; somehow
column9: in his hands
column10: even strip club storytelling comes across as boyish flirtation. Although the lyrics imply he's in the audience
column11:
the song's excitement suggests Lloyd is the one performing.

It's surprising that John Tejada hasn't hooked up with Kompakt before. The twitchy grooves of Parabolas
column2: the L.A. transplant's debut LP for the Cologne
column3: Germany-based label
column4: fit right into founder Wolfgang Voigt's minimal techno aesthetic. What binds Tejada's eclectic decade-plus of work is an approach where it seems like every instrumental tweak and glitch has been studiously labored over for great stretches of time. Parabolas feels that way
column5: too. It's a collection of 12 tech-house instrumentals
column6: pitched somewhere between the visceral punch of classic Detroit techno and the headphone-oriented approach of 1990s electronica like Black Dog Production's Bytes and Autechre's Incunabula.

column1: That's some daunting company to keep
column2: but Tejada has the skills to transform his pilfering into something greater than the sum of its influences. Opener ""Farther and Fainter"" is a case in point. The opening bars initially sound like they're pushing into the kind of densely packed prettiness Aphex Twin was obsessing over on Selected Ambient Works 85–92. But then the deadened bass drum beat kicks in
column3: joined by a series of bell-like samples
column4: and the song stretches to a close via low-end synth noise wrapped around a fading hi-hat. Blanketed in a pensive quality that most bedroom techno shares
column5: the track is a good indication of what to expect from much of Parabolas
column6: which essentially acts like a form of comedown comfort food.

column1: Occasionally Tejada strays close to a full-on ambient sound (""The Dream""
column2: ""The Honest Man"")
column3: but for the most part Parobalas is deliberately stunted at birth. Tracks like ""Subdivided"" juxtapose zesty synth rolls with stabs of murky bass and rarely deviate from that path. Occasionally the trance-like state Tejada favors can be a little monotonous
column4: but he usually works in unexpected twists just before the music settles into a rut. For example
column5: a few corkscrewing samples light up ""Timeless Space""
column6: while ""The Living Night"" tempers its house-y piano stabs by heading somewhere far darker and then frittering into ambience.

column1: The doomy tone that briefly surfaces in ""The Living Night"" recurs across much of Parabolas' later tracks
column2: neatly contrasting with the airy material that opened the album. On ""Unstable Condition""
column3: Tejada even heads close to the kind of relentless downer vibe LFO toyed with on ""Tied Up"" albeit with all the dissonance scraped away to fit with this record's late-night mood. The convergence of light and dark helps make Parobalas work well as a self-contained piece
column4:
while the album's sense of focus elevates it above some of Tejada's typical lurches in style.

Listening to The Lateness of the Hour
column3: I try to hear Alex Clare
column4: but mostly end up seeing a hat. A fedora
column5: to be specific. Always front and center in the mix
column6: Clare's voice drips with the brassy confidence and implied stylistic reverence of post-Mark Ronson ladies' men like Bruno Mars
column7: Wallpaper
column8: and Mayer Hawthorne
column9: artists who seem to exist solely to don fancy duds in men's magazines that congratulate them for doing absolutely nothing to upset the concept of how this stuff should sound and look-- soul music as a fashion accessory
column10: mostly.

column1: The difference with Clare is that the young Brit is being produced by Diplo and Switch and it all feels icky in a way any album does when it comes off like a record exec's version of Listerine
column2: something that invents both the problem and the solution. This year
column3: the likes of James Blake
column4: Jamie Woon
column5: Katy B
column6: and to a certain extent SBTRKT have all made strides in satisfying those who'd prefer the fluidity and innovation of dubstep and UK bass music be delivered by knowable singer-songwriters. It was basically the same issue that people had when trying to monetize electronica over a decade ago
column7: and Lateness offers up the same one-step fix: Keep it goin' louder.

column1: But the idea that this is even a proper forum for discussing the purity of the form gets decimated in less than three-minutes with opener ""Up All Night"". Major Lazer too minimal and chaste for your blood? How do you feel about Arctic Monkeys guitar chug with dancehall beats and that almost-rap cadence from ""Wannabe""? In its quest for confluence with lyrics that play out like a longform Bacardi ad
column2: it's a tidy summary in how the hedonism of pop radio can feel so predatory these days. (Or you'll end up with a justified worry that Major Lazer's collaboration with No Doubt will end up sounding like Transistor-era 311.)

column1: From there
column2: Lateness never does much to prove Clare and his producers were on the same page (let alone reading from the same book). Clare's songs are perfectly innocuous and only occasionally irritating transmissions from the mindset of the modern pop&B male
column3: oversinging underwritten come-ons to either the woman who got away (""Humming Bird"")
column4: the woman who won't get away if he's got anything to say about it (""Relax My Beloved"")
column5: or failing that
column6: her fine-ass friend (""Treading Water""). The line
column7: ""I don't want to hurt you but I need to breathe/ At the end of all you're still my best friend
column8: basically reveals the borders of his worldview.

column1: Another problem is that Diplo and Switch are producing like they don't need Clare's voice and he's singing like he doesn't want their production. The high-NRG drums and sandworm synth lines hardly sound like necessary or even complementary additions to ""Treading Water""-- an ""unplugged"" version is helpfully included on the Deluxe Edition if you doubt me. Likewise
column2: the caricatured deep bass on ""Relax My Beloved"" and the gospel-via-T.D. Jakes gaudiness of ""Sanctuary"" are nice tricks that may make you wonder if Diplo and Switch will regret not saving them for someone who'd actually appreciate the details. As the second half drags on
column3: Clare tries to muster some grit into terribly sappy love jams with self-explanatory titles like ""Love You""
column4: ""I Won't Let You Down""
column5: and ""Where Is the Heart?"" making you wonder if Lateness is essentially a Ray LaMontagne record with beats.

column1: Then comes the cover of ""When Doves Cry"". He's almost certainly aware of the talking points-- not just the supposed audacity of trying one's hand at such an acknowledged and shopworn classic
column2: but in how it fits on a record with such an exaggerated low end when Prince famously removed bass entirely. Like most of <i>Lateness
column3: though
column4: it's more eye-rolling than pernicious. (You could argue ""Tight Rope"" is a worse crime for revealing Clare has clearly never heard of Janelle Monáe
column5: taking the central metaphor from her song of the same name wholesale and nothing else worthwhile.)

column1: Truth is
column2: it's much easier getting mad at the marketing plan of Lateness of the Hour than the record itself: The total mismatch of artistic motivation makes everyone involved come off like innocent bystanders
column3: not manipulators. Call it GQ funky
column4: Purple Label Sound
column5: How To Dress Well (For Real) or whatever... I mean
column6: you play this thing on iTunes and Genius recommends a ""similar"" song called ""Rocket To Uranus"" by Vengaboyz and Perez Hilton. Well done
column7:
all involved.

Like him or loathe him
column2: Colin Meloy has become one of the most distinctive songwriters of his era. Combining antiquated diction with lilting melodies drawn from UK folk rock and U.S. indie pop
column3: his compositions are recognizable whether they're sung by Marianne Faithfull
column4: Patti Smith
column5: or anyone else. What stands out most from the Decemberists' near-decade together isn't the albums. Instead
column6: it's the songs-- ""Billy Liar""
column7: ""16 Military Wives""
column8: ""O Valencia!""
column9: ""On the Bus Mall""-- that are the best showcases for the Portland band's lyrical indulgences and clever arrangements. The pop song
column10: especially the kind that hovers around the three- or four-minute mark
column11: has been the ideal framework for Meloy's explorations of prog rock
column12: sea shanties
column13: wake music
column14: fanfares
column15: and showtunes.

column1: 2009's The Hazards of Love was an especially egregious misstep. A concept album with an overarching narrative involving otherworldly lovers and forest-bound shapeshifters
column2: Hazards was grandiose and mock-epic
column3: but it evoked a world much more circumscribed than can be found in almost any of Meloy's individual songs. Most recently
column4: The King Is Dead's abrupt change in style played as a retreat: a means of making amends to the same fans Hazards risked alienating. Impressively
column5: though
column6: the album's renewed emphasis on standalone tunes made Americana jangle sound like not only a natural detour for the Decemberists
column7: but an inevitable destination. A few months later
column8: the eight-song iTunes Session puts curious punctuation on its predecessor
column9: with nice flourishes of fiddle from former Nickel Creek member Sara Watkins
column10: but a tracklist that pulls from throughout the band's discography while skipping the high points.

column1: The Decemberists fare better on iTunes Session when they play songs from the new album than when they travel back through their own and others' catalogs. ""Calamity Song"" may not be nearly as calamitous here as in its studio version
column2: but the runaway ooh-ooh-oohs make for one of the EP's most unguardedly joyful moments. ""June Hymn""
column3: meanwhile
column4: is no ""January Hymn""
column5: but the song's folksy ramble comes through more clearly in this slightly more stripped-down performance than it did on the LP. Still
column6: King dud ""This Is Why We Fight"" is a dud again here-- further proof Meloy's examinations of military violence work only when he filters them through character and story (see also the genuinely affecting ""Yankee Bayonet (I Will Be Home Then)"" vs. the pedantic ""16 Military Wives""). And the band tries to salvage ""The Hazards of Love 4 (The Drowned)"" by reworking it as a languid country lament
column7: but while fiddle and weepy pedal steel reinforce the tragedy of the lyrics
column8: the melody feels soggy
column9: the performance a bit aimless. ""Shiny""
column10: from 2003 debut EP 5 Songs
column11: likewise rambles
column12: though it's worth revisiting that early effort's ""Oceanside"" and ""I Don't Mind"".

column1: The primary draw of iTunes Session is the pair of covers that act almost as its bookends. They're an uneven couple. The Decemberists effectively recast Leonard Cohen's ""Hey
column2: That's No Way to Say Goodbye"" as a country tear-jerker
column3: but Meloy just can't muster the gravity to sell the song. Though Cohen's lyrical style is as stilted and heady as Meloy's
column4: the elder songwriter's near-comical solemnity is a bad fit
column5: especially considering what Meloy could've done with a tune by wryer Cohen contemporaries like Loudon Wainwright III or Randy Newman. Luckily
column6: a locomotive-paced
column7: countrified rendition of Fruit Bats' ""When U Love Somebody"" better suits the Decemberists' strengths. But it only makes you wonder how something like ""The Engine Driver"" might sound translated to a genre famous for songs about trains. In that regard
column8: the EP's lackluster tracklist leaves iTunes Session seeming clunky and unrepresentative-- like it's not a full set
column9:
but an excerpt from a larger show.

column3: Boston Spaceships have seemed the very sort of band that makes double LPs. Over four albums and a live set

column5: insistent
column6: Meadowlands-ready power-pop caught somewhere between Cheap Trick's Heaven Tonight and the Who's Quadrophenia. Pollard
column7: Decemberists drummer John Moen
column8: and Spaceships sonic mastermind Chris Slusarenko may not play arenas-- in fact
column9: the Spaceships haven't played much of anywhere in years-- but their best tunes have both the hooks and the heft to reach the back-bleachers. Seems like any good arena rock band

column1: 2008's Brown Submarine arrived in the wake of a mid-2000s turn toward overcooked
column2: plodding
column3: patchy numbers run through with too many opposing currents. Over their four fine LPs
column4: the Spaceships have pushed the hooks right out front
column5: done away with almost everything short of the mid-tempo
column6: and culled many of the musical left-turns
column7: leaving Pollard with four of the most immediately enjoyable
column8: fat-free LPs of his career. Between Pollard's excitable vocals and streamlined hooks
column9: Slusarenko's rich but unfussy arrangements
column10: and Moen's rock-solid but far-from-flashy backbeat
column11: the spotlight's always seemed fixed on the songs themselves.

column1: A double LP is different: With all that extra room
column2: you can stretch out
column3: goof off
column4: or beef up
column5: all of which Let It Beard does
column6: sometimes quite well. These guys
column7: 1970s rock junkies that they are
column8: are scholars of the form
column9: and it's to their credit that Let It Beard doesn't sound like two single-length Boston Spaceships LPs affixed at the gatefold. It operates instead like a double LP from that format's classic era
column10: with roomier tunes
column11: more expansive arrangements
column12: ripping guitar solos
column13: and (largely inconsequential) cameos from the likes of  Wire's Colin Newman
column14: the Dirtbombs' Mick Collins and Dinosaur Jr.'s J Mascis. The way they break down Let It Beard's four sides even seems to hold to the classic template: A is for the bombastic
column15: ambitious ones
column16: the rockers are on B
column17: the weird ones on C
column18: and D brings it all together. Alas
column19: that most damning of double-album takedowns is also true of Let It Beard: At 26 songs and 75 minutes

column1: A portent of things to come
column2: bumpy opener ""Blind 20-20"" never finds its footing
column3: shifting brusquely between unadorned piano-and-vocal and a thuddy riff. Titles aside
column4: the empty snarl of ""Juggernaut vs. Monolith"" and the centerless ""Tourist U.F.O."" don't fare much better. These first few songs either fail to get to the point (or don't seem to have much point to get to...). ""Minefield Searcher"" sounds strikingly like a Robyn Hitchcock cover of a Cheap Trick song and it's the set's first truly spirited melody
column5: but it's over before you'll notice. ""Make a Record for Lo-Life"" proves the set's first big winner
column6: its bright
column7: knotty melody bashed out with marksman's ease
column8: but it's quickly followed by the dismal ""Let More Light in the House""
column9: a dirgey
column10: disinterested moaner just barely salvaged by its banjo-and-snare-augmented second half. It's hard to think of a more lackluster stretch on a Pollard record of any vintage. Could be they didn't want to stick all the good ones up front
column11: but whatever the case

column1: Things pick up with lively punker ""You Just Can't Tell""
column2: leading Beard into its heftier second quarter. The album's highest high

column7: it's this run that feels most like the Spaceships LPs that've come before it
column8: their tempos swift
column9: their hooks coming in quick and dirty. In a way
column10: Let It Beard's overly sinewy opening stretch feels like the tension before the glorious release of this rocky run. But the other Spaceships records have never felt the need to tease the listener in quite this way: There's no waiting around for the good song when every song's pretty good.

column1: Then there's ""(I'll Make It) Strong for You""
column2: a stirring
column3: stripped-down curio that ushers in Beard's oddest section. This third side finds Pollard's eccentricties taking over in a way (Circus Devils aside) he hasn't allowed himself in some time. Take the schizoid ""A Hair in Every Square Inch of the House""
column4: vacillating wildly between soft strums and fierce shouts; it's not brilliant
column5: but it's peculiar in a far less leaden way than the row of misses that kicks off the collection. They're not all winners back there-- too bad Pollard wasted a title like ""The Ballad of Bad Whiskey"" on such a dreary tune-- but they're the first indication that a double LP was
column6: in fact
column7: a good idea for the Spaceships. With all this extra time
column8: they can afford to be a little odder

column10: and while it's a shame they seem to separate the pop from the weirdness-- rather than letting them bleed all over each other
column11: as on Pollard's best records-- at least here the latter makes a good showing. ""Let it beard and get all weird

column15: only scragglier. And so it is.

column1: To cap things off
column2: a side of solidly unspectacular riff-rockers and spindly balladry culminates in rousing closer ""Inspiration Points"". While it does bring together the diffuse strong structures
column3: the stop/start energy
column4: and a bit of the off-kilter weirdness that characterizes the preceding sides
column5: it's not quite the misstep-salvaging send-off a piece of this length merits. Through decades of setlists and LPs alike

column7: so it's odd that Let It Beard seems so sluggishly arranged. But Let It Beard's undoing isn't its formatting

column9: and they're spread over a far greater expanse. A terrific amount of thought seems to've gone into Let It Beard's structure
column10: its scope
column11: its knowing nods to an earlier era's  excess. But one vital question seems to have eluded them: Do we actually  have the tunes to pull this off? They didn't; not quite
column12: anyway. In a  surprising turn
column13: an email went out to the Pollard faithful this week
column14: announcing that the brash
column15: boisterous Let It Beard would prove the Spaceships' swan song. That's the other thing about the great arena-rock bands; even in their excess
column16:
they leave us wanting more.

As the tracklisting suggests
column4: a number of the songs on They Came From the Sky address concerns near and dear to the hearts of ""Coast to Coast AM"" listeners: flying saucers
column5: alien queens
column6: ""peopleoids
column7: etc.  Whether Human Eye frontman Timmy Vulgar's a self-aware skeptic when it comes to unidentified flying objects or a Fox Mulder acolyte looking to find a few potential converts is up for debate.  What's important is that he's able to bridge that gap when addressing his congregation.  As far as modern-day garage rock acts go
column8: Human Eye used to be one that had trouble standing out.  They could work up a nice head of steam when they wanted
column9: and their fondness for the stuff of Ed Wood features and other B-movie fare was always charming
column10: but their previous two albums were inconsistent slogs through various levels of fidelity and songcraft. On They Came From the Sky
column11: the band's focus on extraterrestrials has been matched by an equally exacting focus on their music.

column1: Granted
column2: the ""alien"" thing happening on this album is nothing new for Vulgar.  This sort of sci-fi schlock has been a trademark throughout most of his recorded work.  In fact
column3: one Sky track
column4: ""Impregnate the Martian Queen
column6: is a sequel/rewrite of a track from Vulgar's last album as Timmy's Organism
column7: Rise of the Green Gorilla. Also
column8: a few tracks deal with topics that are slightly more grounded
column9: like the self-explanatory ""Brain Zip (Kickin' Back in the Electric Chair)"". What makes Sky stand out in Vulgar's discography is the melding of these semi-nostalgic concerns with a sound that hearkens back to those good old days in a refreshing manner. If the intent with Sky was to create an album that could be the sort of Nuggets-worthy vinyl treasure one would find at a garage sale behind a bunch of dog-eared copies of Famous Monsters of Filmland and a Space Ghost tin lunchbox
column10: mission accomplished.

column1: As a vocalist
column2: Vulgar combines Iggy Pop's laconic drawl with Roky Erickson's unrelenting fervor
column3: giving the pulpy stories unfurled in tracks like ""Alien Creeps"" and ""The Movie Was Real"" a little extra juice.  Sci-fi-friendly sounds pepper a good number of these tunes-- the album's opening salvo
column4: ""Alien Creeps""
column5: features what seems to be the sound of a malfunctioning radio transmitter
column6: while ""Impregnate the Martian Queen"" offers a burbling noise that sounds an awful lot like the 13th Floor Elevators' ""electric jug."" As a guitarist
column7: Vulgar's never too far from ripping off a mind-splitting fuzzed-out solo that
column8: like the rest of his band
column9: is heavy and stupid in all the right ways: His rave-up closing out the album's title track is especially ""out there."" Human Eye have always seemed like the type of band whose perfect day involves a secluded basement
column10: a recreational substance
column11: and a horror/sci-fi movie marathon featuring second-rate monster suits and pie tins dangling on very visible strings. With They Came From the Sky
column12:
Human Eye finally make that sort of get-together sound appealing.

Before starting to read this review of Autre Ne Veut's Body EP
column2: I assume you took a few seconds to investigate the above cover image. It is what you think it is. Not only is it attention-grabbing
column3: it's a good metaphor for the music of this yet-unidentified New York-based artist. You probably wouldn't refer to the extreme close-up of a female sex organ as pornography-- the clinical
column4: uncontextualized presentation is absent any eroticism. Pornography's aim is to provide pleasure
column5: usually presenting the most attractive and desirable package possible. The same is also typically true of pop music
column6: yet Auture Ne Veut is every bit as obstinate as Body's cover about taking pleasure-producing elements and making them raw and discomfiting. In much the same way the photo delivers a view of sex so intimate and vivid it might leave you squeamish
column7: Body's music forswears the niceties of pop and R&B
column8: instead rubbing its squirmingly real feeling in the listener's face.

column1: Body picks up where Autre Ne Veut left off on his terrific 2010 self-titled debut
column2: utilizing pop hooks and R&B declarations predominantly mined from the 1980s
column3: but presenting them as garish and unhinged. The results fleetingly inspire nostalgia
column4: only to warp those comforts into something unsettling and queasy. It's terrain also covered by the likes of How to Dress Well
column5: the Knife
column6: and Ariel Pink: Autre Ne Veut shares those artists' mix of a strongly expressive pop instinct and an arty deconstructionist bent. Starting with disorienting synths and unnerving background vocals
column7: EP opener ""Sweetheart"" immediately announces its disruptive intentions. Autre Ne Veut's vocals bend and leer drunkenly
column8: sometimes sounding sickeningly sweet or affected
column9: sometimes painfully sincere
column10: as he competes with layers of swirling keyboards and blasted-out beats. It's followed by the lone throwaway of the four cuts
column11: ""Not the One""
column12: a scant two minutes of guest vocalist She Wolf's single repeated lyric (""This is not the one that you've been promising me"") sliced and diced and plied with spooky synths.

column1: That eerie aesthetic carries over on ""Just Return""
column2: but here Autre Ne Veut complements the horrorshow synths with a gripping tune
column3: powerfully sliding between vocal tones
column4: starting off softly fragile before emoting with real abandon on the refrain
column5: fervently declaring wishes for empowerment and acceptance that only increase curiosity about the man behind this artistic mask. The EP closes with the similarly effusive ""Your Clothes""
column6: though here the mood is far more playful
column7: with Autre Ne Veut grunting and moaning like an exaggerated R&B loverman over the kind of noisily fun 80s-inspired gallop that Max Tundra is also so good at summoning. Body's over in fewer than 13 minutes
column8:
but you feel like you've been on a legitimate ride: Autre Ne Veut almost never lets up pushing messily human pop exclamations forcibly to the forefront.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16808/homepage_large.af6a908e.jpg|Peanut Butter and Swelly|29839.0|Chiddy Bang|['Rock'
column3: 'Illroots'
column5: Chidera ""Chiddy"" Anamege
column6: the rapping half of the Philly rap duo Chiddy Bang
column7: broke the Guiness World Record for Longest Freestyle
column8: rapping for more than nine hours straight. And if you want to hear some utterly godawful rapping
column9: pull up a video of Chiddy finishing off that marathon. Or rapping for a 10-minute stretch during hour five. Or 22 minutes into it. Really
column10: any random moment from the writ-large publicity stunt is going to give you some truly clumsy time-killing fluffiness. Even if Chiddy was Rakim
column11: he couldn't have pulled this thing off; there's not a rapper alive who could say anything compelling for nine hours straight. But a great rapper wouldn't have attempted this stunt because a great rapper wouldn't have needed to do it. There's no worthwhile artistic reason to rap for that long-- it's pure online traffic-bait. When you rap for nine hours
column12: words stop meaning anything; they become a way to fill time. If you pull up a random video from the nine-hour stretch
column13: you'll see Chiddy wandering aimlessly around a spotlessly furnished room
column14: flopping down on a blinding white couch
column15: lifelessly throwing out words while the other dudes in the room stare at their iPhones. It's depressing.

column1: That same disregard for language is all over Peanut Butter and Swelly
column2: Chiddy Bang's recent mixtape. As a rapper
column3: Chiddy never shows the slightest bit of intensity or emotion. This is breezy cool-kid rap and nothing more
column4: which might be fine if Chiddy did it with style. Instead
column5: we get some truly awkward
column6: forced
column7: jumbled line construction. On the very first song
column8: Chiddy actually uses the word ""hashtag"" in a (terrible) hashtag-rap punchline. Here's Chiddy on himself: ""My life is pretty as the face of a girl/ And watch out
column9: I got too much soul for the world."" On a girl: ""She got them soft legs/ She got them plum thighs/ And her bathing suit is something that is fun-sized."" On his rivals: ""Rapper
column10: you should die/ Reading Catcher in the Rye."" It's grisly.

column1: Chiddy Bang first started building blog attention because producer Xaphoon Jones used samples of some extremely recognizable mainstream-indie pop hits (MGMT's ""Kids""
column2: Sufjan Stevens' ""Chicago"") to build his synth-rap tracks. These kinda-juxtapositions don't quite qualify as a neat trick; rappers have been rapping over weird shit since rap's earliest days. As canny as they are
column3: the production choices are simply lazy
column4: a transparent bid for Chiddy Bang to become the one rap group a certain subset of indie kids cares about. So on Peanut Butter and Swelly we get stuff like Chiddy rapping over Matt and Kim's ""Cameras""
column5: a decent song that's way too thin and burnished to serve as the skeleton for a rap song. Or we get ""Heatwave""
column6: the posse cut where Xaphoon throws bleepy keyboard sounds all over a Martha and the Vandellas song for absolutely no reason. They seem to be aiming for the ""Oh
column7: hey
column8: I know that song"" reaction. It's not like they go anywhere with the songs. It's all reference with nothing behind it
column9: and that also goes for the rapping. A line from all over: ""Got me throwing my arms around Paris
column10: shit: Morrissey."" It just figures that this kid's Morrissey reference of choice would be some shit from Years of Refusal.

column1: On ""Heatwave""
column2: after painful verses from Chiddy and the odious Pittsburgh frat-rap goon Mac Miller
column3: we get a verse from the Texas gangsta legend Trae
column4: who stays on autopilot and steals the entire mixtape anyway. (Rest assured that the score at the top of this page would be a couple of decimal points lower without him.) Trae has been making a transparent bid for career-revival lately
column5: showing up on tracks with ascendant weed-rap goofballs like Wiz Khalifa. Even so
column6: his appearance here feels jarring. Trae made his name with a gutturally depressive hardhead style. He's a ferociously powerful voice who can sound tough even when he's talking about intense emotional pain. That makes him basically the polar opposite of Chiddy
column7:
a rapper who never has anything to say and who always sounds comfortable saying it.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16821/homepage_large.89321f0f.jpg|Science of the Sea|29786.0|Jürgen Müller|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Digitalis']|2011-08-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:45.069591|"

A skeptic might cast aspersions on the tale behind Jürgen Müller's Science of the Sea. The story begins at the University of Kiel in Germany
column2: where the self-taught composer was studying oceanic science in the late 1970s. Müller purchased some electronic instruments and set them up on his houseboat in the town of Heikendorf
column3: where he began crafting instrumental pieces that reflected his love of undersea life. His dream of selling those compositions to film and TV companies for use in documentaries never transpired. But Müller did press fewer than 100 vinyl copies of the recordings in the early 80s and titled them Science of the Sea
column4: giving most of the albums away to friends and family. Fast forward three decades and a copy of the record ends up in the hands of Digitalis Recordings
column5: just as a resurgence of interest in the type of new age recordings Müller was practicing is taking place.

column1: So it's reasonable to wonder if the backstory was constructed as part of a larger concept
column2: the way people continue to wonder about Ursula Bogner or Endless House. One intrepid blog commenter even claims to have contacted the University of Kiel and found no trace of Müller's presence. Either way it doesn't really matter
column3: because the music on Science of the Sea continues that superior strain of contemplative elegance records such as Emeralds' Does It Look Like I'm Here? and Oneohtrix Point Never's Rifts have touched on in recent times. Like those releases
column4: the relation Science of the Sea has to actual new age music is tangential at best. There are no Gheorghe Zamfir-esque pan flute solos or anything that will drive you to join a local color therapy group. Instead it's an uncomplicated series of recordings
column5: mostly based around gently unfolding synth arpeggios set to faintly pulsing rhythms.

column1: The tracks are short-- only five of the 12 here make it over the three-minute mark-- although Science of the Sea doesn't really make sense when broken down into its component parts. Instead each song works as a natural evolution of the theme set out in the opening ""Beyond the Tide""
column2: where great washes of cleansing synth are interrupted by spiky twists of becalming noise that were presumably conceived to mimic dolphin chirps. It's not hard to see why this might have been thought of as a perfect soundtrack to a Jacques Cousteau-style undersea documentary. The following ""Sea Bed Meditation"" is full of rippling loops tied down by globs of tenderly resonating bass frequencies
column3: not far removed from Klaus Schulze's contemplative solo ventures. Müller also shares Schulze's fondness for vaguely humorous song titles (""Dream Sequence For a Jellyfish""
column4: ""The Elusive Seahorse"").

column1: What's remarkable about this album is how acutely it reflects and comments on the environment that served as its inspiration. ""Waterworld"" doesn't travel far beyond the coiling melody that ebbs and flows throughout the track
column2: but it feels like the musical equivalent of a trail of oxygen bubbles arcing to the surface as a scuba diver peacefully plunges to the depths. Similarly
column3: ""Marine Technology"" is all digital interference and signal jams
column4: with zaps of synth noise pinging back and forth across the surface as though an urgent piece of undersea communication were being transmitted. Once you get deep into Science of the Sea
column5: especially on headphones
column6: it feels like Müller is simultaneously replicating that world and conveying his chimerical dreams about what it epitomizes. ""Coral Fantasy"" and ""Vast Worlds Beneath"" function as utopian fantasies about the great unknown
column7: with Müller utilizing slowly disentangling sounds to give a sense of scale
column8: wonder
column9: and a natural curiosity about all the things that lay undiscovered down there.

column1: The way Science of the Sea subtly shifts in theme
column2: from then-current meditations on the ocean to quixotic impressions about its unexplored expanses
column3: is its masterstroke. It feels like you're on a journey alongside Müller
column4: carefully mapping out the thoughts and fears the murky depths have come to represent
column5: all laid out in a way that your brain would naturally process if you were immersed in that world. The closing ""Lonely Voyage"" even feels like a warning of sorts
column6: with its foreboding timbre suggesting that you can plunge a little too deeply into yourself if you spend too much time down there. That's where this album disconnects from anything that could perfunctorily be tagged as ""new age."" This isn't simple relaxation music
column7:
although much of it could easily perform that function. Instead the beautifully uncomplicated surface structures are used to prize open a boundless amount of feelings that are every bit as complex and unfathomable as the ocean itself.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16805/homepage_large.f78aea0f.jpg|Last Words: The Final Recordings|4122.0|Screaming Trees|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sunyata']|2011-08-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:45.763778|"

Many of their Seattle peers ended up disgraced
column2: drunk
column3: or dead
column4: so it's a testament to the strength of the record industry in the early 1990s that selling a couple hundred thousand albums cast Screaming Trees as grunge's hard luck story. Featured on the definitive Singles soundtrack
column5: evergreen psych-rock jam ""Nearly Lost You"" smeared its wah-wah guitar solos and the alluring dusk of Mark Lanegan's vocals all over MTV. But the band couldn't capitalize: Sweet Oblivion had already been out for months
column6: and its ensuing tour resulted in more turmoil than triumph. Four years later
column7: Dust was a very strong follow-up whose staunch classic rock sound made it a critical hit and a commercial non-starter on alt-rock radio. Screaming Trees more or less confirmed that for all of its anti-image posturing
column8: grunge was still about fashion: Having never been embraced as reluctant
column9: PC-friendly sex symbols or drunken lumberjacks (rumors persist that label execs tried to force out at least one of the hulking Conner brothers)
column10: the band called it quits in 2000 and went their separate ways in a manner that didn't leave much to the imagination until now.

column1: Last Words: The Final Recordings was put to tape during 1998 and 1999 at Stone Gossard's studio
column2: features guitar work from Peter Buck and Josh Homme
column3: and was recently mixed and mastered by Jack Endino
column4: but it arrives without much fanfare: It's being released on drummer Barrett Martin's label with tentative plans for physical distribution and
column5: unsurprisingly
column6: Screaming Trees have no plans to reunite. Musically
column7: it's streamlined and aerodynamic
column8: the sort of thing you might expect as a ""back to basics"" move from a band getting together for the first time in over a decade
column9: not one making the follow-up to Dust. But was that direction even really necessary back then? Though they waited until their sixth album to incorporate ambitious signifiers like sitar
column10: tabla
column11: and Mellotron
column12: Dust was hardly the sound of a band gone off the deep end. More pointedly
column13: the parameters for ""basics"" set forth here never existed for Screaming Trees-- this is neither the crusty SST punk of their earliest days nor the shaggy radio rock of Uncle Anaesthesia or Sweet Oblivion. Revisionist history has occasionally cast Screaming Trees as an unremarkable
column14: workmanlike rock band blessed with a distinct vocalist
column15: and if Last Words does anything for their legacy
column16: it makes that notion somewhat true for the first time.

column1: Not much here bears the weight of creative struggle or even an idea dump
column2: just up-the-middle guitar songs that could conceivably be the result of a five-minute writing session or a dogged determination to have something to show for a 12-hour day in the studio. Opener ""Ash Grey Sunday"" boasts the kind of casually anthemic guitar jangle in the lineage of the Yardbirds or ""About a Girl""
column3: but it's garage rock in theory only
column4: all simple transitions and lyrical archetype with no crackling urgency. A similar lack of development pervades ""Door Into Summer"" and ""Tomorrow Changes""
column5: bright and agreeable strummers whose most interesting songwriting touch is a fourth chord on top of the requisite three. Any tie towards actual psychedelia in their rock has been severed as well: ""Crawlspace"" is the most audacious bit of studio experimentation
column6: but it merely subjects Lanegan's vocals to the same tinny flange effect that's found its way onto too many Twilight Singers albums.

column1: Sure
column2: I've got the benefit of hindsight here
column3: but these really do sound like the work of a band struggling with inspiration
column4: more unwilling than unable to push themselves: ""Revelator"" finds them kicking up some Dust with a bluesy front porch jam
column5: but it's a total rewrite of ""Dying Days""; ""Low Life"" pops up later sounding like a minor variation of ""Revelator""
column6: and the closing title track's basically a minor variation of ""Low Life"". I think we can all agree that ""Dying Days"" is a good song
column7: but not that good.

column1: Ironically
column2: Last Words is actually rendered more inessential by its best quality. In terms of sheer tone
column3: Lanegan once again sounds fantastic. But you already knew that. Whether we're talking about his solo albums
column4: collaborations with Isobel Campbell and Greg Dulli
column5: or his more high-profile work with Queens of the Stone Age
column6: there's no shortage of him functioning as rock's equivalent of Scarface (the rapper
column7: not Al Pacino)
column8: relied on as a character actor specializing in a certain kind of brooding
column9: wizened masculinity. An oft-overlooked problem with this lonesome stranger guise is that while Lanegan's lyrics read straightforward on paper
column10: there's something weirdly unknowable about them. It's tempting to read into such a leading title for insight on Screaming Trees' mindstate during the sessions that caused their dissolution
column11: but Last Words is sort of a record about nothing much at all.

column1: Even if the circumstances are different
column2: I can't help but compare this to Rock ‘N' Roll Submarine
column3: the comeback record released by a reincarnated Urge Overkill this year. Both were bands that similarly arose from a primordial
column4: noisy 80s to the perpetual precipice of stardom thanks to a soundtrack hit
column5: only to slowly burn out by the end of the century. And while each developed a distinct sound and subtly covered a lot of ground in their time
column6: they're somewhat awkward to reevaluate in 2011
column7: when few bands (if any) bear any sign of their influence. Screaming Trees lived a full artistic life and were often great beyond ""Nearly Lost You""
column8:
but Last Words is basically an epitaph for a band that died of natural causes.
