All pop music is love and theft
column3: and Soft Metals are particularly upfront about both. The arty Portland electronic duo formed in early 2009
column4: with singer Patricia Hall and keyboardist/programmer Ian Hicks becoming a romantic couple not much later. The two recently did a mean cover of Throbbing Gristle's 1979 ""Hot on the Heels of Love""
column5: a techno-predicting cult classic that mixes robotic arpeggios and steamy vocals (recalling Donna Summer's rapturous ""I Feel Love"" from a couple of years earlier) with the industrial pioneers' own creepy foreboding.

column1: Soft Metals' self-titled album extends that combination of lovers' intimacy and retro-futuristic ominousness
column2: which Hall and Hicks previously introduced on the 2010 EP The Cold World Melts. With Hall's detached
column3: often-indecipherable vocals over Hicks' pulsating configurations of vintage synthesizers and drum machines
column4: Soft Metals bears traces of virtually every bleakly gliding descendant of Kraftwerk's O.G. synth-pop grooves
column5: from gothic early-1980s new wave to house
column6: techno
column7: and electroclash. But it's somewhat telling that this blurrily beguiling debut-- which reprises two tracks from the EP
column8: plus eight new ones-- arrives on Brooklyn-based Captured Tracks
column9: a label better known for the lo-fi noise-pop of Blank Dogs
column10: Beach Fossils
column11: or Wild Nothing.

column1: As with their labelmates
column2: Soft Metals' aesthetic is born not of lavish studios but in the bedroom. The songs on Soft Metals have a foggy
column3: surrealistic shimmer rather than the clear-cut precision of many of their electronic forebears. Where Ariel Pink cohort John Maus uses like-mindedly retro trappings as a jumping-off point for experiments with ideas about art and artifice
column4: Soft Metals concentrate instead on the type of subtly evolving textures you might be more inclined to play when you're drifting off to sleep than when you're throwing a dance party. Even the most lucid songs here
column5: whether echo-besotted EP cut ""Voices"" or swelling first-meeting reminiscence ""Do You Remember""
column6: stake their appeal on their glistening
column7: ever-changing surfaces
column8: not traditional songcraft.

column1: Still
column2: just because your brand of old-school electronics has more in common with mood-oriented Italians Do It Better producer Johnny Jewel (Glass Candy
column3: Chromatics) than with song-driven nu-disco princess Sally Shapiro (""I'll Be By Your Side"") doesn't mean the wordless repetitions of ""Celestial Call"" or ""Hold My Breath"" fully reward our attention. Then again... Soft Metals might wince at this comparison
column4: but it's not such a leap from their album's prelude-to-a-kiss cover art to the Cosmo-copped sex scene (speaking of love and theft!) that adorns Washed Out's latest. Soft Metals' ""Eyes Closed"" may have a faster tempo
column5: a more dangerous charge
column6: and one fewer title syllable than languid Within and Without opener ""Eyes Be Closed""
column7: but they're both headed toward a similarly sensual place.

column1: If Soft Metals are nostalgic
column2: however
column3: it's less for lost innocence than for a lost idea of the future. Where are the flying cars? The album's use of analogue synths isn't a regression
column4: but an attempt to find a new way forward. On instrumental finale ""In Throes""
column5: they finally do
column6: as eerie buzzes and disjointed rhythms chart a course somewhere near the Knife's still-unmatched 2006 dark-electronic landmark Silent Shout. In the end
column7:
the more important love on Soft Metals isn't necessarily between Hall and Hicks; it's between them and three-plus decades of synthesizer music. And wherever that leads next.

Comet Gain are indie pop lifers
column4: and not only because they're fast approaching 20 years of existence. The UK band's discography is a finely detailed and uncommonly honest document of lives lived through music
column5: free of schmaltz and coated with lyrical nods to the records they admire most (""You can hide your love forever
column6: goes Comet Gain's heartbreaking response to Orange Juice). ""Jack Nance Hair""
column7: from 2009 compilation Broken Record Prayers
column8: is a manifesto for people who love music to an almost religious degree: an outsider anthem reflecting scrappy
column9: fallible humanity through a record's imperfections (""Young
column10: free
column11: and single/ Like the crack in the 45"") and the comforting indifference of time through the turntable's ceaseless spin.

column1: The group's sound
column2: accordingly
column3: is a shambolic collision between elements of dream pop
column4: mod psychedelia
column5: northern soul
column6: and riot grrrl (guitarist Jon Slade cut his teeth in Huggy Bear). On The Howl of the Lonely Crowd
column7: Comet Gain's first proper album since since 2005's City Fallen Leaves
column8: singer/guitarist David Feck and his revolving-door lineup of musicians put a new twist on their incessant dialogue with their favorite artists: They recorded with one. Orange Juice's Edwyn Collins produced much of the album
column9: which means Feck got to live out a fanboy fantasy. The new album also features collaborations with some of Comet Gain's contemporaries
column10: such as Alasdair Maclean of the Clientele
column11: as well as their heirs
column12: including the Cribs' Ryan Jarman and Shrag's Helen King. Jarman and Brian O'Shaughnessy (whose credits go back to Primal Scream) lent additional production.

column1: For the most part
column2: Lonely Crowd finds Comet Gain up to their old tricks: paeans to impressive record collections (""Thee Ecstatic Library"")
column3: odes to cult heroes (""Herbert Huncke Pt. 2"")
column4: and wistful balladering (""In a Lonely Place""). The record's first few tracks
column5: in particular
column6: can stand respectably beside the band's strongest material
column7: with jangling standouts like ""The Weekend Dreams"" and ""Clang of the Concrete Swans"". Side B gets bogged down by a few too many inert slow songs
column8: but singer Rachel Evans swoops in to save the side with the ""Ballad of Frankie Machine""
column9: a quintessentially British tribute to the protagonist of This Sporting Life that effectively channels the 1963 film's haunting mood.

column1: Even if Lonely Crowd doesn't quite live up to the bar set by Broken Record Prayers-- which was
column2: after all
column3: a singles collection-- there's still something dependably refreshing about a new Comet Gain record. The band's diehard convictions and carefully wrought lyrics seem even more vital these days
column4: when ""indie pop"" often signifies a marketable sound rather than a lifestyle commitment. Comet Gain cling to the vestiges of that lifestyle with a convert's zeal. ""Some of us don't want to be saved
column5: Feck sings in one of the album's most memorable lines-- presumably because some of us already have been
column6:
as long as the turntable's spinning.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16770/homepage_large.7c466df3.jpg|Volume One 1970-1979|29811.0|Sorry Bamba|['Global'
column3: Mali won its independence from France. It was an exciting time in West Africa
column4: as the colonial governments pulled out
column5: and the first generation of post-independence African leaders translated a wave of African cultural pride into public policy. In Mali
column6: as in its neighbors
column7: then-President Modibo Keita pursued a rigorous program of nationalization and socialization
column8: and he encouraged development of the arts. Musicians were told to modernize the country's traditional music. Much as in Guinea next door
column9: a system of regional orchestras was established.

column1: But modernizing the traditional music of Mali wasn't exactly a simple task-- the country is a swirl of different cultures
column2: ethnicities
column3: languages
column4: and traditions. In the city of Mopti
column5: at the confluence of the Bani and Niger Rivers
column6: a young bandleader
column7: singer
column8: and flutist named Sorry Bamba jumped on board the modernization train with gusto. His band eventually became the Regional Orchestra of Mopti (Mopti is an administrative region in central Mali as well as a city)
column9: and Bamba worked hard to encompass the diversity of his region in his music. Volume One
column10: assembled by Thrill Jockey with involvement from Bamba himself
column11: covers music from Bambara
column12: Fula
column13: and Dogon traditions
column14: updated with electric guitars and organs during the 1970s. By the time this music was made
column15: Keita was in a prison in Kidal
column16: having been overthrown in 1968 by General Moussa Traoré
column17: who ruled the country as a police state until 1991 but continued many cultural programs.

column1: One of Bamba's greatest cultural coups was to get the Dogon people to accept him and teach him their songs. A cliff-dwelling people who lived for centuries along the Bandiagara Escarpment
column2: the Dogon had long kept their religious rituals and customs mysterious to outsiders. But they let Bamba in
column3: giving him such songs as ""Sayouwé""
column4: which honors ancestors
column5: and in return he renamed the Regional Orchestra Kanaga Orchestra after the creator god of Dogon myth. ""Sayouwé"" is included here
column6: and it has an unusual drum rhythm that the band turns into something like funk with guitar and a bit of spacey organ. That same tripped-out organ is the main texture on ""Porry""
column7: a slow-burner that also features a great Afro-Cuban trumpet solo by Bamba himself. The momentum it has might be best described by comparing it to walking when you're tired; it becomes almost more like repeatedly catching yourself in mid-fall than locomotion.

column1: Overall
column2: this compilation explores an intriguing discography that
column3: more than many
column4: really feels like a meeting of folk styles and modern instrumentations. Bamba makes little overt attempt to funk up or psychedelicize the music
column5: and where those qualities are found
column6: it's an organic outgrowth of the old music he was working with. There are lots of call-and-response vocals
column7: snaking horn sections
column8: guitars dripping with reverb
column9: and hand percussion. I love African funk
column10: rock
column11: Afrobeat
column12: and the like
column13: but it's nice to hear a compilation that's so dedicated to music so wholly African (and in a couple of cases
column14: Afro-Cuban) in its construction. If you've found your way into vintage African pop music and are looking to go a little deeper
column15:
this set is one good way to do it.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16796/homepage_large.8b846b95.jpg|Organ Music Not Vibraphone Like I'd Hoped|28467.0|Moonface|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2011-08-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:47.951111|"

Late last year
column2: Wolf Parade announced that they were going on an ""indefinite hiatus."" What this actually means-- and whether or not it's a bit premature to talk of their ""lifespan""-- is unclear
column3: but fortunately
column4: Dan Boeckner and Spencer Krug do not need each other to make good music. Last month Boeckner's electro-punk duo Handsome Furs released Sound Kapital
column5: and it was undoubtedly the most impassioned record they've made yet. The prolific Krug
column6: on the other hand
column7: has been churning out interesting music for years with a variety of different projects
column8: be it the eccentric supergroup Swan Lake or the increasingly ambitious one-time side project Sunset Rubdown. In a moment when many popular independent artists value accessibility
column9: simplicity
column10: and beach-ready blitheness above all else
column11: Krug's continued appeal lies in the fact that he is an anachronism: a songwriter who's trying to squeeze Byzantine grandeur into the unlikely framework of indie rock. His catalogue is dense
column12: charged with anxiety
column13: and-- in a trick he may have picked up from Dan Bejar-- about as self-referential as a late-series episode of ""Arrested Development"".

column1: Organ Music Not Vibraphone Like I'd Hoped
column2: Krug's first post-Wolf Parade LP
column3: feels like ritual music infused with 1980s nostalgia. Like his previous release as Moonface
column4: a 20-minute marimba showcase appropriately subtitled Marimba and Shit-Drums
column5: Organ Music springs from Krug's experiments with a particular instrument. Over Organ Music's five tracks (the shortest of which clocks in at six-and-half minutes)
column6: he creates what you might call Nintendo spirituals: songs that evoke his double-manual organ's devotional vibes just as much as they do-- through the use of drum machine beats
column7: loops
column8: and some skittish programming-- that song that plays throughout all the underwater levels in the original Super Mario Bros. These tracks are meditative
column9: hypnotic
column10: and born of Krug's unmistakable infatuation with the organ's brooding drone. I saw him perform the record live
column11: and whenever he stopped singing he looked completely lost in his own reverie. Which
column12: ultimately
column13: is precisely the problem with this record.

column1: Sunset Rubdown's last album
column2: Dragonslayer
column3: found Krug doing something that his critics didn't think he had in him: self-editing. It remains Krug's most impressive work to date because it's as accessible and immediate as it is thematically complex. Sure
column4: there are dragons
column5: muses
column6: and forays into the Icarus Rhyming Dictionary
column7: but there are also pummeling riffs and catchy hooks galore. Perhaps Dragonslayer's greatest and most unexpected triumph
column8: though
column9: was how emotionally relatable it was. It was a personal record about the toll that the worlds inside someone's head takes on his relationships.

column1: Organ Music
column2: on the other hand
column3: is more of an exercise in shadowboxing. Here
column4: the music drones on without creating an inhabitable atmosphere
column5: and most of its melodies are flat and uninviting. Even when Krug explores Organ Music's more interesting lyrical terrain
column6: it often feels like an echo of something he's done better in the past. The opening verse of ""Whale Song (Instead of a Kiss)""
column7: for example
column8: feels like a retread of Wolf Parade's ""Grounds for Divorce""
column9: but with less of a blunt impact.

column1: Which isn't to say it's all tedium. The opener ""Return to the Violence of the Ocean Floor"" is absorbing and showcases a wide array of the titular instrument's moods. And the standout track is ""Fast Peter""
column2: a charming tale of recreational drug use and long-distance Internet love with a frenetic tempo and a weirdly compelling 8-bit Peer Gynt vibe. These two songs combined are about as long as Marimba and Shit-Drums; they might have made a good EP.

column1: Organ Music's press release has been floating around the Internet for some time now. It was written by Krug himself
column2: and it is magnificently bizarre and fittingly meta. In it
column3: he hints at knowing that this release is more than a little self-indulgent. He tells us the record was twice as long before he cut five tracks; ""You're welcome
column4: he adds. He also seems to wink at the inevitability that we will compare it to the high-water marks of his career. ""Moonface will probably never sound like Wolf Parade or Sunset Rubdown
column5: he says
column6: and he's not wrong. Organ Music isn't reaching for any brass rings
column7:
so it's hard to fault it too hard for not being a highlight of his career when it never tries to be one. And Krug fans who can't get behind this particular side of him shouldn't get too bent out of shape; his back catalogue shows that something completely different could be around the next corner.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16813/homepage_large.46b03f58.jpg|Legendary Weapons|29705.0|Wu-Tang|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['E1']|2011-08-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:48.500741|"

Note the lack of ""Clan"" on the cover of the latest Wu-Tang release. This 37-minute LP isn't a proper follow-up to 2007's 8 Diagrams. But neither is it one of those slapped-together collections of B-sides
column2: remixes
column3: and outtakes that mostly function as stress tests for the W's quality control. With the exception of Masta Killa and GZA
column4: every top-ranking Clansman delivers entirely new verses here. Combined with low commercial prospects
column5: that level of commitment means Legendary Weapons is probably the closest thing we've got so far to a legit
column6: hard-as-fuck Wu-Tang Clan street album. Frighteningly
column7: depressingly
column8: or both
column9: it turns out to be as boring as nearly everybody else's legit
column10: hard-as-fuck street album.

column1: Judging from the tracklist
column2: you might think Wu-Tang are trying to counteract the ""hip-hop hippie"" label Raekwon and Ghostface placed on 8 Diagrams. Guests such as AZ
column3: Sean Price
column4: Roc Marciano
column5: and Action Bronson are peers and stylistic descendants alike. Marciano's Marcberg and Bronson's Dr. Lecter
column6: in particular
column7: prove that records restricting their worldview to grimy New York rap ca. 1994 can still sound exciting to this day. But those guys are about the only ones who treat an appearance on Legendary Weapons as a privilege
column8: and for the most part
column9: the Clan can't commit to underground hunger or regal triumph. Though RZA is listed as executive producer (make of that what you will)
column10: Legendary Weapons
column11: produced by Noah Rubin
column12: burdens itself with nth-gen knock-offs of early Wu producer Tru Master: distended bass
column13: cheap horns
column14: muffled EQ'ing
column15: and drums that knock more like pillowfights than like ""Da Mystery of Chessboxin'"".

column1: But this is still Wu-Tang Clan we're talking about. They've overcome weak production before. I mean
column2: Ghostface Killah shows up on
column3: like
column4: 40% of the tracks! How dull can this be? Legendary Weapons' greatest asset is nearly two decades of goodwill
column5: but at what point are you just flat-out going to admit that Ghostface has been badly coasting downhill for at least five years? Here
column6: Ghost is rapping like he's got someplace else he'd rather be. He leads off every track he's on with verses that weirdly seem to end a couple of bars early
column7: to say nothing of the recycled rhymes about Clarks Wallabees
column8: Mrs. Dash
column9: and cheap rice we've been hearing for ages. Anyone who thinks Action Bronson is currently palming off a weak imitation of Ghostface needs to listen to ""Meteor Hammer"" right away-- it's the equivalent of Allen Iverson's killer crossover on Michael Jordan
column10: Bronson going off in all directions in the record's lone display of joy in sheer wordplay. It quickly gets snuffed out by an atypical swag-rap verse that's as good as you can expect from a guy named Termanalogy.

column1: Almost by default
column2: Legendary Weapons has its moments. Raekwon
column3: who's clearly the most reliable of the crew at this point
column4: pops off a typically adept quickie at the beginning of false party rocker ""Start the Show""
column5: and everyone else at least competently plays to type: U-God the prodigal son
column6: Cappadonna barely staying within the confines of spoken rant
column7: and RZA doing his thing where his conspiracy theorizing flows like steel wool and has only the most tentative hold on erudition (""Islam is the way of life/ Islam is the way of Christ""?). With the higher-ups phoning it in
column8: Wu affiliates Killa Sin and Trife Diesel must sense an opening
column9: because the two go as hard as possible to assert themselves as first-tier. Trife
column10: especially
column11: sounds wholly committed to his aggressively average street soldiering
column12: but whether he's spitting awkward rhymes about famous athletes or confessing the death of his parents
column13: he continues to be proof that you can have all the self-confidence in the world and absolutely zero charisma.

column1: In addition to letting you know this is a Wu-Tang record
column2: the beyond-tired kung fu and blaxploitation audio clips suggest there's supposed to be an astute anti-industry streak underlying Legendary Weapons. But these samples are almost entirely disconnected from the actual contents of the record. Aside from Method Man's streetwise reportage on ""Diesel Fluid"" and Inspectah Deck's skeptical ""Never Feel This Pain"" (actually recycled from 2010's Manifesto)
column3: little on the album acknowledges a world outside its own 16 bars. Truth is
column4: Wu-Tang know time is money. While that much-lauded business acumen might explain the low-profile Legendary Weapons' utter lack of spark
column5:
it hardly justifies it.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16824/homepage_large.c8bbe5e2.jpg|Afro Noise I|29847.0|Cut Hands|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Very Friendly'
column2:
'101 Distribution']|2011-08-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:49.128335|"

When artists with established styles shift into new sonic territory
column3: they're often reluctant to talk about the change. After all
column4: words can ruin the mystery of something as abstract as musical direction. William Bennett must not be worried. In interviews and on his various blogs
column5: the founding member of UK noise group Whitehouse has openly discussed his fascination with Africa
column6: how it influenced Whitehouse
column7: and how it eventually led to his Cut Hands solo project. Bennett has even given his new style a name: ""afro noise.""

column1: Bennett's candor turns out to be wise
column2: because the more you know about Cut Hands
column3: the deeper and richer the music sounds. The artist's longtime interest in African culture and world sociopolitical issues (see his Extreme Music From Africa compilation
column4: or the reading list on his website) adds layers of meaning to the songs. When you learn that Bennett has studied African voodoo
column5: or that he uses native instruments like djembes and doun douns
column6: all the rattling activity on Afro Noise I starts to sound like the rumblings of a global subconscious.

column1: Besides
column2: there's still a lot of mystery here<i>
column3: particularly in how Bennett can make such spacious
column4: often-catchy music retain the penetrating relentlessness of Whitehouse's all-out noise. Part of it is simple evolution: Three of the tracks here are from previously released Whitehouse albums
column5: and they complement newer pieces that mix gunfire beats
column6: heavy atmospheres
column7: and piercing tones. But even the songs that skew furthest from Whitehouse-- like ""Impassion""
column8: which could soundtrack a nature documentary-- have the dark
column9: foreboding quality of Bennett's previous work.

column1: In keeping with Bennett's omnivorous tastes
column2: Afro Noise I also shows impressive sonic variety. On ""Stabbers Conspiracy""
column3: overlapping layers of pulse and clang reach Autechre-like levels
column4: while the echo of ""Rain Washes Over Chaff"" and grind of ""Shut Up and Bleed"" dart between eerie calm and screeching panic. Ultimately
column5: every sound that Bennett adds to his core of percussion reinforces the beats. But taken together
column6: those sounds are a lot thicker and thornier than they appear on first listen.

column1: Still
column2: this album is pretty accessible
column3: and the question of whether Bennett fans would like this music were it done by someone without a noise pedigree will inevitably arise. But with Cut Hands
column4: the point seems moot-- it's hard to imagine anyone else making Afro Noise I. Certain tracks can be compared favorably to other artists-- for me
column5: the more filmic pieces call to mind the Residents' underrated soundtracks to the Discovery Channel series Hunters. But as a whole
column6: Afro Noise I has a scope and vision that's pure Bennett
column7:
making this new direction less a wild leap than a supremely logical step.

"|15699.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15699-afro-noise-i/|7.8|Marc Masters

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16815/homepage_large.2c8a432e.jpg|Field Songs|4635.0|William Elliott Whitmore|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2011-08-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:49.760935|"

William Elliott Whitmore is an old-fashioned sort: He's just 33
column2: but his deep
column3: gnarled vocals suggest a particularly well-trod life. A Lee County
column4: Iowa native
column5: Whitmore plays scrappy
column6: acoustic folksongs on banjo (occasionally augmented by a bass drum)
column7: singing earnestly about things like hammers
column8: steamboats
column9: and dying. It's embarrassingly easy to picture him attacking logs with an old
column10: rusted ax
column11: or sitting by a campfire chewing on a stick of black licorice. There's a dignity to his work
column12: which is unfussy and ambivalent to trends; sometimes that simplicity can feel admonishing. Whether he intends it to or not
column13: something in his voice seems to say: ""Stop Tweeting. It's stupid.""

column1: Field Songs is Whitmore's seventh full length (not counting a collection of demos in 1999)
column2: and stylistically
column3: it's right in step with his previous albums. Whitmore still works on his family's farm in southeastern Iowa
column4: in a fertile little crescent between the Mississippi and Des Moines rivers; his official bio includes the line
column5: ""I was out chopping wood and my uncle said I had a call from a record company."" (Authenticity alert!) He came up in the hardcore scene
column6: sharing the stage with bands like Murder By Death and Converge
column7: serenading crowds of agitated kids with tattoos and shaved heads
column8: and proving that folk music could feel just as revolutionary
column9: just as strong. On his last record
column10: 2009's Animals in the Dark
column11: he became a protest singer
column12: skewering conservative policy and encouraging thoughtful mutiny.

column1: Work is a persistent theme on Field Songs. Samples of chirping critters pop up frequently (Whitmore and his family raise wild birds)
column2: and his lyrics tend to be focused on tactile
column3: useful things: ""We're gonna do some work
column4: spend a day digging in the dirt
column5: he bellows on the record's title track
column6: his voice suddenly big
column7: bombastic. Plenty of these songs position labor as a kind of salvation
column8: a way to insulate yourself from the modern world; for Whitmore
column9: work itself is a threatened institution. ""Three square meals and a living wage
column10: reminds me of the good old days/ Before the manifest destiny of the factory farms
column11: before those cutthroats came and burned down the barns
column12: he sings. It may sound like an awful lot of posturing
column13: but Whitmore sells it; miraculously
column14: nothing at all here reeks of bullshit. ""Here I am
column15: working in the field/ If the heat don't getcha
column16: then the sunburn will
column17: he promises
column18: with all the confidence of a man who knows such things.

column1: Although Whitmore is a talented banjoist
column2: his voice is very much the focus. Weary and full of crags (from a lifetime of smoking
column3: maybe
column4: or hollering at hardcore shows)
column5: it's impressively wide and strong
column6: imbuing his compositions with a kind of welcome toughness. Folk music has a reputation for limpness
column7: but Whitmore's vocals are energizing-- they give these tracks backbone. And while a few pieces are undeniable standouts (""Everything Gets Gone""
column8: ""Let's Do Something Impossible"")
column9: Field Songs really plays best as a single document: a soundtrack to a day in the field
column10:
a day anyone stuck behind a keyboard has probably yearned for once or twice.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16820/homepage_large.803080a4.jpg|Last Night on Earth|1335.0|Elysian Fields|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ojet']|2011-08-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:50.356359|"

For 15 years
column2: Brooklyn's Elysian Fields have been reliable purveyors of dream-pop and alt-rock noir. Singer Jennifer Charles exudes a forbidding cocktail-dress cool; her slick presentation conceals uneasy psychological themes. Think Mazzy Star on a serious Bad Seeds binge. The band has collaborated with many leading lights of the American pop avant-garde-- Marc Ribot
column3: John Lurie
column4: John Zorn
column5: and Mike Patton-- while guitarist Oren Bloedow has backed up demanding traditionalists like Dr. John and Lizz Wright. But Elysian Fields remain a cult act in the States
column6: a condition that Last Night on Earth seems unlikely to change.

column1: At heart
column2: Elysian Fields are doing what they've always done: recruiting prestigious collaborators (the Antibalas horns
column3: Jeff Buckley drummer Matt Johnson
column4: and members of Bon Iver and Antony and the Johnsons) to back Charles' slinky chanteuse vocals. The group still gets the lead out sometimes: ""Red Riding Hood"" is a Grinderman-style seether complete with blues harmonica and a croaking Nick Cave impression
column5: and ""Chance"" bounces on a glinting knife-edge of electric guitar. But more atmospheric styles have risen to prominence
column6: like the foggy old-world folk of ""Johnny"" and the chamber-pop of ""Chandeliers"". Unfortunately
column7: this mostly positive evolution comes with a problematic one in Charles' singing style
column8: which is too blurry to work as a focal point.

column1: I know this is sacrilege: Charles defines this band
column2: and she can certainly sing. But the exaggeratedly breathy and heavily ornamented style she cultivates here overshadows the diversity of the music with a uniform cloud of affectations. Compare these frilly flutters and meanderings with early songs like ""Star"" and ""Jack in the Box""
column3: where Charles carved a svelte
column4: forceful path through the band's chugging alt-era grooves
column5: to hear how her cosmetic decorations sap the music's elemental vitality. She sounds fresh and inspired when she sings a bit straighter
column6: as on ""Sleepover""
column7: a breezy concoction of guitars
column8: horns
column9: and martial percussion; the title track also accrues a spacious
column10: soulful momentum. Between these dynamic bookends
column11: solid musical ideas are too often dissolved in expressive scribbles. Last Night on Earth should do well with those already invested in Elysian Fields-- and they are legion
column12:
especially in Europe-- but newcomers may need to start with 1996's Bleed Your Cedar to figure out what the big deal is supposed to be.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16814/homepage_large.4deb99c2.jpg|Icky Mettle|123.0|Archers of Loaf|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Merge'
column2:
'Fire']|2011-08-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:50.931882|"

No single trend in 1990s indie rock can be traced back to Archers of Loaf. They weren't quite ""lo-fi
column3: they weren't quite ""slackers
column4: their guitars weren't quite ""noisy"" and their drums weren't quite ""mathy."" Eric Bachmann's vocals were gritty and visceral
column5: but his lyrics were oblique and cerebral. Archers of Loaf thrived on subtle contradictions
column6: on purposeful vagaries
column7: on tentative gestures delivered with utmost conviction. It comes as neither a surprise nor a disappointment that this much-needed remaster of the band's 1993 debut
column8: Icky Mettle
column9: isn't particularly revelatory: Everything is still right there in the songs themselves.

column1: It seems fitting that Archers of Loaf's first reunion show this year was not a high-profile festival appearance
column2: but rather an unannounced ""opening"" slot for now-labelmates the Love Language at a mid-sized rock club. Like fellow North Carolinians Superchunk
column3: Archers passed on interest from a major label during the 90s ""alternative"" gold rush
column4: signing instead with independent label Alias (then home to Yo La Tengo and the Loud Family). They released increasingly adventurous records for five years
column5: and broke up with minimal drama or fanfare. This
column6: the first in a series of planned deluxe reissues from Merge
column7: perfectly captures the energy of the band's early days
column8: from their slapdash first singles to the scrappy brilliance of Icky Mettle itself to the more honed recordings that followed.

column1: Released on the heels of some well-received singles and a buzzed-about performance at the CMJ Music Marathon in New York
column2: Icky Mettle was a hotly anticipated debut for the pre-Internet age. To say it starts on a strong note would be an understatement; opener ""Web in Front"" is quite simply among the finest indie rock songs ever written. That a song whose lyrics are all but impossible to parse literally comes off as so immediate and relatable speaks both to Bachmann's skill with words-as-sounds
column3: and to his bandmates' ability to put force and nuance behind his voice. Much of the credit here belongs to guitarist Eric Johnson
column4: whose melodic and fluttery guitar parts seem to hammer the very emotional notes that Bachmann's words intentionally skirt.

column1: ""Web in Front"" finds its near-equal in ""Wrong""
column2: B-side to the band's first single and perhaps their most compelling study in self-effacing aggression. It is only in the second half of the song's ascendant chorus that Bachmann admits
column3: ""I do not think that you could like me anyway/ Because you are superior in all aspects to me
column4: echoing the first half of the chorus but inverting the previously uttered ""inferior."" This self-fulfilling fatalism is at the heart of innumerable rock songs by innumerable bitter young men
column5: but it is rarely expressed with the introspective clarity that Bachmann displays throughout Icky Mettle.

column1: The second disc of Merge's reissue compiles the excellent Vs. the Greatest of All Time EP and the early singles that were previously included on the Speed of Cattle compilation. The five songs from Vs. the Greatest of All Time hint at the more spacious and muscular sound that the band would cultivate on their sophomore LP
column2: Vee Vee
column3: while early 7"" versions of ""Wrong"" and ""Web in Front"" are disjointed and flaccid previews of their album counterparts. The slightly claustrophobic sonics and consistent midtempo clip of Icky Mettle can be daunting at times
column4: and the textural variety of this bonus material makes for a welcome change of pace.

column1: The ramshackle sound of Icky Mettle earned Archers of Loaf comparisons to Pavement (and the occasional dismissal as a Pavement ripoff act)
column2: but Bachmann's earnest self-consciousness is miles away from Stephen Malkmus's arch self-awareness. The strain in Bachmann's voice as he sings ""clearly
column3: this is your loss"" in prescient hipster diss ""Plumb Line"" is devastating
column4:
a crack of self-doubt that masterfully undermines the pointed decisiveness of Bachmann's language. Uncertainty has never sounded so much like a rallying cry.

"|15688.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15688-icky-mettle/|9.0|Matt LeMay

Hudson Mohawke's recent output-- a bonkers remix of Wiley's ""Electric Boogaloo""
column2: a handful of decent edits on his Soundcloud-- has been enough to catch relatively high-profile ears. Not long ago
column3: the Glasgow producer (real name: Ross Birchard) received a ridiculously glowing Twitter shout-out from hip-hop head-knocker Just Blaze
column4: and Chris Brown jumped on an old HudMo track. Still
column5: in a way it's surprising Mohawke has received any level of popularity beyond beat freaks and Warp roster-checkers. His 2009 debut LP
column6: Butter
column7: didn't exactly flow like the melted yellow stuff; it was an unfocused mix of future-R&B pastiche and jumbled funk experimentation.

column1: Good thing for second chances. Mohawke's new Satin Panthers EP shows the kind of improvement that a couple of years in the lab will do for you. His music is still jumbled-sounding
column2: but rather than being sneakily complicated
column3: this record is obviously so; the fact it all works so well is the sneaky part. Mohawke packs in oodles of genre- and artist-specific tics: the hard-hitting repetition of Chicago juke
column4: the sharp melodic tang of Bristol's ""purple"" scene
column5: the sticky swarm of Los Angeles-era Flying Lotus
column6: the light-cycle chaos of hip-hop producer Lex Luger
column7: and the galloping rhythms of UK funky. Which might sound like the recipe for a total mess
column8: except HudMo combines every ingredient expertly.

column1: One complaint: The EP's 17-minute run time feels too brief. Luckily
column2: Satin Panthers offers more than enough to tide listeners over until a potential follow-up album
column3: whether the double-octave bass line on ""Thunder Bay"" or the building synth spirals on ""Octan"". The closing track
column4: a burst of marching-band mania
column5: is called ""Thank You""
column6: but when all's said and done
column7:
there's a lot of gratitude to go around here.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16754/homepage_large.42fd5848.jpg|Come Back to Us|29800.0|Release the Sunbird|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brushfire']|2011-08-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:22:53.209792|"

When a frontman decides to make a record outside of his main gig
column2: the first order of business is to justify its existence. This is particularly true in the case of Zach Rogue's stepping out as Release the Sunbird: though Rogue Wave grew from a solo project to a full-time band in a matter of months
column3: I imagine a guy who sorta named the band after himself maintains as much songwriting autonomy as he wants. But upon holing up in a Bloomington
column4: Ind.
column5: studio with a batch of unfinished songs after a grueling tour stint
column6: you could assume that Rogue wanted to pump the brakes on a band that was getting bigger and not necessarily better. Of all the records from the past decade accurately likened to the Shins
column7: Out of the Shadow and Descended Like Vultures are pretty much the only two that still hold up. But attempts to muscle up for amphitheaters (Asleep at Heaven's Gate) and dancefloors (Permalight) proved Rogue Wave's charming indie pop wasn't really scalable.

column1: On the title track here
column2: Rogue sings
column3: ""I'm already able to cut myself down if I need to
column4: and Come Back to Us goes out of its way to be accommodating to those unconvinced by the direction Rogue had been taking. Described as a ""solo project
column5: yet not
column6: it brings him back to the Out of the Shadow days where the bulk of the songs were just him and his guitar
column7: occasional production touches applied after the fact. Opener ""It's All Around You"" is more of a purposeful mantra than song
column8: the single titular lyric doubling seeping Farfisa (courtesy of the Wave's Pat Spurgeon) and surprisingly loud drums for an enveloping
column9: you-are-there sound. Come Back to Us never rocks that hard again (""rocks"" being relative)
column10: but the homey warmth is maintained through an au naturel recording where every scrape of fingernails on guitar strings
column11: bounce of room echo
column12: and imperfect harmony is kept intact. Even the more surprising studio touches-- a distorted percussive effect on ""Come Back to Us""
column13: guiro
column14: the unsettling reverb of ""A New You""-- come off like natural found sound amidst rumpled folk-pop that doesn't sound composed so much as snuggled into wakefulness.

column1: Yet for all of its dewy production and dog-eared melodies
column2: Rogue's words themselves sag with the burden of addiction
column3: death
column4: and fatherhood: It sounds like early morning music for people who've been up all night struggling with something heavy. Though it's not addressed to anyone specific
column5: ""Always Like the Son"" carries devastating weight
column6: the passing of a brother or one's closest friend being used as a reflection for one's own personal shortcomings. ""Why Can't You Look at Yourself"" instantly recalls an unplugged version of Descended Like Vulture's ""Bird on a Wire""
column7: but forgoes its lighter-waving to seek relief from the powerlessness of watching an alcoholic waste away. If not so much a sharp turn for Rogue sonically (""California"" and ""Christians in Black"" come to my mind)
column8: it's unquestionably the most personal and direct he's ever been-- a lyric like ""all this emotion
column9: can't help myself"" might read cloying
column10: but it's the purest distillation of a record that thrives on straightforwardness and honesty.

column1: But while Come Back to Us isn't Rogue's longest release
column2: it's got the longest tracklist and it's a little too good at establishing mood: The cumulative effect of 12 straight ballads of misty eyes and resigned acceptance after ""It's All Around You"" saps the individual effect of each. Or maybe the most powerful of the songs all come in the first half
column3: and as Come Back to Us pushes toward its disappointingly vague closer
column4: ""Outlook's Anonymous""
column5: Rogue's words get more terse and emotionally illegible without offering any compensation in volume or melody. Still
column6: it's a shame that the songs on Come Back to Us weren't available to Rogue previously
column7: since ""A New You"" or ""Why Can't You Look at Yourself"" could've certainly counterbalanced some of his more awkwardly ambitious moments of late. So even if it's a pointedly despondent record
column8:
it actually makes me hopeful that Rogue hasn't wholly lost touch with the humble charm of his best work.

When I first started listening to Nicholas Szczepanik's latest album
column2: its title felt off by 180 degrees. Its single
column3: 48-minute track is warm
column4: reverent
column5: and emotional. Compared to some recent trends in drone
column6: which tend more toward the dark and cavernous
column7: Please Stop Loving Me's bright organ tones are practically hymn-like. In other words
column8: this is music that sounds like it wants you to love it.

column1: The further I got into the album
column2: though
column3: the more Szczepanik's wry choice of name made sense. Whenever you try to get too comfortable with his drones-- to glide across their surface or ride them like a soft cloud-- he pushes back. His sounds constantly twist
column4: dive
column5: and circle
column6: avoiding complacency and requiring you to do the same. Innumerable shifts in volume
column7: tone
column8: and tempo occur with sneaky unpredictability. Often Szczepanik will lull you into calm waters before tossing you into choppy waves. There is a lot to love here
column9: much of it mesmerizing
column10: even soothing. Just don't turn your brain off
column11: because Szczepanik is more interested in challenging than hypnotizing.

column1: The beauty of Please Stop Loving Me is that he manages to do both consistently. There's really no point along Szczepanik's journey-- which doesn't feel long or short
column2: but more outside of time-- where the music's meditative qualities outstrip its thought-provoking ones or vice versa. In that sense
column3: his material reminds me most of the careful work of Kyle Bobby Dunn. There's an intangible similarity between the ways both musicians turn sounds and patterns into wordless emotional language. But where Dunn is a master at massaging his tones toward quietude
column4: Szczepanik excels at finding subtlety and nuance in immersive volumes. Even at his softest here
column5: he could fill an airplane hangar with his music.

column1: Szczepanik's work conjures lots of images like that one. Whenever I listen
column2: I find myself thinking in pictures and metaphors
column3: giving shapes and colors to his sounds the way I imagine the faces and voices of characters in a book. So it's tempting to concoct a narrative that could accompany this sonic epic
column4: and claim that its arcs and curves are scene changes and plot twists. Maybe they are
column5: but what impresses most about Szczepanik's story is that it could be told only with sound
column6: and only through his particular
column7:
engrossing way with it.

Grieves seems like a good dude
column2: if a pretty intense and single-minded one. He reminds me of an aged-out
column3: nomadic skate rat who posts up in a downtown coffeeshop to scribble poetry about the 10 lives it feels like he's lived so far. He's not a pseudo-intellectual
column4: and while he's been through some shit
column5: he's also not a whiner

column10: ensuring that the smallish number of people who like them will really like them. As for bystanders like me? I wish him the best

column1: Grieves asks us to serve as his casual confidants on Together/Apart. He dwells on the down-to-earth drudgery of being broke
column2: kicking addictions
column3: and getting over ex-girlfriends (On ""Heartbreak Hotel"" he describes one of them as ""the scalpel to open up my doubtful

column5: itchy Okayplayerisms

column7: he switches to a laconic drawl reminiscent of Bay Area backpack OG duo Latyrx; on ""Boogie Man""
column8: he more closely recalls the intense confessionalism of labelmate Slug on the spare verses
column9: before the chorus expands into a more gelled-up rap-rock hybrid.

column1: The duo provides compelling surface-level reasons to hear them out
column2: but in the end
column3: it all adds up to well-produced
column4: confidently delivered Rootsy boilerplate. After an hour of this
column5: though

column7: and you can listen to Grieves' laments only for so long until you start checking your watch

column9: into which Grieves incorporates the positive admonitions of Blackalicious' ""Make You Feel That Way"" and Mos Def's ""Speed Law"". The pieces are there
column10: as they are on much of Together/Apart
column11: but the execution is lacking. Grieves' breathy self-serious vocal rubs the wrong way against Budo's lush
column12: sepia-toned track
column13: his shout-outs to Tamagotchi toys and Fleer trading cards (what
column14: no ""Boy Meets World""?) are weirdly TMI and just sort of bland
column15: and a clunky chorus (you don't need to follow ""once in a while"" with ""sometimes
column16: because they mean the same thing) compel me to agree with Tony Soprano's opinion of ""remember when."" ""Landspeed"" is the sort of tale that works best when its narrator has much more distance between now and then; like the rest of Together/Apart
column17: it's the work of a precocious artist who perhaps assumes we should care about the details of his life
column18:
instead of compelling us to listen.

When MellowHype first released BlackenedWhite on Halloween of last year
column2: the world was a very different place for Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All. Events that would eventually cement the collective's budding stardom-- Tyler
column3: the Creator's ""Yonkers"" becoming a viral sensation
column4: their seminal performance on ""Late Night with Jimmy Fallon""
column5: Tyler inking a deal with XL-- were either weeks or months away. The group at large was still strictly a sensation in a small pocket of the Internet
column6: somewhat mysterious
column7: amorphous
column8: confusing and-- as anyone who tried to grab an album from Odd Future's official blog only to be met with a broken download link could attest-- amateur.

column1: Released after that initial rush of online hype
column2: BlackenedWhite (along with Domo Genesis' Rolling Papers) was
column3: if not an introduction point
column4: at least the first new music released since many had initially heard of Odd Future. Described on the crew's Tumblr as ""The Perfect Soundtrack For Mobbing On A Dark Halloween Night
column5: and littered with references to dead cops
column6: the album easily fit into the general perception of what Odd Future's music was about.

column1: So here we are
column2: some eight-and-a-half months later
column3: and BlackenedWhite has now been remastered
column4: rearranged
column5: and re-released by Fat Possum into a market where Tyler easily coexists next to pop stars. And yet
column6: oddly enough
column7: MellowHype's role is almost precisely the same
column8: again representing the first new release by Odd Future since being embraced again by a wider audience. But where in October 2010 it might've been hard to pinpoint exactly where MellowHype stood in relation to guys like Tyler or Domo or Earl Sweatshirt
column9: time has allowed the different personas within Odd Future to distinguish themselves.

column1: Hodgy Beats' wild-eyed glare can be seen next to Tyler on stage during Odd Future's shows
column2: and it's easy to see how he could be thought of as Tyler's sidekick. And in fact
column3: when people talk about Odd Future on a macro level
column4: especially when that discussion is boiled down to the more controversial elements of the music
column5: who they're really talking about is Tyler (and
column6: to a lesser extent
column7: Earl)
column8: oftentimes glossing over the individual members of the group. Part of that is by design
column9: of course: Tyler has always been front and center
column10: and not only is his star power blatantly obvious
column11: but he feeds on being on a lightning rod. But lost in the shuffle is that the other arms of Odd Future are putting out music that is far from Tyler's trolling self-autopsies
column12: which is both a good and bad thing.

column1: As a rapper
column2: Hodgy seems mostly concerned with stringing together words on the basis of their sound in rapid-fire fashion. This is seen most obviously in ""Igotagun"" and ""64""
column3: the two new tracks added to Blackenedwhite for the reissue. He doesn't have Tyler's focus or imagination
column4: but his garden-variety shit talking
column5: combined with gleefully inhabited fables of drug pushing and cop killing
column6: bring the sort of levity that you would expect from a group of skate-punk ""Jackass"" descendents
column7: and in a way that's much less obnoxious than
column8: say
column9: Tyler's ""Bitch Suck Dick"". What can't be found here are all the things that upset people about Odd Future
column10: namely Tyler's reliance on slurs and his elaborate rape fantasies. And though Hodgy doesn't possess Earl's effortless rapping skill (who does?)
column11: his penchant for tongue-twisting alliteration further separates him from the stoned flows of fellow Odd Future stoners Domo and Mike G.

column1: The flipside of that is when Tyler storms through on ""Fuck the Police"" (now rebranded for Best Buys as ""F666 the Police"")
column2: the effect is slightly jarring. While Hodgy's Flocka homage and producer Left Brain's turn as Timbaland circa ""We Need a Resolution"" work just fine
column3: Tyler tells a strikingly vivid story of getting pulled over and murdering a cop in what is easily the most accomplished verse on the album. BlackenedWhite is the most fun Odd Future release (excepting
column4: arguably
column5: the collaborative mixtapes) and it's one of the easier to digest
column6: but it doesn't hold up to scrutiny in the way that Tyler's or Earl's work does.

column1: This cleaned up version of the album also puts a stronger concentration on the Left Brain productions that lean heavy on Southern rap. Replacing the distinctly Tyler-esque ""Chordaroy"" and ""Loco""
column2: as well as the trifles ""Stripclub"" and ""Gram""
column3: are the aforementioned new tracks
column4: both of which call back to the beats that the Neptunes used to give to Clipse. The result is both a more succinct and cohesive full-length. The catch-22 for MellowHype is that while their centrism certainly has its merits
column5: their music is unlikely to convert anyone that has
column6: at this point
column7: already written off Odd Future. Which leaves them with a solid
column8: fun rap album to satiate a feverish cult and a growing number of casual fans. Things
column9: all told
column10:
could be worse.

It's misleading to refer to Motor City Drum Ensemble's entry in the DJ-Kicks series as ""jazzy
column2: which hasn't stopped a lot of people from doing just that. MCDE's output is often described as deep house
column3: and there's a long tradition of deep house producers simply borrowing polite brass and woodwind arrangements from old jazz records and slapping them on top of featureless beats. The results are usually bland
column4: sometimes plain banal. An hour's worth of the stuff
column5: all that polite chugging and all those waxy saxophones
column6: tends to be good for napping but not much else.

column1: That's not what you get here. The mix opens with an eerily swaying Sun Ra tune
column2: which is a pretty good indication that Danilo Plessow's taste in jazz runs more toward the odd and cosmic than the smooth and placid. But aside from the tart Afro-funk horns on the Tony Allen cut
column3: there's really not much here that sounds like jazz of any sort. Even the Sun Ra record more closely resembles a kind of slightly sinister soul music from outer space. Across the mix
column4: Plessow focuses on what makes the best deep house its own animal: fluid bass
column5: swinging beats
column6: and the spaciousness of good dub.

column1: And even then
column2: as long as his choices fit those requirements
column3: Plessow goes further out than you might expect. He often leaves the boundaries of deep house
column4: or any kind of house
column5: far behind. MCDE throws in old-school IDM and sweaty vintage Afrobeat
column6: polyrhythmic weirdo disco and wombing ambient house
column7: classic Detroit-style techno and the outer limits of the genre's Germanic counterpart. Like all the best DJs not bound to a scene
column8: Plessow has managed to locate connecting points between records released years apart and for entirely different audiences
column9: cuts that feature the muscle of live human drummers and rhythm tracks that sound more like computer hiccups.

column1: And yet all of them feel weirdly natural linked together
column2: as if they were always meant to build to this whole
column3: which begins with simmering dub and Afro-Cuban rhythms
column4: moves through a mini-set of warm and ultra-traditional house
column5: and then launches into various kinds of fractured funk experimentation from the 1980s into the 2000s. While staying doggedly mid-tempo
column6: whether it's techno's pulse or disco's boogie
column7: Plessow proves himself a master of pace. And while there are no floor-filling anthems here from any era
column8: it's all too busy and bustling to be called minimal. Like all deep house fans
column9: Plessow chooses tracks in part because they sound so luscious
column10: with every piano and snare drum sounding extra crisp
column11: perfect headphone music. But the bass here is so uniformly rich and powerful and forward-charging that even at its most gentle you never forget this is still music designed to move bodies.

column1: Plenty of DJs have wide-ranging record collections. Rare are the ones who can seamlessly mix between genres without sacrificing flow for eclecticism or excitement for a display of pure technical skill. MCDE's DJ-Kicks is one of those rare home-listening mixes that is stylistically all over the map but feels unified
column2: that can mix records released three decades apart more because they feel right
column3: because they produce sparks. If you're only a casual house and techno fan
column4: this DJ-Kicks won't catch you up on dance music's cutting edge. But if you're looking for one of the best-mixed and most immersive sessions of the year
column5: dance music that's both a head-trip in the dub tradition and unflaggingly funky
column6:
this is the mix for you.

SSION is Kansas City
column2: Missouri freak-scene collective led by charismatic mastermind Cody Critcheloe. He founded SSION while at art school there-- his extracurricular credits include album art for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and music videos for the likes of Liars-- and the band communicates over a wide range of media: campy
column3: trashy music videos that would make John Waters smile; elaborate stage shows involving garish sets and costumes; and the kind of attitude-heavy electro pop that would go over equally well at the gay disco as the queercore dive bar. The question then is how does this stuff hold up outside the disco
column4: without the dance routines or the videos
column5: on its own
column6: as an album?

column1: The answer on Bent is: unfortunately
column2: only okay. The album's lead single
column3: ""Psy-Chic""
column4: is a delicious tease: just under three minutes of propulsive bass arpeggio
column5: fluttering synths
column6: and Critcheloe singing

It even has a righteous Courtney Love appropriation (""I told you from the start…"") delivered in a deadpan speaking voice then breaking into laughter with a playful ""psych!"" If there's not already an extended 12"" dance mix of this track
column9: it will be necessary to create one. If Bent's shortest song is also its best
column10: then its runner-up is its longest
column11: ""Nothing Happens at Nite""
column12: which spaces Critcheloe's usually dense approach out over eight minutes
column13: making for a kind of dubby
column14: sun-rising house track that's more subtly moving than SSION's tightly wound pop numbers. More of this
column15: please.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Critcheloe's songs and productions are pleasant and utilitarian-- if any of these came on at the right moment on the right dance floor
column3: you'd wanna dance-- but ultimately insubstantial
column4: fizzing out of one's memory almost as soon as they're finished playing. Still
column5: there are some nice touches: the funhouse bells and whistles of ""Blonde With U""
column6: the Freestyle-by-way-of-Hercules and Love Affair ""Luvvbazzar""
column7: the muted beatboxing of ""Growin""
column8: the drippy snaps occasionally overwhelmed by oppressive drum pulse on ""Feel Good (4-Evr)""
column9: the brightly upbeat ""My Love Grows in the Dark"". But nothing on Bent pops off the screen quite as vibrantly as ""Psy-Chic"" or with as much cool confidence as ""Nothing Ever Happens at Nite"".

column1: Maybe it's unfair to judge Bent as a stand-alone object
column2: as the point or the primary document of the SSION project rather than as merely one prong of many in a multimedia pincer attack. But taken on those terms
column3:
it leaves you longing for the discotheque. Maybe that's the point.

Viva Brother are the latest UK hype band to emerge seemingly from nowhere
column2: this time making self-proclaimed ""Grit Pop."" The term is an obvious nod to Britpop but also to their hometown of Slough (which
column3: by the way
column4: still isn't half as gritty as Pulp's early 1990s Sheffield). column5: leave now.""

column1: That kind of sassy talk has polarized the UK press but at least puts them leagues ahead of countless other faceless major label bands in the personality game. However
column2: all that bluster and boasting comes undone when listening to Famous First Words and you realise they actually don't have anything to say at all. The songs range from a parade of clichés to the plain ridiculous

column4: from  ""False Alarm""

column6: but even the Gallaghers had enough sense to qualify their  non-sequiturs with lines about getting high. Also

column1: Musically

column3: lifted almost directly from the coda of Blur's ""Girls and Boys""

column6: by a bedside light-- before sneering ""I got a job/ That I don't want"". It's pretty brainless stuff
column7: the special kind that makes you feel somehow stupider for having listened.

column1: Look
column2: It's easy to see why Viva Brother were given a shot at the big time-- the dual allure of a Britpop revival and four arrogant young men with guitars must have been impossible for record execs to resist. But in execution the whole thing comes off as nothing more than a thinly disguised
column3: crass attempt to smoke latent Oasis fans out of hiding. Unfortunately for them
column4:
Beady Eye already beat them to the punch.

Marvin Gaye submitted a version of the most important single of his career
column3: ""What's Going On""
column4: to Motown Records in the summer of 1970. Over the previous seven years
column5: the relationship between the singer and his label was contentious yet fruitful; gritty uptempo songs like ""Stubborn Kind of Fellow"" and ""Hitch Hike"" were hits
column6: but they undermined Gaye's dream to be a balladeer in the mold of Nat King Cole. Those lusty trifles also roused the internal conflict between the artist's gospel upbringing and his endless desire for carnal pleasure. And while Gaye aspired to be more than just a singer within Motown's assembly-line chug
column7: his boss
column8: brother-in-law
column9: and fellow hard-headed egoist Berry Gordy Jr. wasn't so crazy about the idea. So when Gordy heard that original ""What's Going On"" mix-- which is included in this box set for the first time-- he rejected the song
column10: reportedly calling it ""the worst thing I've ever heard in my life.""

column1: Instead of releasing ""What's Going On"" that fall
column2: Motown put out the Gaye compilation Super Hits
column3: which depicts its clean-shaven star as a cartoon superhero flying through the air and fixing a radio tower as a buxom damsel perilously hangs from his shoulder. But Gaye wanted nothing more than to blow up that gleaming image of himself-- now in his early 30s
column4: he would accept nothing but complete control over his art. And if Motown wasn't going to release his first self-produced song

column13: Marvin Gaye released his full-grown symphony to God

column1: Forty years of ubiquity have made the title track commonplace

column5: trading in that trademark big
column6: bright beat for laid-back grooves inspired by Duke Ellington
column7: Curtis Mayfield

column11: floating

column13: too. ""I felt like I'd finally learned to sing
column14: he told biographer David Ritz. ""I'd been studying the microphone for a dozen years
column15: and I suddenly saw what I'd been doing wrong. I'd been singing too loud."" The record and its creative revelations led to his stunning 70s auteur period
column16: which birthed three more classics: 1973's Let's Get It On

column1: Much has been made of What's Going On's political bent
column2: and it's true that the music was partially inspired by Marvin's brother Frankie
column3: who had come back from a three-year tour of Vietnam
column4: along with troublingly violent episodes like the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. and the Kent State shootings that saw four students killed by national guardsmen. Songs like peace-espousing title track and ""What's Happening Brother""
column5: which finds Gaye expressing a war veteran's helplessness upon returning home
column6: show Marvin's dismay toward his country and government. But this album isn't just a protest time capsule. Far from it. Gaye's disappointment isn't just societal
column7: it's personal as well. During this period
column8: the singer had lost his duet partner and dear friend
column9: Tammi Terrell
column10: and his marriage to Gordy's sister Anna was violently breaking down
column11: and he was being tailed by the IRS for unpaid back taxes. His resulting depression is evident throughout; What's Going On isn't a fiery album filled with timely sloganeering. Part of its long-lasting appeal involves an element of true-to-life resignation. ""Who's willing to try to save a world/ That's destined to die
column12: he sings on ""Save the Children""
column13: pinpointing an American melancholia-- a mix of world-saving power and funereal inevitability-- that endures today.

column1: But the album doesn't wallow
column2: either. It hums and glides on the effortless
column3: multi-tracked Marvins that swoop through the stereo spectrum like ghosts. Gaye's signature vocal ad libs started here and have endured through R&B and hip-hop ever since. His marijuana-soaked delivery
column4: along with the album's mutating
column5: percussion-fueled rhythms
column6: majestic strings
column7: and jazzy horns
column8: give the affair levity. Perhaps this smooth front also has to do with the fact that Gaye was ""hardly an activist in the traditional sense
column9: according to Edmonds. While his Vietnam-battered brother was an emotional catalyst
column10: Gaye had neglected to send him one letter during his army stint. And though he was certainly aware of the Detroit race riot that left 43 people dead in 1967
column11: he viewed the sad display on TV from his cushy home on the outskirts of town. Not to say Gaye didn't wholeheartedly believe in the progressive observations found on What's Going On
column12: but his relative distance from his subjects allows him to fly over top of them
column13: providing a healing pulse to the disarray below.

column1: For an album as timeless as this one
column2: reissue bonus material can provide worthy footnotes to the main article. Probably thanks to the last decade's vinyl resurgence
column3: this 40th anniversary edition immediately sets itself apart from 2001's 30th anniversary release by presenting its iconic cover in a glorious 12""x12"" square. The package's lone LP features the more straightforward
column4: early Detroit mix of the album
column5: while the final
column6: L.A. mix is relegated to a CD. For die-hards
column7: the most alluring part of the package may be the second compact disc
column8: which features 18 mostly instrumental demos recorded in Gaye's post-What's Going On honeymoon period
column9: when his vast artistic ambitions and abilities were being embraced by the greater public. These somewhat experimental demos-- deep
column10: in-the-pocket funk in the vein of Sly Stone
column11: George Clinton
column12: and Jimi Hendrix-- clearly laid the groundwork for much of his subsequent 70s material. Though he doesn't sing on most of these tracks
column13: it's exciting to hear him get loose as keyboardist and band leader.

column1: Just as What's Going On marked the emergence of Marvin Gaye as an all-in-one talent
column2: it also signaled the decline of Motown's reign. It's tempting to simply side with Gaye in his battles with the label that raised him and play into the auteur myth. But it's more complicated than that. Without his tutelage at Motown
column3: first as a session player then as a singer
column4: Gaye wouldn't have been able to conceive a work like this. The help of Motown backing band the Funk Brothers-- credited in the What's Going On liner notes after years of anonymity-- was also essential. Before he was shot and killed by his own father at age 44 in 1984
column5: Gaye was afforded the schooling of America's finest pop academy and then the freedom to flourish and act on his own whims afterward. His 70s brilliance is unfathomable without his 60s pop triumphs. And What's Going On is the turning point
column6: the moment when he was able to bypass his selfishness and self-destructiveness in the name of God
column7: peace
column8: love. It's a nice dream. One that he knew was too good to last. ""Mercy
column9: mercy me
column10: he pleaded calmly
column11:
desperately.

I keep trying to forget who I'm listening to when I listen to Running Blind
column3: as though distancing myself from the associations I have with Philip Selway will help me to hear it as if it were made by a fresh name. I want to be able to judge it outside the shadow of Radiohead
column4: the band Selway drums for
column5: but I'm not sure that's really even possible. As Mark Pytlik did last year in his review of Selway's debut solo LP
column6: Familial
column7: I give Selway all the credit in the world for stepping out on his own and responding to a singing and songwriting muse that's never going to become a part of Radiohead's music. To make such straightforward singer-songwriter music only increases the challenge. It leaves him exposed as a performer in a way he's normally not when he's at the drum kit.

column1: Familial was OK: a couple of memorable tracks and a lot of pretty filler. Running Blind comprises four songs that were left over when Familial was completed. One of them
column2: ""What Goes Around""
column3: was included as a bonus track in demo form on that album and gets fleshed out here. And Running Blind is... OK. It does move the sound on a bit-- Familial was almost self-consciously sparse
column4: as though Selway wanted to distance it as much as possible from Radiohead and that band's mastery of texture and electronics in the context of songs. Running Blind opens up a little to the soundscape
column5: though we're nowhere near The King of Limbs territory in that respect. The additions here are more like textural dressing for Selway's delicate
column6: almost-whispered singing
column7: which hasn't changed from the LP.

column1: The new take on ""What Goes Around"" is the most compelling thing Selway has released under his own name. This has little to do with the arrangement
column2: though
column3: and everything to do with the fact that he strongly delivers a well-crafted melody
column4: and the textural elements of the music pick up the thread from there to emphasize certain feelings implied in the lyrics. The other songs move with a bit less purpose-- Selway is getting good at setting a mood with his songs
column5: as he does with a little Theremin and a brief wordless harmony passage on the title track
column6: but there's very little energy in the music
column7: and the tone doesn't vary much. The vaguely tribal drumming on ""Every Spit and Cough"" adds a little variety
column8: but it can't quite get out from under its blanket of ambient keyboard and low-volume vocals.

column1: The EP reinforces the impression created by the debut that Selway only really runs in one gear on his own. Running Blind is a slight improvement on its predecessor
column2: but its true saving grace may be a run time so short (15 minutes) that it doesn't have a chance to tranquilize the listener fully. Selway is creeping toward making something that stands well on its own
column3:
but he's not quite there yet.
